PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 9 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIBRAA

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 166 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PUPLICK; MARTYR

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Martyr I present the following petition from 10 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the National Women's Advisory Council has not been democratically elected by the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is not representative of the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is a discriminatory and sexist imposition on Australian women as Australian men do not have a National Men's Advisory Council imposed on them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the National Women's Advisory Council be abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal opportunity with Australian men of having issues of concern to them considered, debated and voted on by their Parliamentary representatives without intervention and interference by an unrepresentative ''Advisory Council''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: KEEFFE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 37 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognize that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COLSTON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 70 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within four years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: EVANS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 64 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artifical fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognize that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian Nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: PUPLICK; MARTYR

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Martyr I present the following petition from 155 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That although cottages Numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island is no way impede construction at H.M.A.S. Stirling, they are now required by the Department of Administrative Services to move by 30 June, 1981.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
Cottages Numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island be allowed to remain and to move only when the remaining northern end cottages do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: RYAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 735 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That many thousands of women and children in the Australian community who use the services of Women's Refuges, Women's Health Centres and Women's Rape Crisis Centres:

(1) Express their concern at the decision of the Federal Government to pass to the States the responsibility of funding those essential services because of the poor record already demonstrated by some States;
(2) Call on the Federal Government to reverse that decision;
(3) Request that the Government ensure one Department to administer all funds for the above under the heading of Women's Services;
(4) Propose that future funding should be on a guaranteed triennial basis taking into account inflation and indexation increases; and
(5) Ask for a positive policy commitment for a substantial injection of funds to consolidate existing services and to develop new initiatives for women and children in the Australian community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIBRAA

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 8 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care:
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programmes will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I draw his attention to the refusal of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to involve itself in settling the telecommunications dispute. What progress has been made overnight in settling this dispute? If no progress has been made, how much longer will it take for the Government to concede that its attitude not only generated this dispute but also is now prolonging it from day to day?

—The Government is deeply concerned about the situation which has developed in this matter. It is concerned about it for a number of reasons. It certainly is not a dispute which is of the Government's making. Cabinet met last evening in relation to the matter and will be meeting again this morning. At this stage, I have nothing further to report to the Senate on the matter.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Health consider removing all nourishing, moisturising and revitalising creams from the luxury class of cosmetics, as this class attracts a high rate of tax? It is recognised that many areas of Australia have a harsh and dry climate and these creams are considered by many skin specialists to be a necessity for women.

—It is certainly a fact that the effects of solar exposure in Australia are particularly severe upon women and that much of the medical advice that is given emphasises the need for Australians to keep their faces covered if they want to avoid troubles with their skin later. This applies not only to sun cancer but also to other problems to which the honourable senator's question might properly refer. Whether certain products-nourishing, moisturising or revitalising creams-should attract different rates of financial impost is a question which would involve a matter of policy. I will undertake to make the honourable senator's question known to the appropriate Minister and to seek his advice for her.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs aware of a research project by Ms Bettina Cass at the University of New South Wales which has established that when hidden unemployment is taken into account women have an unemployment level of 18.5 per cent? If the Minister is not aware, will she undertake to investigate this project? Can the Minister say what specific steps the Government is taking to overcome female unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know what information the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has on this matter. I saw a newspaper article about Bettina Cass's survey or study. I will refer the question to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and get a response on the matter for Senator Ryan.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer received representations from business sources expressing concern at the effects the increasing infrastructure borrowings have on the funds available for business and housing in particular? Will the Treasurer pursue the matter with the Premiers in an effort to have them moderate their expectations for infrastructure projects and look for a wider spread of available funds across the broadest range of requirements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the Treasurer has received representations from business sources expressing concern about the size of the developmental and other projects that are at planning stages. The Government has called a Premiers Conference for 19 June and these matters, amongst others, will be discussed with the States at that time and at the Loan Council meeting. The Commonwealth takes the view that the call on resources and financial markets by the public sector should be restrained to make way for productive growth in the private sector consistent with reducing the rate of inflation. Of course, in the economic context these are matters that properly must be discussed with the Premiers. If any further information arises from Senator Archer's question I will see that he is advised accordingly.

—I refer the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate to the enormous disruption to Australian community life that has been caused by the Fraser Government's new federalism policy, which seems to amount to the Federal Government shedding responsibilities on to the States, an attitude further manifested in the razor gang's decisions. In view of the increased responsibilities that have been forced on the States and the resultant reduction in Federal responsibilities, is there any need to proceed with the construction of the new Parliament House in Canberra?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McIntosh's question raised two issues. One related to the new federalism policy of the Government and the other to the construction of the new Parliament House. Let me deal with the latter first. There may be differing views as to the need for the construction of the new Parliament House, but a decision has been taken, and is being proceeded with I understand--
—In a bipartisan spirit.

—I thank the honourable senator. There is bipartisan support here but I do not know whether it is quite so enthusiastic outside this place. But the fact is that a decision has been taken. We have started down the track and will continue.

ANSWER.PARA: That decision does not seem to have very much to do with the other aspect of the question, namely, new federalism. That policy, of course, has been designed to renew and has been successful in renewing the spirit of true federalism in this country after the years of Labor government in particular. Perhaps over many years, even prior to that, centralist policies had been developing in this country. The new federalism policy is not just about money. It is about giving life, as I said, to the Federation, about giving power and responsibility to and consulting with the States. Over the last few years financial assistance grants-which the States are free to spend as they like-have significantly increased. This has given the States much greater freedom in decision making. But apart from that, and perhaps even more importantly than that there have been the consultative aspects of new federalism which, despite what may be said by Premiers in relation to some financial matters from time to time, are very greatly appreciated by them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AFRICAN RUGBY UNION TOUR OF NEW ZEALAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: Why is it that the Federal Government is displaying an inconsistent attitude by urging New Zealand not to host a tour by the South African rugby union team and yet no protests have been made when other countries such as Britain, France and Ireland have sent similar teams to South Africa and when in fact South Africans participate in many other sporting events in Australia and overseas? Does the Government not feel that its protests are being made inconsistently and selectively and that in fact the matter is one for the two countries involved to settle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government accepts unequivocally its obligations under the Gleneagles declaration on apartheid in sport to work to isolate South Africa from international sporting competition as long as the South African Government pursues its policy of apartheid. In addition to refusing South Africa's sporting teams or individuals representing South Africa entry into Australia, the Government has decided that no government grants will be made available to Australian sporting organisations to facilitate sporting contacts with South Africa. The Government opposed the tour of the British Lions rugby team to South Africa in 1980 and the current tour of South Africa by the Irish rugby team as vigorously as it opposes the forthcoming Springbok tour of New Zealand. There can be no question of inconsistency in our approach to such tours.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Bjelke-Petersen suggested that the question of sporting relations between New Zealand and South Africa was a matter for those two countries alone to settle. I should point out that the New Zealand Government has consistently opposed the tour and repeatedly made its views known to the New Zealand rugby football union.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I acknowledge that the Minister may not have full details in relation to my question. If that is the case I would be grateful if he could obtain an answer for me. I refer to that part of the Prime Minister's statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions which outlined that State offices of the Schools Commission will be scaled down. Does this mean that there will be a reduction in staff at these State offices? If so, will the Government make efforts to ensure that any displaced staff will be appointed to other positions within a Commonwealth Government department?

—I think that question would be more appropriately addressed to the Minister for Education whom I am also representing at the moment. I will refer the question to him and endeavour to get an early answer for the honourable senator.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, refers to the problem of teenage employment. Can the Minister indicate what the teenage employment figure was in April 1981 compared with April 1980? What is the aggregate number of young people now employed in the work force? Has the situation shown any improvement in recent years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures that I have show that in April 1981 there were 696,700 15 to 19-year-olds employed. In April 1980 this figure was 669,000. Information is not available to me for May 1975, but in August 1980 there were 650,900 young people employed. This compares with 615,700 in August 1975. That represents an increase of about 5.7 per cent. The figures show that there has been an improvement in employment in more recent months. It is hoped that this trend will continue and that more opportunities are available for all those who are seeking employment in this country. In particular it is hoped that there is a continuing improvement in opportunities for those in the younger age group who are seeking long career opportunities.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer to the misleading advertising practised by several cigarette companies which market many of their products under brand names containing the words 'mild' and 'extra mild'. Does the Minister agree that this description leads people to believe that they are smoking low tar cigarettes, whereas research has shown that most such brands have a much higher tar content? When does the Government propose to fulfil its undertaking of 19 March 1980 to require the labelling of Australian cigarettes with their correct tar and nicotine content? In particular, when will the Government restrict the use of the word 'mild' so that it is applied only to genuinely low tar brands?

—I cannot be certain but I suspect that the statement of 19 March 1980 was a response to a Senate standing committee report. In any event, the Government at about that time responded to a Senate standing committee report and undertook to go down the road in the way indicated by Senator Chipp. The problem seems to be to ensure that the public knows what is meant by the description 'mild' in relation to the tar content of cigarettes. The honourable senator will be aware that for some years now the Government has been examining the tar and nicotine content of different kinds of cigarettes. There have been periodic publications setting out the tar and nicotine content of the different brands of cigarettes available in Australia. I am as concerned as all honourable senators would be by the rising smoking rates, particularly among young Australians. I would want to ensure, as I think all honourable senators would want to ensure, that whatever decisions people make are made on the basis of accurate information. On the basis of that being the goal towards which the honourable senator is aiming, I will make his concerns known to my colleague the Minister for Health. I will try to obtain specific answers as to future actions which are planned by the Government in this area.

—I ask a question of the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I feel that he too may have a vested interest in this question. Does the Government intend to allow the largest and wealthiest States to receive increased tax sharing grants at the expense of the three smaller States in terms of population? Can he advise how Tasmania can offset its loss of an estimated $63m as recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission report? Further, can Tasmania now expect more favourable treatment by way of special grants to offset this severe disadvantage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the concern behind Senator Watson's question. It is a concern which I think would be shared by honourable senators from the States which obviously have been disadvantaged in a very considerable way by the recommendations of the Grants Commission. On the other hand, honourable senators from other States which are benefiting from the recommendations and, indeed, the Premiers of those States, will have a different view. Certainly, the recommendations do present very great problems for the Commonwealth and the States. When I say 'the States', I mean all the States because of the natural conflict that results from the recommendations. At this stage let me emphasise that these are only recommendations. The Grants Commission can only make recommendations. It has done a very full and impressive job but I think it was always assumed that an exercise such as this major review of relativities would present difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: This is not by any means simply a matter for the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is anxious that the States reach agreement in regard to the matter. It will be one for discussion at the Premiers Conference on 19 June and no doubt subsequent to that meeting also. At this stage they are recommendations only and they must be the subject of very considerable discussion. The matters that are concerning Senator Watson as a result of the recommendations-they will be concerning States other than Tasmania-will have to be given very urgent consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Will the decision be left to the State Premiers or will the lead be given by the Federal Government?
—As I have said, the matter will be one for discussion between the Government and the States.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that in March this year Dr Bayley, the Director of the Spinal Injuries Unit of the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital in Stanmore, visited Australia to study work being done in spinal units in this country? Dr Bayley maintained that many accidents which create life-long paralysis and disabilities are preventable. He expressed particular concern for tuition of attendants at sports arenas and swimming pools and those involved in the control of sports. The Minister will be aware of the multitude of television advertisements, mainly to sell cool drinks, which depict young people engaged in practices which could be described as potentially dangerous, particularly if attempted by inexperienced young people without supervision. Have the Minister and his Department, in conjunction with the International Year of Disabled Persons, considered the need for greater public awareness, by way of media advertising, of the dangers inherent in advertising which glamorise dangerous behaviour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator is quite correct when she asserts that many of the accidents which lead to spinal injuries and to people becoming paraplegics or quadriplegics are indeed preventable. I cannot answer for Senator Grimes, but as one of the people who have worked in a spinal injuries unit I would assert that many of the people I saw there would not have been there had the most minimal precautions been taken. For example, people had dived head first into shallow water in the belief they were diving into deep water. Any form of public display which would tend to promote dangerous activity is to be deplored. Much work is being done during the International Year of Disabled Persons to try to promote the kind of awareness about which the honourable senator is talking and about which she is concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of the visit of Dr Bayley to this country, but from what the honourable senator said in her question I would have no difficulty in endorsing the propositions which he put. I also endorse the Government's concern that there be promotion to make known to people the dangers of certain kinds of activities and to make known to people the kinds of protective behaviour which would prevent these kinds of accidents occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister what the Minister's Department was doing by way of advertising to draw attention to those activities.

—The question was addressed to me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health. I am not the Minister for Health. That is a question which I will properly have to refer to my colleague to get the details which are required by the honourable senator. I will do that and I will make the information known to her when it comes to hand.

—My question is addressed to the Acting Leader of the Government. It follows the question asked by Senator Watson. As the Commonwealth Grants Commission review of the relativities between the States, which, I might add, was carried out at the request and with the concurrence of all States, found that Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria had been disadvantaged with respect to the other States, I ask: Will the Minister give the House an assurance not only that the findings of this independent review will be implemented without any modifications but also that insofar as the findings are based on the 1978-79 financial year, and therefore demonstrate an imbalance of financial injustice of at least three years' standing, the Commonwealth will make retrospective payments in the recommended ratios for the disadvantaged States?

—The question of Senator MacGibbon who represents Queensland, following the question from Senator Watson who represents Tasmania, gives a very clear indication of State problems and highlights the problems that arise out of this report. I do not have anything further to add to the answer that I gave to Senator Watson on this matter. The report was received only yesterday. Obviously there has not been sufficient time for the Commonwealth Government to give the matter any consideration. The report contains recommendations to the Commonwealth and to the States. The only assurance I can give is that this matter will be discussed with the States as soon as possible.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Federal Cabinet, therefore, go to Queensland to see our non-existent roads and our barefoot population to ascertain the accuracy of the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission?
—I have nothing further to add to the answer.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General, both in that capacity and as Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, in which latter capacity I suppose it can be said that he is now the Minister responsible for 'Cover-Ups'. Is it the case that more than six months have now elapsed since the Australian Federal Police completed its report on aspects of the activities of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd, the Australian Dairy Corporation and its chairman, Mr Webster, and forwarded that report to the Minister for Primary Industry? Is it the case that that report was subsequently forwarded to the Attorney-General's Department for comment as to the possibility of a prosecution being launched? When did the Attorney-General's Department complete its consideration of that report? Is there any justification of which the Attorney-General is aware for further police investigations of the kind to which Mr Nixon referred yesterday in the House of Representatives to justify his failure to make a promised statement on this matter? Finally, will there ever be an 'appropriate time', to use Mr Nixon's own words, for the making of a statement and for the tabling of documents in this matter?

—The police report has been considered by the Crown Solicitor and advice has been given in relation to the matter. I will have to investigate just when that was, although my recollection is that it was quite recently. Time does move very quickly in this place, as we all know, even on days of the length we are having at the moment. I will have to make further inquiries about the matter. I hope to be in a position to give more details in answer to Senator Evans as soon as possible.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will 'as soon as possible' be before we rise tomorrow, or will time once again get away from the Attorney-General?
—I will seek to obtain as much information as I can from my own sources in regard to the matter before tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to the recent judgment in a defamation case of Bingham v. Australian Broadcasting Commission, relating to a report broadcast on the Nationwide program, in which the jury found against the ABC to the tune of $35,000 damages. Has the Minister yet obtained an estimate of the additional costs to the ABC for its own and the plaintiff's legal fees and other expenses in the case? In the light of the finding of the jury that the Nationwide report deliberately defamed the plaintiff, notwithstanding his protests, without bothering to conduct the most elementary of checks about its material, what disciplinary action is the ABC taking against Mr Hale and Mr Olle for their part in the proceedings? If no disciplinary action is being taken, why not?

—Like most honourable senators in this place, I have had occasion to appear on some of the Australian Broadcasting Commission's programs. I must say that I have received courteous and fair treatment on such occasions.
—Whether you deserved it or not.

—I thank the honourable senator for his most generous and courteous interjection. Nevertheless, the facts of the particular case seem to be as Senator Lewis set them out. There seems to be no doubt that the award was made because of action on the Nationwide program which was inappropriate and unreasonable. The honourable senator asked about estimated additional costs and about disciplinary action. Some parts of his question can be answered only by the Minister for Communications. It might be appropriate, to obtain that detailed information, if I passed the substance of the honourable senator's question to Mr Sinclair and advised the honourable senator in due course.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry recall that on 25 March last I directed to him a question concerning the level of Commonwealth Government funding for the Rural Adjustment Scheme? In a written reply to me on 15 April the Minister responded by saying, amongst other things, that the level of funding was not a measure of the Government's commitment to the Rural Adjustment Scheme but that it reflected the normal economic and budgetary processes and the objectives of the Scheme. I ask: Is he aware that the preamble to the agreement between the Commonwealth and the State says that the Commonwealth and the State recognise that there is a need to provide assistance to persons engaged in rural industries throughout Australia and that the carrying out of the scheme is dependent upon financial assistance being granted by the Parliament of the Commonwealth to the States for that purpose? Therefore, will the Minister agree with me that his reply of 15 April indicates that the Government is more preoccupied with its budgetary processes than with its commitment to the scheme and the family farmers the scheme sets out to help? In short, is the Commonwealth Government writing down its commitment to the scheme?

—I think the simple answer to that question is no, but the honourable senator would probably prefer a little wider explanation than that. This scheme, in common with virtually every scheme that is funded by this Government, other than matters that come under the National Welfare Fund, depends upon an appropriation by this Parliament, as indeed was indicated by the honourable senator in his question. That means that this scheme, like all other schemes, is subject to budgetary considerations. As would be well known to honourable senators opposite who for a period participated in the national government-of course Senator Douglas McClelland was one of them-it is one thing to assess a desirable need and another then to find the money which enables one to aggregate all the desirable needs and to meet them. The program referred to is one for which there is a Commonwealth commitment, one for which the Commonwealth has provided funds. Of necessity, it is subject to the requirement that it be considered in a Budget context and that funds be made available for it in accordance with such funds as are generally available to meet the many desirable social and economic objectives of the Commonwealth Government.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, relates to the Australian Institute of Sport, which is one of the outstanding initiatives of this Government. The Institute has attracted so little publicity that hardly anyone apart from those directly involved has heard of it. Will the Minister suggest to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment that action be taken to better inform the public about the Institute? Will he ascertain whether a report of its activities is to be presented to the Federal Parliament?

—The honourable senator is quite correct in saying that the Australian Institute of Sport has been a very welcome and outstanding initiative of this Government, one which he quite properly draws to the attention of the Senate and of the Australian people. He is also correct when he says that the dissemination of the widest possible information about the Institute is desirable, not least because it would enable those who could take advantage of the facilities offered by it to be aware of its existence and would enable other Australians to be equally aware of them and of facilities offered in the future. For some time honourable senators in this place have displayed interest in the activities of the Institute, and the honourable senator's suggestion has considerable merit. I will pass it on to the Minister whom I represent to see whether it can be carried out.

—I premise my question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, by saying that on Tuesday of this week I asked a question concerning the non-payment of concessions to sickness beneficiaries in accordance with Government policy. At the end of Question Time I received what was purported to be an answer-that the Department of Transport was experiencing some administrative difficulties in carrying out Government policy. I again ask the question that I asked on Tuesday: For whatever reason, in view of the inability of the Australian National Railways to carry out Government policies and give concessions to those on sickness benefits who must travel, will the Department of Social Security make a cash grant to those who have been deprived of the benefits that the Commonwealth promised them last August due to the inability of the railways to get over the administrative difficulties involved?

—The suggestion made by the honourable senator as to a method of meeting that policy commitment is one which I think goes outside the ways previously followed by Federal governments in administering transport concessions of this sort. It is a fact that there are administrative difficulties in this matter and I understand those difficulties arise from the fact that the Australian National Railways Commission uses as its agents various State railway organisations. As a result it is not directly within the ability of the ANR to provide the concession in accordance with the Government's policy. Therefore, it may be that we will be forced back to the suggestion made by Senator Cavanagh in his question. It would be the preference of the Government to administer the scheme in the same way as other transport concessions are administered. As I indicated earlier in the week, the matter is one which has been the subject of correspondence between me and the Minister for Transport, and I undertook to follow up the matter further with him. At this stage that has not been done personally by me but I think it has been followed up by my office. I will endeavour to get a firmer reply for the honourable senator as soon as possible. That is unlikely to be before the rising of this Parliament, in which case I will write to him during the recess.

—Two weeks ago, I asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory questions regarding the disposal of radioactive waste from the Synroc program at the Australian National University. I have not yet had an answer to those questions, and I now add to them. Are radioactive wastes being poured down sinks at the ANU and Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation laboratories? Of what strength of radioactivity are these wastes? Have yabbies and fish in the Molonglo and Murrumbidgee rivers been monitored for the effects of radioactivity? What radiation-affected material is incinerated at the John Curtin School of Medical Research and other parts of the ANU? Has the Government any information on the location of mine shafts in the Shoalhaven area where radioactive waste has been buried and shafts filled in by bulldozers? What chance have I of an early answer to all these questions that I have asked on the matter?

—Perhaps the last part of the question is the part I should address myself to. It would be extremely difficult to bring down an answer before tomorrow. Nevertheless, I will try to get answers, at least to the part of the honourable senator's questions asked a fortnight ago, before tomorrow if at all possible. As to the many detailed matters, I am afraid I have no immediate information on them. I hope to get some reply to the honourable senator during the recess by way of letter.

—My question, addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, relates to the employment of non-public servants in permanent Commonwealth positions. Given that the Commonwealth's anticipated total staff reduction of up to 17,000 will obviously result in retrenchments, I ask: Are people outside the Public Service still eligible to apply for some advertised vacancies? If so, what types of positions are most likely to be open to non-permanent members of the Public Service?

—Following the announcement of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee's decisions, the Public Service Board by way of holding operations suspended all the new staffing actions under the Public Service Act except for certain key occupational groups including trainees and apprentices. Of course this was required to assess the staffing implications of the decisions. As the staffing situation of the Public Service permits, the Board will progressively lift the restrictions. Occupational groups exempted from the restrictions include medical, hospital, environment, air and marine operations, analytical laboratories and meteorological forecasting. The Board has approved a limited base grade recruitment, essentially to compensate for staff wastage. The remaining positions, for outside appointments-I think this area is the main interest of Senator Neal-or promotion of permanent officers will be examined when the Board is satisfied that no staff are or are expected to be surplus at the level of the position concerned. It is not possible to spell out which type of position could be open at present to persons outside the Public Service.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LEGAL AID: ADMINISTRATIVE APPEALS TRIBUNAL CASE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, in a sense follows the question asked by Senator Evans. Has the Attorney received in his Department an application for legal aid from any of the parties before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to the Channel 10 case in Melbourne? If so, how long has he had any such application for legal aid and when will he deal with it, in view of the fact that the party concerned has been described by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as an appropriate group to represent the public interest in that hearing? Has the Attorney considered the answers to questions asked of him up to 18 months ago about prosecutions under the Broadcasting and Television Act for breaches of that Act, as revealed in the decision of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, by the News Corporation or some other company associated with the News Corporation?

—Yes, there is an application for legal aid by at least one of the parties to the proceedings in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I do not propose to identify that applicant as Senator Button did not do so in his question. I am aware of only one application but there may be others which I will just have to make some inquiries about. I hope to be able to resolve the matter fairly quickly. It certainly has been an application for some time now. In relation to the other question which, of course, is quite unrelated, I gave a considerable number of answers to questions on this matter some time ago. I do not have anything to add to them except to say that the whole matter is really in abeyance while the appeal proceedings are going on in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Finance, refers to Statutory Rule No. 127, gazetted on 30 May 1980, which authorised increases in export expansion grant payments to meat exporters for the years 1977-78 and 1978-79. Will the Minister for Finance confirm the estimates of the Department of Primary Industry that these increases were at a cost of some $20m? I further ask: For what reason were higher incentive payments authorised 11 months after meat ceased to be an eligible product for export grants? Why have the full details of the increase, such as the names of the recipients of this amount of money, never been publicly announced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will seek information from my Department on the matter raised by Senator McLaren and respond to him as early as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Research expenditure in Australia is 0.2 per cent of the total health bill. With the massive cuts that have been made recently in the health area, can the Minister say whether research expenditure also has been affected? Does the Minister not agree that with the scientific talent we have in Australia we should promote research instead of relying on findings from overseas, at the same time losing some of our best brains in medical research to other countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Medical research in Australia is funded largely by government and largely through the National Health and Medical Research Council. The amounts of money which have been made available for medical research through this avenue have increased progressively in the last few years. I was a research person in this area for some of my career and I always took the view then that there was never enough, but the fact is that the money has increased progressively. Each year the Government has tried to make sure that the maximum possible support is given to medical research. The fact is that Australian medical research is of a very high calibre by world standards, that the achievements of medical research in Australia are very considerable and that the funding that is available, apart from going to individuals, goes to several world famous institutes, not least of which is the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research in Melbourne. The honourable senator is probably aware of that institute because of the work it has done.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it would be inappropriate if Australia were to lose its medical research scientists, but I assure the honourable senator that with the system we have, under which funding is made to individuals on the basis of the merit of proposals and with the increased funds that have been made available year by year, there is a vigorous research community in Australia. I understand that the amount of money made available will become known in the Budget context-it has been made known each year in the Budget context-and it is not possible to predict, nor indeed is it the practice of the Government to predict, what any specific appropriation is to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. By way of preface I refer to the recent statement by the Government deploring the escalation of violence between Iraq and Israel. Whilst we accept that what has been said is largely correct, why was there no comment about the acquisition of nuclear facilities by a Middle East power? Surely it is a threat to world peace. Why did the Government not say so in its statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the question to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs to see whether there is some reason for the matter to which Senator Mulvihill has referred. I will see that information is given to him as early as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION SERVICES: NORTHERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Having in mind that the Australian Broadcasting Commission in the Northern Territory has just been granted by the Commissioners of the Australian Broadcasting Commission status similar to the status it has in the States, and noting the comments in the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission-the Dix report-which indicate that the role of the Commission in the north has to be substantially improved in the many facets of radio and television services, will the Government ensure that the Dix Committee recommendations are given high priority and that these services are given some parity with those in the more densely populated areas of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interest of Senator Kilgariff in the communications needs and problems of the Northern Territory is well known, and his concern for the people of the Northern Territory is acknowledged. I think most honourable senators will be aware of the very considerable communications difficulties which people face in some of the remote areas of Australia. They would include the difficulties faced by some of the people for whom I have direct ministerial responsibility. The fact that the Commissioners of the Australian Broadcasting Commission have seen fit to grant a new status to the Northern Territory, as Senator Kilgariff indicates in his question, is something which honourable senators would welcome. The honourable senator also draws to our attention the particular requirement for increasing the communications capacities in remote communities. That is one matter that we would want to see followed up.

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot say yet how the Government will respond to the recommendations of the Dix Committee report. The honourable senator will know that it was received only this week and that it is on the list of documents for tabling today. It is really too soon to say how each recommendation will be followed up. I can certainly say to the honourable senator that the Government does recognise the problems which he sets out in his question. It recognises the need to address these problems carefully. I remind the honourable senator that questions of communications in remote areas of the Northern Territory have been under active study for some time. They are a concern of the Government and we would want to see the maximum possible improvement in communications for the people of the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government, refers in part to earlier questioning concerning the Grants Commission report and his promise that conferences will be held to try to ameliorate the devastating impact of that report on Tasmania's future. It was reported in today's Press that the reduction in funds of some $64m will require some 2,000 jobs to be scrapped in the Public Service of that State. Is it a fact that Tasmania was the granary of the Australian colonies? Is it a fact that Melbourne was founded from Tasmania? In other words, is it a fact that the early history of Australia shows that, following European settlement, Tasmania nurtured this nation in its early infancy? As a Tasmanian senator, I ask: If the present-day Australian nation spurns Tasmania, leaving it to wither away and die like some ancient relative, what reason can the Minister offer for Tasmania to stay within the Federation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —If anybody had any doubts about this chamber being a States House, those doubts would certainly have been put to rest as a result of the questions asked this morning about the Commonwealth Grants Commission report. I am glad that Senator Tate, an Opposition senator representing Tasmania, has joined his colleague Senator Watson, a Government senator from Tasmania, in standing up for the interests of their State. I am aware of the many virtues of Tasmania. I am grateful to have been given some other information, such as that contained in the first part of the honourable senator's question, which was a statement about the early history of Tasmania in relation to the foundation of Victoria. I think I had some understanding of that.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said earlier, naturally, there are very grave problems for some States-indeed for all States-as a result of these recommendations. I do not really believe that the States will be going to the lengths that are suggested by Senator Tate. Tasmania has benefited in many areas, not only under the financial assistance grants but also under many other grants. I have in mind legal aid. The per capita contribution to Tasmania for legal aid is well ahead of the average grant to other States for that purpose. Tasmania does derive very great benefits from its membership of the Federation, and indeed the other States in the Federation derive great benefits from Tasmania's membership.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security say what the present unemployment rate in Australia is? The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, on 16 October 1978 said:

QUESTION.PARA: On present trends, that figure (of unemployment) is likely to reach one million by 1981.
He was proved wrong then. In May 1979 he said:
In January and New Year unemployment will be of the order of 550,000.
When he was proved wrong once again he had another stab. On 9 October 1980 he put another proposition when he said:
. . . more than a half a million Australians will be without jobs by the New Year . . .
What credibility will the Australian people place on any further statements the Leader of the Opposition may make?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is remarkable that there have not been more expressions of pleasure in this chamber at the fact that the unemployment figures have improved of late. Even more significantly, the total employment figures have shown a considerable increase for both the young and the older sections of the population. As to the chronicle of predictions by Mr Hayden that was referred to by the honourable senator, whilst I have a great love of fiction I find that writers other than Mr Hayden attract my attention and fancy rather more than he does. The predictions of gloom and doom in which the Leader of the Opposition indulges are typical of so many members of the Opposition. They seem to wish to see this country reduced to the lowest possible state. Honourable senators on this side of the House are very pleased to know that the general employment prospects in this country are improving and have improved. That is mirrored in the general employment statistics issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to numerous half answers that have been given in the Parliament about the availability of the broadcasting and television legislation drafts before the legislation was introduced into the Parliament. Were drafts made available to and/or discussed with the News Corporation and/or its representatives, the Packer commercial broadcasting interests and/or their representatives, any public interest groups, and Herald and Weekly Times Ltd and/or its representatives on or prior to 14 May 1981?

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister inquire from the Department about this matter? I suggest that he could glean the answer from what has already been said publicly by the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. What disciplinary action does the Government propose to take against the Telecom executive, which sees itself as a law unto itself, as the executive's action completely undermined the Government's position in relation to private industry and its wage claims?

—The answer to Senator MacGibbon's first question is yes. The Minister wrote to the Acting Chairman of Telecom along the lines Senator MacGibbon has mentioned. I am not in a position to answer the other part of the question. As I said earlier, the questions that arise in relation to this matter are under urgent consideration by the Government. —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It relates to the general state of the Daw Park Repatriation Hospital. The Minister will be aware of the recommendations and applications made to him for improvements in the hospital's facilities and appliances. I understand that he may have inspected the hospital. —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to an answer given by Senator Carrick on the Deputy Prime Minister's statement in Latin America about Australia's proposed military involvement in the Middle East and remind him of the reaffirmation of Mr Anthony's statement made on AM this morning. Can the Minister clarify the position justify having regard to the confused position that now exists on this very important matter? I particularly remind the Minister of the contradictory position that now seems apparent and how Australia came to be involved in Vietnam in the early 1960s. Are we in a similar position with respect to the Middle East?

—I am certainly not in a position to reaffirm the statement because it has been made quite clear that the report yesterday of what the Deputy Prime Minister said is not correct. TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June Senator Wheeldon asked for information about Mr Juris Bumeisters, who has allegedly been arrested and tried in the Soviet Union for his activities in the Latvian Social Democratic Party. The Government was not previously aware of this case. Senator Wheeldon may like to make available any further information that he has on the matter. The Government will consider what might be the most appropriate action when it has examined all the information available. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Archer asked me a question in connection with the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme. I can provide some supplementary information. The Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme provides funds to consignors of eligible goods by sea. A fundamental change to the scheme-indeed, a new type of scheme-would be needed to extend it in some way to the carriage of goods by air whenever sea transport is unavailable. Similarly, a major change would be required to have a form of Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme applicable to sea and air consignments. It is not visualised that air transport would be a complete alternative to sea transport.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of extending the scheme to cover air freight has been considered on a number of occasions. Each time it has been looked at it has been agreed that such an extension would probably result in a reduction in the availability of shipping services with an overall increase in transport costs which would disadvantage all Tasmanians in the longer term. As honourable senators will appreciate, not all commodities-for example, zinc, paper, et cetera-are able to be transported economically by air. Some of these commodities are vital to Tasmania and are dependent on viable shipping services. The provision of assistance on air freighted goods would, in fact, discriminate against these commodities. It is for this reason that the Equalisation Scheme applies only to goods transported interstate from Tasmania by sea and specifically excludes those goods transported by air.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Elstob asked me a question about medical research funding in Australia. I can add to the answer I gave him the following information: For 1980-81, $18.7m has been allocated to the National Health and Medical Research Council for support of medical research. That represents, in fact, a 33.5 per cent increase over the funding for the previous year. In real terms, if one allows for inflation, that represents an increase of one-sixth in funding. This significant increase in funding is consistent with the thrust of the honourable senator's question and is consistent with the Government's intention to increase gradually the level of funding for medical research to international standards as economic conditions allow. The number of project grants will increase from 543 to 592 and the number of program grants-that is, institutional grants-will increase from three to eight. The only other point on that matter is to observe that the NHMRC funding is actually a calendar year funding. The Budget, of course, provides for financial year figures and the actual NHMRC budget for the calendar year 1981 will be about $22.7m. So the allocation is greater than it seems to be.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question by Senator Kilgariff on 10 June concerning malaria in Australia. I have some extra information to the answer I gave. Notifications of malaria from all over mainland Australia, not just from the north, indicate that the number of cases of malaria continues to increase. As I said in my answer yesterday, this refers to malaria which is imported into Australia. There is, therefore, a risk of malaria being re-established in the areas of Australia north of the 19th parallel where climatic conditions would permit a resurgence. The increase is due partly to the fact that there is a resurgence of malaria in many of the malarious areas of the world. This is partly reflected in an increase in the incidence of malaria in travellers returning to Australia after visiting some of the malarious areas.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked about action being taken to prevent re-establishment of malaria in this country. The action being taken includes: Firstly, the Commonwealth in conjunction with State and Territory health authorities has an efficient vigilance system in northern Australia. This was demonstrated in 1977 when a threatened outbreak at Cape York was prevented and, again, when three cases occurred on Moa Island last year. Secondly, all microscopically diagnosed cases are notified to a central register and a close watch is kept on the infective potential of all cases. Thirdly, preventive and radical treatments are administered to travellers who have been in malarious areas at certain ports of entry into Australia such as Darwin, Gove, Groote Eylandt, Bamaga and Thursday Island. Fourthly, mosquito control measures are well developed in the Northern Territory and insecticide spraying of houses is done twice a year in the highly vulnerable Torres Strait Islands by the Queensland Government. Fifthly, plans are well advanced for the establishment of a malaria field station in Torres Strait. Sixthly, advice on prophylactic measures for travellers to malarious areas is updated regularly. There are currently available publications which set out these matters and which I can make available to the honourable senator.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff asked me a question on 4 June concerning radio interference from the Russian woodpecker device, the over-the-horizon radar. I have some fairly detailed information in response to the honourable senator's question. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
RUSSIAN WOODPECKER INTERFERENCE TO OTHER SERVICES

Member countries of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) including Russia agree to abide by ITU and Radio Regulations. There is an ITU mechanism for protest if harmful interference is caused to radio systems of any member country which is operating within the legal framework of the ITU Radio Regulations. There has to date been no positive evidence of serious harmful interference to any Australian Service from the Russian Woodpecker Over-the-Horizon (OHR) Radar.

The Woodpecker is a military system alleged to be transmitting from a location near Kiev in the USSR. It is believed to operate on the ''back scatter'' principle with high power radio frequency pulses being emitted at a rate of about ten per second.

This system requires sensitive receiving equipment which is linked with sophisticated processing and computer facilities to build up a continuously updated image of objects in a given target area, which may be located some thousands of kilometres distant.

Because of the continually changing ionosphere, on which OHR depends, it is necessary to also constantly change the operating frequency of such transmissions to permit radar signals to continue to track a given target area.

Services which can be affected are the Amateur Service and the Citizens Band Radio Service (CBRS). As the Amateur Service shares a number of bands with other services and has allocations of frequencies to choose from at any given time, there should be scope for avoiding the usually transient interference effects from such radar transmission by Amateur operators temporarily shifting to another frequency at the time such interference is present.

Interference to amateurs is particularly evident in the 14 MHz band where it is often harmful in the sense that a change to a less useful frequency is necessary. Interference to the CBRS is believed to have been minimal in Australia as there has been little complaint until now.

There are no simple technical measures to combat the interference. The signals in Australia depend on Russian power output; and ionospheric conditions above the earth, which vary with solar conditions.
The Department of Communications has written to the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications in the USSR to ask them to investigate the matter, and are currently awaiting a reply.
