PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill is an omnibus Bill by which the Government seeks to make wide-ranging changes to four health Acts. These will give effect to the Government's philosophy and goals outlined in the recent statement by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) in another place on health care services. As honourable senators will be aware, the Government's overriding goal in the health area is that all Australians should have access to the high quality health care services we now enjoy in this country. But the achievement of this aim must be at a cost the individual and community can afford. The Government believes that the most equitable and responsible means of achieving these goals is by means of a health policy that:
(i) Requires the State and Northern Territory governments to take up their full constitutional responsibilities for the provision of health services;
(ii) ensures that those in genuine need receive special assistance to cover their hospital and medical bills;
(iii) results in other people contributing towards the cost of the health services they receive-either totally out of their own pockets or through health insurance;
(iv) ensures that health insurance is available to all people at a reasonable cost and directs the relevant government subsidies towards those who are willing to help themselves;
(v) recognises the importance of the community rating principle for a viable health insurance industry;
(vi) fully acknowledges the important role of the private sector of the health care delivery system, particularly private hospitals; and
(vii) seeks to ensure that users and providers of health care services become more aware of the costs they generate.
The Bill now before the Senate will also:

(i) Ensure immediate eligibility to receive basic insurance benefits for people taking out such cover with a registered health fund between 1 September and 31 October 1981 irrespective of any pre-existing illness conditions;

(ii) ensure that those people who lose their entitlement to a pensioner health benefit or health care card and then choose to insure with a registered health fund can immediately become eligible for benefits at the basic coverage level;
(iii) provide for the Commonwealth to pay all nursing home benefits and, so, take over responsibility for those nursing home benefits currently paid by health funds for insured persons;

(iv) strengthen the powers of medical and optometrical services committees of inquiry to increase their effectiveness in combating the provision of excessive services by medical practitioners and optometrists;

(v) provide further protection to people in a nursing home against being unnecessarily charged for 'extras' that would normally be regarded as part of nursing home care and, therefore, included in the approved fee;
(vi) expand the operation of the isolated patients' travel and accommodation assistance scheme;
(vii) give effect to certain recommendations made by the pathology services working party which have been accepted by the Government;
(viii) overcome a problem in the existing legislation which relates to the bulk billing of certain pathology services; and
(xi) extend the Commonwealth's supervision of the production and supply of certain therapeutic goods.

Mr President, the Senate will recall that in the statement by the Minister for Health on 29 April in another place on the Government's new health policy he outlined new funding arrangements it is proposed to introduce for State health services. They are designed to ensure that the waste, inefficiencies and unnecessary duplication of costly equipment in State public hospital systems highlighted by the Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals are overcome. Such waste and inefficiency cannot be allowed to continue. It results in a needless burden on all taxpayers and the Government would be neglecting its duties if it failed to take appropriate action. The Jamison inquiry found that a major reason for such waste and inefficiency was the problem of divided responsibility between the Commonwealth and State governments. The inquiry recommended that this should be corrected by requiring the states to take up their full constitutional responsibilities for the provision of health services.

The Government's new health care funding arrangements will give the States greater freedom in the spending of Commonwealth funds previously provided for specific health purposes. The States will now be totally responsible for determining their own priorities in this area and appropriately allocating resources. The new health funding arrangements will do this. The relevant enabling legislation-the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill-has already been considered by the Senate. However, an appropriate amendment to the Health Insurance Act is necessary because South Australia and Tasmania have agreements with the Commonwealth that operate until 30 June 1985 under which the Commonwealth cost-shares the agreed net operating expenses of their public hospitals. This is achieved in the Bill now before the Senate.

The Government recognises that some States may seek to undermine the new health service funding arrangements by transferring traditional State functions in the nursing home area to the Commonwealth. It is recognised, for example, that some States could seek to re-classify public hospitals as State Government nursing homes. This would result in the Commonwealth paying nursing home benefits for such people. To protect the Commonwealth against such action the Bill will ensure that State Government nursing homes are not to be approved in future for the purpose of paying nursing home benefits without consideration of the need for such homes in the same way that other nursing home proposals are considered. Similarly, States could seek to classify institutions now receiving their financial support as Commonwealth deficit-financed nursing homes. Such action would, again, be unacceptable to the Commonwealth. The Bill now before the Senate prevents such an action. However, a ministerial discretion is provided in appropriate circumstances where the Minister considers a transfer of a State financial responsibility is not involved.

A basic element of the Government's health policy is that the Commonwealth should provide special assistance to cover the hospital and medical bills of those in genuine need namely: Persons holding pensioner health benefit cards; migrants and refugees during their first six months in Australia; people in receipt of unemployment and special benefits with private incomes below the pensioner health benefit limits; and people whose incomes fall below certain specified limits, plus their dependants. The Commonwealth will ensure that these people will continue to have free access to public hospitals by placing an appropriate condition on the States and Northern Territory. For States other than South Australia and Tasmania this is by a condition in the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill 1981. For South Australia and Tasmania the agreed arrangements will provide for such a condition to apply.

Mr President, in the face of recent media speculation as to the position of pensioners under the Government's new health policy, I would like to again reassure all those people who hold pensioner health benefit cards and their dependants that there will be no change in their position after 1 September next. The Bill now before the Senate therefore retains the existing arrangements for eligible pensioners and their dependants. These people will continue to be entitled to free private medical services where their doctor bulk bills them. And, as at present, where such a person's doctor chooses not to bulk bill, they will be entitled to a Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent of the schedule fee, with a maximum payment-known as 'the gap payment'-of $5 per service where the doctor charges the schedule fee or less.

The Bill will introduce similar arrangements for those other groups outlined above who are considered to be in special need. They will be eligible for free public hospital accommodation and treatment and free bulk-billed medical services. They, in the majority of cases, will receive a health care card before such treatment becomes necessary. A Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent will apply to bulk billed private medical services they receive. This compares with the present level of 75 per cent for those persons classified by their doctors as disadvantaged. It is expected that the majority of people covered will be bulk billed and, therefore, will not have to meet any 'gap' payment. Doctors are, of course, free to choose not to bulk-bill. Provision is therefore made in the Bill for holders of a health care card to be paid a Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent through registered health insurance organisations in such circumstances-in the same way eligible pensioners are-with a maximum 'gap payment' of $5 for each service, so long as the doctor charges no more than the schedule fee.

Honourable senators will be aware that under the Government's new health policy, those people considered to be in a special need are being clearly defined for the first time. The Government has decided to take this action-and no longer leave this in the hands of individual doctors-because of a dual concern, namely: That bulk billed medical services provided under the existing disadvantaged arrangements are growing at a rate which would indicate that those services have been made available to persons who could not normally be regarded as disadvantaged; and people in genuine need are not always able to gain the protection of those arrangements. The Bill enables a person to apply for a health care card on the grounds that he or she fell within the low income category at the time a medical or hospital service was provided. The application may be lodged up to 13 weeks after the service was provided. In special circumstances a longer period will be acceptable. This means that it is not essential that people in special need have a health care card before they receive a service. Of course these new arrangements for those in special need will not apply prior to 1 September 1981.

The Government estimates that nearly two million eligible pensioners and their dependants will be protected in this way and that up to one million people will be eligible for special assistance under the new health care card arrangements. Mr President, I would point out to the Senate that it will not be necessary for these people to take out medical or hospital insurance. However, if they want doctor of choice in a public hospital or wish to use a private hospital, they would-as is now the case-need to take out hospital insurance. I would also point out that the Government recognises that should any person lose his or her entitlement to a pensioner health benefit or health care card, they can obtain immediate cover by basic insurance with a registered health fund. The Bill will achieve this by requiring funds to waive the two months waiting period before people taking out insurance are entitled to receive both hospital and medical benefits at the basic level in such cases.

Under the Government's new health policy those persons-and their dependants-not protected by the special assistance arrangements outlined above will be required to meet their hospital and medical bills. They may choose to do so by personal payment or through insurance. There are, therefore, considerable advantages in taking out insurance, or maintaining one's cover, after 1 September. Additional advantages will be as follows: Commonwealth medical benefits will be available only to those with at least basic medical cover with a registered health fund; secondly, the Commonwealth medical benefit payable will be at a flat rate of 30 per cent and will apply to all items included in the medical benefits schedule; additionally, the total benefit payable to a person with basic medical insurance will be equal to 85 per cent of the schedule fee with a maximum 'gap' payment of $10 where the doctor charges the schedule fee or less-this compares with the present level of 75 per cent and a maximum gap of $10; and, fourthly, a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar will apply for the cost of basic medical and/or hospital insurance with a registered health fund.

These new arrangements will apply from 1 September 1981. As the Treasurer (Mr Howard) stated in his second reading speech when introducing the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill 1981, this rebate will be at a rate of 32c in the dollar and will apply to amounts paid on or after 1 July 1981 for basic hospital and/or medical insurance cover from that date with a registered health fund.

As honourable senators will be aware, persons taking out health insurance are normally required to wait two months before they are entitled to receive benefits at the basic level. The Government has decided that this waiting period should be waived between 1 September and 31 October next. The Government has also decided to put beyond any doubt that a fund should not apply a pre-existing ailment exclusion provision to people taking out insurance at the basic level during this period. As a result, no fund can refuse to accept any person applying for insurance cover at the basic level, no matter how seriously ill they might be when they apply and no matter how long they may have suffered from the illness. This anti-discriminatory measure also applies, of course, to women who are pregnant.

I would stress, Mr President, that the introduction of these legislative provisions should not be seen as a criticism of registered health funds as a whole. The Government believes that, generally speaking, the funds act to ensure that their members receive proper protection against the high cost of health care. However it must be recognised that some funds-very few in number-may not always act in this way and so the Commonwealth must have the means of ensuring that no insured persons are adversely affected by actions of a fund that are contrary to government policy.

In order to further its aim of ensuring that insurance is available at a reasonable cost-and, at the same time, to provide greater protection for the aged and the chronically ill in relation to the cost of nursing home care-the Government has decided to take over full responsibility for the payment of nursing home benefits. The amendments to the National Health Act provided for in Part III of the Bill-together with complementary amendments to the Nursing Homes Assistance Act-will give effect to this decision. They will operate from 1 September 1981.

Since 1 October 1977 registered hospital benefits organisations have been required to pay, as part of basic hospital insurance, all nursing home benefits for their members. These benefits payable by the funds are equivalent in level to the benefits the Commonwealth pays for all patients in nursing homes who are not insured. The Government has decided that this arrangement is unsatisfactory for two principal reasons, namely: Nursing home patients are, in the strict sense, uninsurable through voluntary insurance in which guaranteed benefits without discrimination or exclusions are made mandatory; and the arrangement represents an inequitable liability for the bulk of people with hospital insurance. The Government believes that this decision will ensure a more equitable distribution of the cost of Commonwealth assistance to those in need of nursing home care. The Government also believes that this measure will further assist in containing the cost of health insurance.

The Government will also be providing additional protection for people receiving nursing home care by new provisions to more clearly prevent nursing homes imposing a levy or compulsory additional charge on patients. Regrettably some nursing homes attempt to circumvent the present fee control arrangements by such measures. The Bill before the Senate will prevent this practice. I would add, Mr President, that the great bulk of nursing homes do not attempt to pursue such practices and these new provisions should in no way be taken as a reflection on the industry as a whole.

The Bill now before the Senate also gives effect to the Government's decision to prohibit registered health benefit funds from operating optional benefit tables. These tables undermine the community rating principle under which the cost of health insurance is borne equally by contributors with such cover. The effect of this principle is to reduce the cost of health insurance to the more needy sections of the community-such as the aged, the chronically ill and families with children. The Bill will therefore strengthen the community rating principle. It will also simplify the present health insurance arrangements.

The Commonwealth fully acknowledges the important role of the private sector of the health care delivery system. The Government has received a number of submissions expressing concern at the financial problems facing private hospitals. It recognises that in the medium to longer term its overall health policy will assist in correcting this situation. However, immediate action is necessary to assist private hospitals in meeting the increased cost of servicing surgical beds. Surgical facilities in private hospitals should continue to be available to the community.

To achieve this goal a higher rate of subsidy-of $28 per day-is to be introduced for private hospital patients whose admission to hospital or subsequent treatment is primarily related to a surgical procedure. The new subsidy will operate from the date the Bill receives royal assent. The existing bed day subsidy of $16 per day will be retained for non-surgical patients in private hospitals. It is proposed that the medical services in private hospitals that will attract the higher subsidy will be prescribed in regulations. The Bill also provides that the Minister for Health will have a discretionary power to review individual cases, and by a regulation, to admit additional schedule items to the approved list.

The Bill now before the Senate contains a number of provisions related to the Isolated Patients' Travel and Accommodation Scheme, the Therapeutic Goods Act and several machinery matters. The IPTAAS Scheme is to be expanded in line with the Government's decision last year to include cleft lip and cleft palate patients under 22 years of age requiring orthodontic and associated treatment and other patients requiring specialist oral surgery. The extension of the scheme is to apply retrospectively from 1 January 1981 to coincide with the date of the inclusion of orthodontic treatment for cleft lip patients in the medical benefits schedule.

The Bill now before the Senate would amend the Therapeutic Goods Act. The amendments seek to keep Australia abreast with other developed countries and further exemplifies the Government's belief that it should have the capability of ensuring that the therapeutic goods available in Australia are safe, pure, potent and of good quality. The Bill would amend the definition of therapeutic use to ensure that health care products and medical devices including contraceptive devices, pacemakers and artificial heart valves clearly come within the scope of the Act.

The Bill would also update the references to British publications which are the source of standards for goods for therapeutic use. Unless this is done, the standards upon which Australia has relied for so long would no longer have effect. The Bill would authorise the Minister for Health to set standards by references to other published sources. Under the present legislation the means for obtaining essential information about the way biological products are made is not available. The Bill would provide a mechanism to allow the Commonwealth, when necessary, to seek information about the manufacture and testing of biological products. It will also provide a mechanism to regulate their release onto the market. As the need for a complete list of the medicines used in Australia has long been felt, the Bill would establish the national register of therapeutic goods and provide the power to acquire information regarding the composition of goods included in the register.

To safeguard the rights of manufactures, the Bill will include appeal machinery. It will provide for appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions of the Director-General that affect the commercial operations of a manufacturer. In addition, before the Director-General can seek information about medicinal preparations from a manufacturer for inclusion in the proposed register, those preparations must be declared by the regulations to be goods to which the register applies. The type of information must also be prescribed by the regulations. In this way the Parliament will have the opportunity to oversight the information which has been recorded. Similar arrangements will apply in relation to the expansion of the scope of the Therapeutic Goods Act. Before new health care products can be brought within its scope they must be prescribed.

The Bill also contains a number of clauses related to the rendering of pathology services. It would correct an anomaly in relation to the assignment of benefits for pathology services. The Health Insurance Act now stipulates that in cases of bulk billing, a patient must assign his benefit at the time or after the service is provided. However, in the case of the majority of pathology services, the service is carried out sometime after a specimen is collected from the patient and the pathologist has no face-to-face contact with the patient. The amendment will enable benefits to be assigned in advance of the actual rendering of the pathology service.

The Bill includes a number of changes to the approved pathology practitioner provisions that were recommended by the pathology services working party. This working party was established by the Government in 1976 principally to review pathology arrangements, and schedule fees and benefits for pathology services. Its members included representatives from the Australian Medical Association, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia, the Society of Pathologists in private practice, the Health Commission of New South Wales and Commonwealth departments.

Under the present arrangements medical practitioners requiring pathology tests to be performed must make their request in writing. The Bill now before the Senate will enable the Minister to approve requests in other forms so as to allow modern methods of data transmission to be used. In addition, the amendments would also enable the Minister to approve the use of alternative methods of modern storage media such as on microfilm and microfiche. The effect of the new provisions is to require the Minister for Health to keep the AMA informed in writing of any changes referred to the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee which involved variations to undertakings entered into by pathologists and for the Minister to be aware of the AMA comments before making such changes. The clause also provides for the AMA to be consulted ahead of the implementation of any recommendations by the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee which could lead to variations to undertakings. The Bill sets out those practices which were regarded by the pathology services working party as being inconsistent with the generally accepted standards of professional conduct. The effect of this will be to reduce the incidence of the provision of unnecessary practices. In order to clarify for approved pathology practitioners those practices prohibited by the Bill it will be necessary for them to enter into new undertakings with the Minister for Health. The Bill provides for the transition from the present undertaking to the new undertaking to be carried out in an orderly fashion .

The Bill also contains a number of provisions which deal with the powers of medical and optometrical services committees of inquiry. Medical services committees of inquiry have been set up, under the provisions of the Health Insurance Act, in each State. One optometrical services committee of inquiry for the whole of Australia has also been set up under the Act, to serve a similar function in relation to optometrists. These committees form a peer review system which has been designed to combat the provision of excessive services by medical practitioners and optometrists. The provision of excessive services is a practice whereby medical services are provided to patients although such services are not reasonably necessary for the adequate medical care of the patients concerned. Doctors or optometrists who provide these services may claim Commonwealth medical benefits for them, through the bulk billing facility provided. This means that by providing these unnecessary services these doctors or optometrists are augmenting their income at the taxpayer's expense.

The medical profession is well respected within the community and the Government will work with the profession in maintaining these high standards of ethical conduct. As a corollary to this members of the profession who abuse or defraud financial arrangements put in place by the Government can expect no sympathy.

The Bill now before the Senate contains four proposals for increasing the effectiveness of the peer review system. These proposals have the agreement of the Australian Medical Association. The first proposal will enable the Minister for Health to appoint temporary members to casual vacancies. This will keep the committees fully operational during the time it takes to follow the statutory procedures for filling these vacancies on a permanent basis.

The second and third proposals, which are taken together in the proposed new section 96 of the principal Act, will require practitioners to attend hearings and to produce their clinical notes. Attendance at hearings will give a practitioner the opportunity, if he or she so wishes-and this will be without compulsion-to explain to members of a committee why he or she felt it necessary to provide the services in question. The presentation of clinical notes will give committee members a factual basis for making professional and objective judgments as to whether the services in question were necessary.

Finally, the Bill will allow MSCIs to recommend to the Minister that practitioners be counselled. Sometimes a committee, while being satisfied that excessive services have been provided, is also satisfied that they were provided in good faith by the practitioner concerned. At present the Act does not provide an appropriate course of action which the committees may recommend to the Minister in these instances. This proposal is intended to fill this gap.

Honourable senators may rest assured that any information provided to committees under the provisions of this Bill will be treated in the strictest confidence. All persons involved in a committee hearing are bound by the secrecy provisions of section 130 of the Health Insurance Act 1973, the hearings are private and details of individual patients remain confidential.
Other machinery or clarifying amendments that will be of interest to honourable senators are as follows:

The Bill would extend the provisions in the National Health Act which presently permit the Minister to exempt an organisation from paying medical benefits for certain services to cover also benefits for hospitalisation in respect of these same services. The provision clearly defines the limits or exemptions and protects the rights of contributors who seek to transfer to another organisation because of the exemption.

The Bill will put beyond doubt that under section 43A of the National Health Act the Director-General may request the balance sheets and related statements of nursing homes, as well as other relevant accounts such as profit and loss statements.
Conclusion

The Bill now before the Senate will give effect to the health policy changes the Minister for Health announced on 29 April 1981. The overriding aim of the Government's new health policy is to ensure that all Australians have access to high quality health care at a cost the individual and the community can afford. The Government believes that the most equitable and responsible means of achieving that goal is through a combination of special assistance schemes for those in genuine need and the fostering of private health insurance for other people.

Honourable senators should not lose sight of the fact that major government subsidies, financed through the general taxation system, are provided to ensure that health insurance is available to the average family man at a reasonable cost. However, the Government rejects the concept of a tax financed universal health insurance scheme. The Government believes that such an approach to health financing does not contain sufficient inbuilt checks and balances designed to prevent overuse and abuses of the health care delivery system-and, therefore, that such a system would inevitably lead to an increase in the overall cost of providing health services to the detriment of all taxpayers. Proper health care is vital to all Australians. But the Government's health policy must be both equitable and responsible. The Bill now before the Senate will achieve these dual goals. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT IN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Science and the Environment-Government Response

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator DURACK
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the text of the statement to the report on industrial research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Science and technology provide the technical base for Australia's industrial advancement. The importance of this base has been underlined in reports from several inquiries over the past two or three years. The report on industrial research and development-IR&D-in Australia from the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has, since its publication in May 1979, made a substantial contribution to public discussion of science and technology issues and to the Government's consideration of policies in this area. The Committee identified a need for a statement of a national policy for science and technology and the report incorporates many suggestions and recommendations for elements to be included in national policies.

Of course, many policy elements are already well established. These include the Government's commitment to encourage industrial research and development in the private sector and to support co-operation between Government research facilities and industry as evidenced by substantial increases in funding of IR&D, the Government's continuing commitment to the work of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and support for private sector research associations. Government policies have been framed in recognition of the importance of science and technology in achieving rising standards of living for all Australians by expanding the current capabilities of industry. This Government firmly believes that research and development is an important element in providing the technological base for industry. The development of new technologies both at home and abroad and their absorption into Australian industry will continue to raise the competitiveness of industry and to increase productivity through more efficient use of resources.

The Senate Committee's report highlights the importance of establishing close links between scientific research and industrial research and development and notes that the two should be linked through public policy. The full integration of science and technology policy within that portfolio facilitates interaction between the two essentially different processes of pure science and technological development and will help in the formulation and application of policies to make each process more supportive of the other. The issues discussed in the Senate Committee's report have also been covered in a variety of contexts in reports from other bodies. These include the Independent Inquiry into CSIRO, Australian Science and Technology Council-ASTEC-the Committee of Inquiry in Technological Change in Australia and the Study Group on Structural Adjustment. As the recommendations relating to science and technology in each case have generally been in close accord, the Government's response to the other reports has also served to satisfy most of the recommendations of the Senate Committee. The issues so covered include support for industrial research and development. the operations of CSIRO, contracting out of Government R&D, R&D offsets, patents, encouragement to the formation of research associations, et cetera. Other issues concerning relationships between tertiary education institutions and industry are matters on which the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) will seek advice from the Tertiary Education Commission.

The application of new developments in science and technology is a most important method of increasing productivity and competitiveness of Australian industry. Therefore the development of policies that will encourage the performance of industrial R&D, lead to the effective application of existing technology and create an environment favourable to industrial innovation is being treated as a matter of national importance. The Senate Standing Committee report on industrial research and development has been of considerable value to the Government in assisting the formulation of Australian science and technology policies. With the concurrence of the Senate I incorporate in Hansard the Government's responses to the recommendations of the Committee.
The document read as follows-
REPORT FROM THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT ON INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
Government Response to Recommendations
Recommendation 1.

The Prime Minister give urgent attention to the expression of a clear national policy for science and technology against which planning decisions in support of IR&D can be made. The policy should attempt to identify and support those scientific endeavours in which Australia could best pursue and achieve excellence, and which at the same time are likely to make significant contributions to national advancement.
Response

The Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC), after operating as an interim body from 1976, was formally established in 1979 to advise the Government on science and technology policies, has made a significant contribution to the development of policies in Australia. ASTEC has provided advice and recommendations on areas of science and technology which it considers to be of high national priority. The Government has provided substantially increased funds for those areas, which include marine science and technology, energy and industrial research and development.
Formulation, administration and coordination of science and technology policy has been enhanced by the establishment of the Department of Science and Technology.
Recommendation 2

The Prime Minister direct ASTEC to consider the feasibility of establishing a long-term national plan for the development and application of science and technology in relation to the furtherance of the national well being. This consideration should include a mechanism for involving the community in such planning. The example of the programme of the Royal Norwegian Council for Scientific Research may serve as a point of departure.
Response

ASTEC is currently engaged in studies to assist the determination of priorities in science and technology; they involve the cooperation and collaboration of scientists, technologists, industrialists and other relevant sections of the community. These studies will contribute to the development of long-range scientific and technological priorities.
Recommendation 3

The Prime Minister seek to orient policies for industry away from defensive strategies of protection, towards increased support for determined and adequately followed-through programmes of innovation, within national policies aimed at economic growth.
Response

In the White Paper on Manufacturing Industry the Government has stated a positive policy towards industry development. As part of that policy approach the Government has undertaken to pay special attention to development policies covering fields such as research and development.
Policy measures are in place, aimed at encouraging industry to make more effective use of existing technology and creating an environment favourable for industrial innovation.

In particular the Government's positive approach is reflected in its recent decision to upgrade the IR&D Incentives Program and extend it for a further five years. The main focus of support for IR&D will continue to be the project grants component of the IR&D Incentives Act. The commencement grant element will continue, more detailed guidelines for project grants and public interest project will be issued and the Australian IR&D Incentives Board strengthened. The grant limits for both project and commencement grants are to be increased.

The Government has agreed that the proportion of its R&D contracted out to industry should be increased. It will be increasing its support for new and existing research associations. It has substantially increased support provided under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Program.
Recommendation 4

The Government, depending upon the advice of ASTEC concerning the feasibility of a national plan for the development and application of science and technology, set up appropriate structures to construct, review, monitor and revise such a plan.
Response
This matter will be considered further in the light of further reports by ASTEC relating to recommendation 2.

Policy matters are monitored and reviewed in the present structure which incorporates departments and other bodies established by the Government to advise on various policy matters, including policies for science and technology. These include: the CSIRO Advisory Council; the Industrial Property Advisory Committee; Industry Advisory Councils; Commonwealth/State Ministerial Councils; and the National Energy Advisory Committee.
Recommendation 5
The Prime Minister request ASTEC to examine, within the framework of national policies for science and technology, the desirability of setting up centres of excellence.
Response

In the 1980 Election Speech the Prime Minister announced support for research centres of excellence and has committed funds totalling $16 million for the period 1981-84 for this purpose. The Minister for Education recently announced a committee to recommend how these funds should be allocated.
Recommendation 6

The Government give urgent consideration to the use and importance of technology assessment as a tool to assist in the formulation of national policies for science and technology and their relation to social development.
Response

The Government has accepted the CITCA recommendation that a Standing Committee of ASTEC be established to review on a continuing basis the processes and trends in technological change in Australia and elsewhere; and to evaluate and report on the direct and indirect effects of technological change at the national level.
Recommendation 7

The Government establish policies designed to remove disincentives from, and give positive encouragement to, the systematic commercial adoption of research results. The aim of these policies is to achieve an increase in the proportion of Gross Expenditure on Research and Development (GERD) expended on experimental development.
Response

The encouragement of experimental development was one of the issues covered by ASTEC in its report 'Industrial Research and Development: Proposals for Additional Incentives'. Following consideration of that report and the report by CITCA, the Government has taken a number of initiatives to encourage experimental development; it has continued to substantially increase the support provided through the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme and established a fund for energy research, development and demonstration projects. The Government will also increase the amount of its R&D requirements which is contracted to industry.
Recommendation 8

The Government considerably increase the level of funding for the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme. The level should be such as to at least maintain the effective value of funding of Commencement and Project Grants as in 1970, although the Committee considers that a much higher level than this is warranted of say, $50 million for Commencement and Project Grants and $50 million for 'Public Interest' projects.
Response
Total funding for industrial research and development programs has been increased from $14M in 1977/78 to $54M in 1980/81 and will be reviewed annually in the budget context.
Recommendation 9
The Government allocate an annual appropriation of about $50 million to ''Public Interest'' projects in addition to amounts allocated to Commencement and Project Grants.
Response

Provision of funds for public interest projects under the IR&D Incentives Act is determined in the Budget context. The Government has recently adopted guidelines for the selection of public interest projects and these will be announced before the amended Act comes into force on 1 July 1981. The nature and number of eligible projects is taken into account each year when determining the allocation of funds.
Recommendation 10
The Government make Commencement Grants free of tax.
Recommendation 11
The Government provide IR&D incentives grants free of tax.
Response

The Government does not support these recommendations. Exemption of these grants from taxation would result in anomalies as other forms of subsidy would remain liable for taxation. The Government has taken the view that if additional incentives for IR&D are provided, they should be by way of increased expenditure on the IR&D scheme, rather than by taxation concessions.
Recommendation 12
The Government retain existing taxation allowances permitting depreciation of R&D plant and equipment over 3 years.
Response
The Government will bear this recommendation in mind in any future consideration of changes to existing arrangements.

Existing taxation allowances permit depreciation over a three year period on capital expenditure incurred for buildings and plant used for scientific research. In addition other expenditures of a capital nature, and payments to an approved research organisation for scientific research are allowable deductions for taxation purposes.
Recommendation 13
The Government ensure that all Departments involved in R&D, CSIRO and Defence in particular, orient their policies towards maximising the amount of R&D contracted to Australian Industry.
Response

Following consideration of the ASTEC report ''Industrial Research and Development: Proposals for Additional Incentives'' the Government has accepted a recommendation to increase the proportion of its R&D requirements contracted to industry. As a result Government departments and agencies are to examine their ongoing and planned activities with a view to preparing programs proposing R&D contracts with industry.

In accordance with the Government's decision relating to the Review of Commonwealth Functions direct Commonwealth involvement in defence science R&D is to be reduced and universities and the private sector encouraged to perform more defence R&D.
Recommendation 14
The Government ensure that personnel, facilities, and information services of research establishments be provided as appropriate in support of consulting services to industry.
Response
The Government supports the principle that services provided to industry should be made available on a commercial consultancy basis and at commercial rates.

The Government has recently taken a number of major initiatives in this field. To facilitate the matching of CSIRO resources to industrial needs a Bureau of Scientific Services has been formed comprising the existing Central Information, Library and Editorial Services, a new Science Communication Unit and an enlarged Commercial Group.

The Technology Transfer Council (TTC), directed by the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Metal Trades Industry Association and the Department of Science and Technology, has been set up to undertake a three year trial program in the Metals Industry to help firms in the application of technology and the resolution of technological problems. The Council draws heavily on the resources and expertise of research establishments in meeting the needs of industry. Following the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Government has decided to substantially reduce its activities in relation to technology transfer. Funding of the TTC is to be retained until 1982 and continuing Commonwealth involvement evaluated.
Recommendation 15

The Government encourage its various instrumentalities to examine the possibilities of contracting research to tertiary education institutions, particularly where such institutions possess facilities or expertise not readily available elsewhere.
Response

The Government has accepted a recommendation by ASTEC that universities and colleges of advanced education be encouraged to engage in sub-contracting to industrial firms which have R&D contracts with Government instrumentalities. Tertiary institutions will be encouraged to participate in the Government's R&D contracting out program only where this is not at the expense of the private sector.
Public interest projects under the IR&D Incentives Act can involve contracting out to tertiary institutions.
Recommendation 16

The Government look for ways in which certain entrenched attitudes towards what constitutes appropriate government intervention in industry may be revised, given the constraints imposed by political realities.
Response
Attention is drawn to the statement by the Minister for Industry and Commerce in response to the Crawford Report (Hansard HR 23 August 1979).
Recommendation 17
The Government commission a comprehensive survey of Australia's management attitudes to R&D, with the object of formulating strategies for strengthening positive attitudes toward innovation.
Response

In view of the Government's desire to reduce the ''paper burden'' on the private sector as stated in response to the Review of Commonwealth Functions, a comprehensive survey as recommended by the Senate Committee will not be undertaken.

The Government has undertaken to review the effectiveness of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act prior to its expiry in 1986. Information relating to management attitudes will be taken into account in this review.
Recommendation 18
The Government ensure that wherever possible, calls for tenders for government procurement specify performance requirements rather than, or as well as, design criteria.
Response
Wherever possible, calls for tenders for government procurement will specify performance criteria.
Recommendation 19
The Government closely examine the capabilities of such institutions as the Commonwealth Development Bank with a view to broadening them with respect to investment in developmental projects.
Response
This recommendation will be considered when the report of the Inquiry into the Australian Financial System is at hand.

The Interim Report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System noted that in 1978 the Commonwealth Development Bank (CDB) was given broader scope to finance the development of all kinds of business undertakings, with an emphasis on smaller business enterprises. Since acquiring this broader charter, the share of new loan approvals going to the small (non-rural) business sector has increased substantially.
Recommendation 20
The Government give full support to initiatives of the Department of Science and the Environment in awarding industrial fellowships.
Response
The Minister for Science and Technology will bring this matter forward for further consideration in the Budget context.
Recommendation 21
The Government ensure that arrangements are made in each instrumentality which provides library-based information to consider the views of users.
Response

The two major Commonwealth technical library-based information services are provided by the National Library and CSIRO. Both monitor national needs for scientific and technical library-based information services. CSIRO and the National Library of Australia have announced a new framework of co-operation in the science and technology area. This is aimed at facilitating more efficient dissemination of scientific and technological information to Australian users.

The National Library is evaluating a shift in emphasis from collection building and direct reference assistance to providing national services to support the activities of other libraries. CSIRO library and information services are following the Birch Report recommendation for further integration and rationalization in relation to a national network.
Recommendation 22
The Government encourage attendance by Australians at international conferences on scientific and technological subjects.
Response

Within budgetary constraints the Government already supports government and non-government scientists and technologists travelling overseas for a variety of purposes, including attendance at international conferences. Support is given through, for example, multilateral and bilateral exchange schemes and fellowship schemes. The learned Academies receive Commonwealth grants which among other things enable their members to attend meetings of their international affiliates.
Recommendation 23

The Government, as a matter of urgency, collate the information already obtained through committees of inquiry into scientific and technological information services, bring it up-to-date, and present to Parliament a national information policy together with a scheme for the coordination and development of library-based information services.
Response

Commonwealth/State Ministers having responsibility for cultural affairs are considering the establishment of an Australian Libraries and Information Council to advise Commonwealth and State Ministers on means of securing coordination and cooperation in library and information services.
Recommendation 24
The Government maintain all its international scientific and technological liaison posts.
Response
Following the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Government has decided to substantially reduce staffing in the London and Washington posts and to revise overseas representation.
Recommendation 25

The Government carry out a review of Australia's overseas scientific liaison arrangements to see whether there may not be advantages in strengthening those offices, or creating new ones, where the flow of technical information is particularly high (i.e. in North America, Europe and Japan).
Response
See response to recommendation 24.
Recommendation 26
The Government accept the OECD proposal to study the IR&D activities of foreign owned companies in Australia.
Response

The OECD has recently completed its report on the Impact of Multinational Enterprises on National Scientific and Technological Capabilities. The value of this report as a forerunner to further work is somewhat limited however, because of the difficulty in getting agreement between member countries on the validity of many of its findings. Further information of a related nature is being obtained by the Department of Science and Technology and the Bureau of Industry Economics, who are undertaking a joint study of trading in technology. This study is exploring the factors which influence the IR&D and technology licencing policies of Australian companies.
These reports will be examined by the Department and proposals will be brought forward for any further action that is thought appropriate.
Recommendation 27

The Government commission studies to learn more about current practices governing the importation of technological information and to determine whether their application is in Australia's best interest.
Response

The Department of Science and Technology is conducting several studies on this matter. The Government considers that the development and transfer of technology are important for improving productivity in Australia.
Recommendation 28
The Government commission studies of the significance of the flow of technology from Australia to other countries, looking in particular at its consequences for investment, research and employment.
Response

The Department of Science and Technology and Bureau of Industry Economics have undertaken studies in several related areas. Further work has been dependent on priorities and the allocation of resources each year in the Budget. The Senate Committee's recommendation has been drawn to the attention of the Bureau.
See also response to recommendation 26.
Recommendation 29
The Government provide increased support for research including academic studies of matters relating to science policy.
Response
The Government encourages government agencies involved in research into science policy issues to make their work widely available and welcomes additional academic studies on science policy matters.
Recommendation 30
The Minister for Productivity undertake an examination of both the national and international relevance of present patent laws and agreements to Australia IR&D and the importation of technology.
Response

The Industrial Property Advisory Committee is currently undertaking a comprehensive review of the patent system which will include consideration of the effectiveness of the patent system in encouraging the adoption of new technology by Australian industry.
Recommendation 31

The Minister for Productivity strengthen the means whereby assistance is given, possibly through collaboration with DSTO, to projects originating in industry for military equipment having export potential.
Response

The Minister for Industry and Commerce will consult with the Ministers for Defence, Science and Technology, Trade and Resources, and Foreign Affairs on means to ensure that existing forms of assistance are being fully exploited to encourage and facilitate Australian industry projects for developing new military equipment for overseas markets.
Existing forms of assistance includes policies requiring Offsets to Overseas Procurement and Australian Industry Participation in Defence contracts.
Recommendation 32

The Minister for Productivity require the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board to review its criteria for recognition under 6 (1) (b) and 7 (1) of the IR&D Incentives Act 1976, in particular re-examining the case for recognition of the Industrial Design Institute of Australia.
Response

The AIR&D Incentives Board has examined the question of recognition of the Industrial Design Institute of Australia in terms of the professional qualifications of its members and their suitability in terms of the AIR&D Incentives Act. Since the Institute accepts, as members, persons having no formal training, the Board has declined to provide a blanket approval for the Institute. However the Board is endeavouring to determine the suitability of individual courses and has recently decided to accept graduates from the Sydney School of Arts as 'approved employees' under the Act.

The criteria applied by the Board for recognition of professional institutes, approved research organisations under Section 6; and for recognition of Approved Employee status under Section 7 of the IR&D Act have been chosen to ensure that the highest standards of R&D are encouraged in Australian industry.
Recommendation 33

The Minister for Productivity introduce an amendment to the Industrial Research andDevelopment Incentives Act 1976 to relax the requirement for a company to employ at least one full-time 'approved employee' in favour of a provision whereby IR&D may be contracted to an approved research organisation if required.
Recommendation 34

The Minister for Productivity ensure in relation to Commencement Grants, that the rate of grant be set at 50% of eligible expenditure with a ceiling of at least $25 000 per company, the ceiling to be subject to revision only to take account of inflation or the need to increase motivation towards establishing an R&D capability.
Response

Recommendations 33 and 34 were implemented as part of the new arrangements for the research and development grants introduced in the context of the 1978/79 budget. Furthermore the limit in relation to commencement grants was raised from $25 000 to $40 000 following consideration of the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia.
Recommendation 35

The Minister for Productivity review the published criteria for approval of grants with the object of making them as specific and as detailed as possible. In due course the criteria should reflect the priorities of a national plan for the development of industry.
Response

The Government's recent review of the IR&D Incentives Act included an examination of the criteria for project grant assistance. The guidelines developed in that review are to be implemented from 1 July 1981 and are consistent with the Government's industry policy objectives.
Recommendation 36

The Minister for Productivity examine the possibility of preparing blanket forms of agreement. If it is not possible for the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board to issue blanket forms of agreement then, as an alternative, attention should be drawn in the Explanatory Notes to any mandatory standard clauses.
Response
A standard form of agreement for project grants is in use by the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board.
Recommendation 37

The Minister for Productivity alter the application of the IR&D Incentives Act such that if a grant application is successful then grants are made retrospective to the commencement of the project, provided adequate records have been maintained by the applicant.
Response

Project grants are payable retrospectively to the date of application by the company. Entitlement to a project grant depends on an agreement being entered into between the company and the AIR&D Incentives Board. R&D projects should be discussed with the Board to ensure that the necessary criteria are met before the project is commenced by the company.
Recommendation 38

The Minister for Productivity ensure that the provisions of Section 22 of the IR&D Incentives Act be scrupulously observed. In particular, commercial information provided in support of a grant application should remain confidential to the Board and not be discussed with other departments or outside organisations without the express permission of the applicant company.
Response
The Australian Research and Development Incentives Board maintains strict confidentiality on information provided by applicant companies.
Recommendation 39

The Minister for Productivity establish procedures and criteria for review and re-evaluation of project grant agreements, to take account of project cost changes and the value of the project end product to the community.
Response
The AIR&D Incentives Board undertakes periodic reviews of projects and considers cost and other changes. See also Response to Recommendation 35.
Recommendation 40

The Minister for Productivity require the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board to review its procedures, to ensure that more efficient manufacturing processes are not ignored, when considering projects under the heading of 'improved processes for or in connection with the production or use of material products'.
Response

New arrangements which follow the review of the IR&D Incentives Act will direct the Board to rank project grant applications according to their potential contribution to the Government's industry policy objectives. A technical standing committee will be established to advise the Board on specialised technical and commercial aspects of the selection and progress of IR&D supported by grant assistance.
Recommendation 41

The Minister for Productivity in collaboration with the Minister for Home Affairs, examine the situation with respect to searches of overseas patents, with a view to establishing a system to improve access to INPADOC information.
Response

Improvements have been made by the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office, the National Library and others to provide Australian industry with easier and cheaper access to patent information on both overseas and local patents.

The Patent Office is continuing to develop systems in patent, trade marks and designs administration and patent examination searching. This includes an online inquiry facility; which it is planned, should eventually be available in regional sub-offices and will be suitable for direct access from industry and patent attorney offices.
Recommendation 42

The Minister for Productivity continue to give full support to proposals for research into machine tool technology and management, with a view to assisting establishment of a 'Centre of Excellence' in this subject.
Response

Following the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Government has decided to evaluate continuing Commonwealth support of the machine tool technology work at Swinburne Institute of Technology through support for the Technology Transfer Council (TTC). Commonwealth funding support for the TTC will continue until 1982. The TTC provides a field extension service to the metals manufacturing industry, making use of expertise available in universities and institutes of technology as well as the CSIRO Division of Manufacturing Technology.
The CSIRO Divisions of Material Science and Applied Physics will continue to make valuable contributions to research and development in this field.
See also response to recommendation 14.
Recommendation 43

The Minister for Science and the Environment review the methods, manpower and facilities of Project SCORE to ensure that results are published frequently and as early as possible after completing a survey.
Response

Responsibility for conducting the Project SCORE surveys was transferred from the Department of Science and the Environment to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) in December 1978. Following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, Project SCORE surveys will have their frequency reduced from every two years to every three years.

The Department of Science and Technology retains overall responsibility for Project SCORE, particularly for policy interpretation and comparative analysis of the survey data with other information pertaining to Australia and overseas.
It is intended that the Australian Science and Technology Statement including Commonwealth Government expenditures on research and development will be published on an annual basis.
Recommendation 44

The Minister for Science and the Environment initiate studies to determine the extent to which measurements relating to the output or value of R&D, and scientific information collection and diffusion, can be made and incorporated in Project SCORE, to enhance the value of the material already provided.
Response
The first steps towards inclusion of R&D output indicators in Project SCORE have been taken and further examination of output indicators and the resources required for their generation is in hand.
Recommendation 45

The Minister for Science and the Environment through CSIRO, examine mechanisms such as liaison with further research associations whereby closer contact can be made with industry, including small businesses, to gain increasing awareness of trends and problems, and to facilitate timely relevant assistance.
Response

In the statement by the Minister for Industry and Commerce on the Government's response to the CITCA Report it was noted that support for new and existing research associations will be increased (Hansard (HR) 18 September 1980). New research associations will be assisted by initial Government grants of $40,000 plus matching grants on a $1 for $1 basis up to $200,000 per annum for up to 5 years.

Increased support for new and existing research associations will enable CSIRO to increase its contacts with industry, including small businesses. Following Government acceptance of a recommendation of the Independent Committee of Inquiry into CSIRO, the Executive of CSIRO established a Planning and Evaluation Advisory Unit in February 1979. The Unit's objectives include forecasting industry trends and problems, and research opportunities.

Under the amended Science and Industry Research Act (1978) the Organization's Advisory Council was reconstituted with enhanced functions including the provision of advice to the Executive in relation to industrial and economic matters. This role is strengthened by the revised (also under the amended Act) membership and functions of State Committees.

The Organisation is also active in promoting mechanisms aimed at increasing contact with particular sectors of industry, for example, Metal Trades Industry Association-CSIRO Committees, CSIRODIAL, Australian Scientific Industry Association SIROMATH P/L.
Recommendation 46

The Minister for Science and the Environment investigate the merit of, and possible arrangements for, grants to tertiary education institutions made specifically for industrially oriented research, particularly as this relates to community services and problems.
Response
The IR&D Incentives Act provides for companies to employ universities and colleges, which are approved research organisations under the Act, on specific IR&D projects.
See also response to recommendation 15.
Recommendation 47
The Minister for Science and the Environment request CSIRO to explore the possibilities of an increase in joint project activities with universities.
Response

A Joint Committee of CSIRO and the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee is exploring the feasibility and implications of increased joint project activities. A comprehensive survey of the contacts occurring between CSIRO Divisions and Australian universities is being undertaken with the aim of promoting increased collaboration.
Recommendation 48

The Minister for Science and the Environment request CSIRO to give attention to considering all tertiary education institutions in any proposals aimed at encouraging secondment or interchange of staff.
Response

CSIRO has been actively exploring mechanisms for establishing closer relations with all tertiary education institutions. The matters raised by the Senate Committee are being taken into account in discussions with those institutions.
Recommendation 49

The Minister for Science and the Environment request CSIRO to give consideration to creating opportunities for undergraduate training in connection with the 'industrial situation' experience required for certain science and engineering courses.
Response
See response to recommendation 48.
Recommendation 50

The Minister for Science and the Environment examine the proposal, that in addition to establishing a joint CSIRO and Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee covering universities (as recommended by the independent inquiry into CSIRO) the CSIRO seek a mechanism for promoting collaboration with other sectors of tertiary education, in particular institutes of technology, through the Australian Conference of Principals of Colleges of Advanced Education.
Response
See response to recommendation 48.
Recommendation 51

The Minister for Science and the Environment request CSIRO to consider the need for mechanisms such as consultative committees to identify areas of potential beneficial collaboration with tertiary education institutions.
Response
See response to recommendation 48.
Recommendation 52

The Minister for Science and the Environment request the CSIRO Executive to review the Organization's recruitment and secondment policies in the light of its statutory commitments, taking into account its recently introduced revised structure.
Response

CSIRO's acknowledged success as a research organisation with an enviable national and international reputation is to a large degree due to its policy, followed since its establishment, of selecting the best people available for its research positions. This policy has been reaffirmed by successive Executives of CSIRO and is one which the organisation believes is crucial to its continuing success. The Organisation recognizes the value of both host and home agency of exchanges and secondments of staff and will continue to encourage such arrangements.
Recommendation 53

The Minister for Defence ensure an outward looking approach to DSTO planning which takes into consideration the need to build up domestic industry as well as Australia's defence needs in the light of the anticipated world situation.
Response

The Defence Science and Technology Organisation's (DSTO) main role is to provide scientific support to the Defence Organisation. Only a small part of its resources are devoted to fostering the development of equipment which might lead to later production. Notwithstanding this, the Department of Defence has been able to take a number of measures to enhance industry capability.
Recommendation 54

The Minister for Defence re-orient Departmental policies for R&D contracts and equipment procurement, towards recognising a progressive build up of R&D capability in Australian industry as an important element in national defence.
Response

As part of the Government's policy of increasing the amount of R & D contracted to industry, greater emphasis will be given to R & D offsets. There is a limit to what Defence alone can do but it has made significant progress. For example the $26 million development of the Barra Sonobouy in Australian Industry is nearing successful completion. (See also response to recommendations 13 and 53).
Recommendation 55
The Minister for Defence ensure that means exist for considering potential overseas users, particularly ASEAN nations, when drawing up new equipment requirements.
Response

It is Government policy to include consideration of possible overseas interest and requirements when planning local equipment development and to accommodate these to the extent practicable within the primary objective of satisfying Australian Defence requirements.
Recommendation 56

The Minister for Defence ensure that overseas defence equipment purchase be established as a second preference to domestic procurement, requiring strong justification and only resorted to after full exploration of possible domestic suppliers.
Response
This recommendation is established Government policy but for many major Defence equipments it is not practicable to buy Australian.
Recommendation 57
The Minister for Defence ensure that industry participation in military project R&D is invited as early as possible, preferably at the pre-specification preparation stage.
Response

The Report itself refers to Defence projects where industry has been funded to develop equipment at the pre-specification stage. This reflects a deliberate policy of early involvement of industry in Defence projects wherever practicable.
Recommendation 58
The Minister for Defence arrange for membership of the Defence (Industrial) Committee to be increased to include wider representation of industrial R&D interests.
Response

Industry representation on the Panel of the Defence Industry Committee (DIC) examining ways in which more Defence R & D work could be contracted to industry was expanded during the course of its investigations during 1979-80. The DIC has 8 industry members, most of whom come from firms with significant R & D interests. Additional industry representatives with appropriate interests are invited to join specific groups such as the DIC Panel which examined ways in which more R & D work could be contracted to industry. This panel found, inter alia, that there were few defence non-project R & D tasks which would be attractive to industry. Its recommendations for increased Defence funding for R & D tasks in industry was taken up in increased funding in the 1980-81 Budget.
Recommendation 59

The Minister for Education request the Tertiary Education Commission to examine the possibility of funding for the development of industrially oriented short courses and seminars with associated papers. It may be appropriate for such examination to be considered in connection with 'Centres of Excellence'. (See recommendation No. 5).
Recommendation 60

The Minister for Education request the Tertiary Education Commission to examine the case for giving support to the appointment of industrial liaison officers to those institutions which have, or which intend to develop, close IR & D relations with industry.
Recommendation 61
The Minister for Education request the Tertiary Education Commission to examine the position with respect to staff requirements for contracted research and consulting.
Response

The Minister for Education in Consultation with the Minister for Science and Technology will seek a report on recommendations 59, 60 and 61 from the Tertiary Education Commission, bearing in mind the Statement on 30 April 1981 by the Prime Minister on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. In his statement the Prime Minister announced that an amount of $5 million will be earmarked from within general grants for universities and colleges for institutions which are able to expand their effort in technology and business studies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.
