DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMMITTEE ON DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT AND OCCUPATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation has reported again for the year 1979-80. I draw attention to the fact that a large number of complaints are made by people in the Australian work force about discrimination in their employment. This report records 665 such complaints. The significant thing about the complaints is that the majority of them have to do with discrimination on the ground of sex. In fact, 54 per cent of the complaints recorded are on that ground. Of course, this finding will come as no surprise to those honourable senators who are aware of the difficulties faced by women in employment in Australia, despite the fact that some States now, notably New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, have at the State level anti-discrimination legislation designed to prevent discrimination on the ground of sex.

The operation of the National Committee on Discrimination in Employment and Occupation is useful as it makes available to the Parliament these figures about discrimination on the basis of sex and other matters. However, I would like to make the point that this Committee and the State committees-which the national Committee represents-have no powers to resolve complaints. All that the committees can do is investigate a complaint and then seek to persuade those employers who are discriminating to cease that discrimination. In some cases they have been successful. However, in many cases they have not been successful in persuading employers to cease discrimination. Details of the unresolved cases are in the report for honourable senators to read. Where an employer continues discrimination in face of an attempt by the Committee to have that discrimination ceased the Committee has only one option; that is, to report to the Minister who, under privilege, can then table this report in Parliament. To my knowledge this has never happened. This mechanism for exposing discriminatory employers has not been used in the Parliament. Therefore, I would say that the mechanism is quite useless.

It leads me to the main comment I wish to make in respect of this report. It is clear that there is a great deal of discrimination on the grounds of sex as well as on other grounds in the Australian work force. It is clear that the legislation operating in some States, while providing some redress in certain cases, certainly does not provide complete redress for employees experiencing discrimination. Of course, the outstanding inadequacy in this whole area is that there is no federal anti-discrimination legislation which prevents employers from discriminating on the basis of sex. Hence the large number of complaints, particularly in the federal sphere, which are recorded in the report. The work of the Committee has been successful in drawing our attention to widespread discrimination in the public and private sectors on the grounds of sex. The machinery that the committees have available to them to pursue and to resolve these complaints is inadequate in many cases and it is ultimately inadequate in that there is no legislative basis.

During the next session of Parliament I will be seeking to take action with regard to federal anti-discrimination legislation. I will be speaking in much more detail at that time. I simply draw to the attention of honourable senators the inadequacy of the machinery we currently have for preventing discrimination in the federal sphere or for resolving complaints where they exist. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on State Tax Sharing Entitlements

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I wish to speak very briefly to the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission, not in any depth I hasten to add as this report is a very lengthy and complex document which would have required much more than 20 hours to assess adequately even if we had not been occupied with other business in the meantime. However, since the matter was raised by way of question from Senator McIntosh to Senator Durack today I want to make a couple of comments about Senator Durack's answer. It is correct, as Senator Durack stated, that there have been substantial increases in real terms in general purpose payments or tax sharing payments to the States, whichever term one prefers. However, he did not mention that very large increases occurred in 1974-75 and that substantial increases in real terms since then have been pursuant to the 1975 Act. Effectively, they have been pursuant to the 1975 Act which provided for a betterment factor of 3 per cent after the States had already been compensated for population increases and increases in wage levels which, of course, are somewhat normally in excess of the consumer price index. In fact in recent years it has been that 3 per cent benefit factor which has put the flaw in Commonwealth payments to the States and which has ensured that in real terms, after adjustment for population changes as well as changes in wage levels, payments to the States under this section have continued to increase.

The position following the passage of the new legislation-I think it was last week-of course is quite different. The only guarantee which the States now have is that funds will not fall in money terms-not a guarantee that there will be no decline in funds in real terms, but that funds will not fall in money terms. In other words, that is a guarantee that the rate of real decline cannot be greater than the inflation rate or increases in the consumer price index. As far as guarantees are concerned-there could be ultimate results different from the guaranteed minimum-up until now the States have been guaranteed that after other appropriate adjustments have been made they will receive in real terms an increase of 3 per cent each year. The only guarantee they now have is that there will be no decline in real terms greater than the rate of inflation. It should be added that these payments present only one component of total Commonwealth payments to the States and therefore cannot really be viewed in isolation. It should also be noted that the Commission's report which has been tabled determines the relativities between the States and not the absolute amount which will be paid to the States which is set by independent decision of the Commonwealth Government.

All the recommendations in the report are about the carve-up of any given quantity between the States and the fact that in real terms the States will be squeezed for the first time in the next financial year and are likely to be squeezed thereafter. This will probably be the first decline in real terms that they have had in almost a decade. The controversy which inevitably exists between the States about what is and what is not a fair relativity will be intensified by the fact that in real terms the total payments will decline next year and are likely to continue to decline. The customary acrimony will be intensified by that overall squeeze which the Commonwealth is imposing on all the States.

I make one other comment: Some of the recommendations, on a superficial examination at least, are surprising, one of which is the disparity between the recommendations for the States of Western Australia and Queensland. I do not wish to comment upon the justice or otherwise of that because I really have not examined it in sufficient depth. But it is stated that a major consideration upon which the Commonwealth Grants Commission has based its assessment is the taxing effort made by a State. That may have some relevance to a comment made by the Western Australian Premier last week. An agreement between Alcoa of Australia (WA) Ltd and its employees to reduce working hours prompted from the Premier a threat to increase Alcoa's royalty payments. That begs the question that if Alcoa can afford higher royalty payments after granting reduced working hours it obviously could afford even higher royalty payments prior to granting reduced working hours. Implicit in the Premier's threat was an admission of previous negligence by him and his Government, that is, that Alcoa had the capacity to pay significantly higher royalty payments but the Western Australian Government, through its own negligence, declined to apply the taxing effort to which the Grants Commission refers and may have suffered accordingly in the recommendations made by the Commission. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMITTEE OF REVIEW OF THE AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is very substantial. The Committee sat for almost 18 months and visited many parts of Australia in trying to assess community reponse to the Australian Broadcasting Commission and to prepare this report. The detailed nature of the inquiry can be shown by the fact that 11 volumes make up the report. One can only be impressed by the wide range of inputs to the Committee from consultants drawn from such wide areas as market research, financial management and engineering. The Committee even received a paper by Professor Inglis based on a study of ABC records and the history of the ABC. I think anything I say about the report at this stage should be qualified in view of the fact that it is a very substantial report. The size of the report makes it difficult to make a full and accurate assessment at this stage. It would, I suppose, be a classic case of fools rushing in if one attempted at this stage to pass judgment on any of the recommendations of the Committee.

This is, refreshingly, quite an eloquent document compared with many of the reports which come before this Parliament. The description of the history and current activities of the ABC is quite readable and that is a refreshing change from many reports which we receive here. When I say 'quite readable' I should say 'eloquent'. That is something for which the Committee is to be commended. The report seems to attack some of the main problems of the Australian Broadcasting Commission-management, finances and equipment.

In assessing the current situation of the ABC, the Committee identifies four factors in answer to the question: 'Has the Australian Broadcasting Commission's performance declined?' The Committee singles our four most important areas which point to decline. The first area is broadcasting to non-metropolitan audiences. It is suggested that the ABC provides inadequate services to country and outback people. The second area is broadcasting for the whole of the Australian community. In this case it is said the ABC has failed to reflect the realities of Australian society, particularly the needs of Aboriginals and non-Anglo Saxon Australians. Thirdly, the Committee comments on cultural bias in that the ABC over-emphasises some overseas programs, particularly British programs, on television at the expense of Australian produced programs. The fourth area is the failure of the ABC to decentralise effectively its resources in the States and regions and thus to reflect the interests, characteristics and concerns of the whole country.

I do not think many commentators on the ABC would have serious difficulty in recognising that there are four major areas of defect with the ABC as it is presently structured. I particularly emphasise the question of cultural bias. Some three or four years ago the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, in its report on the self-regulation of broadcasting in Australia, made the comment that there was a need for Australian television particularly to have an Australian look. The ABC has got away with not having an Australian look by having a British look. The comments of the Broadcasting Tribunal were more directed to commercial broadcasting which, of course, has an American or mid-Pacific look. The ABC, on the other hand, has a British or mid-Sahara-or whatever the appropriate place is somewhere between Australia and Britain-look. That aspect of cultural bias is an important factor to which the Dix Committee draws attention.

The report attacks the main problems of management, finances and equipment. The Committee faced up to the difficult problems in seeking ways to overcome the shortcomings of senior management in the ABC. It has opted for a new structure. One might worry whether the new super-management body, the national broadcasting organisation, is the ideal solution and could simply superimpose a new bureaucracy on the old and much criticised one. Those sorts of worries and doubts no doubt still exist. But it seems to me that the new management structure seems much more capable of flexibility and accountability to the Commission's employees, the Government and the people of Australia, than the present management structure.

Any hopes for a progressive and innovative ABC will rest squarely on the talents of those chosen to fill the top positions in the national broadcasting organisation. It should not be assumed by this Parliament, one would hope, that the senior executive positions such as that of director-general would be filled only by those occupying positions in the ABC at the moment. Such positions should be widely advertised and should be capable of attracting the best possible talent, even in spite of the fact that the Committee properly recommends that the position of director-general should not be a lifetime position but should be a position which is readvertised and refilled every seven years.

I should like to make some other points about the Committee's report. The Committee is very concerned with questions of financing a national broadcasting service, accountability of a national broadcasting service and of course the quality and content of a national broadcasting service. It says, for example, in dealing with the question of sponsorship, that it is desirable in their view, as a method of helping the ABC to finance its activities, that there should be corporate sponsorship of a number of ABC programs. Guidelines, of course, must be set for that sort of activity, as the Committee proposes before corporate sponsorship is introduced and there are very obvious dangers in corporate sponsorship of ABC programs unless those safeguards are very strict and very tightly observed. There are real dangers about corporate sponsorship of any program in the public affairs area, for example. There would be real dangers if there were sponsorship in the public affairs area and, indeed, some of the other areas of entertainment with which the ABC deals.

The Committee has recommended the merger of the news and public affairs departments of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. While the word 'merger' is perhaps unkind to the Committee in the sense that it recommends, as I think it puts it, a rationalisation of activities, I think there is need to sound a note of caution that any rationalisation or merger should not be at the expense of forthrightness and imagination in the presentation of public affairs coverage. The Australian Broadcasting Commission news is widely respected by the Australian people but, if anything, it is a little bland, and this blandness should not in any sense be imposed on a vigorous and critical public affairs program of any kind. I think that is something about which there should be some caution.

The next reservation which I suppose I have is that the Committee has suggested that Australian Associated Press should be the basic source of news for the Australian Broadcasting Commission which at present has its own news gathering service. That is a recommendation which I guess comes from a need to be very careful in terms of expenditure. I remind the Senate that at the current time all television news coming into Australia, with the exception of the news on Channel 9, is supplied by Visnews Ltd, an international news-gathering organisation. All overseas television material is supplied from that one source. We do not want in this country a situation whereby all media-print, radio and television-are relying on the one source for domestic news. I draw the attention of the Senate to paragraph 13 of the summary of the report where the Committee makes this point based on survey findings:

. . . the ABC's value to the community is dominated by its importance as a provider of news and information. People who want to know about the world and want authoritative interpretation of major events turn to the ABC.

In a sense, on a preliminary perusal of what the Dix Committee has said, that comment about the authoritative nature of ABC news services lies slightly unhappily, in my view, with the suggestion that AAP should be the basic source of news. That is something which I think needs further examination and care in any implementation there may be of the decisions of the Dix Committee.

I make the point that the hiving off of orchestras could well be a very good thing for both the orchestras and the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I notice that Senator Davidson, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, is nodding his head. That Committee gave considerable attention to this question two or three years ago when I was a member of the Committee and Senator Davidson was its Chairman. We are glad that the Dix Committee has taken up the spirit at least of what we were trying to say in our report on that occasion. At present the orchestras are relatively minor parts of the ABC's activities. They probably suffer only marginally because of that, but the only concern must be for appropriate future funding for both the orchestras and the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

On the question of industrial relations, which the Committee says has plagued the ABC to some extent, the Commitee has given careful consideration to staff management problems. It has recommended the establishment of grievance appeals procedures and the encouragement of mobility within the Commission should help improve this situation of the staff morale and industrial relations. The Committee also recommended that the ABC basically be removed from the jurisdiction of the Public Service Board, other than in respect of top management. That is something which has been sought by the ABC for a long time and for very good industrial reasons.

Looking at the recommendations regarding services provided by the ABC, it is sufficient to say that the Committee referred to the importance of a second radio network to serve country areas in Australia and recommended that this should have high priority. The Committee was, I thought, unnecessarily cool on the question of a second television channel for the ABC in not recommending it as a high priority at this stage. I concede that in terms of the financial requirements of the ABC it must come further down the line in the priorities of rationalising buildings and providing new equipment to the Australian Broadcasting Commission, bringing it into the second half of the twentieth century in terms of the technology and equipment which it has available to it. Those are matters of paramount priority. The question of a second television channel for the ABC should not be ignored. A second radio network is of a high priority and is something which we on this side of the chamber have been arguing for for a long period. More attention should be given to the needs of regional audiences. Any attempt to improve the ABC's services to country people must be welcomed. The report also canvassed issues such as broadcasting for women, children and teenagers, public broadcasting, ethnic broadcasting, triennial funding, Australian content and so on. It is too soon to say anything definite about the recommendations of the Committee on these matters.

This report should be commended to all members of this Parliament for very careful reading. As the Dix Committee itself says, the ABC has been a great national broadcasting organisation but presently it is somewhat run down. This document provides a great opportunity to restore the ABC to the paramount position, as I said earlier, of a great national broadcasting service-an innovative organisation, as it has been in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Help get rid of the Special Broadcasting Service.

—As Senator Townley says, it is also an opportunity to get rid of the Special Broadcasting Service. That is something which the Dix Committee approached with less caution than I would have. We have had a lot of discussion on broadcasting matters in this Parliament in the last few weeks. The Broadcasting and Television Act was amended in the Senate the other night for the benefit of a few friends of this Government and against the interests of the Australian public. That was the first major legislative effort of the new Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). I said on that occasion that that legislative effort was a disaster for this country and will continue to be a disaster for this country. Honourable senators opposite will hear about it for months and years to come. It has turned upside down the whole system of accountability and responsibility for the commercial broadcasting sector which Liberal and Labor governments have supported for many years and the ownership and control provisions of commercial broadcasting which have always existed. That will have most unfortunate results for the commercial sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Having failed there, the Minister for Communications has a great opportunity with the Dix report to redeem himself and to go down in history as a great Minister for Communications rather than with a footnote for what he did to the commercial sector of broadcasting at the instigation of great and powerful friends of the Liberal Party. This is a unique opportunity for Mr Sinclair. I hope that he and all Government senators will approach this eloquent, thoughtful, sane and sensible report in a very constructive and positive way. The ABC, on the basis of this report, can be properly restored to its rightful position as the pre-eminent and most imaginative broadcasting service in this country. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian Democrats welcome the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It is certainly a much needed breath of fresh air through the corridors of power in the ABC. We agree with Senator Button that it is an enormous document which will take a long time to study in all its detail. I believe it is certainly not too soon to express the hope that the ABC will now look hard at itself and allow a situation in which effective decision-making, control and money will be channelled as directly as possible to the areas actually making programs and that there will be a healthy spirit of competition between production groups based on actual results. I believe that only in this way will the Australian people get full value for their dollars invested in the ABC. Staff cuts in the ABC in recent years have tended to exacerbate grotesquely a situation in which the ABC has had far too many chiefs and far too few indians. The Dix report has noted chronic problems of morale and efficiency that have stemmed from that situation. I suggest that its words ought to be taken with the greatest of seriousness and that corrective action should be taken as soon as possible. The British Rediffusion system of competitive program-making for sale to other outlets could be looked at with profit in this area. Prestige, a proper financial reward and a reasonable independence of action ought first and foremost to be the privileges of those who can make successful television and radio programs. That has not been the case in the past and is not the case at present.

SPEECH.PARA: To judge from the feedback I have been receiving of widespread unhappiness amongst ABC staff at the operating levels, such people ought also to have proper technical facilities for their work. Financial priorities should now be directed towards providing those facilities at a fairly basic level. I think any honourable senator who has had much contact with the ABC in recent months will have noted the broken down and antique tape recorders which frequently do not work. I was appalled to see that some of the equipment now in use was exactly the same as that used when I was a working broadcaster in the ABC 20 years ago. It is intolerable to expect professional people spending public money to go on using that broken down equipment. There has also been a tendency for people of ability to be used in two or three different directions so that a person getting a news story also has to do something for Newsvoice and perhaps something else as well. It is not possible for people to carry out their functions properly if that sort of tremendous demand on people at the operating level is continued.

In that respect Senator Button thought there should be reservations about a closer co-ordination of news and public affairs areas in the ABC which, of course, is recommended in the Dix report. It would be a tragic step at this stage of the ABC's development if there were a merging of news and public affairs because there would simply be further reductions in staff and the same people would be expected to serve all those programs, to the detriment of all concerned. I believe quite firmly that the ABC should have its own news staff. It is an independent news service-perhaps at times not as good as it may be-but it has the potential, as it has had in the past, to do outstanding work and it is an essential part of the balance of media in this country.

The ABC's attitude to sport has received some attention in the report. Of course, it is a fact that the ABC, even in the sport area, is curiously blinkered by its predilection for the over-exposure of a sport of minority interest-that is, cricket-which has developed, I cannot quite see how, a completely unjustified position as a holy cow in this country. Many people find watching hours of cricket acutely boring. I think it is time the ABC became aware that there are many other sports.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not saying they are flannelled fools, are you?
—No, I will let the honourable senator say that.
—I want that nailed.
—Let me place on record that I have made no reference to flannelled fools. Senator Mulvihill said that.
—I will let you go on in peace then.
—I thank the honourable senator. I think the ABC should be aware that many other sports such as sailing, skiing, fencing and athletics have equally wide or greater appeal.
—On a catamaran, Senator?

—On a catamaran, if you like, Senator. How about that! Such sports have equally wide appeal and, as Senator Mulvihill realises, are certainly more visually interesting. I would not like to see people who are hung up on cricket deprived of it completely because I know that it has a sort of drug-like quality for them. But please let them not be indulged to the detriment of those people interested in more active sports. Seriously, there is a need for greater balance in the ABC's sporting coverage.

SPEECH.PARA: We welcome the recommendation that the ABC should not carry advertising and commend it most forcibly to the Government. One reason for that is the tedious way in which television and radio advertisements, especialy television advertisements, are repeated in this country. I say to those who advertise by a boring repetition of their messages that, if they hope their messages will have greater impact because of that process, as far as I am concerned the process is totally counterproductive. That kind of advertising on the ABC would be bad, but even more serious is the fact that the ABC would then be at risk of commercial sponsors influencing programs. I think it would be tragic if that situation were to happen in this country. I agree with Senator Button that that area should be regarded as particularly sensitive where news and public affairs are concerned. I do not believe they should have any sponsorship whatsoever, even the sort of corporate backing that has been suggested. I think corporate backing is a good thing for such things as opera and drama in respect of which there is obviously no question of the people concerned having an influence on the content, which is already determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sport?

—With respect to sport, it would be fine. When we have skiing, sailing, and a few other such sports on the ABC let us by all means have some corporate backing. I would like to look at what the Dix report said about WASP-white Anglo-Saxon Protestant-culture. The ABC has notoriously shown itself to be limited to those old ideas of Australian culture and as not recognising that ours is a truly multicultural society. I do not think that it meets this need by coyly presenting from time to time national dancing and things of that sort. We must go much more deeply into the question of how we can use the ABC to present Australia as the multicultural society that it now is. As an ex-program man in the ABC, I would say that there is only one answer-that people of racial origins other than English should be allowed to have their head as program producers. The ABC should bring in Italians, Yugoslavs and people of other nationalities and see what they can come up with in the way of programs that will present those aspects of Australian society. I suggest that that is the way in which we can make progress in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the Dix report has laid down a specification for a much slimmer, more active and with-it Auntie, which I suggest is just what we need in this country-an ABC that will serve Australia very well in the future.

Finally, the Australian Democrats appeal to the Government to allow this process of reform and smartening up of the ABC to proceed along the lines proposed, as far as we have yet been able to see them. I have not yet had an opportunity to read the report fully and at this stage would by no means like to endorse everything that is in it, but its general trend-as we have examined it in the last 24 hours-in presenting guidelines is in the right direction. We would ask that the Government please proceed in this matter with a total absence of that political tinkering which, though no doubt tempting to it, will not be of any assistance whatever in this case. Any tampering with the independence of the ABC, or even any attempt or apparent attempt to tamper with it, diminishes a government and those members of it who suggest that that be done. I seek leave to continue my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Senator Mason should know the procedures by now.
—The honourable senator sought leave to make a statement and has now made it. He may speak to the matter again when the debate is resumed.
—I moved the resumption of the debate and that question was disposed of. Senator Mason sought leave to make a statement and has now concluded it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation in regard to this report.
—Is leave granted?
—Has the honourable senator been misrepresented?
—Yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —To say that I have been misrepresented may be a little strong, but I refer honourable senators to paragraph 11.162 and the reference to The Coming Out Show. I was delighted to read the recommendations on that show, but in regard to the evidence that I gave to the inquiry, the following is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that Senator Walters had no criticism of the information given in the program, which she found to be 'usually accurate'.

That description is a little too broad in view of what I actually said. I emphasised to the Commission that the general information was very biased. The report quotes me as saying that the program lacked professionalism, evidenced by bias, contained prejudicial statements against males and failed to balance these with equally critical statements about females; had a marked tendency to generalise from the particular, and created an overall tone of depression and complaint and conveyed the idea that this is the norm in society. That was the message that I was giving. To say that I had no criticism of the information given in the program could not be regarded as entirely accurate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation in that I think I claim to have been misrepresented. I make this personal explanation this morning because if a misrepresentation occurred it occurred on the Australian Broadcasting Commission news this morning. I have been advised by several people who heard the ABC news this morning that I am said to have 'predicted that the Opposition would support any legislation arising from the report'; that is, the report of the Committee of Review of the ABC. I just indicate that I would be a fool if I made any such prediction. I know many Government senators probably think I am a fool, but I did not make any such prediction.

SPEECH.PARA: What I have said about the Dix Committee report is that it is an imaginative, well considered and thoughtful document which points the way to a better future and a better structure for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. DEBATE.TITLE: INDICATIVE PLANNING COUNCIL FOR THE HOUSING INDUSTRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I indicate that the Opposition supports indicative planning as an important arm in the whole process of properly managing the Australian economy. The report by the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry is not only an important document in respect of that industry but also challenges the basic philosophical position of this Government which relies completely upon market forces to determine the whole process of our economy. In fact, this report is an indictment of that policy as it relates to housing needs and the housing industry in our country.

The report shows, of course, that the housing industry, as presently acting under the constraints imposed by the Fraser Government, is capable of building about 144,000 dwellings a year over the coming triennium and estimates that industry capacity at the national level will remain fairly flat. The report suggests that we would require, on the basis of current projections 174,000 homes to be built in the period 1984-1991, 166,000 homes to be built in the period 1991-96 and 158,400 homes to be built in the period 1996 to 2001 just to keep abreast of the natural increase in population and the increase arising from the Government's migration policies. It is untenable that the housing industry should be placed in the position where market forces are its only regulator when we take into account the established resource development policy of this Government.

As the report indicates, Australia's resources boom will be good news for the housing industry but bad news for home buyers. If we are concerned about home buyers we have to recognise that there is a considerable problem in home buying today not only in relation to the cost of borrowing funds because of high interest rates but also because there is an acute shortage of housing. By not building sufficient homes to meet current needs that shortage will be even more pronounced than it is today.

Such is the case that has been made by the Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) has warned of the expected rise in rentals. He is reported as saying that this would cause 'severe personal hardship' for low income earners, a trend that is already emerging. Of course, this is exactly what the Opposition has been saying. This is exactly and precisely what the Australian Labor Party spokesman on housing and urban affairs, Mr Uren, has been saying continuously in the House of Representatives and in other places. Indeed, spokesmen for the housing industry have been drawing the attention of the Australian people and the Government to what is happening in the building industry in this country. More and more people are being forced into a position in which they are just not able to become part of the home ownership sector of our country because of the limitation on funds and the high rates of interest.

The report bears this out. It points to the fact that in the development of resource-type industries in various regions in Australia the cost of buying or renting a house will rise significantly in the next five years. Of course, that means even greater hardship being imposed upon greater numbers of people. One would have thought, therefore, that this Government would have adopted a much stricter position and policy on resource development and would have been attempting to have that development take place in a planned way so that the provision of the infrastructure, which is the responsibility of State and local governments, and private and public housing, in fact, would run parallel with the development. That would, therefore, not put citizens, workers and those involved in the resource industry in an invidious and disadantaged position. An article, referring to the report, states:
The resource boom would be likely to affect housing demand, costs, the availability and cost of housing finance, and finance for developers.

One other aspect we have to consider-the report deals with this in some detail-is the rising cost of land in our major cities. What the report does not refer to, of course, is that the rate of the increase in the cost of land and housing is rising at about, in average figures, twice the rate of inflation. So there is no point in talking about the inflation rate being kept at about double figures when, in fact, the rate of inflation in respect of land and housing is double the inflation rate. That is the single biggest cost item for a family unit. Greater numbers of people are finding it impossible to come within the ambit of being able to provide for their own housing needs and that is therefore driving more and more people into the area of public housing. Yet this Government, as Mr Uren has pointed out, has in fact reduced the amount of funds available to the States for public housing to such an alarming degree that the waiting lists of the housing authorities in the various States are getting longer and the lack of housing is becoming a national scandal.
The article states:
In most parts of Australia new land coming onto the market in the next five years was likely to be much more expensive than it had been in the past five.

That is understandable, having regard to the inadequate and improper policies being pursued by the Fraser Administration. It reduced to a minimum, and finally abolished, the very important initiatives that were taken by the Whitlam Government, particularly by the former Department of Urban and Regional Development and its Minister, Mr Uren. We established land commissions in the States, the purpose of which was to buy land in large tracts in order to stop private speculation which was a feature of the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s until the Whitlam Government came to office. They enabled the State governments to be part of the process of reducing land costs and maintaining them at a level commensurate with the capacity of the Australian working people to purchase land.

That was a very important innovative step to be taken by a national government because it meant that for the first time in Australia's history the Commonwealth, in co-operation with the States, had established the processes and procedures by which the States would be able to become active competitors in the area of providing funds and subsequently serviced land so that the public sector could compete against the rapid exploitation of land values which arose because of the activities of large scale development corporations which were very considerably exploiting the land hungry markets in the capital cities. That was particularly evident in Sydney and Melbourne. The report is correct when it says that the existing housing stock is adequate to accommodate population growth. That applies not only in the resources areas but also in our major cities.

This report comes out each year and gives some sort of an indication to the government of the day about what policies it ought to pursue if it is concerned about the housing needs of our population. But, as the Fraser Government does with so many other reports, it will receive the report, comment on it and then will fail to act on or take into account the important advice that is encompassed in it. That will mean that the Australian people who are interested in home ownership, who are interested in the continual increase in the cost of rented accommodation and who want to have access to accommodation will be denied yet again an opportunity to become properly and adequately accommodated in respect of their housing needs.

One could say a great deal more because this is a very important report. It ought to be considered by Government back benchers. It is important because it emphasises and endorses the basic position taken by the Australian Labor Party in respect of its housing policies. Of course, we have no confidence that this Government will do more than receive the report, make a few pious statements and then file it away. We hope that at a subsequent time we will have an opportunity to debate this matter further. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EDUCATION POLICY AND FINANCIAL GUIDELINES TO THE COMMONWEALTH EDUCATION COMMISSIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Some ministerial statements that are presented in this place from time to time are obtuse, stubborn, pigheaded, the product of closed-circuit thinking by narrow minds. Some show appalling ignorance. Some show just plain dishonesty in the way in which they state their findings or their recommendations. This statement by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on the subject of insurance brokers, rejecting as it does the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission on the desirability of national legislation in this area, distinguishes itself by possessing clear elements of every one of the characteristics I have mentioned. Above all, it represents a triumph of ideology over common sense.

What has happened is that the Government has rejected out of hand the 1980 report of the Australian Law Reform Commission which recommended the introduction of national legislation, in the national interest, the community interest and the interests of consumers who have been so savagely disadvantaged by the misbehaviour and collapse of so many broking houses in recent years, to regulate insurance agents and brokers. The kinds of recommendations brought forward by the Law Reform Commission which have now been rejected would have resulted in legislation which, among other things, would do the following: Provide for a statutory system of registration of insurance brokers to be supervised by the Insurance Commission and the Life Insurance Commissioner respectively; place an obligation on registered brokers to keep all premium moneys and moneys received from insurers in a separate trust account, the investment of which would be closely controlled; and provide for heavy penalties for misleading conduct by brokers and agents and for greater protection in a variety of ways for consumers by making insurers statutorily liable for the actions of their agents and responsible for the premiums received by brokers.

I have referred elsewhere at some length to the Law Reform Commission report and its recommendations on the kind of legislation which is needed in this respect, in particular on 28 May when introducing as a private member's Bill the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981. As a result I do not propose now to repeat everything that could be said on this topic, particularly also since the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) stated the Opposition's position very effectively in the House of Representatives yesterday. Nonetheless, a number of points must be made to demonstrate what a shoddy short-sighted exercise this is. What we have here is a rejection of all the Commission's recommendations to establish a national system of regulation with only one passing exception, and that is in respect of extended credit by insurers to brokers which it is proposed should be the subject of further consideration by the Commonwealth with a view to some possible minor amendments to the existing Commonwealth legislation to control some of the excesses that have been prevailing in that area. Apart from that one exception, what we have is a complete straightforward rejection of the Law Reform Commission's recommendations-a rejection which is premised on a number of very unhappy assumptions and misleading statements about what this exercise is all about. Let me mention just a few of those.

The first question on which the Treasurer premises his statement is the question of the need for this kind of legislation. Mr Howard says in his statement that he and the Government are simply not satisfied that there is a need, that a case has been made out by the Law Reform Commission. He says that only $7.25m-I emphasise the word 'only'-was known to the Law Reform Commission to have been lost in the 10 years preceding the presentation of its report in 1980. What a misleading-to put it at its mildest-statement that is. One way of responding to that is simply to say that certainly that amount of money was thought to be enough by the Law Reform Commission itself both in absolute terms and comparative terms to persuade it that regulation was necessary and to do so on the basis of a very long extensive consultative process to which I will come back in a moment. Perhaps even more importantly and pertinently, since the Law Reform Commission completed its report there has been a spectacular escalation in the problems in the insurance broking industry, so much so that in the last two years there has been a whole series of collapses of broking houses which have resulted in another $7m worth of losses being experienced. The Law Reform Commission itemised 27 insurance broker insolvencies in New South Wales and Victoria alone between 1969 and 1979 with estimated losses, as the Treasurer acknowledged, of $7,250,000. The Commission was, however, unable to obtain detailed information in relation to 17 other cases of alleged insolvency during that period, so the figure for estimated losses is probably an underestimate.

Subsequently, within the last two years, 1980 and 1981, the additional losses have been put at around $7m, producing a total of $14m plus. That is probably an underestimate of losses over the 12-year period from 1969 to 1981. The Government and certainly some honourable senators opposite perhaps need some examples to remind them of the magnitude of the problem in this area. Perhaps they will remember how in January 1979 Cyril Stanley Pty Ltd collapsed with debts of $1.9m and an estimated deficiency of $619,000. In May 1979 the Hamilton Group of Companies became insolvent with an estimated $400,000 owed to unsecured creditors. In 1980 six Western Australian broking companies collapsed, as Senator Martyr will no doubt recall, with outstanding debts totalling well over $3m. Those companies were Douglas Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd, John D. Seale & Co Pty Ltd, Ibis Holdings Pty Ltd, Morley Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd, Dyson Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd and Town and Country Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd. Over the last 18 months the total number of broking collapses in Western Australia has risen to at least twelve. As recently as March this year Beneficial Insurance Brokers Pty Ltd of Perth went into receivership with an estimated premium shortfall of $1m.

In New South Wales 14 insurance brokers have stopped trading in the last 18 months. Of those perhaps the most notorious is the One Stop Insurance Shop broking group. The New South Wales part of this operation went into liquidation in March this year with debts of $1m. The same amount was owed when the One Stop Insurance Shop Pty Ltd in Victoria went into provisional liquidation. The Queensland affairs of that company are also in the hands of the liquidator. Some 34,000 policy holders around the country were put at risk by the collapse of the One Stop operation and the Australian Premium Financing Co. Pty Ltd which had financed those operations. In March this year two further Victorian brokers folded up. Anthony H. Bown Insurance Pty Ltd went into liquidation with debts of over $320,000. Perhaps the worst case of all to finish up with is Kinloch (Insurances) Pty Ltd which was placed in the hands of the liquidator in March this year with estimated debts of $3m after a premium turnover estimated at about $6m annually.

That recitation, although perhaps tedious to some members of this chamber, demonstrates beyond any possibility of doubt that there is a phenomenal problem at work at large in the community which is simply not acknowledged in the terms of Treasurer Howard's statement. To refer, as he did, solely to the situation which prevailed in the ten years prior to 1979 can be described only as an exercise in deliberately misleading the Parliament and the community as to the magnitude of the insurance broking problem.

The next point that needs to be made about this matter is the dismissal of the credibility of the Law Reform Commission involved in Treasurer Howard's statement. This occurred in the second guessing of it in the first place by seeking views from everyone around the place who might conceivably be likely to be affected by it and the failure to come to grips in any serious systematic way with the arguments that run throughout its detailed report which totals 142 pages. The Government also failed to take into account the qualifications of the Commissioners, chaired in this instance by Professor David Kelly from Adelaide. The panel of people who worked on this project consisted of Professor Castles, Mr Debelle, Mr Jack Ewens-the former Parliamentary Counsel-and two highly regarded and respected silks; Brian Shaw from Victoria and Murray Wilcox from the Sydney bar. The Commissioners were backed up by a team of 40 consultants, all of whose names are listed publicly in the report, who individually and collectively have the highest reputation and credibility in this country and indeed in the insurance industry and with everyone who is concerned with the regulation of that industry.

In the course of the compilation of the Law Reform Commission's report the Commission considered 235 written submissions. It also listened to approximately 79 oral submissions made at a series of hearings that were held in late 1978 in Sydney, Perth, Adelaide, Hobart, Melbourne, Canberra, Brisbane and Darwin. In each case those hearings were accompanied by the holding of seminars organised in association with the Australian Insurance Institute. So a phenomenally detailed and complex process of consultation has been carried out by the Law Reform Commission. It is not just a matter of three or four wise men sitting down in a back room somewhere and generating, off the top of their heads, some proposals which may or may not bear some resemblance to the needs of the real world. On the contrary, as with every report that the Law Reform Commission produces, it is a systematic exposition of the problem, an identification of the various options that are available for its solution and a highly articulate and sensitive argument for the conclusions that are finally brought down.

For this report to be simply rejected out of hand in the way that it has been by the Treasurer and the Government reflects no credit whatsoever on anyone who has been concerned with it. In the statement made by the Treasurer-again there is an element which can only be described as dishonesty in the way in which it was brought down-he sought to convey an impression, throughout the whole statement, that there is major disagreement within the industry, both as to whether there should be legislation at all and as to what kind of legislation there ought to be if any legislation is to operate in this area. But the reality is, as the Treasurer and the Government must know, that the broad thrust of the Law Reform Commission's recommendations has been accepted by everyone in the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a whitewash job.

—It is not a whitewash job in any way, shape or form. The broad thrust of its recommendations has been understood and appreciated. Of course there are nuances and differences of opinion by the respective interest groups that all have their own axes to grind and barrels to push. That is so with every complex social, economic or business regulation problem that anyone ever has to deal with. But the point is that all these things were put into the pot and understood by the Law Reform Commission and the proposals that were generated by it have subsequently had an enormous measure of acceptance within the industry; by insurers, by the more reputable individual brokers, by the brokers organisations, councils and associations and-I will come to this in a moment-by the State governments which have been in the first line with demands by the community and by people who have suffered as a result of these collapses for something legislatively to be done about them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is not the same passion for deregulation and self-regulation as the Government seems to assume exists in every corner, every nook and cranny, of the private sector. That kind of reaction within the insurance industry just does not exist. Mr Nick Renton, the Executive Director of the Life Insurance Federation of Australia-LIFA-commented in the immediate aftermath of the razor gang report which report recommended a significant winding back in the operations of the Life Insurance Commission and the Insurance Commissioner. Everyone associated with the industry knows that so far as self-regulation is concerned the industry has been there, done that and it has not worked. There just have to be more systematic controls in this whole area. We cannot apply ideological prescriptions to these sorts of problems. We cannot make the assumption that regulation is bad, deregulation is good. We cannot do that across the board. We must look at each individual industry situation and judge what kind of regulation is necessary and, will be effective in cases of particularly clearly demonstrated need.

This leads me finally to the question of the attitude of the States to this problem of insurance regulation. This again is an area in which this statement by the Treasurer is so misleading and so full of half truths in the statements it does not make about the reactions of the States to this whole problem as to amount to what can only be described as an exercise in dishonesty. There is a situation in the States that, in the aftermath of the Law Reform Commission's report being tabled last year, there was a meeting in November 1980 of the consumer affairs Ministers of all States. They made an urgent call to the Federal Government to implement on a national legislative basis the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. That is not where the matter has stopped.

The States have been complaining continually for years about the inability of the Government to move in this respect. Those complaints have been escalating in number very rapidly. They have spread right across the political spectrum. It has not been a matter of Labor State governments complaining about Federal Liberal governments. On the contrary, it has been an across the board matter. In Western Australia, there has been a situation where the impatience about government inaction at the Federal level has become so acute that it has recently introduced its own legislation, the General Insurance Brokers and Agents Bill 1981. The New South Wales Government gave notice as recently as 21 May that it was preparing legislation which it would introduce unless the Federal Government took decisive action. In March, Syd Einfeld, the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, said that he completely supported the principles inherent in the report of the Law Reform Commission. The Commissioner for Consumer Affairs in that State, Mr Gallagher, repeated in mid-May that the Federal Government's failure to take action would inevitably compel the New South Wales Government to move in this direction. In Victoria, again in mid-May, just a few weeks ago, the Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Ramsay, added his voice from the second most populous State in the nation to the call for national legislation.

So this is what is being rejected in the interests of some spurious, free enterprise, Friedmanite, razor gang ideology combined with some passion for reverting back to the States functions which could be exercised by them. What will happen? We will not have a situation of self-regulation in the industry because the industry knows that it cannot cope with that and everyone else knows that that will not be good enough. We will need to have legislative controls. Those legislative controls, as has been foreshadowed by all the relevant State governments concerned, will have to come from the States. So we will have State legislation. When we have State legislation in this area, as in so many other areas-we have seen it in the past-we have immediately the spectre of non-uniformity, the problem of different standards and different rules about registration applying nationally from State to State to control what is essentially and overwhelmingly a national industry.

The uniformity problem is something that time does not permit me to go on about in the length that it needs perhaps to be gone on about to emphasise our concern about it. It is always a headache for federal systems of government to create uniformity in regulatory law. We have had that argument over and over again in the context of companies and securities law. We are edging our way gradually forward to solutions. This Senate's Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs dealt, at some length, with the whole problem of uniform law reform in its 1979 report on reforming the law. I refer honourable senators to chapter 4 of that report if they want some further responses to it.

If the States are to go ahead, as they obviously will, to legislate in their own area that will create an enormous number of headaches for the future. In this respect Mr Howard, in his statement, said:
. . . the Government stands ready to assist wherever it may be able in achieving uniformity between the States in this area.

What a horse laugh that sort of statement is when we consider the track record of this Commonwealth Government in its own enactment of national legislation and in its exercises in co-operative federalism. We cannot expect the sort of movement that we need here. The reality is that there has to be a single national legislation. There is no argument about the constitutional powers and the constitutional responsibility of the Commonwealth to legislate nationally in this way to the extent that section 51 (xiv) of the Constitution gives the Commonwealth Parliament explicit power to make law in respect of insurance other than State insurance. This power covers all private insurance except insurance offered by State instrumentalities within the boundary of the home State. There can be no doubt about the nature and extent of the Commonwealth's responsibility in this area. Equally, there can be no doubt about the abdication of that responsibility in this statement.

The Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill which I introduced into this chamber as a private member's Bill on 28 May will establish a single national statutory system of broker registration and financial and other controls to protect the public, being based, as it is, squarely on the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission. That Bill will, I can promise the Government now, be debated in the Budget session. It does have the support of the Australian Democrats. It is a Bill and this is an issue about which the Government and this Parliament will hear a good deal more. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
