DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT IN AUSTRALIA

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Science and the Environment-Government Response

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
The Opposition attaches a good deal of importance to industrial research and development. There needs to be much more of it in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment I would like to make some comments on the Government's response to the Committee's report on industrial research and development in Australia because the Committee was very anxious that the Government should pick up a number of our recommendations. It is pleasing to note that the Government's response, and also the response to reports from bodies such as the Australian Science and Technology Council and the Myers Committee, have served to satisfy most of the recommendations of our Committee. It should be noted that the Committee's inquiry from May 1977 to June 1979 formed part of a widespread growing consciousness that all was not well in Australia in the relationship between academics, industry and government, and that policies were needed aimed at achieving a better balance between research, development, management and the market.

SPEECH.PARA: In recommendations 1 and 2, the Committee recommended that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) give urgent attention to the expression of a clear national policy for science and technology and direct ASTEC to consider the feasibility of establishing a long term national plan for the development and application of science and technology for the national good. The Committee is particularly pleased to note that the Government, through ASTEC and the Department of Science and Technology, is moving towards the development of these objectives. However, much more needs to be done and with the increasing rate of technological change in Australia it needs to be done very quickly.

The Government has rejected recommendations 10 and 11, suggesting that commencement grants and industrial research and development incentive grants be free of tax. However, the Government has stated that if additional incentives are required they should be by way of increased expenditure on the Industrial Research and Development Scheme rather than by taxation incentives. The Committee's recommendation that a comprehensive survey be undertaken of management attitudes to research and development has been rejected on the grounds that it would add to the 'paper burden' on the private sector. Whilst agreeing in general terms with this objective I hope that the promised review of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act will examine this matter extremely thoroughly.

In relation to the decision to reduce the scientific liaison posts in London and Washington, on behalf of the Committee I have already written to the Prime Minister requesting the reversal of this decision. It seems to me to be a retrograde step at a time when Australia is facing problems associated with technological and scientific change that important posts such as London and Washington should not be serviced by a scientific representative from Australia who would be able to keep in touch and communicate with the people involved in technological change in those important developed countries.

There is another issue on which I must comment. The Committee's report was tabled in the Senate on 6 June 1979, just over two years ago. Chairmen of other Senate committees have previously referred to delays in responding to Committee reports. I just want to emphasise my concern that the Ministers have not responded to reports as quickly as they should have. Commendably, the Prime Minister instructed his Ministers to respond to parliamentary committee reports within six months. It should be the aim of all Ministers to achieve that objective. Sometimes-and I think it is reasonable that chairmen of committees recognise this-it is not always possible for Ministers to respond to recommendations within six months. However, I think it is fair to suggest that the Ministers concerned should be in a position to inform the committee chairmen of the reasons why they cannot respond within the time that has been set down by the Prime Minister. I hope that the Prime Minister and the Ministers will ensure that what I have said will be taken note of in the future.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON REGULATIONS AND ORDINANCES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I bring up the seventieth report.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In tabling this report, I wish briefly to draw to the Senate's attention a number of positive features of the Committee's operations since its last report in September 1980. I have already made statements to the Senate earlier this year on ministerial undertakings relating to the Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Ordinance and the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance, and have outlined the Committee's views on the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance. I now wish to mention other actions by Ministers, following consultations with the Committee, which might otherwise escape general attention.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has announced that the Government proposes to introduce amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act to accord with various recommendations made by the Committee. Three Ministers have agreed to present certain delegated legislation to the Committee in draft form. Two Ministers, the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson), have been admirably prompt in ensuring that undertakings made to the Committee have been given legislative effect while other Ministers have agreed to insert review provisions in instruments which have attracted the Committee's attention.

On the other hand, one area continues to be of concern to the Committee. Four examples of financial retrospectivity provisions of more than two years' duration are identified in the report. The Committee considered recommending disallowance, but this would have caused hardship to individuals affected by the provisions. The Committee has concluded that only by public censure of undue delays in production of delegated legislation is the incidence likely to diminish, and therefore it will continue to report to the Senate on any further examples of this nature.

In conclusion, on behalf of all the members of the Committee, I wish to endorse publicly the tribute paid in the report to the Deputy Chairman, Senator Cavanagh, who will retire from the Senate on 30 June 1981. The Committee will miss his wisdom, common sense and experience, but extends to him its good wishes for a happy and well-earned retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cavanagh Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank Senator Lewis, Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, for expressing appreciation for my services on the Committee. It may well be that that appreciation has been over-emphasised. Perhaps it has been more a reflection of the view of the author of the speech than a direct result of anything I did on the Committee. I have enjoyed my work on the Committee. It was only when I read the report that I realised I had been on the Committee for so long. This Committee has become important to me over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: Legal opinion we receive on the effect of ordinances is frightening. As was stated at the Conference of Delegated Legislation Committees which was held last year, regulations and ordinances are not subordinate legislation but laws of the land which are as effective as any law passed by the Parliament. One man, a Minister, may make a law affecting the whole population or part of the population of Australia and this law can be enforced without being considered by the Parliament. Law-abiding citizens could become criminals overnight because of the actions of a Minister or a department. That is the frightening thing about ordinances and regulations.

We witnessed what happened when the Australian Capital Territory Traffic Ordinance was amended recently. Sixty-three women who engaged in an otherwise lawful assembly and demonstration were arrested as a result of action taken by the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) two days before. He amended the Traffic Ordinance prohibiting what the women intended to do. The new Ordinance may or may not have been justified, but as yet Parliament has not had an opportunity to consider whether it was justified.

Although the Attorney-General's Department is proposing alterations to the Acts Interpretation Act to get over some of the problems, there is no way of getting over the problem of power being put into the hands of one man. Whilst normally the system operates all right, from time to time the quality of Ministers changes. We may have an occasion when perhaps a tyrannical Minister takes action that has a detrimental effect. We must consider making provision for a continuing committee to look at ordinances before they become effective. If such a committee thought people could suffer harm from a proposed ordinance, implementation of the ordinance could be delayed until Parliament had time to discuss it.

Senator Lewis also mentioned financial retrospectivity provisions. Although there may be justification for a payment, a Minister should not commit Parliament or the Treasury to a payment for something that happened two years previously. The Parliament should have considered the matter at the time, and dealt with it by either ordinance or Act of Parliament. In the situation we are considering an ordinance may approve a payment with which neither the Committee nor the Parliament agrees. That ordinance may be rejected by the Parliament but the payment may have been made between the time of the making of the ordinance and its rejection by the Parliament. Therefore, a payment with which the Parliament might not agree would be legally paid by the Treasury. These are things that need consideration.

I do not wish to take up the time of the Senate unduly. However, I express again my appreciation for the words spoken about me. I have done only what every other member of the Committee has done. At all times I have done my best. No man can do any more, and no one should do any less. That is the policy that I have carried out.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Education and the Arts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I present a report of a review on children and television, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Davidson Sen G.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report is entitled 'A Review of the Report on the Impact of Television on the Development and Learning Behaviour of Children'. No doubt the Senate will recall the report on the subject which I tabled in the Senate on 23 November 1978. At the time of tabling that report I gave the following undertaking on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts:

Because of the great amount of interest in this inquiry and the likely continued public interest, I inform the Senate that we will be looking at the subject of children's television again in about eighteen months.

A number of factors, which included an assignment from the Senate on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill, the necessity to complete an earlier inquiry on education in the work force and, of course, the intervention of the general election, have considerably extended that 18-month period.

The Committee resumed this review in March of this year. The Committee communicated with a number of witnesses, authorities, representives and organisations and invited them to make submissions that would be of assistance in this review. Additionally, a number of public hearings were arranged. The Committee interviewed 22 witnesses over four days. Included in the group of witnesses was the Minister for Education in New South Wales, the Honourable Paul Landa, MLC; and the Minister for the Arts and Minister of Educational Services in Victoria, the Honourable Norman Lacy, MP. The Committee was appreciative of the interest shown by these two State Ministers.

The review observed, firstly, that there has been significant progress in getting better children's programs to air on both commercial and Australian Broadcasting Commission television stations. In the case of commercial television stations these improvements are due largely to the efforts of the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with co-operation from commercial television management. However, we find that much still needs to be done, particularly in the area of children's drama. To this end we have supported the establishment of an Australian Children's Television Foundation which will act as a means of stimulating production of high quality children's programs and encourage the purchase of these programs by television stations. It is envisaged that the Foundation will be jointly funded by the State and Commonwealth governments. Victoria and New South Wales have already committed funds to the project and other States have indicated their support. We have strongly recommended Commonwealth participation and financial support for this worthy project. However, our review emphasises that if the Australian Children's Television Foundation is to succeed it will need Commonwealth support not only from a financial viewpoint but also in terms of maintaining an effective regulating authority to ensure that good programs for children go to air. In the latter context the review expresses its opposition to any reduction in the powers of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to regulate positively, particularly in the area of children's television.

The review also expresses disappointment at the progress made in research into the effects of television on children. In our review we have urged greater attention to this important area of social science. The report also expresses disappointment that the Government has decided not to proceed with the establishment of the Broadcasting Information Office, which we believe would have played a key role in media research. We also are concerned about the demise of the Broadcasting Information Office for other reasons. Without such an organisation to collect and disseminate information on all aspects of broadcasting we are unlikely to have informed public debate on broadcasting in this country. Therefore, we ask the Government to reconsider the decision in relation to the Broadcasting Information Office.

An important part of our review relates to advertising. The National Health and Medical Research Council, acting on one of the key recommendations of our original report, has found that much of the food advertising directed to children promotes unbalanced dietary habits which can give rise to long term national health risks. We have recommended in our review that the effects of such advertising be offset by the active involvement of the National Health and Medical Research Council in advertising which promotes more balanced dietary habits.

I have briefly mentioned some of the more important aspects of our review. There are other important aspects, and in relation to these I will let the review speak for itself. We emphasise that this document is but a review and its principal purpose is to alert the Senate and the community to the need for ongoing vigilance and awareness in relation to the effects television is having on our society and, in particular, on our children. Furthermore, I emphasise that this review needs to be read in conjunction with the original report of November 1978. I again mention that throughout the review we have expressed our concern about any proposed amendment legislation that would weaken in any way the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's powers to regulate effectively, particularly in the area of children's television.

This Committee has now completed all the work which was referred to it. The overriding and continuing reference relating to all aspects of broadcasting still remains, and I have no doubt that the new Committee will retain this broad heading to initiate further inquiries into this area of public interest. So it is that I table this, my last report. Our program is complete and there are no outstanding references. The new Committee will start its operations with a clean sheet and will commence a brand new program. I place on record my sincere thanks to all members of the Education and Arts Committee who have served since 1975. Their work and contribution as well as their personal co-operation is greatly appreciated.

At this stage I refer by way of tribute to Mr John Lipscombe, the Secretary of our Committee, who is shortly to retire. Along with Mr Kathage and Miss Moyes, Mr Lipscombe has rendered sterling service to the Committee. John Lipscombe has been attached to our Committee since 1975, having first entered the Department of the Senate in 1972. The reports we have put down owe much to John Lipscombe's special skill in analysing the evidence, his special ability in understanding the witnesses, and his capacity to relate to the responses of senators on the Committee. He is to retire from service shortly, and the Senate will lose the services of an efficient and perceptive officer. John Lipscombe has been a good friend to the Committee and to me. He and his wife have been very interested in us and very kind to us. We thank him and we place on record this tribute to him and wish him well in the future.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been my privilege to have chaired this Committee for some nine years, and I am mindful of my indebtedness to a great number of people over that time. We have been able to put down in the Senate some 15 reports, which have covered a wide range of areas within our charter. On a personal note, I extend my best wishes to the new Committee and renew my thanks to the Senate for the privilege of serving it in this way. I commend the review to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of what I am about to say will be covered in the valedictories tomorrow when we are speaking of the work of Senator Davidson. However, I think it would be unfortunate if we allowed this final report of Senator Davidson's to go without some tribute from us to his leadership of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. I can speak only of the time since 1975. Senator Davidson has indicated that he spent some nine years as Chairman of the Committee. Certainly we on this side of the chamber would like to indicate our appreciation not only of the leadership he has given to the Committee people but also of the way he has been able to meet with people outside the Senate chamber in our public hearings.

SPEECH.PARA: It is obvious to all of us who work on committees and find them a very valuable part of the work we do in the Senate that if we have a good front man, if I may use that phrase, to handle the public inquiries, it makes a lot of difference to the sort of information that comes across. Gordon, by his natural charm and his knowledge of the people who have come before us-I say that carefully because he has a wide range of contacts in the industries we have looked at in the five or six years I have been involved-has been able to maintain a good atmosphere in our public hearings. This has meant, of course, that we have had good contributions from the people who have come before us. Let me say again that it is not only that aspect but also the leadership he has given the Committee which is important. We have appreciated his bipartisan approach. By his care, his understanding, and his own personality he has been able to smooth over some of the wrinkles that must come out when six people sit around a table. He has been able to reach a consensus view on some pretty contentious issues, and we have appreciated him for it. We will miss him.

Let me also join him in paying a particular tribute to Mr John Lipscombe, who is leaving the Committee. He has been with the Committee ever since I have been a member of it, and I think it is fair to say that everyone here would appreciate that it is the secretariat that does the really hard work. It is the members of the secretariat who set the evidence before us by getting the submissions and arranging the public hearings. It is they who finally collate the information and present it in the form of a draft for us to look at. Certainly, Mr Lipscombe and his people have been outstanding in that regard. I pay a personal tribute, because he is leaving, to the friendly way in which he has carried out his duties and the very efficient manner in which he has worked with us all and tried to meet our individual idiosyncracies. I make those comments, making the point that further things will be said tomorrow about Senator Davidson. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Science and the Environment

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, I present a report on the Committee's reference on Australian marine science, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, in tabling its report 'Australian Marine Science', draws together evidence from many sectors of the community and presents the Senate with a blueprint for developing and co-ordinating marine science in this country. The Senate will recall that the Committee's progress report on Australian Marine Science, tabled on 22 May 1980, identified certain areas which the Committee believed warranted immediate attention, particularly research vessels and marine science information. The terms of reference of the Committee's inquiry gave particular emphasis to the development of a marine science program for Australia and the co-ordination of research efforts between the various agencies involved in marine science. Witnesses to the inquiry posed several models for co-ordinating marine science. From this evidence the Committee has considered the requirements of marine scientists and their suggested solutions. The Committee also paid regard to the recommendations of the Interim Council of the Australian Institute of Marine Science. The Interim Council proposed roles and functions for an Australian Marine Science Council to co-ordinate the research effort. The Committee was told repeatedly of how the present organisational structure of marine science serves only to fragment the research effort rather than consolidate it.

The Committee drew up a blueprint for the structure, functions and membership of an Australian marine science council. This council would operate as the national adviser on marine science matters especially in policy development, co-ordinate marine science research efforts, liaise with similar bodies overseas, and finance marine science research projects. The Committee recommends that the Australian Marine Science Council co-ordinate research efforts through regional and marine sciences committees and an advisory committee. The council, through its Executive and Secretariat, would be responsible for operating an information services unit and a ship operations unit. The Committee also recommends that the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's divisions of fisheries research and oceanography become research institutes to be managed by the Council. The Commitee believes that marine science could best be served by CSIRO vacating this explicit field of research while the divisions of fisheries research and oceanography could more efficiently consolidate their work in a research institute. The regional and marine science committees would be responsible for co-ordinating research activities within each region and field of marine science respectively. They would assist in reducing unnecessary duplication of research while at the same time encouraging co-operation and liaison between researchers. Mr President, in the interests of time, I seek leave to incorporate the rest of this statement in Hansard. I have already spoken to Senator Robertson about this arrangement.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The advisory committee would advise the Council on program planning and evaluation, education and training, and the conferring of fellowships, scholarships and project and program grants. The information services unit and a ship operations unit would be established under the proposed umbrella organisation, the Australian Marine Science Council. The information services unit would service the information needs of the organisation and researchers and agencies concerned with marine science. The ship operations unit would be responsible for the operational management of marine science research vessels and co-ordinating information concerning available ship time on Australian and overseas vessels in Australian waters. This unit would also administer a fund to enable scientists to take up ship time opportunities at very short notice.

The Committee also examines the development of a marine science program for Australia, and, in doing so, recommends that a marine science policy be developed. This policy should incorporate aspects such as the types of research to be financed and mechanisms for the selection, financing and effectiveness of research as well as the exploitation of research results. The Committee identifies areas of research priority which should be incorporated in a future marine science program. The Committee also further examines research vessels and facilities, manpower requirements and financing for marine science.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, I urge the Government to give earnest consideration to the recommendations in the report, which represent the unanimous views of the Committee. Before resuming my seat, I think it would be appropriate for me to recognise the efforts of the Committee's staff in the compilation of this report. Mr Peter Roberts found on taking over as the Committee's Secretary that a lot of valuable work had already been done by Mr Dawe, the Committee's former Secretary. I want to pay Mr Dawe a compliment. I am glad to see that he is present in the public gallery. I think all members of the Committee would want me to compliment him for the work that he has done for us. This work then became largely the responsibility of Sue Thomson, who is our senior research officer. I would also like to pay her a compliment, as well as our stenographers, June Andrews, Linda Rutter and Robyn Graham, who all worked very well to enable this report to be presented today.

SPEECH.PARA: This seems to be the season for making speeches of farewell to certain honourable senators. I do not think I could let this opportunity pass without paying a very sincere tribute to the work Senator Melzer has done on our Committee. Nobody could wish for a better, more enthusiastic and conscientious member of a committee. I believe that her position on the Committee will be most difficult to fill. I am sure that all of my colleagues join with me in wishing her every success in the future. I hope that she enjoys her retirement and finds some very useful work in which she can pursue her very wide community interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jessop outlined partly in the speech which he gave-no doubt this will be outlined further in the rest of his speech which has been incorporated in Hansard-the basic recommendations in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. I want to make one or two very brief observations about the report. Firstly, let me say that the report generally accepts full responsibility for the 200-nautical-mile Australian fishing zone as a Commonwealth responsibility. The report makes a number of recommendations as to how that responsibility ought to be fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: If I might just make a very brief political point, the contrast between the sensible approach adopted in this report as to constructive policy initiatives and areas of government involvement which should be pursued with the report of the so-called razor gang is stark and, if I might say so, hair raising. I hope it is something that Senator Jessop for one will cogitate about during the coming recess. The report of the razor gang involves the Commonwealth Government in washing its hands right, left and centre of functions of government, for reasons which are in part legitimate and in part ideological. This report suggests certain functions of government which should be pursued constructively in the interests of this society. To that extent it is to be very much commended. It is a forward-looking document which expresses in many ways the sort of involvement which the Opposition has been advocating for some two years in relation to the marine resources in the seas adjacent to this very big continent. I might say that the Australian Labor Party has been advocating this policy for two years. We have had in that advocacy diligent support from Senator Melzer. I would just like to support entirely Senator Jessop's comments about Senator Melzer and about her activities on the Committee. She has been a great help to the process of government in that not only has she contributed to the work of the Committee but also she has contributed very much to the thinking of the Australian Labor Party on these issues, and that is a function and a fact of life which I think should be commended by everybody. It is something that should not go unnoted.

I want to make one other comment on the importance of the initiatives recommended in the report. I want to make a point that we have made many times before. That point is simply this: Governments in Australia would be negligent if they did not look to all the potential areas of resource development which are available to this country. I suppose that in a sense potential areas of marine resources development are still being explored but they must be looked at in terms of the potential wealth and employment opportunities which can be generated in areas of this kind. This very important point emerges from the report. I just make the point that the Government, under the education guidelines which have been brought down for this year, is financing centres of excellence at universities in Australia. That was something that the Government took up in the last days of the election campaign in 1980 in response to the Opposition's policy on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —A response to the Tertiary Education Commission.

—No. The Government even stole some of the words. I can point to the responsible Minister's statement. That is a good thing, as the honourable senator would recognise. As he would say in some of his more pompous moments, that is the function of an Opposition. I hope that he still recognises that fact. We recommend that the TEC, when considering the question of centres of excellence, look very closely at this report in relation to the issues which are involved. The TEC is being asked to consider the establishment of a national school of fisheries. Perhaps it will widen its consideration somewhat to embrace some of the matters dealt with in this report. All of the things that this report says recommend and point very strongly to the need for a national policy in this area. That is something which is very constructive and most important. For those reasons I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse to the hilt all that has been said by the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, and I think that has been substantially endorsed by Senator Button. Firstly, I should like to say that Senator Melzer had the capacity, in any interrogation of witnesses, to go for the jugular vein when the dialogue was slowing down and to get answers. One of the difficulties with committee meetings is that they can be endless, and nobody wants too many long baseline rallies. I refer to item 37 of the report. I believe that the clamour that we made for adequate updated mammal research is timely. Not long ago we had a great example of bipartisan policy in relation to the whaling legislation. The forces of good triumphed. There were some malcontents, but I do not want to get too political. The legislation went through, and I know that the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Thomson, was concerned that it would be unduly delayed. I do not want to go further with that statement. I can see Senator Martin looking at me.
—It has not been proclaimed yet, Senator.

—I will let that go over my head. I had enough to say yesterday; I do not want to start again. I stand by that statement. Item 37 dealt largely with the evidence of Dr Ling, the curator of the museum in South Australia and a leading authority on seals. He was backed up by Dr Guller, reader in zoology at the University of Tasmania. I believe that the tocsin has been sounded for the Government to move quickly on mammal research. Recently we have had increasing incidences of the beaching of whales, and those who read Time and Newsweek would know that several successful operations have been carried out by the United States Coastguard and it has been able to get some of these whales back into the seas. I raised the question on the Estimates committee which dealt with the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, but I received only a vague response. I believe that there are scientists in Australia who can be co-opted into the field. We also know that with the world food demand and the competition for krill all sorts of situations can arise.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me revert to seals. Senator Puplick and myself have had some apprehension about this matter. Perhaps we can be a bit easy in our minds when we compare our position in regard to seals with the position in Canada. There is no case for slaughter of seals here. In conclusion, I say that I hope that the Government will respond to the Committee's efforts. When we see photographs of seals on Moriarty's Reef we will know that they are protected by the humane bipartisan policy of this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In commending the report of the Standing Committee on Science and the Environment to the Senate, I should like to respond to some of the kind remarks that have been made by my leader, by colleagues, and by the Chairman of the Committee. I say, in response, that I have not served under a fairer chairman than Don Jessop. He manages to control members without bullying them. He manages to control witnesses without ever bullying them-not very noticeably, anyway-and without any overuse of authority. He is a veritable example of an iron fist in a velvet glove. The Chairman and Committee members have all shown a deep interest in and a deep commitment to the matters which have come before us. That is a great help for a committee to get to the truth and to write a report which puts that truth further forward. The leadership that Don Jessop has shown in that regard has always been, I think, something of which the Committee can be proud. I think my colleagues represent a broad cross section of Australian people and Australian ideas. It is from that broad grouping that we have been able to bring forward reports that I think make these matters of interest to ordinary people.

SPEECH.PARA: One matter that has been raised over and over in this chamber since I became a senator has been that committees can work very hard, wheedle out and demand evidence in all sorts of quarters and write a report that gets to the nub of the problem, but then the report sits in a pigeon hole and governments cannot be brought to the point of implementing the recommendations brought down by the Committee. I believe that Senate committees will get teeth only when people outside realise how much good and truth there is in reports and how close they get to the actual problems that exist. When people outside realise that the reports do affect and can affect their lives they will start to demand that these committees have some teeth. Only when reports are written in language that people understand and only when people can see the reports as affecting their own lives will they take more interest in the reports that are written by committees in this place. I am very proud of the reports that the Science and Environment Committee has put down because I believe that they reflect real problems and that they are written in the sort of language that real people can understand. I thank the Senate for the opportunity of having served on this Committee. I am very proud to have been on it. I will watch from not too far away the work that it does in the future.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I present a report on the 'Power in Indo-China since 1975', together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report was tabled in the House of Representatives yesterday. Unfortunately, because of arrangements relating to reports, it could not be tabled at the same time in the Senate. Because of the fact that it was tabled yesterday and the constraints on the time of the Senate this afternoon, I shall comment only briefly on the recommendations of the report. I trust that in the next session of the Senate there will be opportunities to debate the report, by which time undoubtedly quite a few things will have happened in Indo-China which would necessitate some updating certainly in the detail of the report.

The report follows the decision by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in November 1979 to inquire into 'the changing power structure in Indo-China since 1975 and its effects on Australia and the region'. Sub-committee A undertook the reference and in the course of the inquiry submissions were received and evidence heard from a wide variety of individuals and representatives of organisations. These included nationals and diplomatic representatives of the Indo-Chinese countries, Australian academics with expert knowledge of the region, representatives of Commonwealth departments and United Nations representatives. Five members of Sub-committee A individually visited the region between 1979 and 1981. This has provided the Committee with valuable first hand information, especially regarding the refugee situation and conditions in Kampuchea.

One of the Committee's recommendations in the report tabled today is that the Government should encourage further and continuous study of this volatile region which is likely to become more important to Australia's future. In this way, the Australian public can become aware of the many political, military, social and economic factors contributing to the present instability of the region, and public interest in events in the region will be stimulated.

The very large Indo-Chinese refugee problem which has arisen in recent years has had direct consequences for Australia, since over 50,000 Indo-Chinese refugees have been accepted for resettlement here since 1975. The humanitarian aspects of the Indo-Chinese refugee situation, and Australia's role in assisting the refugees, is currently being examined by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and has not been studied in depth by this Committee. The existence of a very large body of refugees is also a major cause of instability in the region, particularly in the Thai-Kampuchean border area. The Committee therefore recommends that, working through United Nations organisations, the Government should press for the establishment of some form of administrative machinery on the border so that those Kampuchean refugees seeking resettlement in a third country can be separated quickly from the short term refugees who intend returning to their country.

The report notes that there have been few regimes this century so reviled as the Democratic Kampuchean Government, which is better known as the Pol Pot regime. The Committee recommends that the general abhorrence felt in Australia towards that regime should be kept in mind when considering Australia's attitude towards the Indo-Chinese region and that Australia should discourage diplomatic support for the Democratic Kampuchean regime. The Committee does not, however, support the recognition of the People's Republic of Kampuchea, which is known as the Heng Samrin regime, while Vietnamese military forces are present in Kampuchea. Recent reports of the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations have stressed that Kampuchea's economy is still so fragile that famine conditions could easily return if drought or floods occur, or as a result of political or military upheavals, or if there is an abrupt end to international aid. In the interests of encouraging stability in the region, every effort needs to be made by the international community to prevent the recurrence of famine in Kampuchea. The Committee, therefore, recommends that Australian humanitarian aid to Kampuchea should continue.

One of the most notable developments in Indo-China since 1975 is the emergence of Vietnam as a strong military power. As the report tabled today indicates, Vietnam is apparently determined to maintain its present domination of Indo-China even at the cost of conflict with China. Under the so-called Twenty-five Year Treaties of Friendship and Co-operation signed with Laos in July 1979 and Kampuchea in February 1979, Vietnam has legitimised its military presence in those countries under the guise of defence co-operation. Currently there are 40,000 to 50,000 Vietnamese troops in Laos and some 200,000 in Kampuchea. Consequently, Laos and Kampuchea must now be regarded as client states of their powerful neighbour. The Committee is concerned at this situation and recommends that Australia should support policies which would result in the independence of Vietnam, Laos and Kampuchea, based on democratically elected governments. The Committee also recommends that economic aid should not be given by Australia to Vietnam until it withdraws its military forces from Laos and Kampuchea.

Vietnam's domination of Indo-China entails her continuing dependence on the Soviet Union for large-scale military and economic aid. The Soviet Union has been able to utilise its relationship with Vietnam to obtain access to port facilities and thus increase its own presence in the region. The physical presence of Soviet advisers in Vietnam and the Soviet naval presence, particularly in such major ports as Da Nang, appears to have expanded considerably since February 1979. Vietnam has apparently become an important staging-cum-naval observation post or depot for Soviet naval operations in the South China Sea. To China this no doubt appears part of what is seen as a Soviet plot to encircle her on all possible borders.

A reduction in the tensions in the Indo-Chinese region will not be achieved easily. The Committee believes, therefore, that Australia must face the prospect of continued instability in the region, coupled with the very real prospect of renewed armed conflict there. The Committee recommends that Australia should make strenuous efforts to promote regional solutions to Indo-Chinese problems and, in the interest of peace and stability in the region, attempt to decrease the involvement of the super-powers. The Committee further recommends that the Government should utilise its relationship with the Association of South East Asian Nations to encourage all forms of dialogue between ASEAN countries and Indo-China which may help to decrease tension in the region and promote a peaceful settlement of the conflict in Kampuchea. Australia should also continue to lend its support to international efforts aimed at decreasing regional tension. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Eight of the nine Australian Labor Party members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, along with Senator Sim who was one of the Government members of the Committee, signed a dissenting report on recommendation No. 3. Recommendation No. 3 of the report indicated that economic aid should not be given by Australia to Vietnam until it withdraws its military forces from Laos and Kampuchea. Our dissenting report states:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe a more appropriate recommendation on the question of future Australian economic assistance to Vietnam would read as follows: 'The Government should resume its commitment to the two aid projects to Vietnam suspended in January 1979. Such assistance reflects continuing obligations resulting from Australian involvement in the war in Vietnam. This action may encourage Vietnam to lessen dependence on the Soviet Union and encourage Vietnamese resistance to the Soviet demands for access to Vietnamese facilities for Soviet military purposes. The Australian Government should also use alliance channels to press the US Government to adopt a similar policy'.
We continued later in our minority report to say:

The cessation of Australia's small aid program to Vietnam following the Vietnamese invasion of Kampuchea is understandable, but in the context of our longer term interests, is counterproductive. For Australia to continue to maintain this position deprives us of attaining an identifiable position in the process of reaching a solution to the Indo-Chinese problem.
We realise that the issue of the withdrawal of forces was something that had to be dealt with. We stated:

We should not delude ourselves that Vietnam is likely to withdraw its forces from Kampuchea until it is assured that a government friendly to its interests is firmly established in Kampuchea. The prospects for a resolution of the Indo Chinese problem in the short term are not bright. However, in the longer term an accommodation is possible and we should direct our efforts to this eventuality. In the nature of the process there will of necessity be compromises in the positions taken by all interested parties. A more flexible Australian position will assist in this process.
In the minority report we also dealt with the problem of refugees. We said in part:

As well as our national security interest in seeing Vietnamese dependence on the Soviet Union reduced we need to be concerned with developments which may lead to substantial increases in the numbers of Indo Chinese refugees. We need to be concerned about such developments on humanitarian grounds. We also need to be aware of the social, political and economic damage a large influx of refugees will do to friendly States in the ASEAN group. We must further acknowledge that a massive increase in the number of refugees is likely to pose political and economic difficulties in Australia. So far obligations to accept Indo Chinese refugees in Australia have been undertaken without raising substantial domestic difficulties. This situation may not necessarily continue in the face of surges in the numbers to be accommodated.

It is fair to say that the success of the refugee program, or the manner in which Australia has accepted a number of refugees from Vietnam, is due to the fact that there has been a bipartisan approach to the problem. I believe it is also fair to say that the Labor Party sees economic aid being very closely tied up with these problems. The report continued:

The refugee question is complex. The large exodus of refugees from Vietnam prior to July 1979 was a product of racial and political tensions. However, it is clear that economic problems also weigh with Vietnamese in determining whether or not to permit large numbers to leave. Economic stability in Vietnam is also likely to be a factor in determining whether or not individual Vietnamese wish to leave.
Finally, at the conclusion of our minority report we said:

Aid is a diplomatic entree, one of the few which Australia can utilise. To deny itself an opportunity to use aid for realistic objectives is foolish. Recommendation 3 as it stands does this. The alternative put forward would permit Australia to pursue its national interest more appropriately.

It did concern us that we had to write a minority report on such a sensitive subject. It is worthy of note that Senator Sim who was, up to yesterday, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, also agreed with us and signed the minority report. I think it is worth noting also that when Senator Sim was Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-for a period, I think, in excess of 10 years-we never presented a minority report. We were all able to sit together as a committee to work out whatever differences we had, to approach problems realistically and, finally, to reach agreement. I know that it is easier to reach agreement on a Senate committee with six members than it is to reach agreement with 21 members from both Houses on a joint committee. However, it did concern us that in this sensitive report we were not able to reach agreement on this one issue even though we reached agreement on all of the others.

I have been a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence since 1975 and a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence since 1975. I have served with Senator Sim who was Chairman of the Senate Committee and I have also served with him as a member of the Joint Committee. I know how strongly he feels about overseas aid not only to Indo-China and South East Asia but also to Africa. I take this opportunity today in talking to this report to congratulate him on the distinguished work that he has done on both those committees. I am sure that Senator Primmer and Senator McIntosh, my colleagues on the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, join with me in wishing Senator Sim well for the future. I know that he is not going to lose his involvement in foreign affairs and defence. We are looking forward to the time when he will be able to come before our Senate Committee as a witness and give evidence on the areas and the subjects on which he has been so very well briefed in the past.

I should not conclude my remarks without thanking the staff of the sub-committee on Indo-China for the work they have done in preparing this report. Finally, I join with Senator Martin in saying that the issues involved in this report are too important for it to be pigeon-holed. I also hope, along with Senator Martin, that the report will come up for debate in the Senate at a very early stage in the Budget session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I agree with my colleague, Senator Sibraa, in all he has had to say. As one of the signatories of the dissenting report, I would like to say that there was no way I could agree with recommendation 3. It was that economic aid should not be given by Australia to Vietnam until such time as it withdraws its forces from Kampuchea. I think it was an unrealistic attitude. Therefore, I could not agree with it and I was a signatory to the dissenting report. If one read the body of the report, one would begin to wonder why the Committee made recommendation 3. In the body of the report, the position was made pretty clear. It is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: On several occasions in 1975, North Vietnam reaffirmed its desire to normalise relations with the United States. However, no progress was made on this issue, nor on the question of the United States' payment of war 'reparations'.2 The United States Government further expressed its displeasure at the communist conquest of the south, by announcing that it would veto the separate applications made by North and South Vietnam in July for membership of the United Nations.
The report further states:

In the period 1976-77, following Vietnam's re-unification, the Vietnamese Government launched a diplomatic offensive on a wide front, which echoed what then became the principal theme of its foreign policy: to assert its independence from the socialist giants and improve its image as a genuinely non-aligned nation. In August 1976, at a meeting of the non-aligned bloc in Colombo, the leader of the Vietnamese delegation, Premier Pham Van Dong, said: 'On the international plane, it is necessary to establish, maintain and diversify our relations with all countries, primarily those with developing countries'. In line with Vietnam's need for foreign loans in order to finance its 1976-80 Five Year Plan, Premier Pham Van Dong also called for economic relations with developed capitalist countries.

The report goes on to explain that Vietnam tried very hard to get assistance from America, Australia and developing nations in order to get on to a proper economic footing. It was forced further and further into the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, COMECON, bloc. I think we have to accept some of the responsibility for that situation. It would be rather petty to withhold the pittance of aid that we gave after our commitment to Vietnam. Making aid conditional was, I think, very wrong indeed. In the first place, I do not believe that aid should have conditions and strings to it in that manner. For those reasons I went along with the dissenting report and everything else contained in it.
