DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN ANTITRUST JUDGMENTS (RESTRICTION OF ENFORCEMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act 1979.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard. In doing so, may I mention that three words were omitted from the second paragraph on page 5 of the second reading speech and they have now been entered on the copies that have been circulated.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I indicate that it is a somewhat unusual course for a major Bill of great importance to be introduced without the second reading speech being fully read. Nonetheless, because it is such a substantial document and because of the time constraints we are under, the Opposition has no objection to that course being followed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Foreign Antitrust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act 1979. That Act, shortly stated, enables the Attorney-General to make orders prohibiting the enforcement in Australia of foreign antitrust judgments in the circumstances set out in the Act. This Bill, when enacted, will enable an Australian defendant to a foreign judgment subject to such an order to take proceedings to recover from the foreign plaintiff any amount which has been recovered under the judgment in a foreign country.

It will be recalled that the Parliament has twice previously enacted legislation of a defensive character in regard to foreign anti-trust proceedings-the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act (in November 1976) and the Act prohibiting the enforcement of judgments in Australia, to which I have just referred. That legislation was directly occasioned by proceedings in the United States relating to trade in uranium and, more particularly, the Westinghouse suit, but I wish to recall what I said of the Westinghouse suit in my Press statement of 5 October 1980. I then said that 'it represents an example, even if the most dramatic, of the particular difficulties experienced by foreign governments with private treble damages proceedings where United States extraterritorial jurisdiction was being asserted'.

Mr President, the Westinghouse suit has been settled. But the jurisdictional threat to our export and other trading policies from such private proceedings remains. The measure which I am now introducing is designed to further protect those policies. It is also designed to underline the seriousness with which the Commonwealth Government and the Parliament continues to view this problem. For here, I believe that I express, in a complete sense, a national voice. The two previous Acts were enacted by the Parliament with bipartisan support and, whatever differences in nuance may emerge, the Opposition has been at one with the Government in its concern. Australia is not alone in the difficulties which it has experienced in this area. Belgium, Canada and the Provinces of Quebec and Ontario in that country, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden and the United Kingdom have, at one time or another, felt the need to introduce prohibitory measures as a defence against the jurisdictional assertions of the United States in the field of antitrust enforcement.
Australia's Objections

Let me state as clearly and as fully as I can Australia's objections to the way in which the United States enforces its anti-trust laws extra-territorially. Australia is a major trading nation and a major exporter of commodities. It is the largest or close to the largest exporter of meat, sugar, wheat, iron ore, alumina, mineral sands, lead, bauxite, zinc, coal and nickel in the world. Its export income from agricultural and mineral commodities of $A14.1 billion in 1979-80 represented 77 per cent of the total national export income of that year. Australia regulates its exports under certain laws; chiefly by the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations, but also by other laws incidental to its export control. By Part X of the Trade Practices Act it regulates outwards shipping-and I emphasise 'outward' shipping-from this country. By the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act the relevant Minister may, upon the recommendation of the Corporation, designate the carriers of meat exports from this country and impose certain conditions relating to its carriage.

Let me, in the light of that, turn to United States extra territorial anti-trust enforcement. The United States applies its anti-trust laws to the conduct of aliens abroad, if there is, as a result of that conduct, an adverse effect upon United States commerce. In applying that principle the United States regards it as jurisdictionally sufficient if the conduct has produced the required adverse effect upon the foreign commerce of the United States. That is a special feature of United States anti-trust law. As was stated in a report of the OECD Committee of Experts on Restrictive Business Practices in July 1977:
The special feature of the United States anti-trust laws is that they alone also apply to restrictions on competition which affect the foreign trade of the United States. (Paragraph 119).

And whatever minor gloss may be placed upon it, that remains true today. What that characteristic of United States law means is that jurisdiction will be asserted if there is the required adverse effect upon United States exports or United States imports. That alone is sufficient. To that extent-to the extent that United States anti-trust law extends into foreign commerce in this particular way-it is a trading law. It requires foreign traders to behave in a certain manner in the international market so as not to affect adversely American trade.

Trading laws are common enough. Nations, by their laws, regulate their exports and their imports. I have given certain examples in the case of Australia. But ordinarily what they regulate is their exports and their imports. We would not, for example, regard it as open for a country to impose criminal sanctions upon a foreign trader because he refused to sell to us, nor to require him to sell to our traders at a stipulated minimum price. The United States anti-trust laws, as applied extra-territorially, do proscribe the way in which foreign exporters shall do business where there is an adverse effect upon American trade. But the matter does not rest there. The conduct by foreign exporters is subject to American law even where they are carrying out the laws and policies of the exporting country.

As I said before, nations, in the ordinary course, regulate their exports and their imports. That is clearly a corollary of each nation's sovereignty. Is there then any special justification by which the United States could presume to regulate the conduct of foreign exporters and that, notwithstanding that their conduct is in accordance with the trading laws of their own country? What the United States anti-trust laws are directed against is anti-competitive behaviour. Many countries, including our own, have competition laws. Many legislate so as to take steps to prevent the control of anti-competitive behaviour within their domestic economies from being undermined by external conduct. But with that we are not here concerned. We are dealing with the international market. For it is the conduct of foreign traders and the effect of that conduct on American trade which grounds jurisdiction.

Mr President, let me look briefly at competition policy practice in the international market. Section 51 (2) (g) of the Australian Trade Practices Act provides, in substance, that arrangements relating exclusively to the export of goods are, subject to certain requirements, exempt from the operation of the Act. Australian law is not alone in containing such an exemption from its competition law. The competition laws of Canada, Germany, Japan and the United States itself provide in one form or another for export exemptions. The United States Webb Pomerene Act grants anti-trust immunity to export associations. The fact that such associations might fix prices and thereby injure the trade of another nation is no obstacle to their obtaining immunity.

Mr President, I need not dwell upon the contradiction in the United States position of insisting by its anti-trust laws, that foreign exporters shall act competitively in the international market whilst allowing by specific legislative provision its own exporters to act anti-competitively in that market. Nor upon the collision of laws and policies which would result if each and every nation were to apply an 'adverse effect upon foreign commerce' test of legislative jurisdiction and if, at the same time, each such State were to give effect to an export exemption. Many countries have legislated to require competition within their economies, yet consider restrictive conduct by their exporters to be permissible and justified. And they do so because of the special character of the international market. The international market is not a free market, however much that may be wished. It is distorted by the actions of governments-importing as well as exporting countries. It is not unreasonable to take the laws and practices of the United States for examination both by reason of its prominence in world trade and, more simply, because it is, after all, the United States which has asserted jurisdiction to regulate foreign traders in the manner described. For example, section 201 of the United States Trade Agreements Act provides for relief to be given where goods are imported in such increased quantities as to be 'a substantial cause of serious injury or the threat thereof to a domestic industry . . . '. Successful foreign competition is the criterion upon which that section operates. Moreover, the relief which can be granted-including the negotiation of orderly marketing arrangements-is itself restrictive of competition in the international market. In addition, the United States has entered into what are described as voluntary restraint agreements. References to such agreements almost invariably place the word voluntary in quotation marks. And the reason for this is that they are not voluntary. They are agreements resulting from governments leaning on traders. And so over the years, in order to protect the United States domestic producers from foreign competition, such agreements have been concluded.

Since 1964 the United States has applied provisions for the imposition of quotas on the importation of meat into that country. Those provisions, themselves restrictive of competition, have been relied upon to induce voluntary agreements to limit exports to the United States. I might also mention the legislative provision under which the United States uranium import embargo-which was frequently referred to for its significance in the Westinghouse proceedings-was imposed. The provision enabled an embargo to be imposed to the extent necessary to ensure the maintenance of a viable, domestic uranium industry. In other words, to protect United States domestic uranium producers from foreign competition. The United States is not alone in these policies. The point which I have been endeavouring to make is that the international market is not, as a matter of reality, a free market. And from that it follows inevitably that the United States cannot rely upon the practices in that market to justifiably overreach foreign trading laws and policies and proscribe the conduct of exporters carried out in accordance with them.

There is another quite separate point. It is evident that the difficulties encountered where jurisdiction is based upon an adverse effect on American trade could be substantially mitigated if the kind of effect required were precisely delimited and carefully applied. But this is not the case. There is no consensus in United States legal authority as to the kind of effect required. It has been variously described as a 'direct and intended' effect; a 'direct, substantial, and foreseeable' effect; a 'substantial and foreseeable' effect; a 'direct or substantial' effect; or that 'the better views seem to be that any effect that is not both insubstantial and indirect will support Federal jurisdiction'. And, more recently, in 1979, in the case of Dominicus Americana Bohio, Judge Carter said-and I quote-'indeed it is probably not necessary for the effect on foreign commerce to be both substantial and direct as long as it is not de minimus'. In other words, for the assumption of jurisdiction, although not, in fairness, for its exercise, that court was prepared to accept that any effect on United States commerce which was not trifling would be sufficient to ground jurisdiction.

We live in a world in which the repercussions of economic conduct may be infinitely remote. And we criticise, on that ground, an effects test which is so wide, so vague, and so uncertain. The only clear case in which foreign government laws and policies are taken into account by United States courts in respect of private conduct carried in pursuance of them, is by the defence of foreign sovereign compulsion. That narrowly confined defence is quite inadequate. It requires that the foreign trader shall have been compelled by his government to carry out the impugned conduct. By its nature, it excludes the vast range of foreign laws and policies which approve or authorise trading conduct. In point of sovereignty, compulsion or otherwise is an arbitrary and irrelevant distinction.

Quite as importantly, the doctrine of foreign sovereign compulsion affords a defence only. The foreign law or policy does not, as we maintain it must, go to the question of jurisdiction. This is not a matter of mere theoretical criticism but of great practical importance given the nature of United States proceedings and the cost burden involved. I shall refer in due course to what has become known as the Timberlane principle which does relate to foreign laws and policies.

Let me sum up. As things stand, our export laws and policies and those laws and policies incidental to them are, in our view, quite unjustifiably threatened by the jurisdictional assertions of United States Courts in proceedings against Australian exporters when giving them effect.
Commonwealth Government Policy

I have spoken of the restrictive character of the international market. There is no question that restrictive business practices adversely affecting international trade constitute a major problem. The obstacles they present to trade have been greatly aggravated by the increasing internationalisation of the corporate structure. Australia's policy is, and has been, to participate actively in the removal of these obstacles to world trade. Australia's policy is clear. We believe that where United States' anti-trust enforcement and Australian trading laws clash, the solution lies in inter-governmental consultation. Our policy is to establish a mechanism by which those inter-governmental consultations can take place. On 3 November 1977, the then United States Associate Attorney-General, Mr Egan, made an important statement. He said, in an address to the International Bar Association, that:

''an unyielding and unresponsive anti-trust policy, heedless of considerations of comity could seriously disrupt United States foreign policy. It could weaken vital alliances. It could provoke retaliation.''
And, in the same address, Mr Egan added:
''the only appropriate response is one of seeking accommodation and compromise when United States anti-trust enforcement conflicts with foreign laws and important foreign policies.''.

And so this statement gave us, as we thought, the opportunity for the implementation of our policy. In September 1978, I led a delegation from Australia to discuss the matter in the United States. We recognised that if, in accordance with the statement by Mr Egan, the United States was to accommodate its anti-trust enforcement to the important policies of foreign governments, some means must be devised by which the United States would be apprised of our laws and policies where they might have significant anti-trust implications for the United States. It would also be necessary for there to be full consultation and, subject to the outcome of those consultations, the preservation of the authority and sovereignty of the Commonwealth Government.

I can say that, at that meeting, the Australian initiative was welcomed. A text, in provisional and draft form, was presented by us to the United States and we looked forward to an early and favourable response. The United States submitted a revised negotiating draft agreement under cover of a letter dated 27 July 1979, from the then United States Assistant Attorney-General, Mr Shenefield. In that letter it was indicated that the United States saw little room for negotiating on two matters-private anti-trust proceedings and immunity of Australian enterprises from prosecution in respect of conduct during the process of consultation as contemplated by the agreement.

Mr President, I will deal later with the further discussions that I had with the United States Attorney-General concerning the bilateral agreement and other developments. Our concern in those discussions related very much to the apparent exclusion of the issue of private anti-trust proceedings from the discussions as I have just mentioned. It is not, however, possible to understand the significance of those discussions, or indeed, the need for this present measure, without some general explanation of the law relating to private treble damages suits.
Private Treble Damages Suits

The United States Department of Justice is authorised to bring criminal proceedings for a breach of United States anti-trust laws. In addition, however, a private plaintiff can bring suit to recover three times the amount of any damage which it has sustained as a result of that same breach. The purpose of this multiple damages remedy is penal. Private anti-trust suits, it has been said, serve to supply an ancillary force of private investigators to supplement the Department of Justice's law enforcement. Plaintiffs in such suits are referred to as private Attorneys-General. United States procedures enable judgments in criminal proceedings to constitute prima facie evidence for the purpose of these civil proceedings. Private action is encouraged by a provision permitting the plaintiff to recover costs. The defendant, even if successful, is not entitled to recover costs. And let me add, Mr President, that not enough has been said in discussions on this subject about the matter of costs. Legal costs in these proceedings can amount to millions-and I mean millions-of dollars. The costs alone can constitute a quite undeserved penalty for an innocent defendant.
Procedural Problems Associated with Multiple Damages Suits

There are a number of problems associated with these penal actions which are in form private or civil. Nations have established by their laws a fabric of reciprocity in regard to civil proceedings which are compensatory in the strict sense. But this fabric of reciprocity was never designed to take account of criminal actions or multiple damages proceedings which are civil in form. One such problem concerns the recognition of judgments in those proceedings and, it will be recalled, that in April 1980 I presented a paper on multiple damages judgments at the Conference of Commonwealth Law Ministers at Barbados in the context of a proposed Commonwealth scheme for the recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments. That paper was well received by the Ministers attending the Conference, who represented 38 Commonwealth countries. That Conference expressed general support for the principle that enforcement of judgement arrangements should exclude multiple damages awards. Importantly, in the present context, the concept of recovery back was supported. Details of the Conference and a copy of the paper which I presented can be found in my Press statements of 1 May 1980 and 8 June 1980.

There are other difficulties with private treble damages suits. Under procedures available in civil proceedings, a plaintiff may call for discovery and production of documents to the court from the other party. In most common law countries such a procedure exists and it enables each party to have access to all documents in the possession of the other which are directly relevant to the suit. Under United States procedures, however, the defendant may be required to produce not only documents that are directly relevant but also any documents that lead to admissible evidence.

Accordingly, in the case of private anti-trust suits, discovery may generate the production of massive quantities of documents. In the case of one defendant in the Westinghouse suit, half a million or so documents in Australia were subject to discovery. This matter of discovery of documents leads back to the ambit of legislative jurisdiction assumed under United States law. For it is a clear rule of international law-unquestioned by the United States-that enforcement jurisdiction, of which discovery of documents is an example, can only exist where legislative jurisdiction exists. Accordingly, where that latter jurisdiction is disputed-as is the case with the United States anti-trust laws-it must necessarily give rise to dispute as to the availability of discovery.
The Problem of Jurisdiction and Multiple Damages

But let me return to the central problem with these private treble damages suits-and to the reasons for our disappointment at the United States response to our negotiating initiative of September 1978 by removing the issue of these suits from the further negotiation of the bilateral agreement. The jurisdiction assumed by the court in these private anti-trust suits is precisely the same as that which applies in criminal proceedings. It follows that there is exactly the same possibility of United States national economic policy being given effect by its courts and superseding the trading laws of other countries as I have previously described.

We, of course, have neither objection nor concern with regard to the use of multiple damages to advance national economic policy within the United States. But where extra territorial jurisdiction in private proceedings allows for our own trading policies to be superseded, we are confronted with a quite different problem. It is obvious that a private plaintiff is not, as such, concerned with questions of sovereignty or jurisdiction. Likewise, a foreign defendant is inevitably concerned with its own interests in resisting the claim. Questions of national interest are of incidental importance to a private plaintiff and to a private defendant. Where there are problems of jurisdiction and the matter is left entirely in private hands there is no scope for resolving these conflicts by inter-governmental consultation.
Recognition of Foreign Government Interests in Private Treble Damages Suits

Australia's general concern with the problems of private treble damages suits, of which we had been aware from the outset and which I have dealt with generally, became immeasurably increased by certain events which took place about this time in the Westinghouse suit. Those events related to the failure to accord adequate recognition to foreign government policies and interests in certain proceedings then current in that suit. Those proceedings allowed us to observe the operation of a relatively recent decision of a United States court dealing with foreign government policies and interests.

Mr President, let me explain. In early 1977 the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit delivered judgment in the Timberlane case. In effect, it was held that before jurisdiction should be assumed or exercised in any suit where foreign government policies or interests were involved, there should be a 'weighing' of the respective governmental interests of the United States and the foreign country. Certain factors were enunciated in that and in a subsequent decision which were to be taken into account for that purpose. There then followed a development which appeared to Australia to be of considerable importance. The United States Government, through its most senior officials, endorsed that decision. Indeed, it has continued to endorse the Timberlane principle as the means by which sovereignty of other nations may be respected and comity given effect. Accordingly, when, in relation to proceedings then current in the Westinghouse matter, we approached the United States Administration to intervene, we did so with some confidence.

The Timberlane decision itself was premised upon the view-and I quote from the words of Judge Choy-that 'the effects test by itself is incomplete because it fails to consider other nations' interests'. That being the basis of the decision which the United States Government had so emphatically endorsed it seemed to follow that the Administration would have been anxious to have had Timberlane established as the law of the land as soon as possible. There were, however, more particular grounds for our confidence. It is to be remembered that the Westinghouse suit was preceded by a massive Grand Jury inquiry. Arising out of that inquiry the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice, after a full study of the matter, filed one misdemeanour charge only, and that against a United States corporation.

The United States Government had thus made its own assessment of the governmental interests in question and the result of that assessment was made clear by the then Assistant Attorney-General, Mr Shenefield. That assessment was as follows. In a letter to United States Senator Metzenbaum dated 31 March 1979, Mr Shenefield said that 'the evidence did not support the conclusion that the broad uranium cartel had any significant and foreseeable effect on United States commerce, as required by law'. In January 1980, Mr Shenefield stated to a Congressional committee 'first it is an undoubted fact . . . that the cartel had its genesis in a major anti-competitive action by our own government in walling off a major portion of the world's market to businessmen who had theretofore sold into our market'. He added that 'I think it is also fair to point out also that certainly the Governments of South Africa, Canada and Australia see uranium as being one of their major national resources and took steps following our own Government's anti-competitive acts to try and save an important national industry'. We would have thought that, having made its assessment of the governmental considerations involved, the Administration would then have wished to bring them formally before the court so as to assist it in giving effect to the Timberlane principle which the Administration has espoused.

One of the factors which the Timberlane principle requires to be taken into account is the 'possible effect upon foreign relations if the court exercises jurisdiction and grants relief'. In its Note to the Commonwealth Government dated 31 October 1979, the United States Department of State, in acknowledging that the suit sought large damages from Australian companies which were important participants in the Australian economy, went on to add 'it is also the case . . . that the United States has an interest in the stability and the prosperity of the Australian economy, given our strong political, strategic and economic ties'. Timberlane required a consideration of foreign relations. The Department of State acknowledged that foreign relations were involved. Intervention to explain the foreign relations aspects to the courts would have seemed imperative if that principle was to have any reality. All our requests for intervention have been rejected. It was said by the Department of State that the Commonwealth Government could present its views directly to the court-and I quote-'we are confident that its views will be given due weight'.

Let me then look at the reactions of the courts. In the District Court, Judge Marshall in proceedings before him commented-and I quote-that 'the judiciary has no expertise or perhaps even authority to evaluate the economic and social policies of foreign governments'. In the Court of Appeals the intervention of foreign governments was criticised so strongly that its comments led to a letter from the United States Government to that Court in whom its confidence had been so misplaced. For that letter we were grateful, as I have indicated in a previous press statement.

Mr President, let me sum up the whole position. A decision of a United States Circuit Court called for the weighing of governmental interests in anti-trust suits where the policies or interests of foreign governments were involved. In particular, the court was to consider the possible effect upon foreign relations. The United States Government specifically endorsed that decision as the means by which the sovereignty of other countries may be respected and comity given effect. Nevertheless, the United States Government has not to this stage intervened to assist the court in its consideration of those foreign governmental interests, notwithstanding that the Administration has reached views upon them and acknowledged that the foreign relations of both the United States and the other countries are implicated.

The United States Government refuses to intervene upon the ground that the courts can deal with the matter. United States courts, for their part, have said either that they have no expertise to weigh foreign governmental interests or that the Timberlane principle is not the law of this circuit, or have complained and relied upon the failure of the Department of State to intervene. (Decision of the Supreme Court of New Mexico in General Atomic Co. v. United Nuclear Corporation dated 29 August 1980.) And for good measure, the court, in a recent case, said that 'naturally the defendants must bear the burden of demonstrating that foreign policy considerations outweigh the need to enforce the antitrust laws where the foreign commerce of the United States is affected'. (Dominicus Americana Bohio v. Gulf & Western (1979) 473 F. Supp. 680 at 688). The inconsistencies in the United States position on this matter are clearly apparent.

I have not recited our endeavours to secure United States Government intervention in order to suggest that that represents a solution to the problem of private treble damages suits. The issue is not so much intervention. It is the Timberlane principle itself. It is fundamentally unworkable for the very reason that Judge Marshall gave. The judiciary has no expertise to decide these questions; questions as to the significance of a trading law to another country; as to the need for stabilisation of prices; as to the need to deal with an unforeseen emergency in the export market. Timberlane is not a principle which we can in point of sovereignty accept. We are not prepared to acknowledge that a United States court can judge, on the basis of its view of our national interest, whether it will exercise jurisdiction. For the reasons already given, we claim that there is no warrant for United States anti-trust laws overreaching our own export laws and policies. In Australia's view these conflicts over jurisdiction and sovereignty, on the one hand, and over national interests on the other, can only be worked out by governments. But given United States law as to private treble damages suits, it is extremely difficult for a mechanism of inter-governmental consultations to be arranged.

I met with the then United States Attorney-General, Mr Civiletti, in April 1980. It will be understood, against the background which I have given, that my purpose was to press upon the United States Government the problem posed by the issue of private treble damages suits and the need for that issue to remain negotiable. I also broached with him the need for some legislative change in this area. For it is clear that if the private treble damages remedy were not extended into the field of foreign commerce, many of our problems would be removed. Mr Civiletti was sympathetic to our concerns but I cannot claim any particular success on that occasion.
The Canberra Meeting with the United States Attorney-General

I met with Mr Civiletti in Canberra on 13 August 1980. That meeting was successful. A Press statement was issued on that date relating to the meeting. I do not wish to repeat what was there stated but I refer to it as the meeting forms an important stage in the history of this matter. The important outcome of that meeting was that the United States understood and acknowledged Australia's concern that there should be prior consultations before anti-trust enforcement action affecting its interests was taken. It accepted the need for those consultations to take place in the event of any future anti-trust enforcement action. At the same time both governments recognised the problem of private treble damages suits. The United States Government agreed to prepare a draft text on that subject for our consideration. We have not, as yet, received that draft text. I do not say this by way of any criticism of the United States Government. There has been a new Administration. Perhaps, more fundamentally, there are inherent difficulties in drafting any satisfactory provisions adequately protective of foreign government interests given the present United States law relating to private treble damages.
General Activities Involving the Commonwealth Government

There has been certain activity in the United States Congress in the area of international anti-trust. It is true that some of this stems from concerns within the United States that its anti-trust laws constitute some impediment to United States exports. But there is another strand of thinking which recognises that in the long run accommodation to the interests of foreign governments and a full respect for their sovereignty will in truth enhance the efficacy of its anti-trust laws and the control of restrictive business practices generally. During the last session of the Congress before the elections, a Bill was introduced into the Senate, sponsored by Senator Mathias, which would have the effect of setting up a commission to study international aspects of United States anti-trust laws. In a letter of 16 November 1979 to Senator Mathias, the Commonwealth Government expressed its support for the Bill.

A further Bill in similar terms has been introduced during the present session of Congress. On 6 May 1981, the Australian Embassy in Washington presented a Note to the United States Department of State expressing its support for the establishment of the proposed commission and asking that its views be passed to the Senate Judiciary Committee. The Commission, as proposed by the Bill, would comprise members of the United States Executive, the Congress and private enterprise. As proposed, it would be chaired by the Vice-President of the United States. It would examine, among other things, the effect of the application of United States anti-trust laws on United States relations with other countries and, further, the jurisdiction and scope of the application of those laws to foreign conduct and foreign parties. At the same time a task force of the American Bar Association has examined the international implications of United States anti-trust enforcement and has put forward recommendations, not yet endorsed, but which would involve prior consultation with foreign governments in certain circumstances.

There has also been activity from a different angle at the multilateral level. Basic to the control of restrictive business practices is the collection of documents and information relating to them. At the present time a Working Party of the Committee on Restrictive Business Practices of the OECD is engaged in the important task of reporting on jurisdictional obstacles to the collection of information abroad necessary for the control of restrictive business practices. It has also been asked to look specifically into the consequences of the effects doctrine of jurisdiction in this regard. The Working Party is chaired by the Federal Republic of Germany and is attended by the United Kingdom and a large number of other European countries, Canada, Japan and the United States. A senior official from my Department has attended meetings of this Working Party held in March, June and November 1980 and in January and March 1981. We are not approaching the problem in any negative sense but I think that other countries will allow that we have assisted in identifying the jurisdictional problems behind the enactment of prohibitory legislation.
The Present Position

Stated broadly, we are thus in this position. The United States understands, and I believe accepts, that governmental action on its part by way of anti-trust enforcement which impinges upon our laws and policies should be preceded by consultations. Our ultimate objective remains. That is, to establish a detailed mechanism by which inter-governmental consultations can take place in advance. But that is not possible if any agreement arising out of such consultations can be undermined by private anti-trust proceedings of the kind which I have described. We will continue our endeavours to overcome this problem.

An investigation by the Department of Justice into an alleged violation of its anti-trust laws in relation to shipping between Australia, New Zealand and the United States, is proceeding. There are various proceedings between the Conferences and the United States Department of Justice which we are keeping under careful review. Certain facts disclosed by the United States Department of Justice in the course of answering interrogatories in those proceedings have led Australia to deliver a Note to the United States Government seeking consultations on the matters arising out of the answers. We would expect the United States Government to respond positively to this request in the spirit of the arrangements reached at my discussions with the former United States Attorney-General.

There is also a private treble damages suit which appears to be connected with the subject of the Pacific Shipping investigation. It would be premature to comment upon whether those proceedings involve Australia's sovereignty or bear upon its national interests. We are keeping those proceedings under careful review. At the same time, a private action has been instituted in the United States by the Conservation Council of Western Australia against Alcoa and Reynolds. A motion by the defendants to strike out that complaint is presently before the court and this week I released a copy of the amicus curiae brief filed by the Commonwealth Government in those proceedings.
The Present Bill

It is, in the Government's view, imperative that Australia's legislation should give the utmost protection to our laws and policies and hence the need for the present Bill. The Government is introducing the present measure with a view to it being debated at a subsequent sitting of the Parliament. It will itself give close consideration in the interval to the form of the legislation and will, of course, pay close attention in the meantime to the current proceedings and developments in the United States. The effect of the Bill is to amend the Foreign Anti-trust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act so that where the order has been made under that Act prohibiting the enforcement of a foreign anti-trust judgment, an Australian defendant-described in the Bill as a prescribed person-may take proceedings to recover from the foreign plaintiff any amount which has been recovered under that foreign anti-trust judgment.

The United Kingdom enacted similar legislation in March 1980-the United Kingdom's Protection of Trading Interests Act. The purpose of that legislation was the same. The United Kingdom legislation provides for the recovery back of the punitive-non-compensatory-part of any multiple damages. We have not adopted this option. The Bill is consistent with the present provisions of the Foreign Anti-trust Judgments (Restriction of Enforcement) Act which provides for an order prohibiting the whole of the judgment in Australia. It is to be noted that, in any event, we consider that the principle involved is not directed to multiple damages suits as such but multiple damages suits combined with extra-territorial jurisdiction. It will also be observed that the Attorney-General may, on making such an order, specify that portion of the amount of the judgment may be recoverable in Australia and there is provision in the Bill precluding the recovery back in respect of amounts allowed by the order to be recovered in Australia.

I now turn to the details of the Bill. Clause 3 of the Bill extends the operation of the Act to the external Territories. In addition, it provides a specific interpretation section of general application in the Act. The clause includes a definition of related company by reference to the definition of that item in the Australian Capital Territory Companies Ordinance 1962. That definition is consistent with the definition contained in the Companies Act 1981, which was passed earlier this sittings. Clause 4 repeals certain definitions of words and expressions contained in sub-section 3 (1) of the principal Act. It also inserts a new sub-section 3 (2A) which restricts the right of the Attorney-General to make an order under sub-sections 3 (2) (c) or (d) where the proceedings leading to the foreign judgment relates to conduct which took place in the jurisdiction where the foreign judgment was given.

Clause 5 creates the right of recovery back where a foreign judgment, to which an order has been made by the Attorney-General under sub-sections 3 (2) (c) or (d) of the principal Act, has been enforced against an Australian defendant outside of Australia. Under new sub-section 4 (1), as provided in clause 5, where the order has been made under sub-section 3 (2) (c), the amount of recovery back allowable is the whole amount paid as a result of the enforcement outside of Australia. New sub-sections 4 (2) and (3) operate where an order has been made under sub-section 3 (2) (d) allowing the foreign plaintiff to enforce his foreign judgment to the extent specified in the order. Sub-section 4 (2) provides for recovery back in the situation where there has been no previous Australian or any overseas enforcement has not exceeded the reduced amount in which case the recovery back is limited to the amount by which the enforcement exceeds the reduced amount. Sub-section 4 (3) provides for the situation where the previous enforcement of the judgment had already exceeded that reduced amount, in which case the amount that can be recovered back under a later foreign enforcement is the amount in excess of the reduced amount. Sub-section 4 (4) describes the prescribed persons who are able to take advantage of the cause of action being created by sub-sections 4 (1), (2) and (3). These are Australian citizens, companies incorporated or deemed incorporated under a law of a State or Territory or governments or governmental authorities.

In relation to bodies corporate, sub-section 4 (5) allows bodies corporate related to the body corporate mentioned in sub-section 4 (4) to have the same right of recovery back as is available to the body corporate mentioned in sub-section 4 (4). Sub-section 4 (6) provides that where there is more than one prescribed person with the right to recovery back, any one of those prescribed persons may institute proceedings for recovery back. Sub-section 4 (7) provides that where a number of prescribed persons bring an action in respect of a cause of action arising under sub-sections 4 (1), (2) and (3) and the defendant to those proceedings has been adjudged liable to pay an amount to those prescribed persons, then the defendant will be under no further liability in relation to those proceedings. Sub-sections 4 (8), (9) and (10) confer jurisdiction on the Federal Court of Australia to hear and determine proceedings arising under sub-sections 4 (1), (2) and (3). Sub-section 4 (11) provides a limitation period for the institution of proceedings for the recovery back provided by the Bill. In relation to each overseas enforcement of the foreign judgment that limitation period is three years from the date of the overseas enforcement.

Clause 6 provides a new section 5 (1) which allows for the enforcement of a judgment under that Bill in a foreign country which has a law corresponding to that contained in the Bill where a reciprocity agreement has been entered into between Australia and that other country. Sub-section 5 (2) provides that the enforcement of a judgment of a foreign country under a corresponding law to that contained in the Bill will only be allowed in Australia where the Attorney-General has, by order in writing, declared that judgment to be enforceable in Australia. Sub-section 5 (4) provides that an order under sub-section 5 (2) shall, as is the case with orders under the Act generally, be laid before each House of the Parliament. Sub-section 5 (5) provides that where an order has been laid down before each House of the Parliament and neither House has within 15 sitting days passed a resolution disapproving the order, a copy of the order shall be published in the Gazette and the order becomes effective from the date of publication. Sub-section 5 (6) provides that where an order under sub-section 5 (2) is in force, a judgment, or a certified copy, may be filed in the Federal Court after which it may be enforced as if it was a final judgment of the Federal Court.
Conclusion
Mr President, I conclude by a quotation from an address on this subject given by a former United States Attorney-General, Mr Griffin Bell, on 8 August 1977. He said:

Comity is a very small word that stands for a very large principle. Comity is a way of saying fair play-that each of two parties will yield to the one which has interests that are clearly paramount. It is a word signifying a concern for common decency in conduct towards others. Where conflicts arise between sovereigns, the sovereigns have an obligation to resolve the conflict with restraint, co-operation and good will. That is the essence of comity . . .

Mr President, I believe-the Government believes-in every word of that. In that statement lies the solution of our differences. In the meantime, I introduce this measure. It is defensive; it is necessary. I regret the need for it. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to make provision with respect of offences connected with the counterfeiting of money or of certain kinds of securities and other activities injurious to Australian currency, and for related purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will update and revise all existing Australian law relating to the counterfeiting of currency-both domestic and foreign-and Commonwealth and foreign Government bonds and other forms of securities. It will also create offences in relation to reproduction of Australian paper money and prescribed securities. This legislation, when in operation, will also enable Australia to accede to the International Convention for the Suppression of Counterfeiting Currency, which was opened for signature at Geneva on 20 April 1929.

The International Convention was made under the auspices of the Council of the League of Nations at Geneva in 1929. By a resolution of the United Nations General Assembly in November 1963 any member of that body may accede to the Convention. In all some 70 countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, France, West Germany and Switzerland, are now bound by the Convention. Australia has been unable to accede to the Convention because of hitherto inadequate legislation which has not enabled Australia to reciprocate the protection afforded to Australian currency by a large number of member countries of the United Nations.

The Convention seeks to ensure the prevention and punishment of offences relating to the counterfeiting of currency wherever those offences may be committed. The Convention is aimed particularly at counterfeiting operations involving more than one country; suppression of operations of this nature could, in the absence of international agreement, be hindered by national boundaries. Under the Convention, each state party undertakes to provide appropriate protection against the counterfeiting of domestic and foreign currency. Before becoming a party to the Convention, each party must ensure that its legislation and its administrative organisation conform with the rules of the Convention.

There are significant inadequacies in present Commonwealth and State law dealing with counterfeiting of currencies, both Australian and foreign. It would not be appropriate to describe these inadequacies in detail but, by way of example, I refer to Part IV of the Crimes Act 1914 dealing with counterfeiting of coins. The prohibition on counterfeiting of current coin is limited to coins that have been coined in a mint in any part of the Queen's dominions or that are lawfully current in any part of the Queen's dominions. These provisions would obviously not fulfil the obligations arising under the Convention.

National legislation concerning the counterfeiting of government securities was urged in a resolution passed in 1969 in Mexico City at the 5th Conference of the International Criminal Police Organization-Interpol. The Government sees merit in this recommendation and accordingly counterfeiting of both foreign and domestic government bonds and other securities, while not covered by the Convention, are dealt with in the present Bill. Australian experience has disclosed weaknesses in the laws relating to the reproduction of coins of numismatic interest-for example-in relation to the reproduction of the Spanish coins known as 'Holey Dollars'-and we consider that the opportunity should be taken to deal with these problems in the legislation now introduced.

Mr President, there can be few more important objects of legislation than protection of the currency of the nation. This is the primary purpose of the present Bill. Until now, law enforcement bodies dealing with currency frauds have had to apply piecemeal pieces of legislation, both Commonwealth and State; these have not given full satisfactory protection to Australian currency and often no protection at all to the currencies of other nations. Adequate protection will now be provided by one comprehensive piece of legislation.

Because the Bill will affect all sections of the community, the Government proposes that the Bill should lie before the Parliament until the Budget session to enable it to be adequately studied and interested parties to supply comments, if they so wish. It is also the Government's intention that the legislation will not be brought into force until the expiration of at least three months after passage. This will allow the community to become acquainted with its terms and persons in possession of articles contravening its provisions to surrender them to the authorities. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: LANDS ACQUISITION (NORTHERN TERRITORY PASTORAL LEASES) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is to set aside any doubt as to the Commonwealth's right to title and possession of the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases in the Northern Territory. These properties were acquired by compulsory process under the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 on 23 June 1978. The chief provisions of the Bill are:

(a) Clause 4 is designed to put beyond any legal doubt that the Mudginberri and Munmarlary leases are vested in the Commonwealth and that the Commonwealth is entitled to immediate possession of the lands.
(b) Clause 10 preserves the right of the former lessees to claim compensation for interests in the land under the same terms as when land is acquired under the Lands Acquisition Act 1955.
(c) Clause 14 is intended to ensure that this Act does not affect the rights of the former lessees to contest the validity of the original acquisition in 1978.
(d) Other clauses are of a machinery nature and are generally self-explanatory.

Leasehold interests in the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases were, prior to 1978, vested in two companies. In 1977 the Government adopted the recommendation of the Fox Report on the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry that the lands be included in the proposed Kakadu National Park. At that time it was also recognised that the lands could become the subject of Aboriginal land claims. Honourable senators will be aware that a claim is, in fact, currently under consideration by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, in relation to lands in the Alligator Rivers, Stage II region which incorporates the Mudginberri and Munmarlary leases.

The Commonwealth offered in early 1978 to acquire the leases but it was not possible to reach agreement on the amount of compensation. The leases were compulsorily acquired on 23 June 1978, however the companies holding the leases have contested the validity of that acquisition and further attempts to reach a voluntary settlement have so far failed. So long as these two leases are held, or appear to be held, by the companies, the Government is inhibited in giving effect to policies which relate to future activities in the Alligator Rivers Region.

The former lessees have instituted proceedings in the Supreme Court in the Northern Territory to challenge the validity of the Commonwealth's acquisition of the leases. The Bill now before honourable senators would give the Commonwealth title and right to immediate occupation of the leases but at the same time ensure that the rights of the former lessees to continue to contest the validity of the original acquisition is in no way affected. The Bill also provides for any compensation to persons who had interests in the acquired lands to be paid on just terms.

Honourable senators will appreciate that the determination of validity of the original acquisition as well as negotiations on compensation could be very protracted issues. It is the view of the Government that these matters should not prejudice or delay the determination of the Aboriginal land claim in the Alligator Rivers Region which is required in order that Government policies relating to establishment of the Kakadu National Park and mineral development can be implemented. The Government has therefore decided that it is appropriate that legislation be passed to ensure the Commonwealth's right to title and immediate possession of the Mudginberri and Munmarlary pastoral leases. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to the Government's decision to provide bounty assistance to the production in Australia of certain yarns. The decision to adopt this form of assistance follows the Government's consideration of the recommendations by the Industries Assistance Commission contained in its report No. 240 of 30 April 1980 entitled 'Textiles, Clothing and Footwear'.

This bounty proposal is part of the Government's broader program designed to encourage the development of a more efficient industry structure for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. It will also provide substantial benefits for industries using bountiable yarns in manufacturing textiles or textile products. User industries will benefit from reduced costs of material inputs and greater flexibility of sourcing. To this end the proposal is in agreement with the broad objectives of the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendation. The Bill provides for the bounty to be payable to producers of most yarns at rates calculated as specified percentages of the value added to the yarns, on a factory cost basis, in their production. The yarns eligible for the bounty are specified in clause 2 of the Bill and the rates of bounty proposed for each type of yarn are specified in clause 6 of the Bill.

The Government in August last year established the bounty rate for several yarn types, including yarns spun on the cotton system, at 33 per cent. Following extensive discussions with industry sectors, and based on an assessment of up to date information, it has become apparent that assistance for cotton system spun yarns at this level would be likely to result in a degree of disruption that could not have been foreseen at the time the Government took its original decision, particularly in some regional locations. For this reason the Government has decided to set the bounty rate for these products at 43 per cent.

From 1 January 1982 imported yarns similar to the bountiable yarns will be quota free and subject only to minimum rates of duty. Wool carpet yarns and yarns for handcrafting and sewing thread will not be eligible for the bounty. Sewing threads and hand craft yarns are to be assisted by import duties from 1 January 1982. The processes and expenditures eligible for bounty are specified in clauses 2 and 3 of the Bill. In general the 'additional value' provision excludes materials such as fibres and polymers, dyes, yarn additives and some packaging materials. It also excludes other costs such as general administration, selling and distribution.

The bounty scheme is to operate for a period of seven years from 1 January 1982, and it is estimated that bounty payments during that period will be $47m for 1981-82 and $71m per annum thereafter. Bounty eligibility will be restricted to yarns produced in premises registered under this Act and used in registered textile factories. Textile factories will be treated as registered for the purposes of the bounty scheme if used for the commercial manufacture of textile products and if registered as a factory under a State or internal Territory law. In the case of internal Territories which do not have laws suitable for these purposes, buildings used for the commercial manufacture of textile products and approved by the Comptroller-General of Customs will be recognised as registered factories. The Government expects that the assistance proposed by this Bill will encourage further improvements in the efficiency of this industry, reductions in cost, and responsiveness to changing consumer needs. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 1.1 to 2.15 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GAMING AND LIQUOR AUTHORITY BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, we have already had a second reading debate on the Australian Capital Territory Gaming and Liquor Authority Bill. We had it cognately with the debate on another Bill and it remains only to put the question, unless the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) is prepared to give us some more reasonable reply than he offered last night.
—Senator Evans, do you have an amendment to move?
—Mr President, I thought the amendment had been moved. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted to provide that the dispersal of funds raised by the Authority, other than those committed to the racing industry, will be in accordance with determinations of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly but limited to purposes associated with sport, recreation, culture, welfare and community related activities in the Australian Capital Territory'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to Senator Evans that I covered this matter quite adequately during the debate last night. I have nothing further to add to my remarks then.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition proposes to move an amendment to the Bill in respect of clause 5. It concerns the composition of the Gaming and Liquor Authority. Honourable senators will have noticed that the new Authority is proposed to consist of five members including a chairman and a deputy chairman with no specific membership qualifications being prescribed. No doubt honourable senators, with the close attention they have given to this measure, will have noticed also that the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) in his second reading speech indicated that as a practical matter he would, because of the important community implications of the Authority's activities, include a member of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly and a legal practitioner. It is the view of the Opposition that Mr Hodgman's promises in this respect would be a little more satisfactorily embalmed for posterity were they to have statutory force. It is our proposition that there ought to be not just one but two members of the Authority who are persons nominated by the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. The amendment proposed by the Opposition to clause 5 is to ensure that result insofar as it proposes that sub-clause (1) of clause 5 be left out and in its place the words included in the amendment be inserted. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page (2), clause 5, sub-clause (1), line 34, leave out the sub-clause, insert the following sub-clause:

'(1) The Authority shall consist of 3 members appointed by the Minister and 2 Members who are members of, and nominated by, the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly constituted by the House of Assembly Ordinance 1936 of the Australian Capital Territory as amended.'.
I commend that amendment to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendment. The amendment is unacceptable for two reasons. Firstly, it reduces the size of the Authority from five members to three. The Government believes that an Authority comprised of three part time members would be unable to carry out satisfactorily the work load associated with the running of the Australian Capital Territory Totalisator Agency Board, liquor licensing and poker machine control. The new Authority will carry out a wide range of functions and will be required to act in a quasi-judicial role in relation to both liquor and poker machine matters. It will have a wide range of administrative functions as well and will be responsible for significant staffing and funding matters. Secondly the amendment is unacceptable on the ground that it would require that two of the members of the Authority be nominated by the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly; that is, out of those three members two would be from the House of Assembly. Senator Evans pointed out that in the second reading speech of the Minister for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) the Minister said that out of five members to be appointed one would be from the House of Assembly and the other a legal practitioner. The appointment of one member from the Assembly is consistent with the present appointment made to the Australian Capital Territory Liquor Licensing Board and the Poker Machine Licensing Board. Only one member of those Boards is a member of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. Clearly, if the Government were to allow the Authority to be comprised of only three members, two of whom would come from the House of Assembly, it would lead to a situation in which the House of Assembly would in effect exercise executive function. Such functions are clearly beyond the purely advisory role which the House of Assembly presently enjoys. Of course, that is consistent with the argument in relation to the second reading amendment moved by Senator Evans last night. I am sure that honourable senators will recall the referendum held in the Australian Capital Territory in 1978 when residents decisively rejected a proposal that the House of Assembly be given either legislative or executive powers.

—The response of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) seems to have been founded on a quite bizarre misapprehension as to what in fact is being proposed by the Opposition. It is no part of our intention to reduce the total membership of the Authority from five to three. If the Minister will perhaps look again at the text of the Opposition amendment he will see that we proposed that the Authority should consist of three members appointed by the Minister and two members who are nominated by and members of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly. I appreciate that the Minister, in his previous incarnation, was an accountant and accordingly cannot entirely be relied upon to get his arithmetic completely straight, but I would have thought that it would not be beyond the wit or resources even of a front bench member of the present Fraser Administration to be able to add up three and two and reach the conclusion that the total is, in fact, five! There is no question of executive functions being superseded by Australian Capital Territory nominees swamping the membership of the Authority in question. Perhaps the Minister could, with this important measure, take another gulp at answering the Opposition's objection and indicate to us how his objections stand up if that particular premise on which his reply was founded is in fact altered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems as though there may have been some variation between the amendment now mentioned and the one in the Government's possession last night. I apologise for that if there has been some problem. I look now at the copy of the amendment circulated and I see the point that Senator Evans made. Notwithstanding that aspect, I think the earlier argument I put in connection with consistency in the Australian Capital Territory is relevant and my argument stands.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1981INCOME TAX (DIVERTED INCOME) BILL 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of the first reading of the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill to deal with a matter, I believe, of some seriousness. As it relates to a degree to my shadow portfolio of electoral matters, I felt the need to raise this matter at this time. I must admit that, when I was given the responsibility to speak on electoral matters on behalf of my party, I did not at that stage consider that my jurisdiction extended beyond rather radical changes in the Commonwealth Electoral Act and electoral procedures in our country. But, having had some matters brought to my attention as a result of two deputations by constituents, there is a matter I wish to raise now because it shows that there are wider implications in respect of matters conducted by the Australian Electoral Office.

SPEECH.PARA: Several weeks ago, some constituents interviewed me about what appeared to be a serious conspiracy against certain Australian Labor Party members in the leadership of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union. At first glance, these matters appeared to be related only to the matters they had raised with me. Subsequently, further information came into my possession. The issues involve an apparent attempt to set up the present officials of that union-the President and Secretary-and a manipulation of postal ballots in respect of that union which are conducted by the Australian Electoral Officer in New South Wales. I am concerned because these allegations suggest grave improprieties by certain law officers and grave irregularities by one or two persons in the post office. The allegations confirm that attempts are being made by unscrupulous persons to unduly influence ballot results in certain selected trade union elections.

I am concerned too at suggestions which show that there is a concerted move by some elements in New South Wales to provide money and resources to undermine the leadership in a wide variety of union ballots taking place this year. This interference affects the proper functioning of unions not only in my own State but also in the State of Victoria. I have sought political and legal advice about the documents which I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard. I have had discussions with the officers concerned and, consequently, I believe there are compelling reasons for me to raise with the appropriate Minister the possibility of an inquiry into the seriousness of the matters placed before me by the constituents. These matters fall into several categories. They are, firstly, a conspiracy against officers of a union; secondly, interference in Commonwealth electoral ballots for union elections; thirdly, the availability of large sums of money to defeat sitting union officials; and, fourthly, interference in internal affairs of selected unions by unauthorised persons. I wish now to elaborate. I was handed a photostated leaflet headed 'Attention: Telecom Members'. I seek leave to have this document incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ATTENTION: TELECOM MEMBERS

The documents you will find attached to this covering note are of grave concern to our Union. The two documents, one an affidavit from the Vice President of our Union, Frank King, and an 'advising' outlining a process of obstructing the Union officers, demonstrates clearly that there is a substantial plot to undermine the effectiveness of your Union.

The tragedy of this situation is that it comes at a time when the officers of the Union are determined to oppose in the strongest way possible the outrageous cuts initiated by the Fraser 'Razor Gang'.
We do not intend to summarise these two crucial documents. The facts stand for themselves. We urge you to read these documents and make up your own mind.
To us what is contained in these documents represents a most serious undermining of Union leaders that we have heard of in many years and a complete breach of ethical behaviour.

A campaign of obstruction designed to reduce the effectiveness of leaders of the Union bears close resemblance to CIA activities in Chile and other countries. All fair minded unionists cannot tolerate them.
We call upon you to join with us in demanding that outside forces leave our Union alone, and that the few individuals who are obstructing our leaders immediately cease this anti Union behaviour.
Issued: On behalf of the Telecom Action Labor Committee. HANDS OFF THE EFFECTIVE HAWKINS/BATESE LEADERSHIP

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall just briefly refer to the documents handed to me which include an affidavit from the Vice-President of this union and an advising by two legal officers. The legal advisings show a process by which union officials can be undermined and how the union can be effectively undermined as well. The document reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy of this situation is that it comes at a time when the officers of the Union are determined to oppose in the strongest way possible the outrageous cuts initiated by the Fraser 'Razor Gang'.

This leaflet handed to me by the constituents has attached to it two legal advisings and the affidavit which is signed by the union official concerned, Mr Frank King of 34 Salsoe Street, Mayfield, New South Wales. In the affidavit, he states:
I, Frank King of 34 Salsoe Street, Mayfield in the State of New South Wales, Union Officer, being duly sworn make oath and say as follows:
1. In late 1979 I, together with Joe Kanan, Paul Watson, Barry Polson and John Wilson had an appointment to meet Mr Brian Wallace, Solicitor partner in McClellands solicitors.

I say at this point that, whilst that organisation has that name, in no way am I suggesting any impropriety on behalf of the former member of this place or, also, his subsequent partner, Mr Landa. The affidavit continues:
2. This meeting arose out of charges that had been laid against Noel Battese and Merv Hawkins alleging misuse of Union funds.
3. At that meeting I asked Mr Wallace, the Union Solicitor whether it was possible to use those charges that had been laid to have Mr Hawkins and Mr Battese removed from Office.

The affidavit went on. That statement sets out the means and the processes by which Mr Hawkins, the Secretary of the union, will be given such a work load that it will be impossible for him to carry out that work load and make decisions of the union and, as a consequence, charges would be laid against him for dereliction of duty. What is particularly disturbing is that Mr Wallace, the law officer concerned, is, in fact, the union's solicitor. It would appear on the basis of this affidavit and the subsequent advising that he did conspire with a section of the union to undermine and thus cause charges to be laid against the State Secretary of that union which means, of course, that there is a conflict of duty. Subsequently, Mr Hawkins, who is a member of my party's administrative committee in New South Wales, was charged along the lines I have referred to.

Coupled with this affidavit and its grave implications is a legal advising by Mr Garry Johnson, barrister, obtained by Mr Wallace and dated, I believe, either 17 January 1980 or 17 December 1980. As I have said, coupled with this affidavit and its grave implications is a legal advising setting out the charges in the form in which action was subsequently taken. It shows not only that Mr Johnson was briefed to frame Mr Hawkins in the document but also that he prepared the charges. Of course, both these gentlemen are legally involved in this matter. I understand that the matter has been brought to the attention of the Law Society of New South Wales. The fact that they, as official union solicitors, set out to advise a small opposition group in the union shows the extent to which actions can be taken to undermine the effectiveness of a particular union and also to cause grave difficulties for an elected official. AFFIDAVIT

(vii) The State Executive then has the power to hear and determine the matters: Rule 56 (iii).

6 It seems to me that Hawkins activity and duties comes within the following Rules:
(i) Keep a correct account of all money's received and expended: Rule 59.
(ii) Not to appropriate the funds of the Union for any purpose except in accordance with Rules, Resolutions and minutes: Rule 59.
(iii) Produce Bank passbook for inspection at State Executive meetings when requested: Rule 59.
(iv) He shall keep a separate account for money's owing to Head Office: Rule 59 and Rule 17.
(v) He shall have books ready to hand over to Branch when requested: Rule 59.
(vi) He shall act according to instructions of State Executive Rule 59.
(vii) He shall answer all correspondence and answer such questions etc: Rule 59.
(viii) Keep memo book and insert date of postage: Rule 59.
(ixx) Enter in account book detailed account of money's received and expended: Rule 59.
(xx) He shall be responsible for all funds and property of Branch: Rule 59.
(xxi) He shall act as directed by State Executive: Rule 59.
7 I have not been briefed fully with the information concerning the above duties. However, it seems to me the procedure should be adopted:

(i) A member of the Union should lay charges against Hawkins. The charges should be in the form as per attached draft. The person laying the charges should probably be a member of the State Executive and as such he will not be able to participate in any way with events leading up to the hearing nor the voting itself.
(ii) The matter should come before the State Executive and the procedure as outlined above should be adhered to strictly.
DRAFT OF CHARGES
Preferred against Merv Hawkins
Letter to be sent to Hawkins as Secretary/Treasurer in the following terms
