I have also sent copies of this correspondence to the President of the New South Wales Branch of the Union and the Assistant Secretary.
Yours faithfully,
DRAFT CIRCULAR TO MEMBERS
Dear member;
This circular is sent to you as a member of the N.S.W. Branch of the APTU so that you are aware, as you are entitled to be, of the financial position of the N.S.W. Branch of your Union.

On 3 October 1980, a firm of Chartered Accountants on instructions from the Federal Executive of the Union prepared and submitted a Report on the financial operation of the NSW Branch. Specific mention was made of the period Oct (1978)-November (1979) before the last State Executive elections.
If the facts contained in this report are correct (and there is no reason to doubt the integrity of those investigating) it shows that the current leadership of the NSW Branch have a lot to answer.

To give just three (3) examples. The summary of the findings of the Chartered Accounts was ''that Generally the Standard of Record keeping maintained by the New South Wales branch is not at the level we consider adequate for an operation with an annual turnover approximately $1 million'' and ''we have observed many cases of expenditure incurred without documentary evidence being present in the files.'' Further ''we feel that the apparently casual way payments are made may not be unconnected with the growth in expenses. Because of the quality of the Branch's Records, we feel it is difficult to be certain that all money has been correctly and productively spent for the benefit of the membership as a whole.''
Concerning specific examples you should be aware that:
(i) That a computer purchased in May 1977 for $62,409 as at Oct 1980 was not operational and providing no benefits at all to Union members.
(ii) Travelling expenses reimbursed to President Batesse when Federal Executive resolved no expenses to be reimbursed.
(iii) Sub-standard keeping of important necessary accounts.
(iv) Use of election funds to cover shortfalls in postage fund.
(v) Deficiencies in the expenditure records of the union.
(vi) Inadequate records for loss of time and travelling expenses.
(vii) Payments of fire insurance premiums some 40 per cent above average quotes.
(viii) Breaches of the Union Rules.
(iv) Payments to individuals and companies allegedly doing work for the Union who cannot be contacted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In these documents is a circular drawn up by Mr Johnson to be sent to all members of the union in order to denigrate the elected Secretary of the union. The tragic part of this incident is that the events predicted in the original documents did, in fact, take place and charges were laid against Mr Hawkins and Mr Battese. They were charged before their peers in the State branch and the charges were later dropped. They were not proceeded with at that level because another union ballot took place which, to some extent, altered the balance of power in that union.

SPEECH.PARA: However, similar charges were laid at the federal level. I am informed that charges against the State President, Mr Battese, and the State Secretary, Mr Hawkins, were dealt with at a meeting of the federal executive of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union. I am happy to advise the Senate that this body, under the leadership of a colleague and friend of mine, Mr George Slater, did not, I believe, on the basis of the matters I have raised, proceed to deal with the defendants by way of suspension or expulsion. I am concerned that, on prima facie evidence, Mr Wallace and Mr Johnson did conspire with and give advice to a dissident element in the union to discredit and to expel two properly elected officials.

Let me deal with some of the other grave irregularities that seem to have occurred in this union's elections which are, after all, conducted by the Australian Electoral Office. I do so because I think we have to recognise that, in the changed world of today, we need to have some regard to how we can tighten up the procedures in respect of Commonwealth electoral ballots. I have been advised that in respect of an election conducted by the Australian Electoral Officer for positions in the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union, both Federally and in New South Wales, there occurred an example of how easy it is for unscrupulous persons to interfere seriously with a postal ballot. The ballot I am referring to was conducted during September 1979. In this instance it occurred at a medium sized post office outside the Sydney metropolitan area. It involved the illegal seizure of some 380 ballot papers by an official of the New South Wales branch of the union and a candidate who at this stage I would prefer to leave unnamed. When ballot papers are addressed to each financial member and are despatched by the Commonwealth Electoral Office they inevitably arrive at the appropriate suburban or country post offices for distribution to the members at their various addresses. What then happened in this case was that the official and the candidate took steps to get into the post office and take out the 380 envelopes containing ballot papers. They then proceeded to open them and, in the presence of others, filled them in to suit this person's candidacy. I am informed that through this gross interference they were able to alter the overall result of that union election. Consequently, these matters were raised at a meeting of that union and the resolution passed at that meeting states in part:

That this general meeting wishes to express its outrage at the recent physical assault carried out on NSW ALP member, Peter Baldwin. We also wish to express our disquiet regarding rumours circulating that criminal elements may have succeeded in infiltrating sections of the Labor Party in this State and that these criminal elements may have utilised funds gained from their illegal activities in order to attempt to gain influence in or control of this union.

We therefore request the state secretary to contact the Australian Labor Party to ask them to conduct an investigation into any campaign funds which have been donated to assist any member of this union during the last APTU state and federal elections, bearing in mind that . . . NSW Union organiser for the APTU stated that he had in fact received a large sum of money from a member of Parliament for this very purpose.

After examining this matter further I am satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that it is possible-indeed probable-that persons are able to interfere seriously in such union elections. It is possible to do it here-it has been done-and it is possible to do it elsewhere. I remind the Senate that in the computer age it is now possible for a well-organised group to get a computer print-out of eligible voters in a union election broken down on a locality basis or even, in built-up areas, on a street-by-street basis. That group can then steal ballot papers from letter boxes, particularly in circumstances where husband and wives are at work, and so unduly affect the result of a union election.

One cannot say that these matters have very little relevance because in a particular case involving another union, in a judgment handed down in 1974 by Justices Joske, Nimmo and Sweeney which dealt with certain ballot papers and envelopes which were posted to a number of people in Sydney, Justice Joske said:

In these cases we are satisfied that the offences have been proved beyond reasonable doubt. In each case the defendant visited the home of a member of his union on the day ballot papers for an election of officers of his union could be expected to be received by those members and by various subterfuges he took possession of the mail containing the ballot papers forwarded to those members by the Commonwealth Electoral Office. The defendant was one of a team of candidates opposing the officers in the election. He thus obtained possession of the ballot papers without lawful authority or excuse. His conduct not only deprived the member of his vote but was a fraudulent interference in the election.

Section 171 of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act makes procedures available for the conduct of union ballots and specifically lays down that no person has the right to collect, personate another person or in any way get possession of a ballot paper other than his own. Of course there are other ways in which postal ballots conducted by the Commonwealth Electoral Office can be corrupted. Some ballot papers in my State are returned undelivered-that is, in 'return to sender' envelopes-to the Darlinghurst Post Office in Sydney. I ask: Is there watertight security as far as these 'return to sender' envelopes are concerned because they contain ballot papers? In this period of great mobility of the work force, as well as the difficulties that ordinary citizens have in rented premises, there is a larger than normal number of 'return to sender' envelopes in every union ballot conducted. Consequently, there needs to be a tightening up of the procedures involving these envelopes. There are also those letters returned to the dead letter offices in each of the capital cities.

Most disturbing of all is what some persons can do, and have done, in other union elections conducted by the Commonwealth Electoral Office. I believe there is a case for tightening up the conduct of union ballots by the Commonwealth Electoral Office. I assert that there are insufficient safeguards and electoral officers should be directed to ensure that no person other than the legitimate voter votes in union elections. This would involve greater supervision in the distribution of ballot papers to voters and a demand that a certificate be signed by each postmaster concerned stating that ballot papers were duly delivered to the voters and that responsible officers were stationed specifically at the return to sender office and the dead letter office in the respective States. In making these charges I do not want it to be suggested that I believe that employees of Australia Post, perhaps with one or two exceptions, have acted improperly or corruptly in these matters but I do believe a case can be made out that there was some interference in the elections to which I have referred.

I now wish to refer to more recent ballots and other corrupt practices that have been brought to my notice I refer to ballots conducted in Victoria by the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, and the Australian Railways Union's current ballot for officers and to a pending ballot in the New South Wales branch of the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union. I would be the first to acknowledge the need for rank and file members to participate in union affairs. I recognise that apathy is not a good thing for the trade union movement. Members should at all times be encourged to take an active interest in union affairs and to stand for office if they are not satisfied with the conduct of their union.

However, I regret that there are several disabilities in regard to all of these matters particularly as they relate to standing for office in a union. The particular disadvantage which rank and file unionists have is the inability to raise sufficient funds to post to each voter information in support of their own candidacy. A disquieting feature is the apparent ease with which some candidates are able to get access to large sums of money to push their candidacies. This is of particular concern as large amounts of funds have been shown to be readily available for certain types of candidates in selected unions. I refer to the APTU and a resolution carried by that union at its July meeting. It was mentioned that a sum of $20,000 was available for a ballot. An amount of $20,000 was being made available to a rebel group which lacked any basic rank and file support to raise those sorts of funds. Similarly, in the recent AMSWU Victorian ballot involving the challenge to Mr Jim Roulston, a very well respected official of that union and Federal Vice-President of my party, and Mr Halfpenny, a sum of $10,000 was made available from certain quarters to the challengers in that ballot. I understand that another $10,000 was made available to challengers in the Australian Railways Union election in Victoria and it is claimed that this money is coming from certain circles in New South Wales.

In regard to the ballot taking place for the current union elections of the liquor trades union, I accept that there is a measure of discontent by the rank and file of this union because of recent award variations. This has led to some nominations against the sitting officials of that union. However, the relevant fact is that more than 40,000 members of this union are eligible to vote, so the rank and file is up for approximately $10,000 in printing and postage costs just to place themselves before each person who has a right to record a vote. That means that a large sum of money is essential and they need to have access to nominal rolls and printed material. It has been suggested to me that a post-out to every member of that union has occurred. The question must therefore be asked: Where does the $10,000 come from? Did the rank and file contribute to those funds? I have information in my possession which suggests that the substantial funds needed did not come from the rank and file movement.

I also refer the Senate to an election conducted several years ago by the south coast branch of the Federated Ironworkers Association. It was established that unauthorised persons had taken envelopes and ballot papers out of individual letter boxes belonging to the financial members of that organisation and that as a result an official complaint was referred to the Attorney-General but no prosecution or action followed. If people set themselves a task of taking letters out of letter boxes when persons are at work it is, of course, very difficult to establish later on that that process took place, even though it may be obvious that it did take place.

I refer to these cases not in any way to further the difficulties of the unions, but rather to bring them to the attention of the Senate and simply to show the Senate and the public at large, including unionists, how easy it is for individuals to interfere with the democratic right of members properly to vote in the process of electing their officials. When we are talking of such large sums of money, we have to ask where the money is coming from. It has been suggested to me that it is coming from certain sources in New South Wales, that there is plenty of money available for certain types of campaigns and candidates. It has been suggested to me further that the money comes from a number of sources-firstly, from employers who are interested in the result of union ballots because of the militancy that might be pursued by the officials of the particular union involved. I say to persons who hold different points of view, even within the labour movement itself, that union officials come under threat of undue interference by outside forces. The money comes from persons associated with gambling syndicates in New South Wales. It is suggested that it comes from persons who had associations with the now failed Nugan Hand bank. There are, of course, those of us who believe that that organisation was a conduit for Central Intelligence Agency funds in our country. I am pleased to note the response made by Mr Newman to a question in the House of Representatives yesterday. In that response he pointed out:
Of recent months the Commonwealth directed that the task force--
He was referring to the task force established by the Commonwealth and the State of New South Wales-

extend its activities to looking into drug trafficking associated with the Nugan Hand bank and people involved in drug trafficking who may have had associations with the Nugan Hand bank. The work of the task force will take a long time. I am advised that up to 1 May the task force can claim the following achievements . . .

He went on to speak about the important gains that have been made in breaking up a number of drug syndicates in our country. It has also been suggested to me that certain funds could be made available from from the National Civic Council and from a certain tobacco company. Whilst we all support the democratic right of union members to nominate and become active in union affairs, and whilst we would all want unionists to become active in the internal affairs of their union, there is evidence that a person can get into a post office in a certain manner in order to get his or her hands on ballot papers. Such action, on the information which is available to me, had the effect of completely altering the result of the union election to which I referred earlier. As we know, no more than a few hundred votes were involved in the election that took place in the AMWSU in Victoria recently. If malpractices do occur in union elections they need to be identified and wiped out. We need to establish a much stricter control of the way in which these matters are dealt with by the Australian Electoral Office.

Whilst it is true, as I have said, that when the Senate resumes it will be asked to look at the whole question of electoral matters generally, I must admit that we will also need to look at the way in which safeguards can be written into the Act in order to establish a democratic process whereby no person, other than the individual voters themselves, shall have the right to vote in union elections. As I said at the outset, the case of conspiracy which seems to be evident in the matters involving Mr Hawkins and Mr Battese are serious ones and ones which I hope will occupy the attention of the appropriate Minister. I hope that he will take certain steps to establish the veracity or otherwise of the charges that I have made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity on the first reading of the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill of raising a matter which I have raised in this Parliament before. I will not take very much of the Senate's time to reinforce the argument I advanced on 24 February when I was speaking to the tabling of the Australian National Railways Commission annual report. In speaking to that report I was very critical of the Australian National Railways for the way in which it handles its passenger bookings. I said that I had run into some difficulties in getting accommodation on the train from Perth and that on my way back from Perth I had spoken to the people who run the train and was informed that because the railways were not taking steps to see that the train was full on every trip dead cars were running on the train and some of the staff had to be paid 60 per cent of their salaries to travel back as passengers. I went on to ask:

SPEECH.PARA: Why on earth cannot these cars be full? People wanted to get seats on the Indian Pacific or on the Transcontinental but were told no seats were available.
I went on to say that the railway was not doing its job in promoting the wonderful service it offers. I further said:
I say the service it offers is second to none anywhere in the world.
I stick to that statement. During my remarks Senator Jessop interjected:
You wouldn't know what you are talking about.

Today I received a letter from a great friend of mine, Mr John Dunnery, who is the Australian Workers Union organiser at Port Pirie in South Australia, where most of the personnel who service these passenger trains live. I am proud to be a member of the AWU. I joined it well over 40 years ago and I am still a financial member. Mr Dunnery wrote to me on 9 June. The letter reads:
Senator Geoff McLaren,
C/o The Senate,
Parliament House,
Canberra, ACT 2600.
Dear Geoff, Attached please find copy of letter to the ANR from Bill Albough concerning bookings on the Indian Pacific, for your information.
Yours faithfully, JOHN DUNNERY, Organiser.
The letter referred to is a very interesting letter. It backs up to the hilt the complaints I was making in this Parliament on 24 February. The address on the top of the letter is:
22 Paddock Close,
Quorn,
Leics,
England. L1512 8AX
It is dated 4 May 1981 and reads:
Operations Manager,
Australian National Railways,
Port Augusta, SA.
Dear Sir,
I write to acquaint you with an alarming state of affairs in respect to our booking for 21 persons on the Indian Pacific on Sunday 3 May.

Our original application was declined by your GSA Thomas Cook having been advised by yourselves that the train was 'full'. Our tour being constructed around the Indian Pacific-I was involved in the BBC T.V. series Great Railway Journeys of the World which included 'The Long Straight', the Indian Pacific-I obviously could not accept your answer so long in advance of the date of travel.

A participant of the English tour working in Rockhampton Queensland contacted the Brisbane office of the Western Australian Tourist Development Corporation, whose Mr Ray Stenhouse contacted various States asking for their help in obtaining seats on the train. I regret to tell you the reply was always 'full'.
Eventually an impassioned telex to Westrail obtained the seats-imagine our astonishment to discover this departure-
He was referring to the train on which they travelled-
has 113 passengers aboard, whilst 144 is the maximum complement.

Would you please investigate this matter thoroughly and advise me why we were so misled. Our BBC TV film has been seen on its initial launch by 60,000,000 viewers with further viewings scheduled, including your own State of South Australia. We may need to add a warning: It is impossible to book on this train because its operators mistakenly believe it is full.
Should you wish to contact me, my group is c/o QUORN 13--
I take it that is a telephone number at Quorn in South Australia-
until Friday 8 May, when we join the Indian Pacific again, at Port Augusta. Perhaps you might care to meet me to discuss the matter?
Yours sincerely, BILL ALBOUGH Tour Director TEA/BBC TV

That is a damning letter to have to read into the Hansard record of the Parliament. It backs up the criticism I made of Australian National Railways that it is not doing its best to fill the train. I have spoken to many people who go to tourist agencies and railway offices wanting to book seats on the train and cannot get them, as is borne out in that letter. Recently I asked why the Australian National Railways paid $409,000 to change its name from Australian National Railways to AN, or Australian National. The answer was that this was to promote the railways and give them a logo which people knew about. Yet tourists from the United Kingdom who write many months in advance to book seats on the train are told by the railway authorities that the train is full. The people who work the train repeatedly tell me-they tell John Dunnery, the Australian Workers Union organiser in Port Pirie-that the train is not full and that they are running dead cars.

I will not take the time of the Senate now, but I will pursue the matter further in the Budget session when we have the appropriations before us. If something is not done I will have a lot to say about it. I hope that the people responsible for handling bookings and allocating seats on the train hurriedly do something about it. I raised the matter on 24 February. The letter I have read was written on 4 May. A great deal of time elapsed between those dates but people still could not get seats on the train. The film which has been made about this great railway has already been shown to 60 million people, and the railway has been publicised at no cost to ANR. But if the BBC does not get a satisfactory answer by the time the film is shown in Australia it may need to add the following warning:
It is impossible to book on this train because its operators mistakenly believe it is full.

That will be very damaging to the railways. It is up to the railways to take immediate action and publicise the train, as people in the Soviet Union publicise the Trans-Siberian Railway and as people in Canada publicise the Canadian Pacific. I have been on both those trains, and I can say that the standard of service offered on them, although it is good, does not come up to the standard of the service offered on the Indian Pacific or the Trans-Continental. Yet the people who run our railways are not doing them justice because they are not getting word to all the tourist agencies and bureaus and fully advertising them to see that they have a full complement of passengers. If they do that they will be doing a service not only to this country by promoting tourism but also to the people in Port Pirie and in Parkeston in Western Australia who work on this train. I hope that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) who is in charge of the Senate at the moment, will draw my remarks to the attention of Mr Hunt, the Minister for Transport, so that some remedial action can be taken and we can fill the train every time it runs from the Pacific Ocean to the Indian Ocean.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-

INCOME TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1981 This Bill, in terms both of its size and the range of matters it covers, may well be described as an omnibus measure to amend the income tax law. Three of the measures will give effect to policies foreshadowed in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) for the last election. These are an immediate deduction for capital expenditure on the connection of a business property to mains electricity; a concessional deduction for the cost of insulating a taxpayer's first home; and an immediate deduction for capital expenditure on storage facilities for petroleum fuel. Also included are provisions to give effect to the decision, announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) late last year, that tourist buses may qualify for the investment allowance with effect from 1 January 1976. The Bill also contains further amendments to the gift provisions of the income tax law, including some that will give effect to the 1980-81 Budget decision to allow deductions for gifts to certain overseas aid organisations.

Last, but by no means least in importance, the Bill proposes amendments designed to provide a counter to various forms of tax avoidance. Trust stripping, expenditure recoupment schemes, and exploitation of trading stock transfer provisions and of the tax-exempt status of certain bodies are the avoidance areas covered. Extensive details of most of these changes have already been announced and, relying on that and on the detailed explanations contained in an explanatory memorandum that has been circulated to honourable senators, I propose in this introductory speech to limit myself to the key points.
Cost of Connection to Mains Electricity

In this respect the Government is aiming to provide assistance to persons who, particularly in remote areas of Australia, face the often heavy cost of obtaining the facility of a mains electricity supply. Capital expenditure on connecting mains electricity, or upgrading an existing connection, to a property on which a business is carried on is to qualify for deduction in the year in which the expenditure is incurred. Qualifying expenditure will be the capital costs incurred by an owner of the property, or by a lessee or share farmer, in bringing the mains electricity to the point on the property where the supply authority meters consumption. The deduction will be available only where the connection or upgrading is, at least in part, to be used for business purposes in the production of assessable income. The concession will apply to connections or upgradings costs incurred on or after 1 October 1980, irrespective of when contracts were entered into.

In the form in which the Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives, the concession would have applied to connections or upgradings effected under contracts entered into on or after 1 October 1980. The Bill was amended by the Government in the House of Representatives to delete that qualification in the light of representations to the effect that the former arrangements would have disadvantaged people in rural areas who, after having contracted for supply, may have to wait a considerable period for the connection to be made. I add that the Government is aware that some may see scope in the concession for the inflation of costs so as to benefit the utilities that supply electricity. I give notice now that any action of this kind could very well place the continued availability of the deduction in serious jeopardy.
Home Insulation Costs

This concession will provide tax assistance to people who take steps that have an effect of reducing energy consumption. It is proposed that an income tax deduction will be allowed for amounts paid by a resident taxpayer for insulating a first home. Amounts paid by a taxpayer for thermal insulation materials and for the cost of their installation in a dwelling are to be an allowable deduction if the dwelling is the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer in Australia. It is a further condition of the deduction that the taxpayer or, in the case of married couples, the taxpayer or his or her spouse, has not previously owned another dwelling in Australia that he or she used as a home. The deduction will be available for insulating a dwelling purchased by the taxpayer on or after 1 October 1980, as well as a dwelling constructed by the taxpayer, where construction started on or after that date. Amounts expended by eligible taxpayers for the insulation of extensions to their dwellings will qualify for the new deduction under corresponding conditions.
Fuel Storage Facilities
The third election policy initiative covered by the Bill relates to the capital cost of storage facilities for petroleum-based liquid or gaseous fuel.

The Bill will authorise a deduction, by way of a 100 per cent depreciation allowance, in the income year in which the facilities are first used or installed ready for use to produce assessable income.

The allowance will apply to plant in Australia used wholly and exclusively to store fuel held for use in a business as fuel or as trading stock for disposal. Ancillary plant used wholly and exclusively to convey fuel in and out of storage, or to measure the amount of fuel stored, will qualify. So too will the cost of installation of eligible plant. Storage facilities for crude oil and other fuels being held for further processing will not qualify for the allowance, nor will rail, road or shipping tankers, pipelines or containers for use in the transport of fuel. Expenditure will qualify for the allowance if it is incurred under a contract entered into on or after 1 October 1980 or, if the expenditure is on facilities constructed by the taxpayer, if construction commenced after that date. Facilities that a taxpayer acquired secondhand on or after 1 October 1980 will qualify if used by the taxpayer at a site other than where they were situated at that date.
Tourist Buses

Honourable senators will recall that, late last year, legislation was enacted to give effect to the Government's decision to remove the specific exclusion from the income tax investment allowance of plant for use in connection with amusement or recreation. At the time when that legislation, which applies from 1 October 1980, was introduced it was announced that the Government had further decided to permit tourist buses to qualify for the investment allowance as from 1 January 1976, the date of commencement of the allowance. Measures to achieve that result are in this Bill. By these measures, the exclusion that applied for the period between 1 January 1976 and 30 September 1980 of plant for use in connection with amusement or recreation will be treated as not having applied in relation to tourist buses. Buses brought within the scope of the investment allowance by this amendment will, of course, remain subject to the general requirements of the investment allowance provisions. For example, the general exclusion from the allowance of cars and other light vehicles will mean that buses designed to carry fewer than nine passengers will continue to be excluded, as will buses of any size that are hired out on a 'drive-yourself' basis.
Gifts

Amendments under this head will extend the existing gift provisions of the income tax law which confer deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more to specified funds, authorities or institutions in Australia.
One extension will introduce a scheme to authorise deductions for gifts to certain public funds maintained for the relief of persons in developing countries.
That proposal, which has been most warmly received, was announced in the 1980-81 Budget Speech.

It was supplemented by a ministerial statement on 18 September 1980 which listed 22 organisations that are to qualify for the concession, with effect from that date. The proposed arrangements will accommodate the decisions announced in that statement and, as well, will make provision for further additions to the list of eligible organisations and funds.

Under the legislative scheme proposed in the Bill, gifts made to a public fund established by an organisation approved for purposes of the scheme by the Minister for Foreign Affairs may qualify for deduction.
It will be necessary that the Treasurer be satisfied that a particular fund is for the relief of persons in a country that is certified by the Minister for Foreign Affairs to be a developing country.
A further requirement is that the Treasurer-by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette-declare the fund to be an eligible fund for purposes of the scheme.
Generally, gifts to an eligible fund will be deductible from the date of the Gazette declaring its eligibility.

Transitional arrangements will apply so that gifts made to a fund maintained by one of the 22 organisations nominated in the ministerial statement may qualify for deduction when made after 18 September 1980.

Other amendments will mean that gifts to the International Disaster Emergencies Committee Africal Relief Appeal will qualify for deduction when made after 30 June 1980. Further amendments will ensure that deductions are available for gifts to the IDEC Kampuchean relief appeal made after 30 June 1980 when the present authorisation of deductions was to have terminated.

The Bill will also authorise deductions for gifts to the Herbert Vere Evatt Memorial Foundation made after 16 January 1981, and for gifts made after 23 December 1980 to a public fund that is established and maintained exclusively for the purpose of providing religious instruction in government schools in Australia.
This latter amendment places on a general basis a right of deduction now contained in the law in respect of a limited range of bodies.
Tax Avoidance

I turn now to remaining provisions of the Bill designed to deal with a variety of income tax avoidance practices. With one qualification that I shall specify later, the amendments have all been foreshadowed in announcements that the Treasurer made last year on 5 March, 24 June and 4 August, and on 30 January this year. With the introduction of this Bill, all proposals for action against specific schemes of tax avoidance foreshadowed in announcements by the Treasurer will have been given legislative form. I also expect that, before the Senate rises for the winter recess, new general anti-avoidance provisions will be brought before the Parliament for consideration.
Section 36A Schemes

The Bill proposes the amendments foreshadowed in the Treasurer's statement of 30 January 1981. These are designed to provide a counter to tax avoidance schemes that set out to exploit the special provisions of section 36A of the income tax law that apply to changes in interests in trading stock, such as changes that occur on the formation of a partnership. This exploitation takes place under arrangements whereby a person who has, for example, some cattle about to be sold or a crop ready to be harvested, enters into a partnership with a company controlled by the promoter of the scheme. The cattle or the crop, as the case may be, is transferred to the partnership for an amount roughly equivalent to market value. However, a special right of election available under section 36A is used so that the property is treated for tax purposes as having been transferred at the substantially lower tax value at which it would have been brought to account if the transfer had not taken place. The net result is that the former owner realises an amount close to market value of the property, but is taxed only on the substantially lower value.

The amendments proposed will make an election under the section ineffective where the person who disposes of an interest in relevant property receives consideration in respect of the disposal that is substantially more than the amount that might reasonably have been expected if the property had been valued at the low tax value applicable as a result of the election. The consequence of the ineffectiveness of an election in these circumstances will be that the person will be treated as having disposed of the property at its market value. Transfers made in ordinary family or commercial dealings are specifically excluded from the scope of the amendments. These amendments will apply generally to changes in ownership or interests occurring after 30 January 1981. However, consistent with action taken previously by the Government to debar the carry-forward of paper losses resulting from avoidance schemes, the Bill will ban the carry-forward from one year to another of such tax losses resulting from earlier section 36A schemes, with first effect for the income year 1980-81.
Trust Stripping Schemes

Changes that the Treasurer outlined on 5 March 1980 to deal with variants of the trust stripping arrangements against which remedial legislation was enacted early in 1979 are the next matter covered by the Bill. These arrangements, which sought to free from tax altogether the trading profits and other income of trusts, commonly entailed a specially introduced nominal beneficiary being made presently entitled to income of the trust that was to be stripped. By this means, the trustee was relieved of any tax liability in respect of the trust income. The arrangements were at the same time designed so that not only did the special beneficiary escape tax, but the family from which the income was diverted received the benefit of it in a tax-free capital form.

The 1979 amendments are contained in section 100A of the Income Tax Assessment Act and operate to treat income to which a beneficiary is nominally made presently entitled under reimbursement arrangements of this type as income of the trust estate to which no beneficiary is presently entitled. The trustee is thus liable to be taxed on the income at the maximum rate of personal income tax, which for 1980-81 is 60 per cent. The variants of the trust stripping arrangements with which this Bill deals exploit the exclusion from the 1979 amendments of income of a trust estate to which a beneficiary becomes presently entitled in the capacity of a trustee of another trust estate. That exclusion was intended to ensure that section 100A would apply only in relation to the last link in a chain of distributions through interposed trusts, thereby removing any possibility of double taxation on income as it passed through the chain.

The amendments now proposed will continue the scheme of applying section 100A to the last nominal beneficiary only, but in a way that aims to prevent the exploitation that has been being experienced. For this purpose, the exclusion from section 100A of income to which a trustee-beneficiary becomes presently entitled is to be limited to so much of that income as is passed on by the trustee as income to which a beneficiary of that trust estate is in turn presently entitled. Further amendments will deny deductions for losses or outgoings incurred under arrangements to which the section applies. This will prevent the section being frustrated through such amounts being available for write-off against other income of the nominal beneficiaries. The amendments will apply generally to trust income paid to, or applied for the benefit of, a beneficiary after 5 March 1980 and to losses or outgoings incurred after that date.
Expenditure Recoupment Schemes

Legislation against expenditure recoupment schemes already exists. It was foreshadowed on 24 September 1978 and now applies to a range of losses and outgoings. Broadly, the legislation applies to deny a deduction where the specifically designated loss or outgoing is incurred under an arrangement whereby the taxpayer or an associate obtains a benefit the amount or value of which, together with the tax advantage sought, effectively recoups the claimed loss or outgoing. In a statement on 4 August 1980 the Treasurer foreshadowed action to extend the provisions to deal with variants of the recoupment type schemes that had by then been encountered. These involve paper losses generated in producing or marketing films, in operating gold mines, in purchasing consumable supplies and in carrying out market research. The amendments in respect of these variants are to apply with respect to losses or outgoings incurred after 24 September 1978. The decision to do this follows the clear warning given on that day and repeated subsequently.

I add that more recent information coming from returns of income for 1979-80 indicates that, before the Treasurer's announcement on 4 August 1980, still further schemes of the expenditure recoupment type had been implemented. As in the case of the schemes referred to in that announcement, it would appear that promoters of the further schemes had chosen to ignore the Government's repeated warnings. In the light of the information now available, and of the clear Government commitment to put an end to expenditure recoupment schemes, the Bill proposes extensions of the existing legislation additional to those already announced by the Treasurer. These latest identified variants against which remedial action is now proposed involve paper losses generated in acquiring a licence under a copyright existing in computer software; by way of commission for collecting assessable income; by way of a fee in relation to the growing, care and supervision of trees; by way of an amount paid in relation to the enhancement of the value of shares held as trading stock; and by way of a fee in relation to the procuring of master sound recordings.

Honourable senators would be interested to know that one of these schemes-that built on commissions for collecting assessable income-generated identified claims for deductions for 1979-80 of $111m. The additional amendments will also have effect from 24 September 1978. They, and the amendments specifically outlined in the Treasurer's statement of 4 August 1980, will ensure that the ban on the carry-forward from one year to another of paper losses created under tax avoidance schemes, and which at present applies to expenditure recoupment arrangements, will apply similarly in respect of all the latest variants.
Exempt Bodies

In a statement on 24 June 1980, the Treasurer foreshadowed legislation on tax avoidance through attempts to exploit the tax-exempt status of various entities. As the Treasurer said at the time, two earlier warnings about the abuse of the privileged status of tax-exempt bodies had gone unheeded, and there was clear evidence that substantial revenue losses were accruing through the use of these bodies as vehicles for diverting taxable income from individuals and companies. The kinds of schemes being employed were outlined in the statement. I do not think it is necessary to describe them in detail again now. Broadly, however, the schemes involved the diversion of income from a person who would otherwise be liable to tax on it to a body that has no tax liability. The exempt body was required to pay to the person from whom the income was diverted, or to an associate of that person, a tax-free consideration equal to the greater part of the diverted income. As a fee for its participation it retained a small amount of the income for its own benefit.

As mentioned in the Treasurer's statement, the legislation will operate where, under a tax avoidance agreement entered into after 24 June 1980, an exempt body provides consideration for property giving rise to diverted income and the consideration is substantially more than the amount that, in the circumstances, would be paid by a taxable public company. The income derived by the exempt body in these circumstances, without deduction of losses or outgoings incurred under or in connection with the tax avoidance agreement, will be subject to tax at the maximum rate of personal tax. These measures will apply only to income derived by exempt bodies from participation in the particular tax avoidance schemes. Their ordinary income will continue to be exempt from tax.

Finally, the last, and bulkiest, clause of the Bill contains a number of formal amendments, incorporating changes in drafting style. These will result in the adoption, in references to other provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act, of a forward referencing style. Before concluding, I mention that legislation in pursuance of the Government's commitment to provide tax incentives for investment in Australian films is at an advanced stage and will be brought before the Parliament before the winter recess. I commend the present Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (DIVERTED INCOME) BILL 1981

This Bill is closely related to measures contained in the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1981, about which I have just spoken. By reason of those measures, income tax is to be charged on income diverted to an exempt body under a tax avoidance arrangement entered into after 24 June 1980. The overall design of the legislation is to counteract the exploitation, for tax avoidance purposes, of the privileged status of tax exempt bodies. This Bill will formally impose tax on the diverted income. The rate of tax of 60 per cent proposed by the Bill is the same as that payable by a trustee of a trust estate on accumulating trust income and is equal to the maximum rate of personal tax. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before the Senate are being debated together. The major Bill, the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1981, covers several of the 61 electoral bribes announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in his policy speech on 30 September last year. In many cases they were announced right off the top of his head and were either uncosted or dishonestly costed. Many of those bribes took the form of tax concessions. The Bill also covers a couple of minor matters not related to the Prime Minister's policy speech. In this Bill we have examples of both dishonestly costed and uncosted tax concession bribes offered by the Prime Minister in the pre-election period.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, the Bill provides for the cost of connection to electricity mains in rural areas to be immediately and fully deductible from taxable income, for the cost of fuel storage facilities used by business likewise to be fully and immediately deductible from taxable income, and for the cost of insulation of a first home to be deductible from taxable income. Previously, the latter deduction was not available at all, and the costs of electricity connection and fuel storage were deductible at a very much lower rate.

The Bill also provides that the investment allowance shall be granted to tourist buses. It seeks to close off some tax avoidance practices, particularly those related to the transfer of stock in such a way as to avoid the payment of tax on the appreciating value or on a growing crop. It also covers some donations to charity. It is ironic, but not unusual, that in the one Bill there is an attempt by the Government to close off loopholes in the Income Tax Assessment Act which have induced tax avoidance and simultaneously to insert a number of tax rorts into the Act which will, of course, in time add to the length and complexity of the Act and provide scope for future tax avoidance.

There are a number of universal objections to the use of tax provisions in the way that this Bill uses them. Firstly, tax concessions of this nature, that is, deductions from taxable income, are always regressive. The maximum benefits are gained by people on the highest incomes. The benefit to an individual taxpayer is directly related to the marginal rate of tax being paid. Therefore, inevitably, such concessions are regressive. If tax concessions are to be provided-in the Opposition's view at least insulation of a first home is a cost for which some form of tax concession can be justified-it ought to be provided by way of a flat rate rebate of tax payable which, although it may still have some small element of regressivity in it, is not overtly regressive in the way a taxation deduction provision is. That sort of flat rate rebate, probably at a rate of 32 cents in the dollar, which is the lowest marginal rate, would also have a less distortionary effect on investment decisions than would deductions from taxable income, which can be and usually are related to the highest tax rate of 60 cents in the dollar.

Secondly, and probably most objectionable of all, once a concession is written into the Act it escapes the annual review or even the notice of Parliament. It is an implicit expenditure of the Commonwealth Government, a hidden subsidy, which continues automatically year after year without anyone having his attention regularly drawn to it and without Parliament having the opportunity to scrutinise it year after year, as it would if the same amount of industry assistance were provided through the appropriations. Thirdly-this is ironic in view of the Government's professed commitment to small government taxation concessions will distort investment priorities and decisions made by individuals. They are one of the manifestations of big government. Implicit in the provision of a taxation deduction for any form of business investment is the belief that government are better able to judge the areas into which business investment should be directed than are individual entrepreneurs guided by pure market forces.

The penchant of the Prime Minister for providing enormous amounts of hidden assistance to business by way of taxation concessions certainly calls into question his credentials-indeed, those of many of his colleagues-as a disciple of the free enterprise system. I believe that in the case of the Prime Minister at least this would be a completely accurate assessment. The Prime Minister does not believe in market forces. He does not believe in free enterprise. But he uses the rhetoric of a market economy and free enterprise to rationalise an existing distribution of wealth and income which is highly favourable to himself and his class and is therefore wholly acceptable.

The other, and final, objection to all taxation concessions is that they destroy the simplicity of the taxation Act. Probably nobody-certainly very few-really understands the Australian taxation Act. At present it comprises more than 1,000 pages of legalese. It is complex, inconsistent and fairly easily evaded. The ease with which it can be evaded is a function, to a very substantial degree, of its length and complexity as well as an aggregate of decisions by a compliant High Court. Its length and complexity, in turn, are a function of its having been misused for decades as a vehicle to carry electoral bribes offered by an assortment of irresponsible politicians, chief among whom is the present Prime Minister. The reprehensible practice of offering electoral bribes by way of taxation concessions has become cental to his political and economic policies. In the last three years this Government has added more than 300 pages to the Income Tax Assessment Act. This year, with less than half the year gone, it is already in the process of adding another 70 pages.

It appears that, in the strange mind of the Prime Minister, the hidden expenditure of a tax concession is qualitatively different and different in a numerical sense to overt expenditure by way of appropriation. In a political sense it is quite different, for reasons that I have just explained, as appropriations are regularly and necessarily reviewed by Parliament. Equal assistance-assistance of equal magnitude-once written into the taxation Act is there indefinitely and without parliamentary scrutiny. The enormous damage which the present Prime Minister has done to the taxation Act in terms of its comprehensibility and effectiveness is probably equalled only by the damage that Sir John McEwen did to Australian manufacturing industry in the 1960s. The general objection to taxation deductions applies even if the specific concessions and rorts being opened were considered and rational decisions. In this case they clearly were not.

I challenge any Government senator to justify it. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) certainly has not attempted to do it. I challenge the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), in his reply, to justify on a rational basis the provision for immediate write-off of expenditure on fuel storage capacity for business, for reasons that I will detail in a minute. I challenge any Government supporter to provide a rational justification for that decision. These concessions came-like the ridiculous film tax rort which accompanied them in time, the full dimensions of which are not grasped even by many people opposed to it-uncosted and unconsidered off the top of the Prime Minister's head in a pre-election crisis atmosphere. In the case of the film tax rort, it has subsequently been revealed that the original inspiration came from a television studio cosmetician who was saddled with the task of humanising the Fraser face.

Many of these concessions are clearly embarrassing to the Treasurer. They have certainly infuriated the Secretary to the Treasury. No justification has been offered by the Treasurer or, to my knowledge, any other member of the Government for at least the concession concerning fuel storage, and that is no wonder because no rational justification can be offered. The promise originally given by the Prime Minister was related to expenditure on fuel storage by farmers for storage on farms. Initially, it was rationalised in that way and was subsequently extended as a more general concession to business. I stress that this was not presented as a measure to assist people in financing their normal operational fuel reserves. It was presented as something to assist in financing an emergency or strategic reserve.

In my view, there is nothing wrong with having emergency or strategic fuel reserves, given the relatively high risk of disruptions to overseas supplies and even through unforseeable acts the disruption of local supplies. The Opposition does not criticise the measure on the grounds that there is no case for adding to the nation's strategic or emergency fuel storage. However, it just happens that the cheapest and most effective reserves for any given quantity of fuel as an emergency reserve are those held in larger storages at a number-100, perhaps 1,000-of strategic centres around Australia rather than scattered around hundreds of tens of thousands, maybe hundreds of thousands, of private businesses. The proposal which the Prime Minister has put up does precisely the opposite because the finance is provided by way of taxation concessions to small business, it is regressive, and the costs of all those things are not regularly examined.

The storage will be done mostly by small business and it will inevitably be in small tanks. It will be held almost entirely in 500-gallon or 1,000-gallon tanks. If, as a result of this measure being introduced, sufficient people were induced to provide a capacity to store sufficient additional fuel to provide a six months supply for agriculture, the cost of providing that quantity in 500-gallon tanks would be $235m. The cost of providing that quantity in one-million-gallon tanks would be $67m, that is, about one-quarter of the cost for one-million-gallon tanks as against 500-gallon tanks. To store it in five-million-gallon tanks it would cost $37m, less than one-sixth of the original cost. I ask the Minister to examine a table which sets out the tank requirement for storing that quantity of fuel-267 million gallons or 1,200 million litres. I will seek to incorporate that table in Hansard later.

The actual cost of this proposition is unknown at this stage. When the proposition was first put up by the Prime Minister it was costed at $10m. If the cost is in fact that small, its effect on the quantity of fuel held for emergency use will be negligible. If the effect of this concession is to provide extra fuel equal to six months' agricultural usage, as the table which I will incorporate suggests, and if it is stored in 500-gallon tanks and the average marginal tax rate of the people who are storing it is 45 per cent, the cost to government revenue will be in the vicinity of $110m, just 11 times the estimate given by the Prime Minister. That estimate, of course, like most of the costing estimates in the Prime Minister's policy speech was fraudulent. It would be cheaper, indeed, for the Government to give oil companies the tanks to store one million gallons of fuel than it would be to finance the storage of that fuel by way of this taxation concession simply because fuel stored in large containers is much more cost-effective than the storage of fuel in small containers.

That is not the only objection that we have to this ridiculous proposition. If an emergency arises in a particular locality and the only source of fuel is that which has been delivered to 100,000 small businesses scattered all over the country, it will be more difficult to retrieve the fuel and use it for emergency purposes than if the fuel were stored in 270 one million gallon tanks scattered around the countryside. Distribution for emergency services from those regional tanks would be much easier than recovery and distribution from tens or hundreds of thousands of small tanks. The other thing-I restrict my remarks to agricultural which was the ground on which the provision was originally rationalised-is that this is a very attractive proposition to a farmer paying the maximum marginal tax rate of 60 per cent who can easily find the capital required to provide the storage and to buy the fuel to put in it. If fuel prices continue to appreciate at the rate they have recently appreciated-that would seem unlikely-an investment in liquid fuel would be a very good investment since the appreciation in value has exceeded in the past the going rate of interest. But it is a fine proposition for the farmers who are in a liquid position and on a high marginal tax rate. Who will provide the emergency reserves for those farmers who are not in highly liquid positions and who can not get the capital either to purchase the tanks or the fuel to put in them? The stocks of a regional storage of the type which I propose would, of course, be held by someone else and that problem would not arise.

There is also, I might add, some technical objection to the storage of distillate, particularly in small tanks, over a long period. This is related, I understand, to the degree of oxidisation which takes place and the subsequent engine damage. This is a ridiculous proposition. I trust sincerely that not everybody in the Liberal Party lacks the capacity to see what a ridiculous and indefensible proposition this is. It is a tragedy that they are so cowed by party discipline that none of them would have the courage to come over to this side of the Senate to vote for the amendment to the second reading which I now move.
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate notes with concern that-
(1) The introduction of several additional tax concessions raises serious questions as to the suitability of tax legislation as a means of extending assistance to particular interest groups;
(2) No reasons have been given to the Parliament for providing these concessions through the tax system rather than through the expenditure side of the Budget;
(3) These concessions, being in the form of deductions rather than rebates, are inequitable in that they provide most assistance to highest income earners and least assistance to low income earners;
(4) No costings have been provided to the Parliament by the Treasurer on the concessions; and

(5) The Government has not developed a national strategic crude oil storage policy and calls on it to establish such a policy with the objective of meeting the International Energy Agency's target for national crude oil storage of 90 days national consumption'.

The provisions other than the fuel storage tax provision in the Bill are certainly less objectionable and may even be defensible except that the Government has gone about financing them in the wrong way. There remains the overriding objection to the unnecessary complication and lengthening of the Income Tax Assessment Act. But if the Act were to be used as a vehicle it would be both more equitable and more efficient if whatever degree of assistance was provided through the Act was provided on a rebate basis instead of a tax deduction basis.

The associated Bill, the Income Tax (Diverted Income) Bill 1981, is not opposed by the Opposition. It is an attempt to block off avenues for tax avoidance which have been opened up by previous Government amendments and com- plexification of the Act. We note again the irony of the Government simultaneously attempting to close off loopholes opened up by its previous fiddling with the Act and continuing to fiddle with the Act and open up other and different loopholes for future tax avoidance. I seek leave to incorporate the table which I mentioned earlier and which has now been perused by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of the points that have been made in the course of this debate by Senator Walsh relate to the amendment. Consequently, I think that he was speaking in support of that amendment. I will come to those individual points a little later. I firstly indicate that the Government does not accept and does not propose to adopt Senator Walsh's amendment. I turn now to some of the points which the honourable senator raised. Firstly, he accused the Government of producing an amendment and providing a concession to certain persons in the community on the basis that these were uncosted or, at least, dishonestly costed in terms of the Government's promises made in the policy speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) before the October election last year. I think the honourable senator referred to them also as bribes. The Government rejects that kind of criticism. It points out clearly that these statements on costing were made at the time of the election policy speech and were subject to discussion at that time. I am not aware whether or not Senator Walsh and the Australian Labor Party raised criticisms on the costings at that time. I feel that, perhaps, they did not do so. In fact, in subsequent times we have heard bleatings to this effect. But again, very little conclusive evidence has been brought to bear.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the clearest indications of that is the first table which Senator Walsh had incorporated in Hansard which relates to fuel storage costs. It does not refer to all businesses; it refers only to farming business. Secondly, he seeks to assert in that table that automatically all those persons who are covered-presumably he is talking about farmers-would seek to take advantage of the deduction in one year. Obviously that is not a proposition which is real and quite clearly is not contemplated by this amendment. Clearly, people will choose their own times for taking advantage of the concessions in order to build up their supply of and their storage facilities for fuel. Furthermore, Senator Walsh seeks to make the point that these kinds of deductions should be made available by virtue of a rebate rather than a straight out deduction which he equates then with the normal kind of concessional rebates which are provided in the Income Taxation Assessment Act for such things as spouse rebates.

Clearly that is at odds with the general principles of the income tax law under which business deductions of all kinds, including depreciation and some straight out deductions for various kinds of expenditure are allowable under the general law in one year. In fact they are deductions and are not presented in the law in the form of a rebate. Clearly the one area in which there might be some support for Senator Walsh's argument is the area of home insulation which of its very nature is a private domestic expense. Consequently, there may be some support for this argument in that area. Nevertheless, I think he would agree that the action that has been taken by the Government by virtue of this amending legislation is in conformity with the kinds of policies in relation to energy conservation which his party supports. Consequently, I believe that exception is well and truly justified.

Further to that point, Senator Walsh said that all deductions are by their very nature regressive. Naturally, if he follows the argument I have just been putting he will realise that whether the argument that he has proposed is relevant and in fact real depends on how one defines income. That is the key question in determining whether his argument should be accepted. I wonder whether, for instance, he would consider, in line, I think, with the general policy of his own party that the cost of travelling to and from work by individual employees should be allowable in the form of a rebate or in the form of a deduction. Perhaps he would consider the same argument should apply in respect of expenditure by tradesmen on tools of trade and the special clothing which those people wear when engaging in their profession. The honourable senator might care to consider those matters alongside the general argument which he has put.

In relation to the question of the simplicity of the legislation, it is quite clear that Senator Walsh seeks to mislead us a little in this area. Firstly, I think he will acknowledge that of the tremendous number of amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act that have been made in recent years-I think he mentioned a figure of some 300 pages having been added to the Act; I am not able to confirm that figure at this stage-most have been related to countering tax avoidance. I think the honourable senator will acknowledge that point. Further, the Opposition on most occasions--

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons you have such a tax avoidance problem is that the Act is so complex.

—The honourable senator has not made out that argument at all; in fact I challenge him to do so. I think he will find that most of the tax avoidance which has arisen in this community and which has been countered by the Government in taking the kinds of actions that it has taken is not related to any deductions of the sort that he has mentioned. In fact, there may be one or two but they are very much in the minority as I think Senator Walsh, if he were to consider the question, would recognise. Certainly it is true too that the substantial number of amendments which have occurred in this period have been put through this Parliament with the support of the Opposition. Most tax avoidance questions have been strongly supported by the Opposition. In fact, I recall many occasions on which Bills of this kind have been criticised by the Opposition as not being strong enough in certain areas. I would be surprised if the Opposition had changed from that position.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of simplicity, surely we ought not to throw stones at this set of legislation. Rather, we ought to look at the broader framework of the income tax law in this country. I do not think there are any further major points, other than the general ones which Senator Walsh has raised during the debate, which require answering. I believe all of the points that he made have been adequately covered. Consequently, I reiterate that the Government does not accept the amendment.
