TALK.START.PARA: —I have no objection to the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill and the Income Tax (Diverted Income) Bill being taken as a whole in Committee. I want to address a few remarks to clause 8 of the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill which deals with costs and the principal philosophy of taxation deductibility for business expenditure. The provision generally accepted in Australian tax law and in the tax laws of most other countries is that an investment in plant or equipment is more or less written off over the period encompassing the useful life of the asset. There is a qualitative difference between the payment of wages where the expenditure is immediately incurred by the business proprietor and the value of the labour dissipated or obtained immediately and investment in an item of plant which may continue to perform useful services for a number of years. That principle is well recognised and well established.

SPEECH.PARA: On occasions governments divert from that principle. This Government increasingly diverts from that principle and allows the full and complete write-off of items of capital equipment which continue to provide useful services to a business for a number of years. It is quite appropriate and logical that labour, fuel and some other expenses associated with earning income should be written-off immediately and fully. It is not appropriate either on logical grounds or on grounds of our whole taxation experience that investment in capital equipment should be written off on that same basis. In other words, items such as the ones which are before us are special concessions offered to business through the Income Tax Assessment Act. Given that they are special concessions, our argument-which either the Minister did not understand or does not want to understand-is that the benefits of those special concessions ought to be distributed on a less regressive basis than they necessarily are if they are provided by way of taxation deduction. If they are to be provided at all, they ought to be provided by way of tax rebate where the benefits obtained by every taxpayer are directly related to the absolute amount of the expenditure instead of-as is the case with taxation deductions-being the product of the absolute amount of the expenditure multiplied by the marginal tax rate which, of course, provides the greatest benefits inevitably to the people on the highest incomes.

The table which I incorporated regarding the costs dealt with in clause 8-incidentally, I incorporated only one table in case there is some confusion about that-states the assumptions behind the cost figures given. The assumption is that that is the cost of storing 267 million gallons of fuel which happens to be equal to six months' agricultural consumption. I am well aware-the Minister has stated also-that the provision applies to businesses other than farm businesses. To the degree that it is exploited by businesses other than farm businesses, it is emergency fuel storage. From an agricultural point of view, that same quantity must last something less than six months. But it was an agricultural emergency storage that the idea was first rationalised by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

The assumptions underlying the Prime Minister's estimate of $10m as the cost of this provision are not stated. They were not stated on 30 September, they have not been stated by the Minister today and they were not stated in the House of Representatives two weeks ago. I assert that that was a dishonest costing. It is certainly a nebulous costing until the assumptions underpinning it are revealed. As the lack of honesty in the costing of various items in Mr Fraser's policy speech has been raised, I will cite three in relation to which, on the Government's own admission, there have been drastic revisions in cost. The most spectacular, of course, is the film industry tax rort, dishonestly and fraudulently costed in the policy speech at $2m. This was subsequently admitted by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) a month ago to be $20m and, on the basis of the figures released by the Treasurer last week, it is more likely to be $30m. That costing has gone from $2m to $20m on the Government's own admission and it is more likely to be $30m.

The extension of the liquefied petroleum gas subsidy is estimated to cost between $9m and $11m. A letter from the Treasurer which is in my possession acknowledges that the revised estimate-as he euphemistically calls it-is $13m. That is another costing in the Prime Minister's policy speech. The 20 per cent depreciation allowance for various items of farm equipment, which was estimated in the Prime Minister's policy speech to cost $7m, was subsequently admitted by the Treasurer in a letter to me to be $20m. So there are three examples of fraudulently dishonest costings in that policy speech.

Since the Prime Minister's assumptions underlying the cost estimate of $10m were not stated, I suppose one cannot say categorically that they are wrong. The assumptions underlying that $10m cost estimate still have not been stated and I invite the Minister to do so. If a 45c in the dollar average marginal tax rate, which is probably a conservative estimate for this provision on fuel storage, and the cost of storing 267 million gallons of fuel, which happens to be equal to about six months' agricultural consumption-the Minister may relate it to something other than six months' agricultural consumption if he wishes-induces fuel storage of that magnitude in 500 gallon and 1,000 gallon tanks, the cost to the revenue at that 45 per cent marginal tax rate will be between $80m and $108m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall quickly answer the points raised by Senator Walsh. Certainly in connection with the estimates of the costing, while I think he is correct in claiming that the cost of the fuel storage facility stated in the election policy was of the order of $10m, I have an-up-to-date costing on that figure which indicates that it will be of the order of $12m. I believe the cost is not of the proportions mentioned by Senator Walsh during his argument on the matter.
—I stated my assumptions.

—Senator Walsh's assumption, of course, goes back to a one year implementation of the proposition which I think cannot really be assumed on the basis of the argument he has put forward, especially on the basis of the table which he had incorporated in Hansard. In terms of the broader question which Senator Walsh raised, there is the matter of the immediate write-off and the total cost being claimed for one year as compared with the depreciation charged which might otherwise have been claimed.

SPEECH.PARA: I think everyone in this Parliament would acknowledge that one of the problems that Australia faces, and one of the most urgent and real problems, is the lack of storage capacity in the event of major dislocations of international oil supplies which may affect our capacity to keep our factories, farms and food production going which all relate very closely to the individual well-being of every Australian. That is an important matter, bearing in mind the highly mechanised state of Australian industry. Consequently, this proposal, which is aimed at ensuring that we encourage people to develop storage facilities of this kind to the highest possible degree, only enhances the total reservoir of fuel in this country which can be kept on hand ready for any emergency. If Senator Walsh cares to think back to the time of the election campaign when this proposal was put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), he may recall that it was within a month or so of the Iraqi invasion of Iran, with all kinds of difficulties in assessing the long term and short term effects on Middle East oil supplies at that time. Certainly, that war continues, with escalations possible in other areas which may indeed lead us to a state in which our oil supplies may be dislocated. These factors are considerable ones and ones which the Government has in mind in the assessment and establishment of this policy. Clearly, the Government does not resile from it and believes such action is correct in the proper circumstances at the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again refer to the assumptions. In the table I had incorporated on the cost of this measure, I stated the assumptions. The assumptions having been stated and if they are accepted-they are assumptions and by definition are not claimed to be absolutely correct; they are stated assumptions, no more and no less-what follows then is a question of calculating. It is a matter of arithmetic. While the assumptions may be doubtful, from then on there is no doubt. It is just an arithmetical calculation. On those assumptions the cost to the revenue is between $80m and $108m to store that quantity of fuel in tanks of that size. The Minister has given an estimate of $12m as the cost to revenue, I presume in the current financial year. He has not stated the assumptions underlying that estimate. If he has them I would like to know how much additional storage has it been assumed will be induced by this measure. In tanks of what size is it anticipated that fuel will be stored? I invite him to state certainly those two assumptions. There may be some other relevant assumptions, but I cannot think of them at the moment. Certainly those two are relevant and I invite him to state what they are.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of what he said, although it has been said before it is apparently necessary to repeat it, the Opposition is not opposed to emergency fuel storages. The second reading amendment which we moved in fact called upon the Government to increase the storage of crude oil in particular. The Opposition is in favour of greater emergency fuel storage but it is in favour of doing it in a cost-effective way in larger and more accessible storages. What the Government proposes to do is to store emergency fuel in a cost-ineffective way. The fact that it will be cost-in effective is guaranteed by the proposition in clause 9.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figure which I cited earlier in the debate in fact has been prepared by the Australian Taxation Office staff with their normal care and ability. We know that they are the experts. The point I seek to make is that that kind of independent advice is available to any government of whatever colour and certainly is not, as Senator Walsh would seek to assert, a figment of some person's imagination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it somewhat ludicrous that a government would seek to introduce legislation to bring about an increased storage of fuels in this country by this method. The Minister has proclaimed what he believes to be the results of that-there will be an increased storage of fuel. It will be scattered all over the place. I am inclined to agree with the sentiments of my colleague Senator Walsh in that it will be stored hither, thither and yon. There will perhaps be massive storages amongst the wealthy farming community, there will be minuscular extra storages amongst the great bulk of the farming community. One of the things that worry me is this: In the event of an emergency in some part of the continent and the fuel in some other part of the continent is wanted in an endeavour to overcome problems in the disaster area, how does the Government propose to get that fuel back?

SPEECH.PARA: Having been a farmer for 40 years and knowing the mentality of farmers-based on the concept 'what I have, I hold'-and having paid for that fuel, will the Government ride shotgun on tankers with sheriffs or something and take the fuel? Will its inspectors check what fuel every farmer in a given district has and at the time of an emergency, when that fuel is required, will a sheriff, policeman or army officer demand that fuel? Unless it does something such as that the fuel to a large extent will not be available to the community that the Minister is talking about in the event of some emergency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not let the Minister get away with the way in which he gave that reply. I certainly have not accused the Australian Taxation Office of shonky costing on this issue. The shonky costings come from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or from the Prime Minister's office, not from the Taxation Office. Having produced an estimate of $12m cost, presumably the cost to revenue in the current financial year, does the Minister have available to him now the assumptions underlying that estimate and specifically the quantity of additional storage which it has been assumed will be affected by this measure? In what size tanks will that fuel be held? Does he have that information? If he does have that information, what are the figures?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have those figures immediately available at this point of time. However, I am willing to take that matter on notice. I will communicate with Senator Walsh at a later time and provide him with some information about that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Messner) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation that the Senate is now debating is the very controversial and indeed notorious legislation designed to give additional tax concessions to the Australian film industry. Honourable senators and members of the public will be aware that this legislation represents one of the worst examples of the incompetence and dishonesty of the Fraser Government. The saga of extravagant promises, broken promises, modified promises and the absolute chaos that has been created in the film industry by the Government's handling of this issue is something that all Australians who are interested in having an Australian film industry or who are involved in the Australian film industry will not forget for a very long time. The upshot is that we still have a totally unsatisfactory situation. We now have presented to us legislation which the Opposition, for reasons I will go into in some detail, finds itself unable to support, much as it wishes and desires to support a truly Australian film industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us examine what the legislation in its latest and perhaps final form actually does. The legislation provides a tax deduction for investors in Australian films equal to 150 per cent of the capital expenditure on the film. This deduction is now to be available only when the film has been completed and used to produce income. It provides a tax exemption on income from Australian films for an amount up to 50 per cent of the qualifying investment in the film. To qualify the film must be an eligible Australian film according to a definition which the Opposition believes is significantly and improperly broadened by this legislation. It must be a feature film, a documentary or a mini-series of a television drama and be produced for exhibition to the public in cinemas or by way of television broadcasting. An amendment moved by the Government to its own legislation in the House of Representatives on Friday allows that investment in films under contracts entered into between 1 October 1980, when the first series of extravagant promises were made, and 27 May 1981, will qualify for deduction in the year of expenditure rather than in the year the film is completed and used to produce income.

I would like to remind the Senate that for the second time in two days-the first being the broadcasting and television amendment legislation-the Senate has been presented with a situation where the Government has made a detailed announcement of its intentions, then brought in a Bill which diverges drastically from its announced intentions and then proceeds to amend its own Bill in the House. So this is another example of the Government's incompetence and inability to develop and stick to a realistic policy. Of course, this legislation is a further example of legislation, one of the main beneficiaries of which is Mr Rupert Murdoch who, as well as his other activities in airlines, broadcasting and so on which have been so favoured by the Government during this legislative program, has recently entered into the film making business on a large scale and so, of course, will receive one of the largest benefits from the tax concession which this Bill introduces.

The Australian Labor Party, as I think everybody knows-certainly everybody in the film industry knows-has long been committed to a vigorous, thriving Australian film industry. In government we took a number of steps, not least of which was the setting up of the Australian Film Commission, to ensure that we did have a burgeoning Australian film industry. During our period of Opposition we have continued to support any measures which were genuinely in the interests of the local film industry and genuinely in the interests of those talented people who work in that industry.

However, we have to oppose the amendments before us. We oppose them for a number of reasons. Firstly, they undeniably create opportunities for tax avoidance which will damage the film industry and create unacceptable losses to public revenue. I do not think any Government senator can argue with those assertions. It would be charitable to say that the costing for this scheme must represent one of the greatest Government bungles of recent times, and many bungles have there been in recent times. The cynical view would be that the Government deliberately misrepresented the projected loss to revenue when the scheme was first announced during the election campaign. At that time-this was in October 1980-the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) estimated the loss to revenue would be $2m on an annual basis. This was revised by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 11 March 1981 when he informed the Parliament that the latest estimate indicated the annual loss to revenue would be in the region of $20m rather than $2m. On 29 April 1981 the Treasurer, in response to a question by my colleague Mr David Charles, did not deny David Charles's suggestion that the loss to revenue would be $30m annually. We are now informed in the Treasurer's second reading speech that the total budgeted cost for the 170 applications which have already been received for eligibility for this scheme is $130m. If the 170 films were all to go ahead the loss to revenue would be over $200m.

This projection is a staggering indictment of a government which bases its claim to credibility on a platform of economic responsibility. I think the truth is that in a desperate bid for votes in a disintegrating electoral situation during the election campaign the Prime Minister got more than a little carried away and made promises which he could not afford. I must point out that he made those promises with virtually no consultation with major bodies in the film industry such as the entertainment unions. He made them on the suggestion of one group only. Of course, he undertook no proper costing. As the Opposition warned at the time, the estimated $2m was a figure which was pulled out of the air and could not be substantiated by anybody who knew anything about the film industry or indeed anybody who knew anything about the operation of the Income Tax Assessment Act. At a time when public expenditure in almost every area of genuine need is being reduced, slashed and razored, we have this extravagant costing of a tax concession proposal which will result in a tenfold to one hundredfold increase in this form of assistance to the Australian film industry.

Another point to be made about the Fraser Government's apparent willingness to assist the industry in this way is that, of course, it fits in with the Government's ideological attack on publicly accountable public spending. If the Government is so willing to put the taxpayers' money into the film industry, what is wrong with doing it by way of increasing assistance to the Australian Film Commission which is, after all, the national body set up by the Labor Government and maintained by the Fraser Government to engage in investment in films, to assist the production of experimental films and other activities. That form of public assistance is, as I said, publicly accountable. It can be examined by senators at Senate Estimates committees. As a result, the public is in no doubt about how much money is going to the film industry by way of direct allocation to the Australian Film Commission.

The other means, of course, is public expenditure by stealth. There is no accurate way of costing the concession. Even now, in its present form, there is no accurate way of costing it. There is no way in which the public can know from year to year what it will cost. There is no accountability for this form of tax concession. All that happens is that an undefined number of people get undefined reductions of their tax bill. But we as a Senate, we as a parliament, never get to examine what is lost to public revenue in that way. For although it is a burden to the taxpayer, it is a hidden burden, a disguised burden which allows the Fraser Government, with its particular ideology against the public sector, to claim that it is reducing public expenditures when of course it is creating vast and undefined new burdens for the public purse. I must stress that that is a particularly obnoxious feature of the scheme to which the Opposition is quite hostile.

What effect will the legislation in its present form have on the film industry? The Opposition, I must say, is well aware of the high risk nature of investment in the film industry. We are aware that of the total investments in Australian films between 1972 and 1979, amounting to $22.97m, only $8.7m or 38 per cent has been returned to investors. We are aware that investors have a one in two chance of losing 100 per cent of an investment in an Australian film. We are aware that only one in every five Australian films provides a clear profit to investors. In light of the high risk nature of the film industry, the Opposition does not oppose realistic taxation concessions. We have not opposed them in the past and we would not oppose them in the future if they were realistic. We oppose these particular taxation concessions because they are outrageous and irresponsible.

The Treasurer himself described them in the House of Representatives on Friday as 'unparalleled in our taxation laws'. Furthermore, we believe that the Government will not be able to maintain these tax concessions. Again, the Treasurer foreshadowed this when the Bill was debated in the House. He said:
. . . the operation of the Scheme will be carefully monitored over the next six to 12 months and, if the need is demonstrated, appropriate action will be taken.

I say to film investors: 'Be warned. There are more changes in the wind'. Some of the changes might involve retreating to a position which is less obnoxious to the Opposition than the original position was. But the whole point about attracting investors, as anybody in this place ought to know, is that the worst thing for investors is insecurity, instability. We believe that the film industry would have been much better served by a much more modest but stable form of tax concession which would have allowed investors and producers to plan over a long period and which would have allowed the industry to adapt to a realistic and stable level of growth. This stop-go, on-off approach is the worst possible thing if the Government's objective is truly to attract investment into the film industry.

The Government, through its vacillation, has already caused great instability and damage to the film industry. It introduced an unsuccessful tax concession scheme for the film industry in 1978. When this scheme led to large scale tax avoidance, in August 1980 the Government took action, properly, to close tax avoidance schemes in the film industry. But by doing so and by doing so without introducing a stable scheme to take its place, it precipitated a collapse in the industry. This new scheme has been announced in one form, introduced in another, and then amended at the last possible moment. The film industry cannot prosper under the see-saw tax policies of this Government. What is required is realistic legislation to ensure a stable source of private investment and an ongoing and stable source of public investment in the film industry. But it is clear-as the Treasurer, in the same breath that he is introducing this latest lot of amendments, is already foreshadowing more changes-that the stability so desperately required by this particular high risk industry will just not be achieved under the Fraser Government.

The effect of this legislation on the film industry will be an initial over-production of films, subsequent poor distribution deals for Australian films, and a shortage of labour which will push up production costs. Evidence of all of these things is already available. In the long term, the legislation will result in the production of 'quickie' films, produced and distributed within the year in order to obtain taxation concessions in the year of expenditure. This legislation mitigates against the production of quality Australian films. It is actually a deterrent to the achieving of the objective the Prime Minister said at the outset that he was trying to achieve, which is quality Australian films.

The legislation also broadens the definition of 'Australian film' to an unreasonable degree by including within it a film made pursuant to a co-production agreement with a foreign government or an agent of a foreign government. That is all detailed in the specifications of what an Australian film is. Previous requirements found in section 124ZAD are not to apply and a co-production with a foreign government is automatically to be an Australian film. There is no justification for allowing tax concessions, a cost to the taxpayer, to go partly or half to a foreign government or an agent of a foreign government. Unlike the Government, the Australian Labor Party does have a comprehensive policy designed to support the Australian film industry. The Labor Party, as I said, would seek to provide tax incentives at a level which would ensure a stable souce of private investment in films without creating a haven for tax avoidance. I wrote to the Treasurer on 4 May urging him to introduce incentives legislation with the following modifications. The first of these modifications was that any salaries paid to overseas actors, directors, writers, or other participants should be excluded from the production total liable to attract the new tax incentive. My reasons for making that proposition are self-evident. If we are to have expensive tax concessions, they ought to be there to help the Australian industry and to help the talent in the Australian industry. There is no justification for what is happening and what can continue to happen under the legislation in its present form, which is that foreign talent can be brought into an Australian production, a vastly inflated salary paid to that foreign talent, and that vastly inflated salary added to the production cost which will, of course, attract the tax concession. That is simply throwing the Australian taxpayers' money overseas and is an irresponsible action which, of course, again mitigates against Australian producers looking around Australia first to find the talent they need for the production. So that provision should be removed.

I also pointed out that brokerage fees, which shot up to over 20 per cent of production costs recently under the influence of the new incentives, should be excluded. It is perfectly proper for brokers to get the money for a production together, and for a producer to pay a fee to that broker. But why should a brokerage fee of 20 per cent of the total production costs be included and attract a tax concession at the Australian taxpayers' expense. There is no justification for that at all, and no properly preventive measure of such a rort in the present legislation. I pointed out to Mr Howard that the tax write-off of 150 per cent should be modified and reduced to a figure which would attract genuine investment in film rather than the tax evaders. It seems to me and to the Opposition that while ever we have this extravagant figure of 150 per cent that can be written off tax bills we will attract the tax evaders, whatever steps the Commissioner of Taxation takes to try to prevent this happening.

These are modifications which the Labor Party would require before it could consider supporting this legislation. The Treasurer chose to ignore our constructive suggestions and has modified the legislation in a way which deals with none of these problems of abuse and which deals with none of the problems of taxpayers' money going to subsidise overseas talent. Therefore the legislation is still unacceptable to the Labor Party. However, while recognising that tax incentives may be necessary in the short term, the Labor Party would, in the long term, attempt to get a better deal for Australian films, and thus Australian producers and investors, by regulating or by restructuring the distribution-exhibition system in Australia, thus obviating the need for extravagant tax concessions.

The need for regulation of the distribution-exhibition system will become more apparent when the current 30 Australian films in production come onto the market and there are not sufficient exhibition outlets to screen them. This is the whole point. Producing a film is only half, and perhaps the least important half, of why we want to see government support for the Australian film industry. Surely the films are being made to be seen by the Australian public. Surely what it is all about is to provide the Australian public with Australian films that are good and that they want to see. Yet, if we allow the current distribution-exhibition arrangements to continue, many of the films which will be made and which will attract tax concessions will not be seen by the Australian public.

The Senate well knows that the original Australian film industry of the late 1920s and early 1930s collapsed primarily because of the takeover of Australian cinemas and film distribution by foreign interests. As a result, between 1940 and the early 1970s only a handful of feature films was made in Australia. Government action since the early 1970s has been aimed at reversing the situation and establishing a viable Australian film industry. All programs for the development of the Australian film industry so far, by State and Federal governments, have been production oriented. The problems of exhibition-distribution have been pushed into the background. The problems of foreign controlled film exhibition and distribution were put to the Royal Commission into Motion Picture Production in 1929 and the Senate Select Committee on the Encouragement of Australian Productions for Television in 1962 and were dealt with in the 1973 Tariff Board report on motion picture films and television programs. Tariff Board recommendation No. 5 included:
That legislative provision be made to adjust and regulate the ownership and control of cinemas.

The report concluded that, to give Australian films a fair chance in the market, the present concentration of control within the industry should be reduced. The report states that this is only possible if the dominance of exhibition outlets by the Village, Greater Union and Hoyts groups is broken. To achieve this the report recommended limitations on shareholdings on exhibition outlets along the lines set out for television in the Broadcasting and Television Act. The report also recommended that in future no producer or distributor should control exhibition outlets. This is the major problem of the film industry and it is a problem that the Government has failed to grasp. The Australian Labor Party recognises that by providing production assistance alone governments will not solve the problems of the Australian film industry. We recognise that there are overseas precedents, such as in the United States of America, for the restriction of links between distributors and exhibition interests and for the breaking up of monopolistic exhibition chains. We also recognise that there are legal options for taking Federal action along these lines in Australia.

In conclusion, the Labor Party does not oppose tax incentives to the film industry in principle but they should be at a reasonable level. They should benefit only the local industry and not overseas investors. They should be designed in such a way as to minimise abuse and, of course, they should be closely monitored and in a form whereby the public has some idea of what the scheme is costing. In none of these respects does the legislation before us measure up. It fails in all respects. We are unable to support it. I would like to say that as a long term means of assisting the industry the Labor Party does not believe tax concessions are the most appropriate form. We are prepared in the short term to maintain tax concessions at a reasonable level-perhaps tax concessions at a reasonable level in the long term-but they are not the most appropriate means of assistance to the industry. They are by no means a comprehensive means of assistance to the film industry. There ought to be-and the Labor Party is committed to providing-ongoing public investment in the Australian film industry by the Australian Film Commission. Of course, the States film corporations are carrying out a very important role in this respect.

Most significantly, we would seek to develop alternative assistance to the Australian film industry through the restructuring of the system of distribution and exhibition. Again, in this vital area the Government has failed to act. The legislation which is before us is just another excuse for the lack of any Government policy to ensure the long term survival of the Australian film industry. The Australian Labor Party is determined that the Australian film industry will survive. We reject the amendments proposed by this legislation because they endanger the survival of a quality industry. At the earliest possible opportunity we will seek to take action along the lines that I have outlined to put the Australian film industry on a firm and stable base where it can grow, develop and build on the record of success which it has had in the last decade of which I believe all Australians and, may I say, in particular the Australian Labor Party, are very proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise in support of this piece of legislation-the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. The feature film is probably the only original art form to come into existence in the twentieth century. The nature and type of films produced by any national cinema say a great deal about the nation which produces them and about the culture for which they are produced. Had time permitted, I would have liked to have said something in detail about the history and development of our Australian film industry. However, I do not intend to do so this afternoon. I know that many of these points will be covered in a speech to be given later in this debate by my colleague Senator Hamer. I say simply that the film has been an integral part of Australian culture for a long time. From Soldiers of the Cross through to Gallipoli, Australians have been producing quality films which in their own distinct way have been world leaders and have said a great deal about Australia, about the skill and integrity of Australian film makers and about the values that are important to Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, it is true that in recent years the film industry has had its notable ups and downs, particularly in terms of the number of films being produced. From about 1975 to 1979, on an average some 20 feature films each year were produced with varying degrees of artistic and commercial success. For those who are particularly interested, they will be able to find in David Stratton's book entitled The Last New Wave: Australian Film Revival a complete analysis of those films and of their commercial and artistic successes. It is certainly true that in 1980 this had declined so that only about eight feature films were produced. At the moment it looks as if in this current year we will see something in the vicinity of 25 films being produced.

Senator Ryan has already drawn attention to the number of film backers who have sought certificates in order to qualify for this tax concession. In her second reading speech, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mentioned a figure of some 200 films to a value of $145m. An assumption is drawn from this that, simply because certificates are issued, because the value of the films for which certificates are issued is $145m, this is a realistic estimate of what the cost to revenue might be. The physical constraints imposed on the Australian film industry in terms of personnel, producers, directors, cameras, crews, processing, location and all of the other factors which are significant will lead to a situation quite contrary to what Senator Ryan predicts. She claimed that there was already over-production of films. Rather for the reasons that I have mentioned there will be a quite clear limitation on the number of films capable of being produced. It is certainly not possible to say how many films that will be. I concede that. It is certainly not possible to say how many there will be, but it certainly is possible to say that there will be nowhere near the 200 which have so far sought some preliminary certification.

This concession is unparalleled in its generosity. It is not true to say that the Australian film industry is the only industry for which all sorts of special exceptions have been made. Under section 51 (1) and under Division 10, the Income Tax Assessment Act already provides for concessions to the film industry. Section 160ACA provides concessions in terms of capital subscribed for off-shore petroleum exploration ventures. Section 78 (1) B deals with afforestation. Section 23 (O) deals with gold mining. Division 10 deals with mining operations in general. Division 16 deals with income averaging provisions. Each of them has been introduced in the Income Tax Assessment Act as a measure of Government support for a particular industry or for a particular set of income arrangements or to encourage certain activities which the Government wishes as a matter of policy to promote and foster.

I accept that a grave responsibility now lies not only on the Government but also on the industry itself to be conscious of the fact that there will be people who will seek to exploit this in the worst possible sense. It also ought to be indicated that some of them have been around for a long time. Perhaps the most crooked and most wretched of these particular schemes is one run by United American and Australasian Film Productions Pty Ltd and a notorious character by the name of Mr Picton Warlow who, using the existing provisions of section 51 (1), writes to potential investors and says, in effect, that he can turn an investment of $10,000 into a deduction of between $37,500 and $45,000 under the existing scheme. He is not the only one knocking around in the market. I have real worries about a group that calls itself Ozfilm Pty Ltd and has an associated group which calls itself Nolava Consultants. They are currently putting out prospectuses but they do not really want too many people to know exactly what they are offering. In fact, in the opening page of the document Ozfilm puts out, it says:
No part of this outline--
That is the scheme to raise money for the production of a film tentatively entitled Going Platinum-

is to be reproduced or transmitted to or discussed with any member of the public or any potential investors at any time unless personally known to the General Partner and such person has received a numbered copy of this confidential outline. Any reproduction transmission or discussion is a breach of confidence and may constitute a violation of the Companies Act or The Security Industry Act.
A similar organisation called Quantum Films is seeking money for a film called Relatives. It says in its document:

Neither this document nor its content is to be reproduced or transmitted to or discussed with any member of the public at any time or any potential investor unless such investor is personally known to the offeror or its agents. Such prohibited reproduction transmission or discussion may constitute a violation of the Companies Act or of the Securities Industry Act and is a breach of confidence.

Groups like Film Co., Tasman Developments Australia Pty Ltd, and Cassandra, about which one can find out very little in the market-place, are similarly getting themselves involved in this operation. They are concerned only about financial lurks not about our great film industry. It will be in the interests of the industry, more than anybody else, to police these concessions and to ensure that they are not put at risk by the unscrupulous operators who would be attracted to any scheme, no matter how generous or ungenerous it happened to be and no matter who it genuinely sought to help. Liberal and National Country Party governments have had a long record of support for the Australian film industry. Prime Minister John Gorton was a great supporter and introduced much of the early legislation in support of the industry. In the current arrangements being made for other parts of the film industry, it will be noted that this Government has committed a large sum of money to the rehousing and reconstruction of the Australian Film and Television School. That is a wonderful investment in the industry and in the young men and women who are its future. I am not one who takes the view that the Opposition front bench spokesman, Senator Walsh, has put so far as this industry is concerned. When speaking about continued support of this policy by the Government, Senator Walsh criticised the Government and said:

Since the Government has broken promises to just about every other section of the community, why should it honour irresponsible undertakings to a noisy, greedy, egocentric bunch of tax dodgers and their parasitic advocates is beyond comprehension . . .

I think that there are hundreds of very genuine people in the Australian film industry, a lot of people who have done a great deal for Australia within the Australian film industry. To describe them as 'noisy, greedy, egocentric tax dodgers and parasitic advocates' brings great discredit on the Opposition. It sits very ill with the statements that Senator Ryan made earlier about the extent to which the Labor Party allegedly seeks to support and encourage the Australian film industry. It is clear that groups like the Australian Film and Television Producers Association will have to play a pivotal role in ensuring that this legislation is policed and is made effective. Its representatives have been down here having discussions with Senator Ryan, the Treasurer (Mr Howard), me and others. In particular, representations were made by Ray Beattie, its President, James Mitchell, its Executive Director, and Tom Hayden, one of its councillors, who are themselves reputable and significant figures in the film industry. I know they are awake to their responsibilities.

It is certainly true that changes were made between the statement of 18 December 1980 and the legislation as it currently stands. There was a situation in which in changing those rules some disadvantage would have occurred for those who had genuinely invested their money prior to 27 May on the basis of an understanding of what the statement of 18 December in fact meant. Amendments to the Act were made in the House of Representatives to ensure that these persons were not disadvantaged. I have a letter from Mr Skrzynski, the General Manager of the Australian Film Commission, addressed to the Treasurer and a telex response from the Treasurer to Mr Skrzynski which goes further and in fact outlines some of the interpretations which I think are important in regard to those persons who had invested or agreed formally to invest their money prior to 27 May. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard both the letter and the telex.
Leave granted.

Amendment to Income Tax Act re Film Investment to 'Restore Benefits of December Statement'
We are concerned that the above amendment cover persons who have entered into financial commitments as a result of the Ministerial Statement of 18 December.
Two classes of person are involved, producers and investors. We identify the categories as follows.
