Dear Mr Skrzynski

In response to your telex of yesterday I confirm that the Government has agreed to amend the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1981 with respect to expenditure on film investments under contracts entered into on or after 1 October 1980 and before 28 May 1981.

Subject to the general eligibility requirements for the income tax concessions being otherwise satisfied, this will have the following consequences for the four categories of situations described in your telex.

Category 1 Investors who paid cash into eligible film projects on or before 27 May 1981 will qualify for deductions in the 1980-81 income year (assuming regular accounting periods for income tax purposes).

Category 2 Investors who entered into unconditional contracts on or before 27 May 1981 to invest in a film will attract deductions in the 1980-81 income year for eligible expenditures incurred under those contracts by 30 June 1981. Any expenditure incurred after 30 June 1981 under such contracts will attract deductions in the year in which the expenditure is incurred.

Category 3 The existence of an escape clause in a contract that would have permitted the investor to withdraw in the event of the legislation not being in accord with the ministerial statement of 18 December 1980 will not prevent that contract from being recognised as valid for these purposes. The tax treatment of persons in category 3 will correspond with that for category 2 if the contract is honoured.

Category 4 Whether a pre-28 May 1981 contract to invest in a film had been made is a question of fact to be determined in each particular case. Persons who had not made a contractual commitment on or before 27 May 1981 will not qualify for deductions in respect of any investment until the film has been produced and used to produce assessable income from exhibition.

On the basis of your telex it is not readily apparent that investors subsequent to 27 May 1981 would have been party to any prior commitment on the basis of assurances received by producers from investment intermediaries.
Yours sincerely
JOHN HOWARD Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I wish to respond quickly to three things that arise from what Senator Ryan said earlier. The first is that I think Senator Ryan presented a most misleading presentation of the Treasurer's commitment for a review of this legislation. She in fact implied quite clearly and deliberately that if the expenditure was getting out of hand, within six to 12 months the Government would review it with a view to reducing the concessions being made available. If one examines the second reading speech of the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, one will find that she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I note that representations have been made to the Government that the effect of the modifications to December Statement will be to direct investment away from quality productions which may take some time to reach the market place.
The Government has examined these comments carefully but does not consider that, with the exception of pre-28 May contracts, they should lead to any departure from the approach taken in the Bill.
The Minister stated further:
Nevertheless, the operation of the scheme will be carefully monitored over the next six to 12 months and, if the need is demonstrated, appropriate action will be taken.

That does not mean appropriate action to withdraw the concessions. Far from it if, in fact, the claims made that these recent changes to the concession as originally announced will lead to the production of lower quality films are actually seen to occur. Given the fact that the thrust of the Bill is to encourage quality productions, that is what will be reviewed. It is not that the concession will be reviewed in order to wind it back but that the operation will be reviewed to ensure that there is no deleterious impact on quality films in Australia. I think it is also untrue for Senator Ryan simply to present the move to what has been called 'quickie' films without any discussion of the argument which says that through the operation of the provisional tax system this in fact will not necessarily occur. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement which set this out. The statement was made by a colleague of mine from the other place, Mr Michael Baume. It deals with the question of the use of provisional tax by film investors. I seek leave to have it incorporated because it explains this situation and I will not have to go into detail in the course of this speech.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
MICHAEL BAUME, M.P.
MEMBER FOR MACARTHUR
Address all correspondence to-
P.O. BOX 643
NOWRA, NSW 2540
PRESS STATEMENT
5 June 1981
Financiers had 'blackmailed' film producers into objecting to the Government's new taxation assistance to the film industry, the Member for Macarthur, Michael Baume, said in Parliament today.

Mr Baume, who was speaking on the Second Reading of the Income Tax Assessment Bill, said, 'Many potential investors in the film industry have threatened to withdraw funding to existing and proposed film projects now that details of the legislation are known.

''As a result, film producers have been imposing ridiculous pressure on the Government to remove the safeguards against tax 'fiddles' that have been introduced since the initial statement on taxation assistance was made last year.
''The reality is that these generous concessions (which the Labor Party described as 'outrageously generous') will result in a flood of money becoming available for the Australian film industry.
''So the fears of film producers that they will be bankrupted by the withdrawal of funds by these 'blackmailing' investors are unfounded.

''On the contrary, the relatively small number of remarkably capable Australian film producers will in future be in a position to pick and choose their financial backers out of the enormous volume of potential investors who will be attracted by the Government's generous concessions.

''These highly capable and world-renowned Australian film makers will not be under any real pressure to revert to producing 'quickies' as a result of the Government's tax incentives as claimed by the Opposition.

''In the first place, their integrity is too high for that, and in any event the tax concession adequately provides for those films where the major expenditure can be spread over as long as 21 months while still providing the same tax benefit, in terms of timing, as would be received by investing in a 'quickie' movie within 12 months.

''This is because of the effect of provisional tax which is not applied until 9 months after the close of the previous financial year, and which is paid at the same time as tax liability for that previous year falls due.

''I know of no film ever produced in Australia where the major expenditure has been spread over a longer period than 21 months, so that there is no serious cash-flow disadvantage to investors in longer movies of this nature as against 'quickies', particularly as borrowing and other costs incurred by investors can be deducted from current year income.

''Those film-makers protesting at the present sensible safeguards in these tax concessions are not serving the best interests of the film industry. Instead they are helping those 'investors' whose only interest is in trying to keep open as many tax dodge loopholes as possible'', Mr Baume said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The third point I wish to raise is that, in effect, Senator Ryan said: 'This will lead to a rip-off because there will be grossly inflated brokerage fees built into the cost of production and we will have to provide deductions for all of these glorified inflated brokerage fees'. That is simply not true. If one looks at the explanatory memorandum under the heading of 'The deduction' at page 2 one will find that it states:

SPEECH.PARA: In circumstances where money is expended by way of contribution to the production of a film, the expenditure will qualify for deduction only to the extent that the moneys so contributed are applied directly in the production of the film.

I stress that word 'only'. This in fact is a guarantee in the legislation that the over-inflated brokerage fees which rightly have caused concern in the industry will not be permitted to be part of the concessions and will not lead to the distortion that was alleged previously.

In summary I say these things: First, I am extremely unhappy about the role which the Australian Film Commission has played in this whole sad saga of these recent changes to film industry tax legislation. I hope that the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wilson) will get round to putting a radical broom through the Australian Film Commission and to putting into effect some of these Peat, Marwick and Mitchell recommendations about the Australian Film Commission. I certainly hope he will get round to doing something about the role of the General Manager of the Australian Film Commission which, within the history of the development of this film legislation, will be seen in retrospect to have been a disgrace and to have been contrary to the best interests of the Australian film industry. I do not believe that the AFC is the appropriate vehicle for the channelling of all government moneys into the production of films. It is certainly a good socialist solution to the question of how to encourage the film industry. It is not a solution that commends itself to anybody who does not believe in government control extending further and further, especially in artistic and cultural endeavours. When one looks at some of the investment decisions of the Australian Film Commission, its members would certainly be the last persons whose judgment in this matter I would trust. When one looks at the commercial success of films such as Mad Max, one is constantly reminded of the success of commercial films that have never been able to get-or have not sought-a cent out of the Australian Film Commission.

There are certainly at least three major issues which still have to be grappled with in terms of the overall position of the film industry. The first is the question of the importation of release prints rather than requiring that more and more of the release prints be produced in Australia by Australian processing laboratories. The second is the problem of the distribution of films in Australia. In fact it was an error made in the taxation legislation in 1936 which in effect penalised Australian distributors in favour of foreign distributors and put them out of the market. We need to rectify the situation which has grown historically since then. Our films cannot continue to be hostage to the whims of foreign controlled distributors. The third is the need for a more intelligent approach to the support and encouragement of Australian film archives. Anybody who has noted the enthusiastic reaction of people when the Sydney Film Festival was able to open with a showing of the film The Term of His Natural Life, made I think in 1927 and substantially reconstructed and made available for today's viewing audience by Ray Edmondson and his devoted colleagues in the Film Archives section of the National Film Library, can see the importance of archives to the Australian film industry.

Those who look at John Hindes's recent book Other People's Pictures will come to understand the pervasive and important position of film as part of any national culture. I believe this Bill attempts to bring about a situation which not only encourages in a direct sense the genuine people in the Australian film industry but also keeps out the unethical operators. I believe this is yet another indication of my Liberal Government's determination to support one of the most interesting, dynamic and significant parts of the creative life of Australia. I have great pleasure in supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to Senator Puplick for the last quarter of an hour or so I can only endorse the verdict of the electors of New South Wales, who decided last October that he will be leaving the Senate at the end of this month.
—He will be back.

—Somebody tells me that he will be back, so I presume that the stories we have been hearing about the National Country Party getting rid of Senator Carrick are correct. Senator Puplick told us how good Australian films are, and I certainly would not dispute that. However, he did not tell us much about the specifics of the Bill. That is not surprising. He claimed that there were precedents for these sorts of concessions, which is just not true. In the taxation Act there is no provision, and never has been, for capital expenditure to be written off against taxable income at the rate of 150 per cent, let alone immediately; nor has there been a simultaneous provision for any part of the return on that investment to be free from income tax.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague and leader Senator Button has often referred to the bad legislation of the Fraser Government and the mad legislation of the Fraser Government. With this Bill the Government has managed to put the two together-this legislation is both mad and bad. David Barnett, the Press secretary of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), following the Premiers Conference early last month, attempted to stand over the Australian Broadcasting Commission with threats of dismissal to ABC staff in an attempt to censor the news. That showed the very ugly face of the Fraser Government, as distinct from the phoney face of the Fraser Government concocted in the Senate by such people as Senator Baume who mouth pious platitudes about the independence of the ABC. The reality behind that phoney face and those pious platitudes is David Barnett and other members of the Prime Minister's Press staff standing over people in the ABC, storming the ABC office in Parliament House and attempting to censor the news and to suppress the dissemination of accurate information, the attempts, in some cases, being backed up by threats of dismissal. This measure shows not that ugly face of the Fraser Government but the farcical and very unfunny face of the Fraser Government. Its original inspiration, we now know, came from a television make-up girl. That was compounded, of course, by the Prime Minister's penchant for tax dodging schemes of all types.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the imputation that the Prime Minister has a penchant for tax dodging schemes of all kinds is not in accordance with the Standing Orders. It is an imputation against a member of another chamber.
—I do not know whether the honourable senator was using parables. He might clarify that point. I missed the thrust of it.

—The Prime Minister certainly has a high propensity to write into the taxation Act provisions which facilitate the avoidance of income tax by a variety of people; and the legislative record testifies to that. Since the commitment was first given at the end of September we have had the film industry taxation concessions scheme marks I, II and III. All of them are stupid and all of them are obnoxious. It first surfaced in the Prime Minister's policy speech and accompanying policy document, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Tax concessions to encourage investment in the production of Australian films ($2m).

That was the estimated cost. That estimate is and always has been inaccurate. It is and was a fraudulent estimate. It could have been correct only if the total investment which qualified for deduction had been equal to $3.3m. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has since admitted that the estimated loss to revenue now is $20m and on the figures he recently gave it is more likely to be $30m. In acknowledging that the $2m was in error by a factor of 10, the blame was transferred backwards on to the Film Industry Association-it was an industry estimate-which I must say incorporates the novel proposition of the acceptance of program costing by the beneficiaries of the programs. If the Fraser Government were to extend that principle to the area of education, we would have self-assessment instead of examinations and people would award themselves degrees and higher academic titles. If the Prime Minister is to accept industry costings of programs when he promises to inflict them on the taxpayers, one wonders why half the staff of the Taxation Office is being retained.

That original brief and non-specific commitment-non-specific except in terms of the fraudulent estimated cost-was supplemented by a Press statement on 15 October which stated that '150 per cent of the investment would be eligible for the write-off in the first year of expenditure' and 50 per cent of the net earnings of the film would be tax free. There has been some confusion subsequently about the meaning of 'net earnings'. If there is an investment of $1m in a film and that $1m is all written off at the rate of 150 per cent, the term 'net earnings' as defined in the legislation means that every dollar of income from that film between $1 and $500,000 will be exempt from taxation. On 18 December we got a definitive statement from the Treasurer and from the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Ellicott, who was aptly described recently by my colleague Dr Klugman in the other House as an innumerate lawyer. The statement reads:

Deductions will be available in the year of income in which the capital is actually expended by the investor for example, under the common type of investment arrangements, at the time that the money is paid into the relevant production account . . .

I emphasise: '. . . at the time that the money is paid into the relevant production account'. A subsequent clause in the statement adds that unless the film is ultimately completed the deduction will be disallowed. The important point to note is that, according to that statement, at the time the money is paid into a production account-before a film has been produced-it will be eligible for deduction from that year's taxable income at the rate of 150 per cent. That proposition would have been incredibly expensive to public revenue, and still is. It was also, because of that production account provision, an open-ended invitation to tax dodgers to defer taxation without ever making a film. All they had to do was pay the money into a production account. They got their tax deduction of 150 per cent for that year and in the next year could argue with the Deputy Commissioner about whether or not they had made a film.

If such a provision had been put in the Act-subsequently it was dropped-the only way of avoiding the deferral on a year by year basis of virtually unlimited tax liabilities would have been to vest in somebody an arbitrary power to decide whose production account was legitimate and whose was not. That would have been possible, but it would have been very bad law. I am sure that even a majority of the members of the Liberal Party would agree that such arbitrary power to decide what is a legitimate production account, one which qualifies, and what is not should not be vested, if at all avoidable, in any individual.

It is also possible, because of options to vary provisional tax, that the tax benefits could actually be obtained before the money was paid into a production account. Provisional taxpayers have until the end of March-it is not unusual, on a de facto basis, for one to have the option of a somewhat later date-to vary the provisional tax which has been assessed by the Australian Taxation Office in respect of the current financial year's income. Thus, a provisional taxpayer intending to pay into a production account some time in June-I have no doubt that this has been done-would have varied, on the personal option basis, the provisional tax liability normally due for payment on 31 March. In other words, he would gain a taxation benefit-assessed taxation would be deferred or avoided-before he had actually paid the money into the production account, let alone made a film. An oversight in respect to that occurred in even the Australian Financial Review editorial on the subject. Although quite rightly the editorial was highly critical of the whole proposition, for that reason it understated the case against this legislation.

I have absolutely no doubt that if not the loudest squeals, then certainly the heaviest push, which forced the Government backdown last week on the production account provision would have been provoked by the tax dodge which would have produced a concession before money was even paid out or a film made. Tax dodgers would have been participating in the scheme effectively from the end of March of this year, through varying their provisional tax, and if that had been subsequently disallowed they would have had some awkward explanations to make to the Deputy Commissioner.

Of course the Treasury people, who are infinitely more numerate than is the Prime Minister and possibly even than television make-up girls, realised very quickly the potential for deferral on a year by year basis of virtually unlimited amounts of tax liability if that production account clause remained. Therefore, a fortnight ago when the legislation finally was introduced after a protracted struggle, that provision was dropped. That was film tax rort Mark II. The eligibility under Mark II for the 150 per cent write-off was not to be available until the film was concluded, whereas under the 18 December definitive statement, it would have been available as soon as the money was paid into a production account. That alteration closed off the opportunity for deferral of tax liabilities by the pure tax dodgers who, I emphasise, need never have even made a film. All they had to do to qualify was to pay into a production account.

However, it opened up two other problems. First, it provided an obvious incentive for making 'quickies', because the film had to be completed before the tax provision would become available. The point that Senator Puplick made about provisional taxpayers and the option to vary-although unfortunately I did not see his table-might have some effect on that but would not entirely cancel it out. There is still, with or without considering the implications of provisional tax and the option to vary, a definite incentive to make 'quickies' which, incidentally, would be fine for owners of television stations who also happened to own a film company. That is true of one well-known media magnate, perhaps two, but certainly of the well-known Rupert Murdoch. Perhaps we can see his influence behind this legislation as well.

For the Government the second problem of that change was that it upset the articulate lobby, although I emphasise that all the benefits which were available under the original proposition, Mark I, to people who actually made films, as distinct from those who exploited a stupid suggested law to defer tax liability without making films, were still available under proposition Mark II-and indeed are available under Mark III-except that the year in which they could claim the benefit may have been affected.

I have referred to the oversight in the editorial of the Australian Financial Review. The Melbourne Age, which is another one of this country's leading newspapers, in rightly condemning this proposition, also understated the case against it by saying, in an editorial of last Saturday:
. . . income from their investment (should the film make a profit) will be tax free until the income exceeds 50 per cent of the outlay. Few films actually show a profit.

I touched on this matter earlier. The implication-although it could have been expressed more clearly-is that the film income which is tax free is that which is derived after 100 per cent of the capital investment has been recovered by income. That is not the way it is. The income which is tax free is not that which represents between 100 per cent and 150 per cent of the original investment. In fact, it is the income which is between one per cent and 50 per cent of the original investment. The fact that two of the nation's best newspapers, whilst opposing the proposition, did not grasp fully the dimensions of the rort, is highly significant. The Government incompetence and irresponsibility was beyond belief. That was Mark II and that stood until last week. It was threatened last Sunday week-on 31 May-when the Prime Minister attended a dinner for, I understand, the National Institute of Dramatic Art. The lobbyists there caught him on a bit of a binge and, in what the Australian Financial Review euphemistically described as an oddly-worded speech, the Prime Minister promised to review the change made in Mark II, which was to insist that the film actually be completed before the tax benefits became available. That produced Mark III, which was the same as Mark II except that money which had already been committed to a production account between 18 December and 27 May qualified for the 150 per cent write-off in this financial year.

I suggest that the short term cost to revenue of that backdown could be as high as $10m. The cost of the whole proposal-implicity admitted in the total investment figure which the Treasurer gave the other day-is $30m, against the $2m fraudulent original Government estimate which is now being blamed on the industry. Apart from being incredibly expensive in their final form both Mark II and Mark III provide, if not an incentive to make bad films, certainly an incentive to complete films quickly so that the tax benefits can be obtained. With or without provisional tax, there is no getting away from that fact. There is an incentive to complete films as quickly as possible. People who are going to make quality films of the type for which the Australian film industry, rightly, has an enviable reputation will find it difficult if not impossible to make those quality films within one financial year. They will be in the position of being unable to attract the limited supply of film making resources, as Senator Puplick has already mentioned. They will not be able to bid those resources away from the manufacturers of the 'quickies' who are interested in a quick return, at the expense of the public revenue, rather than in making quality films.

There is no doubt that both Mark II and Mark III would be and will be deterrents to the production of quality films. It is axiomatic that a production subsidy would be a more cost effective way of assisting quality film production than any of the propositions put forward. It would be more cost effective because the benefits of that flow directly into the industry. The benefits of Mark I, Mark II or Mark III of this proposal flow substantially, if not entirely, not to the film industry but to the tax avoiders. Channelling any given quantity of public assistance into the Australian Film Corporation would probably be an even more effective way. Perhaps that has something to do with Senator Puplick's hostility to the Film Corporation. Money channelled to the Film Corporation cannot be syphoned off by tax dodgers. The record of the Government and the Prime Minister, in particular, on this issue is the type of record that would be expected from an innumerate president of a banana republic. As I said earlier, the full dimensions and the full horror of this proposition have not been grasped even by those editorial writers in the nation's leading newspapers who justifiably condemned the situation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which shows the position from the viewpoint of both the public revenue and the individual investor.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
Investment of $1m by Investor Paying Marginal Tax Rate 60 per cent and Assuming Film Producing Income of $0.5m
Investment = 1.0; tax deduction = 1.5; tax saving = 0.9
Film income = 0.5; tax-free; investor income = 0.5
Initial outlay = $1m; net return = $1.4m
Tax revenue forgone, $1.2m (i.e. 0.9 immediate reduction in tax payable, plus tax forgone on $0.5m film revenue = $0.3m)

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows that an individual investor, providing he is paying the maximum marginal tax rate of 60 per cent, who invests money in a film-I know now that the film has to be completed, so they will make a 'quickie'-will attain an immediate return in the form of a remission of tax liability equal to 90 per cent of the investment. In other words, if this investor puts $100,000 into a film he will reduce his tax assessment by $90,000. If the film returns income equal to 10 per cent of the cost of making the film the investor recovers the other 10 per cent. In other words, the break-even position for the investor is a film that produces 10 per cent of its own cost. All revenue between 10 per cent and 50 per cent of cost in the form of revenue is tax free profit to the investor. For an investment of $100,000 in a film which generates income equal to only 50 per cent of its cost-in other words, a dismal commercial failure-an investor will receive total benefits of $140,000, $120,000 of which is at the cost of the public revenue. Income, if any, above 50 per cent of the production cost will be taxed in the normal way. For that taxpayer, the public revenue would effectively get 60 per cent of it and the investor would get 40 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the situation from the point of view of the investor. What is the situation from the public revenue point of view? The minimal cost to the public revenue will be 90 per cent of the cost of making the film. The maximum cost to the public revenue, which is maximised at an income to the film equal to 50 per cent of its production cost, is an additional 30 per cent of the production cost because that is the taxation forgone on what otherwise would have been taxable income. In other words, the cost to the public revenue of making these films under this proposition will fall somewhere between 90 per cent and 120 per cent of the cost of making the film. It should not be too hard to deduce from that that it would be cheaper for the Government to make the films itself; to fund the films wholly and to give them away to whoever wanted them. The Senate is being asked to support legislation which will be more expensive to the public revenue than the proposition that the Government should entirely foot the bill for the production of films and then give them away.

I will have one last word on the investor who, for example, has $100,000 to invest, who puts the money into a film and who pays the maximum marginal tax rate. Let us assume the investor makes a film every year, that it shows a 50 per cent return-income equal to 50 per cent of its cost-that he puts the funds back each year for five years. Would any honourable senator like to hazard a guess as to what the investor finishes up with at the end of five years for his $100,000 initial investment? The answer is $538,000. That is 40 per cent interest compounded for five years. Fortunately, I think there will be some physical constraints which will prevent too many people actually achieving that sort of unearned capital gain at the expense of the public revenue. But I suspect that people in control of film making companies and television broadcasters will devise some way of going pretty close to it.

I will now refer specifically to Division 10BA of the Bill and the exclusions qualifications. Among the exclusions are a film forming part of a drama program series that is, or is intended to be, of a continuing nature and a training film. I am not criticising the people who drafted the legislation. Given a mad government which is committed to passing bad and stupid legislation the blame for any defects certainly should not be attributed to the people who had no option but to draft the provision the best way they could. The question of intention arises; the provision refers to series intended to be of a continuing nature. Again, there is that problem of arbitrary power being given to somebody. Not only is arbitrary power being given to somebody but also it is subject to appeal to the courts. Those provisions relating to intention have been one of the long-standing errors in the whole taxation Act. When one writes sections such as that into the taxation Act whereby one has to determine the intention of somebody, when quite clearly it is impossible on any objective basis to determine what the intention was, it is arbitrary power and bad law and it opens up potential for tax avoidance, particularly for those people who are both film makers and television producers.

This is an appalling piece of legislation. It is an insult to the intelligence of every member of this Parliament to ask that they support it. I have absolutely no doubt that if the few numerate members of the Liberal Party had a clear choice they would certainly vote against this legislation. Most of them, perhaps all of them, and certainly all of the Opposition would provide assistance to the film industry. We have a great respect for the quality of films that has been turned out, but this is not a scheme to provide provision for the film industry on a cost-effective basis. It has built into it now, both in its Mark II and Mark III forms, provisions which will probably sound the death knell of the quality Australian feature film industry because the people who want to make quality films will not be able to compete in the market place for the limited film resources against those who are primarily interested in tax dodging and, therefore, in turning out quickies.

Senator Hamer will follow me in this debate. I will be surprised if he does not make some pertinent observations about this Bill. In particular I would like him to comment on the points I have raised and to justify his support for the Bill-if he is going to vote for the Bill; I assume he is-in view of the enormous cost to revenue, the enormous potential gains at public expense to investors through exploiting the provisions for tax avoidance, the deterrent effect to the making of quality films and the fact that it will be cheaper for the Government to make the films on its own account and give them away than to assist the film industry in this way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian film industry has had a long and turbulent history. Film production started early in Australia, the first film-which included footage of the Melbourne Cup-being screened in 1896, only one year after the world's first public film screening in Paris. In 1906 the Tait Brothers' film The True Story of the Kelly Gang was one of the first feature length films made anywhere in the world. The early years of the Australian film industry were dominated by the figure of Raymond Longford whose life mirrored the fortunes of the Australian film industry. He made 31 films between 1911 and 1934, including Australia's first screen classic, The Sentimental Bloke, made in 1919. After 1934 he was prevented from making any further films, not only because of problems with financial backing but also because of the very great difficulty of gaining public release for any Australian feature film at that time. This gifted film maker ended his working life as a night watchman on the Sydney wharves.

SPEECH.PARA: By the 1930s the once flourishing Australian film industry was in ruins. It had been hit by the flood of American imports, by the arrival of the talkies and by the domination of the cinema outlets by large foreign-controlled chains which were not interested in exhibiting Australian made films. The consequences were catastrophic. In 1930 only three feature films were made compared with 16 in 1926 and 18 in 1916. The first 25 post-World War II years were also barren for the Australian film industry. Feature film production was almost non-existent. The British film industry made a few films here in the 1940s and the 1950s and the occasional American unit came to Australia. But these were not Australian films. They were American or British versions of Australian stories made for foreign audiences, with foreign actors making peculiar attempts to be Australians. Admittedly, a few Australian feature films were made during this period, mostly by Chips Rafferty but, frankly, they were not very good films. In any case, they could not be properly distributed through the foreign-controlled outlets. The Commonwealth Film Unit did turn out competently made documentaries but they could not match the far more imaginative productions of the Canadians, for instance.

All in all, until little more than 10 years ago, the Australian film industry was a mess and it would have been a brave person who would have predicted that it would get out of it. Yet now, in 1981, the mood has completely changed. Our film industry is internationally acclaimed. Look at the roll-call of success: Sunday Too Far Away, Picnic at Hanging Rock and Caddie in 1975; The Devil's Playground and Storm Boy in 1976; The Getting of Wisdom, The Picture Show Man and The Last Wave in 1977; The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith, News Front and Mouth to Mouth in 1978; Cathy's Child, My Brilliant Career and Mad Max in 1979; and Manganinnie and Breaker Morant in 1980. Of course, not all the films made have been successful. More than 125 feature films have been completed since the film revival started and only a small proportion has been financially or artistically successful-by no means always the same thing, by the way.

By 1980 only 16 per cent of the feature films the Australian Film Commission had invested in had made a profit, that is, less than one in six was profitable: 49 per cent-nearly half-had brought in no money whatsoever to the producers. In other words, they had not covered their print and distribution costs. The other 35 per cent had covered their costs and brought back something to the producers but not enough to cover production costs. Yet this is a common pattern of film making everywhere. It is a high risk industry with many failures. What has been astonishing about the new Australian film industry has, in fact, been the number of films that have been artistic and critical successes. However, a depressing number have been far more artistically successful overseas than at home, for we still have the remnants of a cultural cringe, though we have no reason to hang on to it.
The new wave of Australian films is receiving praise all round the world, with remarks being made such as 'maturity', 'intelligence' and 'clarity' or, as an English critic said about one film:
. . . exciting, subtle, beautifully made, beautifully photographed, superbly acted and extremely moving-I regard it as just about perfect.

The prominent English actor James Mason recently confessed that he was 'tremendously jealous' of the Australian industry. Formal international recognition is starting to come too with Jack Thompson winning a best supporting actor award at Cannes, Judy Davis winning the best actress British Academy Award and no less than three nominations for this year's American Academy Award oscars. Of course, it is not only feature films that have been in the sensational new wave. Bruce Petty won an American Oscar in 1976 for the best animated film and documentaries such as The Last Tasmanian and Frontline have been winning widespread acclaim.

What caused this dramatic turn around? I think the most important thing was that by 1970 Australia's cultural cringe-a deplorable expression but all too true-was starting to recede a little. For this we owe a lot to the post-war tide of non-British migrants. While we remained an intellectual and cultural dependency of Britain the cringe would have stayed. As part of this developing sense of national identity the establishment of the Australian Council for the Arts-now the Australia Council-in 1969 was both a reflection and a catalyst. The Australia Council has had an enormous influence on the arts in Australia. Perhaps it can be seen most dramatically in the theatre, an activity closely related to film. Before 1970 no one wanted to know about an Australian play, yet in the years 1975 to 1978 a total of 175 Australian plays were given their first production by the 18 major drama companies.

In the film world, the establishment by the Gorton Government in 1969 of the Experimental Film Fund was of critical importance. It was part of a package approved by Prime Minister Gorton. The package consisted of a film school, a film bank along Canadian lines to support feature films, and an experimental film fund to make it possible for new film makers to have a go. Gorton was something of a maverick nationalist and nothing of a film buff but he was the central figure in the development of the new Australian film industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —He appeared in one of them, didn't he?

—Yes, he did. The film bank, initially called the Australian Film Development Corporation and later the Australian Film Commission, started in 1971 and the Australian Film and Television School in 1973, having been slightly delayed by Gorton's loss of office. In the last five years the Australian Film Commission has supported about 50 feature films, and without doubt it has played a major role in the Australian film renaissance. The example of the Australian Film Commission was soon copied by the States until it seemed that every State had to have a film corporation in the same way as every newly emerging nation has to have its own airline. Of course, by no means all the money invested in films came from government. Two of the film distribution chains-Roadshow Distributors Pty Ltd and the Greater Union Organisation Pty Ltd-have been substantial investors. The third-Hoyts Theatres Ltd, which is controlled by Twentieth Century Fox-has been a minor investor. Other investors have covered an extraordinary range, from the Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd investing in The Mango Tree to the International Women's Year Committee investing in Caddie.

SPEECH.PARA: The trouble is that costs are steadily rising. The Adventures of Barry McKenzie, which was made in 1972, cost $250,000. Picnic at Hanging Rock cost $450,000 in 1975 and My Brilliant Career cost $890,000 in 1979. A realistic average cost for a film now is probably $1.5m. There is no way an average film can recover its budget in Australia alone as cinema audiences have actually declined since colour television was introduced. As a rough rule, for a film to break even it has to gross $5 at the box office for every $1 invested. There is no way a $1.5m film could gross $7.5m in Australia. So such a film, if it is to break even or actually make a profit, has to make substantial sales overseas. It is vital for us to remember that the films that have done best overseas-critically, anyway-have been the distinctively Australian ones. Attempts to make films specifically for the American market have usually been disasters.

The purpose of this legislation is to try to improve the trickle of non-government money coming into the film industry. The Australian Labor Party seems to abhor this approach, if Senator Ryan is representing the ALP's attitude accurately. It seems to want government controlled production. In fact, it was said by Senator Walsh that the Government could more economically make films itself and then give them away. The problem is that I doubt whether anyone would want government controlled films. We are seeking to get away from too much government intervention, to encourage support of the film industry by others. To that end, in April 1978 the Government announced a scheme to permit investment in Australian films to be written off income tax over two years instead of 25 years. 'The legislation contains safeguards against tax avoidance', said the Treasurer (Mr Howard), hopefully, at the time. The heartbreaking thing about tax incentives for the arts is that most of them seem to be immediately corrupted by the tax avoidance industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this one will be.

—I will come to that in a moment. I think we have sufficient safeguards in this legislation but certainly it is an area we have to watch. As I was saying, the effect of the 1978 tax concession was not very great on film production but it was certainly very great on tax avoidance for by August 1980 the Treasurer was announcing retrospective measures against expenditure recoupment schemes on film investments, including tax gearing-a tax manipulation scheme that was giving up to $5 deduction for every $1 invested. Such schemes were designed to provide tax benefits whether films were successful or not. Perhaps the Commissioner of Taxation was somewhat heavy handed with his crackdown, for some genuine investors felt that their 100 per cent write-off over two years was at risk, the money dried up and production dropped to a minimum.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly something had to be done. Although I was a lobbyist for an improved scheme, I must say that I was a bit startled by the generosity of the scheme announced last December and implemented by the present Bill in modified form. The scheme provides for an income tax deduction of 150 per cent of the value of an investment in a film production. The person who invests $100,000 in a film would have permissible tax deductions of $150,000. At the maximum marginal rate of 60 per cent, that would be worth $90,000, so at a net cost to himself of $10,000 he would have a $100,000 investment in a film. Of course he might lose his $10,000. Promotion and distribution costs have to be covered before there is any return to the producers. Quite a few films in the past-and certainly there will be as many in the future-have not returned anything to the producers. If there is a return to the investors there will be an exemption from income tax for the first 50 per cent of the investment. This is pretty generous.

As I said, I was startled by the generosity of the scheme. I was even more startled to hear from the Treasurer that the Treasury's original estimate of the cost of the scheme was $2m a year. I think that figure came from the Australian Film Commission. The Treasurer has since revised his estimate to $20m a year, a fact which must be causing some teeth to grind in the Treasury. Actually, I think the cost is more likely to be $30m a year, based on 20 feature films at an average cost of $1.5m each. By the time that figure is reached Treasury officials will be grinding their gums. I offer them one consoling thought. Although $30m is a very great sum-it is more than the total grant to the Australia Council, for instance-the Taxation Commissioner might not have been able to collect the money anyway. It might have gone in paper tax avoidance schemes which have no redeeming social benefit. At least this money from the tax avoidance industry will have a useful output.

That brings me to a key point. The only justification the Government can have for such large subsidies for the film industry is that it will raise the level of Australian film culture and the output of high quality films. There can be no other justification. So let us look at what is intended to be helped and then at the safeguards to prevent abuse. The tax concessions will apply only to films produced for exhibition to the public in cinemas or on television. They must be feature films, including animated feature length movies and telemovies, documentaries or mini-series of television drama. I must say I was delighted to see documentaries included in the scheme. We are making some excellent documentaries-for example, Frontline and The Last Tasmanian-and a first class documentary seen on overseas television by an audience of millions may do more to improve Australia's international image than anything else we could do.

What controls are there to prevent abuses of this scheme? There have been suggestions of various uses of the scheme by the sleazy tax avoidance industry whose morality would make Al Capone look like a saintly figure. There have been allegations of flagrant cost inflation through the use of excessive brokerage fees and commissions-up to 45 per cent has been mentioned-spurious management charges, so-called producer fees and doubtful overheads. Several suggested schemes have involved special loans to investors so as to give tax deductions at no real cost to themselves. This last gimmick was one of those that wrecked the 1978 scheme. These devices should not work. The Commissioner of Taxation has the authority, which I am sure he will use, to disallow such expenditure as not being directly related to the production of a film. But this danger of abuse is what has forced the Treasurer to alter the scheme so that the tax concession is not available until a film has been completed and is earning money-that is, until it has obtained its copyright-although the original promise to permit the concession in the year of expenditure will be allowed for films started before 28 May.

I should like to pay a tribute to the Treasurer, who spent many hours with some of us examining various suggestions for improving the assistance to genuine film makers without leaving the scheme wide open for the tax avoidance industry. Sadly, we could not find a scheme better than the one we now have, which, by the way, is still a very generous scheme. Much of the criticism of the changes has been stirred up by the tax avoidance industry and some of its acceptance has been by people who do not understand how the provisional tax system works.

A key role in all of this will be played by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson). He has to certify a film as having a significant Australian content and also that it is an eligible film produced for exhibition to the public. It remains to be seen how the Minister will interpret the expressions 'significant Australian content' and 'produced for exhibition to the public'. The Department of Home Affairs and Environment has produced a formidable questionnaire to be filled in, but tough interpretation of 'significant Australian content' will be essential if the aim of raising the standard of Australian film culture is to be achieved. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the document headed 'Application for Certification of a Film as an Eligible Film with Significant Australian Content'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far, so good, but who is looking at the quality of the films? Someone has said that it would be possible for a man to make a blue movie starring his mistress, pay her a fee of $300,000 and claim the lot as a tax deduction. The film would have a significant Australian content and could be exhibited in the so-called adult movie houses that have sprung up all over the place. This may be an extreme case, but how do we weed out the rubbish? The market place is not effective with such a heavily subsidised scheme. I toyed with the idea of moving an amendment imposing an additional requirement in order to qualify for the tax deduction-that at least 10 per cent of an investment should be put up by one or more of the seven film commissions. At least, I thought, the film commissions should be aiming at quality. The trouble is that their track record is ambiguous, to put it at its kindest. But we may have to come back to such a scheme if the film making boom shows signs of heading off in the wrong direction with tax avoidance quickies being made which will damage rather than raise the level of film culture in Australia. As a possible refinement of this scheme of control, it might be worth looking at having as an alternative a certificate from the Film and Television Producers' Association of Australia that the script is a developed one, the production arrangements and costs are reasonable and the film, if produced, is likely to be creditable. The Opposition seems to underestimate the extent to which we can trust film makers. In my experience they are very honourable men and I reject totally the description of them by Senator Walsh as being 'a noisy, greedy, egocentric bunch of tax dodgers'. I think that is a most reprehensible description of a very honourable group of creative people.

SPEECH.PARA: The type of control I am talking about is all in the future. The Treasurer has said that he will review the working of it, to see that it is not going off in the wrong direction with tax avoidance quickies being made, in six to 12 months. We might have to look at such a scheme then. I hope that this type of quality control, which by its very nature is clumsy, will not be necessary. But we must be prepared to act if it looks as if this wonderful scheme is being distorted. It is a wonderful scheme. It looks as if soon we may well be producing feature films at a rate of about 30 a year, plus a greatly increased output of documentaries and shorts. We have the chance to make a dramatic impact on the world cinema scene and an impact on mass television audiences. The increased affluence of the industry will enable all involved to be paid a fair rate for their work. In the past they have been badly underpaid.

Of course, there are dangers. There is always a reverse side to any coin. There is no doubt that the Treasury knives are waiting for any transgressions and it is up to the industry itself to try to police the scheme to see that they do not happen. This waiting in the Treasury will be particularly thorough because the loss to revenue is going to be at least 10 times as great as was originally thought. This is of course the reason why it is so desperately important that the scheme should not be exploited by unscrupulous tax avoiders and also that the quality and ultimate international prestige of the films produced should match the Government's investment. But these are not all the dangers. There are probably at present enough first quality teams to make four feature films at any time. Although plans have been announced for training schemes to produce new production crews, this will take time. It is not the top people that we are going to be short of. There are plenty of well-trained top people just waiting for their chance. The scarcity will be in the assistants-the assistant directors, assistant cameramen, gaffers, grips, boom operators, continuity people and so on. It will probably take a year to train them in the numbers needed. In the meantime, some of the new wave of films will be produced by relatively inexperienced crews.

One of the consequences of this will be that the ordinary laws of supply and demand, coupled with the new affluence of the film industry, will bid up the price of the experienced crews. This is already happening with high budget films such as The Earthling. A substantial increase in film industry pay is desirable, but it must not go too far. There is a further danger here. If the present boom is followed by a relative slump, there will be pressure for the kind of feather-bedding that is chronic in Britain in order to provide work for the surplus crews. This would of course only make the slump worse and recovery from it less likely. One of the most impressive things about our recent film production has been the economy in the use of resources, largely as a result of the use of a sort of sub-contracting system among the production crew.

Then there is the question of exhibition. If the top estimate of 50 feature films a year comes true-and talk of 170 or 200 films a year, as Senator Ryan was saying, is absolute nonsense-that will be one world premiere a week. Where on earth will we find the cinemas? Of the 30 or so feature films being produced in 1981, only 10 or 12 so far have firm distribution arrangements. The possibility of reasonable distribution should be one of the things closely watched by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment. The Australian Film Institute, with its cinema outlets in Sydney, Melbourne and Hobart, can exhibit some Australian films which would otherwise not achieve commercial release, but there is a limit to how many. Besides, it would be totally unreasonable to expect the AFI to exhibit low quality films made as a tax lurk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly under the sterling leadership of the moment.

—I thank the honourable senator. The final danger-and the most deadly-is that we will cease to have an Australian film industry, and have instead a mid-Atlantic film industry subsidised by the Australian taxpayers. The ghastly examples of Britain and Canada should always be in our minds. There are ominous signs of stirrings in this direction-Tony Ginnane's execrable Harlequin for instance. Here again the attitude of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment will be crucial. How it defines 'significant Australian content' will determine whether we continue to have an Australian film industry as opposed to a film industry producing films in Australia. For we must have the confidence to be ourselves.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the role of the various film commissions. Obviously, their funding role will diminish greatly. It can be said, I think, that government funding created and saw the revived film industry through its first decade. Now we are in a dramatic new phase. This is not to say that there is no role for the film commissions. Script development is an obvious need. Scripts are perhaps the weakest part of our film industry. Promotion, particularly overseas promotion, is the other obvious need. The Australian Film Commission, after a shaky start when promotion was in the hands of the Film Australia people with no knowledge of feature films, has now reached the stage where it can perform effectively in overseas promotion. Of course, there is more than script development and promotion for the Australian Film Commission to do. It has to run Film Australia, the Government's documentary film-making unit. It has to administer the vitally important creative development fund, the seed bed of the next generation of film makers. It has to support the Australian Film Institute as a key organisation in raising the level of the film culture in Australia.

As if that were not enough, I should like to give the Australian Film Commission more to do. I mentioned earlier the vital role the Minister for Home Affairs and his advisers have to play in administering this new scheme. He has to decide whether a proposed film has sufficient Australian content. He has to decide whether the proposed distribution arrangements are honest and adequate. This troubles me on two counts. First, neither the Minister nor the public servants working for him in this field are likely to have any practical knowledge of the film industry. To put it bluntly, they are just not qualified to make such vital decisions. Secondly, the concentration of power of this type in the Minister's hands violates the arm's length policy of arts administration which we are supposed to be following. The Minister's predecessor recently relinquished his power of approval of proposed productions of Film Australia because he had found it embarrassing and inappropriate. The sort of power the Minister will exercise over proposed films under this new scheme will be a hundred times more embarrassing. The idea of an arm's length policy in the arts is that one takes funding decisions out of the political arena and gives them to a body of experts, operating under broad public guidelines from the Minister. The expert body makes the decisions and it takes the flack from the disgruntled, who always outnumber the satisfied. Such delegation is sound politics and sensible administration. For that reason I suggest the Minister should delegate his powers under this new film scheme to the Australian Film Commission. I agree with Senator Puplick that a further overhaul of the Australian Film Commission is very desirable.

It is vital that this new scheme should be well administered and should have the confidence of the public in general and the Treasury in particular. In the last decade we have arrived on the world scene as a significant, though minor, film producer. If this scheme is wisely administered and sensibly used by the film industry we have the chance to become a major film producer with dramatic effects on Australia's international prestige. For films are of universal appeal. After all, films are the one new art form of the twentieth century.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1981. We have had four very interesting speeches giving a variety of views. I pay tribute to Senator Hamer. He was too modest to state that he is the Chairman of the Australian Film Institute which is carrying out an important function in this area. As a member of the Australia Council, he is closely involved in the administration of the arts in Australia. I also pay tribute to Senator Puplick for the speech he made. I say to my colleague and my former research worker that he has had a very distinguished first three years in the Senate. I think the speech he made today set out the issues before the Senate. I wish him well.

SPEECH.PARA: The matters before the Senate have been set out by Government speakers who have stated that what we are intending to do is make it possible to produce more Australian films and encourage the film industry in this country. The Government's decision has been one which, as my colleagues have pointed out, will seek to encourage the industry, expand film production, offer incentives to Australians to participate themselves, develop more pride in what we can do ourselves in the area of film production, give Australians more opportunities to involve themselves at every level and work in the film industry to develop the skills to which Senator Hamer has referred in some detail in the speech which he has just made. Because the scheme is designed to operate by way of taxation incentives and inducements, it is being presented as an Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. It was to some of the details of the scheme as it will apply to income tax law that Senator Walsh addressed his remarks. I must say that it was sometimes quite difficult to know who was speaking for the Opposition. The messages that came from the two speakers from the Opposition were quite disparate and separate in their emphases. I hope that Opposition senators share our delight in the new opportunities which will flow to those actually working in films in Australia from what the Government is proposing to do.

The Bill is an important one. The scheme has been subjected to much public examination and gaze. It has been discussed at some length. It has also been discussed at some length in the debate. Time is pressing in the Senate. We have a considerable program ahead of us. Because of the exhaustive and comprehensive way in which the issues have been canvassed and in which questions have been answered I do not intend to go over the issues again. Honourable senators may raise particular questions during the Committee stage which will follow. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 June, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill is the long awaited re-write of section 260, the general anti-tax avoidance provision in the Income Tax Assessment Act which has been, of course, notoriously emasculated by the High Court of Australia over the last 20 years and for most of that period has been a hopelessly inadequate weapon against tax avoidance. The Opposition does not oppose this Bill but we do have a number of major reservations about the approach which has been adopted by the Government and which we seek to explain, not in any carping spirit but rather a constructive one. We regard the fight against tax avoidance as one which should proceed, so far as humanly possible, on a broad bipartisan basis because tax avoidance is such a destructive phenomenon in the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: It continues to be a problem of quite staggering dimensions with the war upon it, as a result, properly remaining and continuing to be a matter of the highest parliamentary priority. Estimates as to the size of tax avoidance and tax evasion necessarily vary because inevitably it is the sort of thing about which precise information cannot be known. But as a crude rule of thumb it probably remains fair to say that avoidance and evasion, between them, fall into three broad categories each of which produces a loss to revenue and to the community as a whole of something around $1,000m per annum.

The first category is straight out crude tax evasion, the most obvious example being undisclosed cash transactions. The only way we can really deal with that approach to one's taxation obligations is by heavy criminal sanctions of the kind that were enacted last year and also by effective on the ground enforcement. The size of crude tax evasion is, in fact, probably more than $1,000m per annum but it is really anybody's guess as to how much of that black economy exercise is now going on.

The second category takes us into the area of avoidance, properly so-called-the distinction being that avoidance is behaviour which is arguably within the literal letter of the law whereas evasion is behaviour which is unapologetically outside it. The category of avoidance is divisible into two. The first kind of avoidance, and the second broad band of things we need to worry about, is avoidance in the form of blatant, contrived, artificial schemes-the kind of notorious scheme like the original Curran scheme and its various successors. These schemes have no conceivable redeeming commercial or family justification. They are recognisable at 40 paces as being wholly immoral tax avoidance schemes. The magnitude of this band of the problem is again hard to assess. These days it is probably a little less than $1,000m, but still very substantial indeed.

The third category, which in terms of the magnitude of the impact on revenue is again of the order of a thousand million dollars, probably plus in this case, is the other kind of avoidance-avoidance in the form of more ambiguous or less obvious artificial arrangements not involving particular kinds of transactions which always, in every case, must necessarily, by their very nature, be avoidance-motivated, but rather arrangements involving income-splitting and tax shelter arrangements of various kinds which may or may not have the character of reprehensible tax avoidance depending on all the circumstances-in the particular context. The kinds of things which have traditionally been involved here are various kinds of family trust arrangements, service trusts in a partnership situation, administration companies of the kind used by professionals, some sorts of exercises involving, for example, inflated mark-ups in the purchases of trading stock and arrangements of this kind which one cannot completely outlaw by their very structure because they may have a legitimate operation in a particular commercial situation but which are capable of being misused in circumstances where there is no real justification for them other than that of tax avoidance and which are, as a result, producing a very significant drain on revenue. Again I suggest that something of the order, in very broad-brush figures, of a thousand million dollars a year is involved.

That is the sort of situation we are confronted with. For the purposes of the rest of this debate, tax evasion drops out of consideration. What we are concerned with-I want to make this distinction clear-are the two broad categories of tax avoidance, properly so-called. On the one hand there are the crude, blatant, manifestly contrived, artificial schemes and, on the other hand, there are the more ambiguous arrangements of the kind I have described. The traditional legislative strategy for dealing with tax avoidance back in the days before avoidance really did become a significant phenomenon in the community at large was twofold. It was to close off prospectively as many specific loopholes as could possibly be envisaged within the detailed language of the tax legislation and then to back that up with a general anti-avoidance provision, namely section 260. That was the original approach, the original motivation of those who drafted our present tax legislation. That kind of approach worked reasonably well for a number of years. To put on the record what it is that we are talking about-section 260-I seek leave to incorporate the text of existing section 260 into Hansard.
Leave granted.
The section read as follows-

260. Every contract, agreement, or arrangement made or entered into, orally or in writing, whether before or after the commencement of this Act, shall so far as it has or purports to have the purpose or effect of in any way, directly or indirectly-
(a) altering the incidence of any income tax;
(b) relieving any person from liability to pay any income tax or make any return;
(c) defeating, evading, or avoiding any duty or liability imposed on any person by this Act; or
(d) preventing the operation of this Act in any respect,
be absolutely void, as against the Commissioner, or in regard to any proceeding under this Act, but without prejudice to such validity as it may have in any other respect or for any other purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —That strategy began to miscarry a little over 20 years ago with Newton's case and then the whole succession of familiar High Court cases largely taking real effect and really beginning to bite during the Chief Justiceship of Sir Garfield Barwick. In the course of those cases the language of section 260, which seems on its face to be very broad indeed in giving the Commissioner ample discretion to pick and choose between illegitimate and legitimate schemes, that broad-based language, was steadily read down and reduced to impotence by the High Court in particular cases-the most notorious and recent of which is probably Cridland's case in 1978-inventing and applying what has become known as the 'choice principle'. This is the principle that if the scheme in question consists of the arrangement of the taxpayer's affairs or the casting of a transaction into a particular form so as to attract a tax advantage specifically contemplated by some provision somewhere in the Act, then the scheme is no more than the product of the making of a choice provided for by the Act and is therefore invulnerable to attack. That principle was invented, as I said, by the High Court, particularly under Sir Garfield Barwick and became the vehicle through which the broad-brush discretionary annihilation power vested in the Commissioner by section 260 was emasculated and reduced to complete impotence.

SPEECH.PARA: Encouraged by this development in the High Court and the failure of the legislature through successive governments to do anything about it-I readily acknowledge that the Labor Government was less active than it might have been in coping with this phenomenon-and perhaps also as a result of various structural problems showing up in the tax legislation-for all these reasons, in recent years tax avoidance has become a rampant phenomenon. It has become necessary for the Government to square up completely again, to confront a wholly new phenomenon and to devise a wholly new legislative strategy for dealing with it. That legislative response of the Government has taken a particular form during the first five years of the Fraser Government which I will describe as soon as we resume after dinner. It is because of the failure of that particular strategy that the Government has now moved to the further strategy that is embodied in this legislation. We will proceed to that also after dinner.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Davidson, who I think is the longest serving senator on the Government side-I am not sure about that-was a colleague of mine on the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. Senator Maunsell, has been, I think, a universally liked member of this Senate. You, Mr President, will be remembered and respected by us all for your courtesy, kindness and gentlemanly conduct of the affairs of the Senate in your period as President.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my personal wish that those Government senators who are retiring will not be lonely in their retirement. I wish to assure them that we on the Opposition side will be doing our best to ensure that a number of their colleagues join them after the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: On my side of the Parliament I mention first my colleagues Senators Bishop and Cavanagh. Sometimes I have had disagreements with them. Perhaps they belong to a different generation from mine. But I say in all sincerity that I have always been grateful for their very sound advice. They have both been great Labor men. They understand the Australian Labor Party and its traditions. The advice which they have given me I have valued very much.

Senator McAuliffe has always been, I think, a colourful senator; he has made a colourful contribution to this Parliament. Of course, we will all miss him. Senator Melzer is a senator who should not be leaving this place. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I might now return the Senate to the much less diverting topic-certainly a less sentimental one-of the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). I remind the Senate that before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was describing the unhappy state of affairs that had developed with respect to High Court interpretation of the existing general anti-avoidance provision-section 260-and the unhappy implications in terms of that section for the escalation of the tax avoidance industry. The way in which this Government has in office hitherto responded to that situation has been by a series of after-the-event remedial changes to try to correct problems as they have arisen, to plug the loopholes after they have been disclosed.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1975, there has been a whole succession of such legislative initiatives each occupying some 20 or 30 pages of the statute book and adding in all something over 400 pages to the Income Tax Assessment Act. But none of those remedial pieces of legislation have been fully retrospective in their operation or effect. They may have been retrospective back to the date at which the artificial scheme in question first came to the attention of the Government and first prompted a government announcement of intention to overcome it, but they have never been retrospective back to the date of the first known operation of that scheme. That has resulted in a situation whereby, for successive years-I am now going back five or six years-non-taxpayers willing to participate in highly blatant, contrived avoidance arrangements of this kind have been getting a start on the Commissioner of Taxation. Usually they have had one year's advantage from this scheme in question before it has come to the notice of the Commissioner of Taxation, or come to his notice in a sufficient way as to enable legislative steps to be taken to retrieve the situation for the future.

The search for new loopholes has been continuing year after year. The problem of artificial schemes has simply not been solved by this kind of legislative strategy. Not surprisingly, the Government has sought an alternative anti-avoidance legislative strategy. It is this search for an alternative in terms of a catch-all anti-avoidance provision, prompted by the demise of the original section 260 and the necessity to replace it, which has produced the legislation before us tonight. Admittedly, it must be said it is before us after a really quite extraordinarily long gestation period-an unhappily long gestation period because all of us have been wanting to see much more effective remedial legislative techniques in operation much sooner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lawyers are like that.

—Maybe, but Senator Messner will see that we are a bit quicker when our turn comes in 1983. What people, I think, were expecting was a redraft of section 260, a new provision which would enable the Commissioner to range effectively over the whole field of tax avoidance or what I have described as the two basic areas of it-in the first place, the blatant contrived schemes, and, in the second place, the ambiguous arrangements of the kinds I earlier endeavoured to describe. What we in fact have in the Bill before us now is something rather narrower. What we have is an extensive new Part IVA of the Bill which is clearly designed to have an effect and which clearly is capable only of having a potential effect in a narrow area, and that is the area of blatant and contrived schemes. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) has been at pains to make it clear that this is not intended to bite in any way on the area I have described as ambiguous arrangements. It is intended to exclude completely, as the Treasurer said on numerous occasions in the debate in the other place, what are described as 'ordinary business or family dealings', even, it seems, if those business or family dealings have a colour of tax avoidance about them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me describe what the Government seems to have succeeded in doing in this Part IVA before us. It has produced an anti-avoidance provision which has three main characteristics. First, it very narrowly defines the schemes to which the Part is to apply. There are a number of ways in which this narrow definition operates in terms of the behaviour which is encompassed by the provisions. There is an omission of preliminary steps or partial steps in the creation of an avoidance arrangement. Really, one has to have gone the whole way and to have fully completed the anticipated plan of action before this provision begins to bite. Again in this respect the definition of 'tax benefit' has been quite narrowly defined in such a way as to refer really only to specific identifiable deductions which actually have been obtained or specific identifiable amounts which have not been included in assessable income. That is to be compared with the kind of definition of tax benefit which would include anything which amounted, in effect, to less income tax being payable than otherwise would have been the case. The other aspect of this first element in the Commissioner's plan is its circumscription of the tax avoidance purpose to situations in which the avoidance purpose is in fact the dominant one as distinct from simply being one purpose among others or being merely a less than incidental purpose. In this variety of ways, first of all there is a very deliberate legislative narrowing of the kinds of schemes and arrangements to which the part is to apply.

The second main characteristic that comes through this part IVA as we now see it is that no broad statutory discretions are vested in the Commissioner of Taxation and the boards of review either, in the first place, to decide whether a tax benefit as defined has been obtained or, in the second place, to determine whether that tax benefit was obtained for a tax avoidance purpose.
