What we have is a series of very precisely worded objective tests for application, in essence by the courts, to determine when these requirements are being satisfied. It is not the Commissioner, in the exercise of a broad discretion, exercising a feel on the ground for the character of the situation, that is to prevail here. It is the very precisely worded objective tests which are set out in very precise terms in the language of the draft.

The third and remaining characteristic of Part IVA is that it creates heavy penalties. Automatically applicable, non-discretionary, non-flexible penalties are imposed upon people found to have offended this general anti-avoidance provision equivalent to 200 per cent of the tax avoided. So the tax avoider who is caught out as a result of the operation of this scheme will have to pay not only the additional tax that should have been payable but also he will have to pay this amount twice over by way of a penalty. There is no doubt that that will have a deterrent effect of some significance, but clearly, and I think this point is an important one, it will encourage the courts to be very careful indeed in determining how and when this section should be applied. They will undoubtedly read it in the same way as they read, and properly so, all substantial penal provisions on the statute book. They will read it in such a way that it gives the benefit of the doubt to the person who is subject to these very heavy, very savage penalties.

It seems to me that Treasurer Howard wants the courts to operate in this way. He has indicated that that heavy penalty aspect of it and the precision with which the tests have been drafted and so on is very much part of the legislative approach that has here been adopted. He seems to take the view that this combination of techniques will be appropriate to bite on at least the blatant, the contrived, the artificial schemes. But what has happened, and what seems to us to be very likely to be the case, is that though it may bite on those schemes it will not bite on anything else. We have a situation where Part IV as it has been drafted represents an application of traditional drafting techniques. It is our concern that as a consequence it will achieve only traditional results, that is, not very successful results. As I have said, it may be successful. It may prove to be successful against the cruder paper schemes of the Curran variety.

However, even in that respect it cannot be expected to get quick results. The innumerable complex provisions which now will have to be carefully applied, not only by the Commissioner but also by the courts-undoubtedly they will be second guessing what the Commissioner does in this respect, because that is the way the legislation is drafted-will have to be interpreted. There will be prospects of appeals and counter-appeals and endless delays. It is for those reasons that we have people like the appalling Peter Clyne publicly rubbing his hands with glee, saying: 'Instead of creating a broad set of discretions for the Commissioner to apply which will rub out people like me very successfully, giving me very little avenues of appeal, very few legal points to take, here you have created a whole new statutory minefield, a field of roses for someone like me, creating the opportunity for me to pick my way through them for years ahead in the courts'.

The situation we confront is a piece of legislation that may ultimately be successful against the cruder arrangements, but even then only at the price of taking a lot of time to bite and being the product, in the process, of a pretty long-winded anticipated series of court proceedings to determine what these various provisions mean. Furthermore, it is a provision which cannot be expected to be successful at all in relation to the ambiguous schemes-those kinds of tax splitting, tax shelter arrangements which may have a commercial or domestic justification in some circumstances, some contexts, but certainly have not in many real world situations. Certainly it seems that this approach is at best going to be unsuccessful in covering the field that in our view, and I think in the community's view generally, needs to be covered by effective anti-avoidance legislation.

By contrast, the Opposition's approach is really quite different. Let me try to explain what it is. We believe that it is possible to have effective legislation counteracting both these main classes of avoidance. We believe it is possible to have legislation operating very effectively, and indeed very quickly, against blatant, contrived, artificial schemes, the ones that, as I have said before, one would recognise at 40 paces. We also believe it is possible, in a way that Treasurer Howard and this Government do not seem to think it is, to have legislative sanctions operating fairly so as to enable the authorities to pick and choose between the legitimate and illegitimate arrangements within this broader ambiguous category.

How is it that we would argue that this could be done? It is as follows: The first leg of our approach would involve, in relation to the blatant, contrived, artificial schemes, the unashamed application of retrospective legislation. By this I mean fully retrospective legislation with the taxation benefits of the schemes in question being wiped out right back to the date of the first known operation of the scheme; not just back to the date on which the Government finally cottons on to the existence of the scheme and says that it will legislate against it, but right back to day one to wipe out the tax advantage. There is no doubt about the efficacy of that kind of approach. It concentrates the mind of tax avoiders quite wonderfully. It means, if it is applied in any particular case, that they lose the particular tax advantage that they otherwise would have derived. They lose the opportunity to get into some other more legitimate tax minimisation scheme for that year of income, and also in the process they will very often lose the very substantial fees that they pay to the promoter of these shonky schemes.

Clearly, retrospective legislation of this kind is an instrument which has to be wielded with a great deal of care indeed. In everything that I and the Labor Party have been saying about the operation of such legislation-I have said it at greater length than I will be able to tonight, for example, in a speech on 12 September 1979 in this chamber, and on a number of other occasions subsequently -we have been very careful to try to explain that we have in mind a very narrow operation for this kind of legislation. We see it as operating only against those schemes which are unambiguously blatant, contrived and artificial and would be so understood by everyone who had a look at them. We regard legislation of this kind, fully retrospective legislation, as appropriate only in the case of specifically identified schemes in the terms of very specifically drawn legislation. It is quite inappropriate for retrospectivity of this kind to apply in a discretionary context where the Commissioner of Taxation, for example, can apply his own discretion, extending backwards for some years. That is quite wrong. It must be only when Parliament has had an opportunity to say: 'Yes, this is a scheme of a blatant, contrived, artificial kind and it is appropriate that that be wiped out from day one, because nobody could have gone into that scheme with his eyes closed. It would only be an unambiguous tax avoider, a social parasite, who would do that'. Parliament would have that judgment in its hands in each such case.

Finally, in respect of such schemes, they would certainly have no penal content. It would be quite inappropriate for any retrospective legislation to impose penalties against the persons and schemes to which it applied. It would only operate to wipe out the tax advantage that otherwise would have been derived and create a situation in which the taxpayers simply had to pay tax at the marginal rate that would otherwise have been applicable in the circumstances in question. The idea is becoming better understood and better accepted that there be retrospectivity of this kind. I have no doubt that it is an idea that is personally accepted by the present Treasurer. I also note with some interest that it is an idea that seems to be very much in the forefront of the Government's present thinking, according to an article in the Bulletin of 16 June 1981 by someone who describes himself as 'the officious bystander' but is better known to be the ubiquitous and indeed rather well connected Mr Malcolm Turnbull of the Sydney Bar, and who says:
I am informed, by the highest authority--
I have no doubt that in his case it is the highest authority:

that if the Federal Government's revamped anti-avoidance provision . . . does not meet with success in the High Court and fails to stop those tax-dodging schemes which are not explicitly covered in the Act, the Government will legislate retrospectively to counter tax avoidance.

It is very much there as an option up the Government's sleeve. There is a bit of backing and filling and shying away from it at the moment, but everyone knows that retrospective legislation can be fairly and precisely applied, and it is proper to apply it against blatant, artificial schemes of this kind.

That is our approach, and we are quite unapologetic about it. We believe that it is effective and fair and we believe that it will be understood. The other side of the coin, the other part of our approach, is to enact a genuinely effective new version of section 260 of the Act to deal with the more ambiguous arrangements, to give the Commissioner a non-punitive discretion-a non-retrospective discretion, too-to pick and choose between these schemes which are illegitimate in the sense that they manifestly involve a tax avoidance motive of a significant kind as distinct from those schemes which may be similarly constructed but which do clearly in the context have a proper commercial or domestic justification. The opposition has a pretty clear idea of its own on the basis of really quite long discussions which extend back now for some months with a highly qualified group of tax lawyers brought together-anonymously, it must be said, because their identity would be quite startling if it were known-under the auspices of the Australian Society of Labor Lawyers taxation working group. On the basis of that consultation, we have produced an alternative draft of section 260 which I believe will touch all the bases that need to be touched in a broad-ranging discretionary anti-avoidance provision of the section 260 variety. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an alternative draft to section 260.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PART VIIIA-SCHEMES TO REDUCE INCOME TAX
Object of Part

260A. The object of this Part is to ensure a fair sharing of the tax burden and to promote the revenue-raising, economic and redistributive functions of this Act by preventing or counteracting tax avoidance, and accordingly the provisions of this Part shall be deemed to be remedial and shall be given such large, liberal and purposive construction as will best ensure the attainment of the object of this Part.
Interpretation
260B. (1) In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears-
'liability' includes a potential or prospective liability; 'scheme' includes-
(a) any agreement, arrangement, understanding, promise or undertaking, whether express or implied and whether or not enforceable or intended to be enforceable by legal proceedings; and
(b) any plan, proposal, action, omission, course of action or course of conduct;
and without limiting the generality of the foregoing includes-
(i) any act omission transaction or other step preliminary to or forming part of a scheme; and
(ii) a unilateral arrangement, plan, proposal, action omission, course of action or course of conduct.
'taxpayer' includes a taxpayer in the capacity of a trustee.
(2) The definition of 'taxpayer' in sub-section (1) shall not be taken to affect in any way the interpretation of that expression where it is used in this Act other than this Part.

(3) A reference in this Part to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme shall be read as including a reference to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme together with another person or other persons.

(4) A reference in this Part to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for a particular purpose shall be read as including a reference to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for two or more purposes if-
(a) such purposes included or include that purpose; and
(b) that purpose was not or is not merely an incidental purpose.
Operation of Part

260C. (1) Subject to sub-section (2), nothing in the provisions of this Act other than this Part or in the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 shall be taken to limit the operation of this Part.
(2) This Part shall not be taken to affect the operation of Division 16C of Part III.
Tax benefit
260D. A reference in this Part to the obtaining by a taxpayer of a tax benefit in relation to a scheme shall be as read as a reference to a taxpayer being liable but for the operation of this Part-

(a) to pay less income tax in respect of a year of income than he would have been liable, or might reasonably have been expected by the Commissioner to be liable, to pay in respect of that year of income but for the scheme; or

(b) to pay any income tax in respect of a year of income which is a later year of income than the year of income in respect of which he would have been liable, or might reasonably have been expected by the Commissioner to be liable, to pay that income tax but for the scheme.
Schemes to which Part applies

260E. (1) This Part applies to any scheme in relation to which a person acts or omits to act or has acted or omitted to act after 27 May 1981 (other than a scheme in relation to which a person acted or omitted to act before that date), whether in Australia or outside Australia or partly in Australia and partly outside Australia, where:
(a) The Commissioner is satisfied that a taxpayer (in this section referred to as 'the relevant taxpayer')
(i) has obtained a tax benefit in relation to the scheme; or
(ii) would but for Section 260G obtain a tax benefit in relation to the scheme; and
(iii) might reasonably be expected to obtain in the future a tax benefit in relation to the scheme; and

(b) the Commissioner is satisfied that a person who acted or omitted to act in relation to the scheme or any part of the scheme did so for the purpose of tax avoidance, whether or not the first mentioned person obtains any tax benefit in connection with the scheme and whether or not any person affected by the scheme is a party thereto.

(2) In determining whether a person acted or omitted to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for the purpose of tax avoidance the Commissioner may have regard to any one or more of the following:
(a) the manner in which the scheme was entered into or carried out;
(b) the form and substance of the scheme;
(c) the time at which the scheme was entered into and the length of the period during which the scheme was carried out;
(d) the result in relation to the operation of this Act that, but for this Part, would be achieved by the scheme;
(e) any change in the financial position of the relevant taxpayer that has resulted, will result, or may reasonably be expected to result, from the scheme;

(f) any change in the financial position of any person who has, or has had, any connection (whether of a business, family or other nature) with the relevant taxpayer, being a change that has resulted, will result, or may reasonably be expected to result, from the scheme;
(g) any other consequence for the relevant taxpayer, or for any person referred to in paragraph (f), of the scheme having been entered into or carried out;
(h) the nature of any connection (whether of a business, family or other nature) between the relevant taxpayer and any person referred to in paragraph (f);
(i) the extent (if any) to which the relevant taxpayer used or committed his own funds in the scheme;
(j) whether the scheme created or failed to create rights or obligations which normally would not or would (as the case may be) be created between persons dealing with each other at arm's length;
(k) any other relevant matter.
Tax avoidance purpose

260F. (1) A reference in this Part to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme for the purpose of tax avoidance shall be read as a reference to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for the purpose of
(a) directly or indirectly altering the incidence of any income tax;
(b) directly or indirectly relieving any person from liability to income tax; or
(c) directly or indirectly avoiding, reducing or postponing any liability to income tax,

and references in this sub-section to the incidence of income tax or to a liability to income tax shall be read as including references to income tax which might reasonably have been expected to be incident upon any person but for the scheme or income tax to which any person might reasonably have been expected to be liable but for the scheme, as the case may be.

(2) The Commissioner may be satisfied that a person acted or omitted to act in relation to a scheme for the purpose of tax avoidance notwithstanding that the scheme or any part of the scheme or any tax benefit obtained in relation to the scheme was or might be contemplated by another provision or other provisions of the Act.
Cancellation of tax benefits, &c.
260G. (1) Whenever this Part applies, the Commissioner may at any time in relation to the year or years of income in which the tax benefit is obtained, or in relation to any other year of income-
(a) treat the scheme or any part of the scheme as void for the purposes of the Act; and

(b) adjust the taxable income or liability to income tax of any person affected by the scheme to the extent necessary to counteract the tax benefit obtained in relation to the scheme or to any lesser extent.

(2) Where pursuant to sub-section (1) any income is included in the taxable income of any person or any adjustment is made to the liability of any person to income tax, then for the purposes of this Act such income shall be deemed to have been derived by virtue of this section by that person and by no other person or such adjustment shall be deemed to have been made by virtue of this section to the liability of that person and of no other person, as the case may be.

(3) Where the Commissioner has adjusted the taxable income or liability to income tax of any person under sub-section (1) in relation to a scheme to which this Part applies, the Commissioner may, in relation to any taxpayer (in this sub-section referred to as the 'relevant taxpayer')-
(a) if, in the opinion of the Commissioner-

(i) there has been included, or would but for this sub-section be included, in the assessable income of the relevant taxpayer of a year of income an amount that would not have been included or would not be included, as the case may be, in the assessable income of the relevant taxpayer of that year of income if the scheme had not been entered into or carried out; and
(ii) it is fair and reasonable that that amount or a part of that amount should not be included in the assessable income of the relevant taxpayer of that year of income.

determine that that amount or that part of that amount, as the case may be, should not have been included or shall not be included, as the case may be, in the assessable income of the relevant taxpayer of that year of income; or
(b) if, in the opinion of the Commissioner-

(i) an amount would have been allowed or would be allowable to the relevant taxpayer as a deduction in relation to a year of income if the scheme had not been entered into or carried out, being an amount that was not allowed or would not, but for this sub-section, be allowable, as the case may be, as a deduction to the relevant taxpayer in relation to that year of income; and
(ii) it is fair and reasonable that that amount or a part of that amount should be allowable as a deduction to the relevant taxpayer in relation to that year of income,

determine that that amount or that part, as the case may be, should have been allowed or shall be allowable, as the case may be, as a deduction to the relevant taxpayer in relation to that year of income,
and the Commissioner shall take such action as he considers necessary to give effect to any such determination.

(4) Where the Commissioner makes a determination under sub-section (3) by virtue of which an amount is allowed as a deduction to a taxpayer in relation to a year of income, that amount shall be deemed to be so allowed as a deduction by virtue of such provision of this Act as the Commissioner determines.

(5) Where, at any time, a taxpayer considers that the Commissioner ought to make a determination under sub-section (3) in relation to the taxpayer in relation to a year of income, the taxpayer may post to or lodge with the Commissioner a request in writing for the making by the Commissioner of a determination under that sub-section.
(6) The Commissioner shall consider the request and serve on the taxpayer, by post or otherwise, a written notice of his decision on the request.

(7) If the taxpayer is dissatisfied with the Commissioner's decision on the request, the taxpayer may, within 60 days after service on the taxpayer of notice of the decision of the Commissioner, post to or lodge with the Commissioner an objection in writing against the decision stating fully and in detail the grounds on which the taxpayer relies.

(8) The provisions of Division 2 of Part V (other than section 185) apply in relation to an objection made under sub-section (7) in like manner as those provisions apply in relation to an objection against an assessment.
Amendment of assessments

260H. (1) Nothing in section 170 prevents the amendment of an assessment at any time before the expiration of 6 years after the date on which tax became due and payable under the assessment if the amendment is for the purposes of giving effect to sub-section 260G (1).
(2) Nothing in section 170 prevents the amendment of an assessment at any time if the amendment is for the purpose of giving effect to sub-section 260G (3).'

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I will describe the elements of that scheme in very broad terms. The Opposition and I believe that any broad based discretionary scheme should have six characteristics. Let me briefly identify them and refer to the text of the draft provision that I have just incorporated so that if not listeners to the debate then certainly readers of this speech-if there are any-will appreciate what we are getting at. The first thing that any such provision has to have is a clearly articulated objects or purpose clause which indicates to the courts the desire of the legislature that the legislation be interpreted in a purposive way that has regard to the manifest intention of Parliament. This matter has been the subject of a deal of public and parliamentary discussion in a variety of contexts recently. Perhaps I can have a word or two more to say about the clause-the proper content of it and the implications of it-in the Committee stage. Proposed new section 260A in the draft just tabled is the objects or purpose clause.

SPEECH.PARA: The second element that any such draft has to have is a broad definition of schemes which seek to avoid tax which are the subject matter of the legislative sanction. There should be an extremely wide definition, in our view, of the threshold conditions defining the schemes prima facie caught by the provision. The basic approach that we regard as appropriate is to cast the net as widely as possible with discretion placed in the Commissioner and the boards of review not to apply the operative provisions-for example, to bona fide family and commercial transactions. This in turn requires broad definitions of all the various constituent elements of this threshold test. I refer to the definition of what constitutes a scheme that is referred to in proposed section 260B (1) in the draft, the description of what constitutes a tax benefit, and that is referred to in proposed section 260D in the draft, the description of persons who obtain the tax benefits-this draft makes it clear that the provision extends to any taxpayer-the description of the purpose of tax avoidance which is in proposed section 260F, and the specification which is in proposed section 260B (4) that the tax avoidance purpose need not be the dominant purpose in the particular transaction but must be not merely an incidental purpose.

The third element in the Opposition's proposal-the third criterion of likely successful legislation-is that which would give a broad discretion to the Commissioner and boards of review to decide whether the anti-avoidance provisions should apply to a particular scheme. The provisions should be cast in such a way-they are in our draft section 260E-that the Commissioner must be satisfied that a tax benefit was obtained or was reasonably expected to be obtained and that the tax avoidance purpose was operative. The discretion to determine these things should, we say, be vested in the Commissioner. (Extension of time granted). I am indebted to the Senate and my ministerial colleague for the indulgence. It will assist matters in the Committee stage. I assure the Senate that I will not trespass on its time on two occasions.

Let me complete this recitation of the elements of a likely successful scheme. The Commissioner ought to have a broad discretion with respect to determining for himself in all the circumstances of the case these basic elements. There ought to be accordingly the widest possible set of criteria to which the Commissioner may have regard in assessing whether the relevant purpose was present, in particular by being able to look at the whole transaction and its implications for any person affected by it. As an indication of the additional criteria as compared with those which the Government has seen fit to adopt and those which we would regard as appropriate, I refer briefly to paragraphs (i) and (j) in our proposed new section 260E (2) which provide for additional criteria for the Commissioner to take into account. Paragraph (i) states:
the extent (if any) to which the relevant taxpayer used or committed his own funds in the scheme;
That is the United States test which has proved very effective as a guide to what is in fact a tax avoidance situation. Paragraph (j) states:
whether the scheme created or failed to create rights or obligations which normally would not or would (as the case may be) be created between persons dealing with each other at arm's length.

That is another well-understood legal concept-it is a very well-understood commercial concept too-which we believe would have a practical and very useful application in aiding the Commissioner in the exercise of this discretion. The fourth element in any successful anti-avoidance scheme in this area must be a specific legislative exclusion of the choice principle which I described this afternoon before the suspension of the sitting for dinner-I will not repeat it-and which is the subject matter of our proposed new section 260F (2).

The fifth criterion which is necessary is a reconstruction power vested in the Commissioner subject to safeguards and under the supervision of the boards of review; that is, a power vested in the Commissioner-this is articulated in proposed new section 260G of our draft-to construct a liability to tax after declaring the scheme void and to adjust taxable income without having to justify the adjustment by reference to a particular taxing provision of the Act. The problem with the existing section 260 is that it has been repeatedly held by the courts to be an annihilating provision only, so that once the scheme has been struck down there is no actual liability to tax which can then be created out of that particular wreckage unless there is left some identifiable income of the taxpayer which would have been taxable if the scheme had not been entered into. It is a necessary part, and indeed that is acknowledged by the Government in the Howard draft. It is necessary that there be a reconstruction provision of that kind. The Opposition thinks that its provision is a little more successful than that which the Government has built into Part IVA.

The final element is a delicate and sensitive one, but it raises a very important point. I do not believe it is appropriate that in any such broad-ranging discretionary catch-all provision for there to be a penalty provision. I do not think it is appropriate for there to be any penalty provision at all, other than, of course, a requirement that the taxpayer pay the tax that should have been payable and the interest upon it. This kind of scheme certainly is not appropriate for the application of savage punitive measures such as the 200 per cent penalty that is provided for in the current Part IVA. Once penalty provisions of that kind are put in the whole nature of the scheme is changed. In this sort of legislative measure one loses the capacity to create, fairly anyway, broad-ranging discretions vested in the Commissioner. This I note, as honourable senators no doubt would have noted, has been a point that I think has been very effectively made in the current public debate about the present Part IVA in letters to the Australian Financial Review. I refer first to a letter written on 5 June by Mr P. M. Burgess, Senior Lecturer in Law at the University of New South Wales, and, second, to a letter dated today, 11 June, and written by Geoffrey Lehmann from the University of New South Wales. That point, although perhaps not acceptable to all of my college, I personally regard as indispensable to the fair operation of a genuine broad-based discretionary catch-all anti-avoidance provision of the section 260 variety. That certainly is built into the kind of scheme that I am proposing for the future. Summarising what I have said in one sentence, I believe it is possible to have effective legislative constraints against both classes of avoidance. This double-barrelled approach will do the job of countering tax avoidance across the board in a way that simply will not be managed and cannot be managed by the Government's own proposals.

I should like to say finally that if the Government will not accept this approach-it seems it is unlikely to do that at least tonight but I hope it will bear in mind what I have said for the future-there might be a great deal to be said at least for keeping the existing section 260 intact rather than effectively repealing it as is accomplished by clause 10 of the present Bill, thus making it inoperative for the future. There are two things which suggest that the existing section 260-the emasculated and impotent section 260 which the High Court in previous years anyway has well and truly worked over-might have some life left in it. There are two things encouraging me and many other people to believe that it might be worth a punt to keep section 260, particularly given the highly penal nature of new Part IVA. It might be worth while keeping the existing section 260 to operate as a non-punitive, general discretionary power to cope with the sorts of ambiguous arrangements that I referred to previously. I urge that point very seriously upon the Government for its consideration. There are two things which suggest it might be worth while. One is the manifestly changing attitude of the Court itself, spectacularly demonstrated in the Cooper Brookes case decided last week on 5 June in which the Court, not consisting in this instance of Justices Murphy and Brennan whose approach to this sort of legislation is well known to be purposive but consisting of all the other justices, came down nearly unanimously in favour of a totally non-literal and purposive construction of a tax provision. Chief Justice Gibbs and Justices Stephen, Mason and Wilson made it very clear indeed that they were no longer prepared to tolerate the sort of approach which in the past has been synonymous with Sir Garfield Barwick and which in this case was doggedly ahered to by His Honour Mr Justice Aickin. There is some evidence before our eyes as to what is going on.

The other new card in the pack is the new section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act. Perhaps I can say a little more about that because its effect has been given again wildly misunderstood in many quarters in the recent public debate on it. I believe section 15AA, while not amounting in itself to any kind of legal revolution, does amount to a clear legislative statement of its intention that in these ambiguous statutory situations when there appears to be a conflict between what the Act says and what the manifest intention of the Act is the courts ought to go down the path of the manifest intention of the legislature. With this change in attitude which seems to be evolving quite independently in the Court itself, together with the reinforcement offered by the legislative direction now embodied in new section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, I believe there is a very real chance that section 260 could rise like a phoenix from the bed of ashes which it has been inhabitating for so long and could operate, without any amendment at all, as a potentially quite effective weapon in the area at least of these ambiguous avoidance arrangements.

I have sought not to be destructive in what I have said but rather to share with the Government the Labor Party's thinking in this area-we have devoted quite a bit of thinking to it, as I hope is reasonably evident, over the past few months-and also its hope that the Government's resolve will be stiffened to introduce some of the sorts of approaches which I have described. We believe that what has been done by the Government in this Bill is inadequate for all the reasons I have outlined, but we do not oppose the Bill because we see it, on balance, as having some advantages and as representing something of an advance. We are not trying tonight, as my colleague Ralph Willis said in the other House, to score party points in any way at all, but simply to improve this legislation in the national interest because the fight against tax avoidance in all its aspects is one that concerns all the community and is one that we, as parliamentarians, will have to share responsibility for if it is going to be won.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to comment very briefly on the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) which replaces the old section 260 with a new Part IVA, aiming to eliminate blatantly artificial tax avoidance schemes while at the same time not inhibiting normal business, commercial and family arrangements. I hope it works. It has good prospects, because its tighter wording is reinforced both by the recent and proposed amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act and also by signs, in a recent case, that the High Court is at last taking a more sensible attitude to tax legislation. But it will certainly be tested by the tax avoidance industry, and if a blatantly artificial scheme gets through on some legalistic technicality, the Treasurer will have to legislate to ensure that those concerned get nothing out of it. Such legislation would be legally but not morally retrospective. The tax avoiders have been given fair warning, but the only way we will destroy them is to convince them that, even if they win on a technicality, they will make nothing out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a saying that nothing in life is certain but death and taxes. A small, very selfish, wealthy section of the community has been successfully disproving the latter part of this saying. It is vital to the stability and morality of our society that we should ensure that they pay their fair share of the costs of the community of which they are a very privileged part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of Senator Tate, who no doubt will arrive fairly soon, I might proceed.
—If I give you his speech, will you read it?
—Or incorporate it?

—Perhaps we could incorporate his speech and I could then proceed to make mine. The Senate is currently debating the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981, which, as Senator Evans and Senator Hamer have pointed out, seeks to replace section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act with a much more complex provision. I must say that the layman, in trying to follow what has happened in relation to section 260, would no doubt be very confused. Section 260 contained a very simple provision to the effect that any scheme by any taxpayer which was designed to avoid income tax, which was payable to the Commissioner of Taxation, would be invalid. Listeners may think that was a fairly simple and not unreasonable provision.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened was that taxpayers then started to enter into arrangements which seemed designed to change their tax position. Upon an examination of the provisions of section 260 these arrangements were upheld by the High Court of Australia. I refer to simple matters such as a partnership under which, for example, an electrician might share his income with his wife. To some, that might have seemed to have been a scheme which was designed to avoid taxation, in that it reduced the taxation of the electrician. Some might have thought, under the original section 260, the scheme should have been held invalid. However, the High Court held that such schemes were valid. I suppose that if one looked at them in all reasonableness they might be seen as genuine. Perhaps the wife had to answer the telephone, send out the accounts or engage in some other activity in relation to the collection of income by the electrician. It may have seemed reasonable that the income should be shared in order to reduce the liability to tax of both parties.

What happened was that the High Court looked at the actions of the parties to see whether the taxpayer was organising his affairs so as to minimise his tax or evade tax. If the High Court believed in the circumstances, all he was doing was attempting to minimise his tax it did not disapprove the rearrangement of his affairs. That seemed reasonable. I might add that when I first went into practice as a lawyer some 25 years ago it seemed to me to be reasonable, and in many cases the arrangements which parties seemed to enter into in those days seemed to be genuine. However, in the past 25 years, the interpretation of the taxing Acts by the High Court has altered so that, in recent years the taxpayer and his advisers seem to have been able to get away with any scheme of rearrangement of affairs, even if the scheme seems not to be part of a genuine business arrangement.

I first started to talk about this problem back in 1978. I am aware that for at least the last three years the Government and the present Treasurer (Mr Howard) have been looking at the problems created, in effect by the decisions of the High Court, in relation to its interpretation of, what then seemed to be, a simple provision that if any scheme were designed to avoid income tax it would be invalid against the Commissioner of Taxation. What has happened in recent years is that the interpretation of section 260 by the High Court has been such that it is almost as if the Court has said that those words are meaningless. I do not say that that is what the Court has said but it has found legal ways of saying that. The result has been of great detriment to the revenue of the governments of Australia.

I cannot explain or justify these decisions by the High Court. I do not attempt to, but I can and I do criticise these decisions because the results of those interpretations by the High Court is that the payment of any tax by a business man in Australia has become a voluntary thing. If a taxpayer in business in Australia wants to pay tax, he goes to his accountant and tells him, in effect, the amount of tax he wants to pay. They discuss this and arrange so much of a scheme as would enable him to pay that amount of tax. The businessman pays the accountant a fee and then the return is lodged with whatever contrivance they have managed to arrange. If he wants to pay no tax at all he can find accountants, lawyers-the infamous Mr Clyne-around Australia who will devise a scheme that will enable him to pay no tax at all. This is regardless of income. It could be $500,000 or $1m. It does not make the slightest bit of difference because a scheme can be devised to enable him to pay no tax at all.

Of course, this greed has seeped through the community to such an extent as to be almost unbelievable. The result has been that many people in the business community who are able to enter into these schemes which are designed to avoid or evade tax have been made millionaires. One reads about people paying $1m for houses, units and penthouses around Sydney and Melbourne. There can be no doubt as to who is paying those prices for premises for those people. There is no doubt. It is not necessarily those people's incomes but the taxpayers of Australia who are making those contributions because the tax avoidance industry is now robbing the nation of revenue of about $2,500m a year. The sort of greed that has seeped through this society in relation to tax avoidance is almost unbelievable to me. It has happened in my lifetime. It has happened during my time as a lawyer involved, partly, in this industry.

Try as this Parliament might it has been unable to prevent that. Decisions of the High Court have constantly found against the legislation and in favour of the taxpayer. As I said, the result has been that the burden of providing the services upon which this nation depends has passed from the businessman to the wage and salary earner who has his taxes deducted by an employer before he receives his income. The result is that the defence of this nation, social welfare payments by governments, our roads, education and health expenditure are all being paid by the wage and salary earner and not by the businessman.

I find that meeting after meeting I attend I get attacked because the Treasurer of the nation is determined to strike out tax avoidance. I find businessmen putting to me propositions that they have to avoid tax in order to cope with inflation and other problems. When I put it to them that that is rubbish and that their incomes might exceed $50,000 or more and that they are not paying tax on that, but paying substantial accountancy fees, I see a lowering of eyes and a cowering as they move away. I point out to them that the fellow sweeping the streets outside might be on $180 or $200 a week and he is paying his fair share to revenue. But I point out to them that they, on incomes of perhaps $50,000, $100,000 or $500,000, are paying, in fact, no taxation at all. More and more this burden has fallen on the wage and salary earners of the nation, and the burden has become intolerable. For three years this legislation has been in gestation. For three years I have been pestering the Treasurer to find out when the legislation would hit the Parliament and for three years he has been telling me of the difficulties involved in the preparation of the legislation.

I can say only that unless the High Court of Australia gives this legislation some sort of more favourable interpretation-more along the lines of the precedence given to taxation legislation in the High Court by Sir Owen Dixon rather than along the lines of that given to it by the High Court in more recent judgments-the inevitable result will be that we will get more and more oppressive legislation and more and more discretion to impose taxation granted to the Commissioner of Taxation. We will get more and more of the legislation suggested by my colleague from Victoria, Senator Evans, who suggests in his propositions that the Taxation Commissioner should have discretionary powers and there should be retrospectivity.

I know that members on my side of the Parliament are opposed to retrospective propositions and I know that there are senators and members on the other side of the Parliament who are opposed to retrospective propositions. As a matter of fact, when I look back at the debate that occurred in 1978, it is very interesting to see that my then colleague from Tasmania, Senator Sir Reginald Wright, who followed me in the debate talked about discretions and the problems that have been created in the Parliament. Senator Sir Reginald Wright is reported in Hansard of 8 June 1978 as saying:
I am indebted to Senator Lewis for drawing attention to the question of discretions, as Senator Messner did. I just remind the Senate that in 1964--
He was able to go back a further 14 years-
we had a terrific crisis here when the Government was kept up all night and had to divide a Bill because of my opposition to discretions . . .
I draw attention also to what Senator the Honourable John Wheeldon said in the same debate. I cannot find the passage at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps Senator Tate took it.
—As Senator Cavanagh said, perhaps Senator Tate took it. He did not. In the course of that debate Senator Wheeldon said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be appropriate if I were to intervene just briefly at this time to reaffirm the opposition of the Australian Labor Party to retrospective legislation.

The Parliament has no wish to introduce retrospective legislation. It has no wish to grant discretionary taxation powers to the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. We have been saying this over and over again. Unless the interpretations of the legislative provisions of this Parliament by the High Court are more generous in favour of the Commissioner of Taxation and more harsh to the taxpayer and unless there is a much more open interpretation, as I have said, along the lines of that given to it by the High Court when it was constituted under the Chief Justiceship of Sir Owen Dixon, the inevitable result will be harsher and harsher and more oppressive taxation legislation as the legislature and the executive government endeavour to extract taxation from those greedy taxpayers who are not prepared to pay their fair share of the contribution to revenue which it is necessary for all people in the nation to make.

After those words, may I say I am delighted that, after this period of gestation, this legislation has finally come into the Parliament. I welcome it. I certainly hope that the Senate will pass it this evening and I certainly hope that it will be given a fair and reasonable interpretation by the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to speak on the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill. I apologise to the Senate for not being present at an earlier moment, as I was taken by surprise by the succinct nature of the contribution made by Senator Hamer. Nevertheless, I rise because of the very real seriousness of the matters under discussion. This Bill at last embodies the Parliament's response to that most crippling phenomenon within our society whereby people whom I have described at other times as the tax bludgers, the real subversives within our society, have been undermining the very fabric of our democratic institutions. Not only have these tax avoiders been refusing to make their fair contribution, as Senator Austin Lewis has said, to the revenues necessary to sustain the programs of a democratically elected government but also they have been creating within the community a sense of disparity in treatment, a sense of unfairness, such that the very social cohesion which binds us together as a nation of free people is beginning to feel the strains of this greed, this avarice, which has manipulated the tax laws of this country in favour of those who were described so well by Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we have had within our society greed operating on an unparalleled scale, such that many commentators, including I think Professor Mathews, and Senator Lewis have made the point that for those earning high salaries or deriving large incomes within that free democratic wealth-producing society the payment of taxes has become discretionary; taxes are paid if it suits the taxpayer to pay them. The sorts of arguments they put up for taking that stance and employing the lawyers and accountants whom they do are specious. I will come to them in a short time. The scope of the problem is well known. In fact, Mr Howard, in answering Mr Ralph Willis, the economic spokesman for the Australian Labor Party, came to the conclusion that at least $1 billion a year was involved in Treasury revenue losses through the operation of these tax avoidance schemes. That means that the ordinary taxpayer-the wage and salary earner within our society, the person subject to the pay-as-you-earn scheme-is funding the roads, the hospitals, the education system and the very defence of the nation, within which the tax bludgers operate and enjoy a standard of living within a free society unparalleled, I would say, in the entire world.

The main argument put forward by tax avoiders, as has been commented upon earlier-and I must say that I am finding it very hard to follow the train of my own thoughts with the competition from Senator Kathy Martin on the other side-is that over the last few years their contribution to revenue has become so intolerable that they have had to find these means of avoiding making a contribution according to the tax scales set down by this Parliament. It has been pointed out in an article by Mr Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 June that those taxpayers earning over $18,000 a year in 1976 real terms have had a decrease in their average tax rates in the five years 1976 to 1981. In other words, with the tax indexation system such as was partially adopted and operated by this Government, those who in 1976 were earning around $20,000 a year in assessable income paid tax, on average, at the rate of 34.8 per cent. In 1981-82 they paid an average tax rate of 33.9 per cent. But more startling is the fact that in 1976-77 those who had an assessable income of $50,000 a year paid a tax rate of 51.8 per cent while in 1981-82 they paid a tax rate of 48.8 per cent. In other words, there has been a decrease of 3 per cent in the average tax rate payable by the earners of such large incomes. In other words, the argument that the tax scales have operated adversely against the earners of large incomes is not borne out by the facts. Of course, that argument is circular anyway.

One reason why personal income tax rates have to remain as high as they do is simply that the Treasury has to take into account the likely loss of revenue in the year for which the tax rates are set. In other words, it is a catch-22 situation. The only way for tax scales to be moderated is for tax avoidance to cease. The fact is that if tax avoidance ceased the average wage and salary earner would be paying some $4 or $5 less a week in his contribution to Federal revenue than he pays now. At present, as is well-known, the burden of personal income taxation is inexorably falling onto the average wage and salary earner, the pay-as-you-earn person, who cannot afford to pervert the best legal and accounting brains in this country for his greedy purposes, such as is the case with the large income earner. This is where the social cohesion within our society is breaking down. It is the ordinary taxpayers like the Reg Frosts of this world who are given the appearance of being mugs by smart-Alick, glib-tongued people of Peter Clyne-I was going to say 'stature' but that would have been quite the wrong word. I was delighted to see that only last week the High Court knocked back a case in which he, I think, refused to make available a tax return to the Commissioner of Taxation in the year of income 1977-78. Mr Peter Clyne was found to have feet of clay. Those who pay thousands of dollars to attend his seminars ought to keep in mind the fact that in the personal case that he took to the High Court last week, he lost, and lost badly. I for one was delighted to see that that was the case.

I think what is very important about this legislation is that it re-establishes, reaffirms and asserts the view of this Parliament in relation to the High Court-a matter which has already been commented on by senators on both sides of the chamber. What we have had in the last several years is a situation in which the clear intention of the elected representatives of the people, in both chambers of this Parliament, as expressed in section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, has been totally frustrated and impeded by a non-elected bench of justices of the High Court. I say 'non-elected' to make the point that in a strict sense they are politically irresponsible. They are responsible to no-one for the consequences of their judgments within this society, whereas we, of course, are subject to the disciplines of the ballot box every three or six years as the case may be. That politically irresponsible, non-elected bench of justices has undermined and frustrated the clear intention of this Parliament. I for one would have thought it would be almost sufficient for this Parliament to negate section 260 for a day and then relegislate that section simply to say to the High Court that it is the firm intention of the elected representatives of the people that those who engage in these schemes ought to have them vitiated, rendered null and void as against the Treasury.

For some time the Treasurer, Mr Howard, has dealt with schemes on a piecemeal basis. Such a basis is invariably ineffective, because without retrospectivity we catch up with a scheme only after it has been become known to the Taxation Commissioner and in any case it encourages the sporting atmosphere of 'one for the Commissioner, one for us'-the constant to and fro between the skilled draftsmen on the one hand, protecting the revenue, and the accountants and lawyers on the other hand, serving the interests of the greedy within our society. When one scheme is cut down ten more spring up in a hydra-headed manner to replace it. That piecemeal approach is superseded at last by a more comprehensive attempt to legislate in a way which expresses the intention of the Parliament that schemes which obtain a tax benefit for a taxpayer in a way which is described should be dealt with so that, if the case is established, the taxpayer faces double the tax payments that he or she sought to avoid. I will come to how the case should be established in a moment.

At this point I simply say how surprising it is that within this legislation there is no statement of objects or purpose. There is no preamble. Even in the Title of the Bill itself there is no lengthy statement which would enable the High Court to see what purpose or object the Parliament had in mind. The Title merely states: 'A Bill for an Act to amend the law relating to income tax'. One would have expected that at least a longer Title or even a preamble or objects clause within the body of the Bill would have been provided in order not only to express the intention of the Parliament but also, in doing so, to take advantage of the Acts Interpretation Act amendment which was passed by the Parliament only this week and which made it clear that in the view of the Parliament the High Court should promote the purpose or object underlying the Act. Why has the Government not seen fit to state clearly the purpose or object underlying the legislation? In my view, of all the amendments to be moved by the Opposition in the Committee stage of this Bill, none is more important than that which proposes a statement of the object of the legislation. It states:

The object of this Parliament is to ensure a fair sharing of the tax burden and to promote the revenue-raising, economic and redistributive functions of this Act by preventing or counteracting tax avoidance, and accordingly the provisions of this Part shall be deemed to be remedial and shall be given such large, liberal and purposive construction as would best ensure the attainment of the object of this Part.

I believe that with such a statement of Parliament's clear intention in framing these provisions the High Court would be bound to promote the purpose or object underlying the Act, if there were any question in its mind about the extent, range or reach of these provisions in relation to any artificial contrivance which had been dreamed up in the offices of the accountants or lawyers of this country. It seems to me that the High Court is pre-disposed to be sympathetic now to that sort of objects provision. Of course, one was extremely pleased to see that only last week the High Court in a landmark judgment decided in favour of the Commissioner of Taxation and against an artificial tax avoidance scheme. It appeared, certainly in the opinion of the High Court, that there had been such a miscalculation in the drafting of the Act that a literal interpretation would have allowed the taxpayer to claim $44,000 in tax losses in a completely artificial way. Within that judgment, for example, Justices Mason and Wilson, talking about various rules of construction, stated that they had to ascertain the legislative intention. They said that the propriety of their looking to the object of the Act rather than relying on a literal interpretation 'extends to any situation in which for good reason the operation of the statute on a literal reading does not conform to the legislative intent as ascertained from the provisions of the statute, including the policy which may be discerned from those provisions'.

It is true that in a general sense the policy can be discerned from the various provisions of this taxation law. But how much more strengthened the hand of the High Court would have been if, as is proposed by the Opposition, a very explicit objects section were written into the Act. I repeat that we need to assert in the revenue-gathering legislation of our society the dominance of those who are the elected representatives of the people, answerable to the taxpayers and voted for by the taxpayers over the non-elected Bench of High Court justices.

Conscious as I am of the time of the Senate and the enormous program of legislation still to be dealt with, I will only briefly mention some points on which I would otherwise have elaborated. Firstly, because of the failure of the Government to include an object clause in this amendment, and because of the lingering mistrust of the courts which the Opposition still has in this area, the Opposition has thought it wise and prudent to place more clearly in the Commissioner's hands the determination of whether a scheme has been contrived to confer a tax benefit on a taxpayer of the type described. In other words, it is thought quite proper that the Taxation Commissioner should have this power-a power which of course is subject to appeal in the normal way through the taxation Boards of Review and so on. It is not an unreviewable power. It is a power to determine questions of fact and to make some assessment of their impact, but it is not unappealable and we think it ought to be largely in the hands of the Commissioner.

As to retrospectivity, whilst it is not a feature of the present Bill before the chamber the view of the Opposition is well known. On the whole, I have never been one to support in the general run retrospectivity where penal provisions are provided and where penalties and monetary imposts are made on ordinary citizens. Nevertheless, it is a fact that in the very country which has given us our judicial and political institutions, namely the United Kingdom, it has been recognised from the Second World War onwards, by both the judicial and political wings of the United Kingdom, that retrospectivity in this area is necessary and justified in order to enable society to deal with those who would undermine the very fabric of society by refusing the democratic government its revenues and creating this sense of unfairness between citizens who are taxpayers.

Finally, in certain situations where a tax avoidance scheme has been found to operate, it is a fact that there are provisions which will penalise the taxpayer to the extent that he will have to pay double the tax which he has sought to avoid. There have been outcries that this is an outrageous impost or penalty on the taxpayer, but to my mind it does not go far enough. I have often said in this chamber that the penalty of payment of moneys by people of this character and with these resources is not the way to deal with them. What is needed is a penalty which clearly states that such persons are beyond the pale of democratic society. I emphasise that to my mind they are undermining the very fabric of our democratic institutions.

One finds, for example, in the Commonwealth Electoral Act that no person attainted of treason shall be entitled to have his name placed on or retained on any roll or to vote in any Senate election or House of Representatives election. In my view, these people ought to be placed in the same category because ultimately they are just as dangerous to the democratic institutions and way of life of this country as are people who are more clearly and more easily seen to be subversive or treasonable. To put it in the form of a slogan and with due deference to the American Revolution, there should be no representation without taxation. If these people refuse to pay taxation, they should have no right to a voice in the election of persons to the councils of government of this nation. It they demonstrate an unwillingness to contribute to the revenues of the Government, they should have no say in its formation. I support the most stringent penalties, the most onerous monetary imposts on these people, but I go further. In relation to these subversive persons I summarise my beliefs by saying: No representation without taxation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, in introducing this measure, has certainly approached the subject of tax avoidance in a very novel way. Clearly we have, over the last few years, adopted an approach, as has been outlined by all speakers, based on a specific approach to particular problems that have occurred from time to time. Certainly, that has been, on the whole quite successful. Speakers for the Opposition have demonstrated that maybe it has its weaknesses insofar as it is an ex post facto operation and we do not always catch up with those who succeed in getting through the tax avoidance net quite cleanly. In that respect, I think that particular problem has been addressed in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out one or two aspects of that approach from the point of view of the difficulties which I think have been handled in this amendment. As we look at the question of tax avoidance, I think it is quite clear that the approach of the legal and accounting professions of the last 10 years has changed significantly from one which relied upon the arrangement of the affairs of a family or business in such a way as to minimise taxation liabilities to one in which straight-out avoidance became the main objective. Certainly, that has been the main thrust of the well-known practitioners in this field over the last few years. We have seen the rise of a consortia of legal accounting operations and even public companies involving themselves in widespread dividend-stripping and asset-stripping operations and schemes of that kind. They have attracted people who, on previous occasions and in normal circumstances which may have been present in previous years, would not have found themselves attracted to those kinds of schemes. In fact, I think it is clear that persons who believed in the past that there were certain limits beyond which people would not go in this area have found attractions in dealing with practitioners in this twilight zone of the accounting and legal professions.

Nevertheless, the fact is that we have seen these developments in the last few years. I recall, in particular that before Senator Evans came to this House there was a very good debate on the question of retrospectivity in respect of the Curran case. That was in, I think, May or June of 1978. That case raised many substantial issues in connection with this whole area of tax avoidance. Senator Lewis referred to that debate earlier tonight. He quoted some of the remarks of Senator the Honourable Sir Reginald Wright in that debate. Clearly the considerations which were mentioned by Senator Sir Reginald Wright in that debate-the question of retrospectivity and the question of discretion being given to the Commissioner of Taxation in particular circumstances-are matters which have been widely canvassed in this Parliament and ones which I think all honourable senators appreciate and properly understand.

In connection with the particular matter of this debate, we come down to an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act which lays down a new set of criteria by which tax avoidance schemes, contracts and various transactions might be judged. The difficulty in these circumstances is always to establish a criterion, a test, which ascribes tax avoidance in fairly clear terms but which, at the same time, does not produce the kinds of effects in respect of legitimate business and of family arrangements and transactions in such a way as to annihilate them. The point is that we should not take the baseball bat to swat the fly. We should allow normal business transactions to be carried out without a high level of concern being imposed on businesses by the Commissioner of Taxation. That is the fundamental dilemma which any government faces in designing the kind of legislation of which we can see the fruits in this Bill. The legislation has been drawn in a very careful manner. Over the last two years there has been considerable consultation among the Government, its counsel who have been appointed to advise in respect of these sections of the law and the Taxation Advisory Committee which was established recently by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and which consists of experts who are currently practitioners in taxation law. In addition there has been considerable political input into this whole area through the Government members committee on taxation, and that has been a worthwhile contribution to this whole area.

I now address myself to several of the remarks of the Opposition senators who have spoken chiefly in support of their own amendments which will be put during the Committee stage. In particular the Government sees some dangers in some of the approaches which have been outlined by Senator Evans and Senator Tate in particular. They have spoken of the area of retrospectivity in respect of this kind of law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not this kind of law, only in respect of specific remedial provisions; not a general provision of this kind.

—I am glad Senator Evans has made that clear. He has referred to specific transactions. Firstly, let us examine the position with regard to the philosophy of that matter. Whilst this Parliament did pass a Bill in 1978 which introduced a degree of retrospectivity in respect of Curran type situations, the general approach of this Government has been to oppose retrospectivity in its various forms. That is not to say, however, that having given notice to the public by way of an appropriate public statement that certain areas of the taxation law would be subject to legislation at some future time the law would not be proclaimed to take effect from the date of the statement. I believe that is a different concept from that of straight retrospectivity which the Opposition is currently supporting.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the whole area of retrospectivity one should also test such a proposal by a consideration of its effectiveness. Would an effective tax avoidance system be brought into effect by virtue of such an amendment? Certainly one of the chief objectives of those engaged in tax avoidance schemes is not merely to avoid taxation permanently but to delay the effect of taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opportunity for delay is infinitely greater with your amendment than with the UK style.

—The point here is that, notwithstanding the effect of retrospective legislation such as the Opposition proposes, we would be placed in a situation in which action could not be taken by a government until the facts of the case became known to the Commissioner of Taxation, until the facts were properly assessed and until all the legal processes were finally brought to a conclusion. This, of course, involves appeals through the normal channels in the income tax law structure such as boards of review and the courts including the High Court. During that time taxpayers have the advantage of not having to have paid the tax that may have been due under any amended assessment that might have been made by the various judicial authorities in that circumstance. Consequently, these processes may take a considerable time-two years, three years or more. This confers a great advantage on taxpayers in this situation. One could argue very strongly that that form of retrospectivity-given all the side effects and all the deleterious effects it may have on the legal system generally and particularly on the view of the public towards the Parliament-could endanger the whole system of law under which we live in this country. I think the point has been made that the system outlined by the Opposition would not be regarded as the most effective approach to this problem. This scheme, as outlined in the legislation, gives us a full opportunity of approaching the matter from a new standpoint.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the general question of discretions is and has been for a long time a matter of great debate in this Parliament. The ability of this Parliament to confer a wide discretion upon the Commissioner of Taxation in respect of particular transactions is one of those powers which ought to be very jealously guarded by the Parliament. This Government will be very careful to ensure that this sort of thing does not become widespread. I might just point out in regard to that matter that to give effect to a discretion through the law may bring about only a very modest increase in the potential for fighting tax avoidance in its usual form. We cannot see that that would achieve very much at all. One has to have regard to the fact that the Commissioner's decisions will be subject to review by the boards of review and other courts of appeal. Consequently, the Commissioner would not necessarily be in a position where his word was final. Again, the Opposition's view on this matter, upon which it has heaped much support, could well fall to the ground in this situation.

I noted that Senator Evans mentioned that the penalty of 200 per cent was manifestly excessive and that this amounted to a clear command to the courts to be very cautious in their approach to the interpretation of the proposed new Part IVA in this legislation. Counsel to the Government have advised that the penalty provisions could lead to strict construction, but they are agreed that the proposed penalty is necessary and appropriate. In fact what is proposed is little different from the present legal situation. The penalty is always subject to remission and as such is well contemplated by the law and certainly by those who administer the law. This will not have a great effect upon the ability of the Government to enforce this law against tax avoiders in the way proposed by the Opposition.

Finally, I think it is apt to observe that in recent times there have been some very well-known cases of tax avoidance. Senator Tate mentioned the case of Mr Peter Clyne. He has been very public in his approach to the whole question of tax avoidance and indeed tax evasion. In recent times he probably has become the very epitome-if one likes, the very image-of tax avoidance and has carried the fight against the Taxation Commissioner to the nth degree. The fact is that this man, who clothes himself as some kind of Robin Hood looking after those people who are oppressed by the law in certain ways, is robbing not only the rich but also the poor to feed the rich. It is that kind of man whom this country does not strongly support, and certainly this Government has no interest in supporting. This man, who claims to have been so successful in the area of tax avoidance, in fact has not won a case against the Taxation Commission. Senator Tate drew our attention tonight to the fact that he lost a case last week in the High Court of Australia with respect to the non-lodgment of his family's taxation returns for the year ended 1978.

I believe that the community demands action of the kind represented in these amendments against persons like Mr Peter Clyne and against other tax avoiders. That is the basis on which the Government has been taking a continual action not only in respect of specific schemes over recent times but now through these very important amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act which are based upon a whole new concept of tests in respect of tax avoidance schemes. As I think the Opposition has acknowledged, it certainly is a major step forward in this area, and consequently I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To expedite what could otherwise be a very long Committee debate-it was a rather long one in the other place-and also to honour the undertaking I gave to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) when he very kindly moved an extension of time for my speech at the second reading stage, I propose to deal in one batch with the five Opposition amendments that have been circulated and which of themselves are quite long, technical and complex and in fact speak to them, I hope in one 15-minute gulp, which will make it unnecessary for there to be further contributions. I seek leave to move together amendments Nos (1) to (5), which have been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Pages 2 and 3, clause 7, proposed section 177A, leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:

Object and interpretation of Part '' '177A. (1) The object of this Part is to ensure a fair sharing of the tax burden and to promote the revenue-raising, economic and redistributive functions of this Act by preventing or counteracting tax avoidance, and accordingly the provisions of this Part shall be deemed to be remedial and shall be given such large, liberal and purposive construction as will best ensure the attainment of the object of this Part.
'(2) In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears-
''liability'' includes a potential or prospective liability;
''scheme'' includes-
(a) any agreement, arrangement, understanding, promise or undertaking, whether express or implied and whether or not enforceable, or intended to be enforceable, by legal proceedings; and
(b) any plan, proposal, action, omission, course of action or course of conduct,
and without limiting the generality of the foregoing includes-
(c) any act omission transaction or other step preliminary to or forming part of a scheme; and
(d) a unilateral arrangement, plan, proposal, action, omission, course of action or course of conduct; and
''taxpayer'' includes a taxpayer in the capacity of a trustee.
'(3) The definition of ''taxpayer'' in sub-section (2) shall not be taken to affect in any way the interpretation of that expression where it is used in this Act other than this Part.

'(4) A reference in this Part to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme shall be read as including a reference to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme together with another person or other persons.

'(5) A reference in this Part to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for a particular purpose shall be read as including a reference to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for two or more purposes if-
(a) such purposes included or include that purpose; and
(b) that purpose was not or is not merely an incidential purpose' ''.
(2) Page 3, clause 7, proposed sub-sections 177B (3) and (4), lines 22 to 30, leave out the sub-sections.
(3) Pages 3 to 5, clause 7, proposed section 177C, leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:

Tax benefits '' '177C. A reference in this Part to the obtaining by a taxpayer of a tax benefit in relation to a scheme shall be read as a reference to a taxpayer being liable but for the operation of this Part-

(a) to pay less income tax in respect of a year of income than he would have been liable, or might reasonably have been expected by the Commissioner to be liable, to pay in respect of that year of income but for the scheme; or

(b) to pay any income tax in respect of a year of income which is a later year of income than the year of income in respect of which he would have been liable, or might reasonably have been expected by the Commissioner to be liable, to pay that income tax but for the scheme.' ''.
(4) Page 5, clause 7, proposed section 177D, leave out the proposed section, insert the following section:

Schemes to which Part applies '' '177D. (1) This Part applies to any scheme in relation to which a person acts or omits to act or has acted or omitted to act after 27 May 1981 (other than a scheme in relation to which a person acted or omitted to act before that date), whether in Australia or outside Australia or partly in Australia and partly outside Australia, where-
(a) the Commissioner is satisfied that a taxpayer (in this section referred to as ''the relevant taxpayer'')-
(i) has obtained a tax benefit in relation to the scheme;
(ii) would but for section 177F obtain a tax benefit in relation to the scheme; or
(iii) might reasonably be expected to obtain in the future a tax benefit in relation to the scheme; and

(b) the Commissioner is satisfied that a person who acted or omitted to act in relation to the scheme or any part of the scheme did so for the purpose of tax avoidance, whether or not the first mentioned person obtains any tax benefit in connection with the scheme and whether or not any person affected by the scheme is a party thereto.

'(2) In determining whether a person acted or omitted to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for the purpose of tax avoidance the Commissioner may have regard to any one or more of the following-
(a) the manner in which the scheme was entered into or carried out;
(b) the form and substance of the scheme;
(c) the time at which the scheme was entered into and the length of the period during which the scheme was carried out;
(d) the result in relation to the operation of this Act that, but for this Part, would be achieved by the scheme;
(e) any change in the financial position of the relevant taxpayer that has resulted, will result, or may reasonably be expected to result, from the scheme;
