(f) any change in the financial position of any person who has, or has had, any connection (whether of a business, family or other nature) with the relevant taxpayer, being a change that has resulted, will result, or may reasonably be expected to result, from the scheme;
(g) any other consequence for the relevant taxpayer, or for any person referred to in paragraph (f), of the scheme having been entered into or carried out;
(h) the nature of any connection (whether of a business, family or other nature) between the relevant taxpayer and any person referred to in paragraph (f);
(j) the extent (if any) to which the relevant taxpayer used or committed his own funds in the scheme;
(k) whether the scheme created or failed to create rights or obligations which normally would not or would, as the case may be, be created between persons dealing with each other at arms' length; and
(l) any other relevant matter.

'(3) A reference in this Part to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme for the purpose of tax avoidance shall be read as a reference to a person acting or omitting to act in relation to a scheme or part of a scheme for the purpose of-
(a) directly or indirectly altering the incidence of any income tax;
(b) directly or indirectly relieving any person from liability to income tax; or
(c) directly or indirectly avoiding, reducing or postponing any liability to income tax,

and references in this sub-section to the incidence of income tax or to a liability to income tax shall be read as including references to income tax which might reasonably have been expected to be incident upon any person but for the scheme or income tax to which any person might reasonably have been expected to be liable but for the scheme, as the case may be.

'(4) The Commissioner may be satisfied that a person acted or omitted to act in relation to a scheme for the purpose of tax avoidance notwithstanding that the scheme or any part of the scheme or any tax benefit obtained in relation to the scheme was or might be contemplated by another provision or other provisions of this Act.' ''.
(5) Page 7, clause 7, proposed sub-sections 177F (1) and (2) lines 2 to 19, leave out the proposed sub-sections, insert the following sub-sections:

''(1) Whenever this Part applies and notwithstanding any other provision of this Act other than this Part, the Commissioner may at any time in relation to the year or years of income in which the tax benefit is obtained, or in relation to any other year of income-
(a) treat the scheme or any part of the scheme as void for the purposes of this Act; and

(b) adjust the taxable income or liability to income tax of any person affected by the scheme to the extent necessary to counteract the tax benefit obtained in relation to the scheme or to any lesser extent.

''(2) Where pursuant to sub-section (1) any income is included in the taxable income of any person or any adjustment is made to the liability of any person to income tax, then for the purposes of this Act such income shall be deemed to have been derived by virtue of this section by that person and by no other person or such adjustment shall be deemed to have been made by virtue of this section to the liability of that person and of no other person, as the case may be.''.

I add that in the light of the Minister's response, there is one additional reason for my co-operation in keeping the Committee stage short; that is, my profound disappointment at what can be described only as the fat-headed intellectual level of the response that has been forthcoming from the Minister in this chamber and, indeed, from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the other chamber. I make no distinction as to the level of fat-headedness by the Government respondents in either case to what have been very carefully thought out, constructive arguments put forward not in a polemical spirit but in an attempt to raise the level of what hitherto has been a pretty abominable standard of argument and understanding of tax law and tax avoidance law in this country. Having removed my spleen in that fashion, I now proceed more constructively to say that the object of these amendments is to improve Part IVA to make it more effective than it is at the moment by going a good way down the track that I outlined in my second reading contribution.

I make it clear that, although there are many points of similarity between the proposed new section 260 that I put into the record in my speech at the second reading stage and the changes that are here proposed to the Part IVA, we are not in fact by these amendments seeking to go the whole way and embody the whole of the approach that was adopted in the separate section 260 proposal I put at the second reading stage. To do that would be to try to graft onto the Government's own approach here what is in essence a quite different approach. So I think all we can reasonably try to do is to improve the Government's own approach and to indicate some of the ways in which the Bill as it presently stands might be made more effective on the ground.

To explain what our various amendments are about would be a long and technical business and would undoubtedly try the patience of the Committee, not to mention anyone who might be listening to this debate, quite considerably. Moreover, that explanation was done quite effectively, I think, in the other place. I believe it might serve the purposes, if not of this Government then at least of posterity, to put in the record an explanatory memorandum, if I might so distinguish it by describing it as such, of our own indicating how it is that these amendments differ from the Government's Bill and indicating rather succinctly, nonetheless very effectively I believe, the arguments in support of those amendments and those changes. So I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Opposition's small 'e' explanatory memorandum.
Leave granted.

This principle states that, if a taxpayer creates a situation by entry to a transaction which will attract tax consequences for which the Act makes specific provision, the validity of the transaction is not affected by s. 260 merely because the tax consequences which it attracts are advantageous to the taxpayer and he enters into the transaction deliberately with a view to gaining that advantage. TALK.START.PARA: —There are just three particular matters to which I believe specific attention should be drawn. With the indulgence of the Committee, let me say something reasonably briefly on each of them. Those three matters are in turn: Firstly, the objects clause which we propose; secondly, the question of dominant purpose which we propose to amend; and, thirdly, the question of the choice principle which is technical but which is indispensable to an understanding of how this whole extraordinary situation developed legally. As far as the objects clause is concerned, the Opposition is proposing, as Senator Tate read into the record, an objects clause in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Part is to ensure a fair sharing of the tax burden and to promote the revenue-raising, economic and redistributive functions of this Act by preventing or counteracting tax avoidance, and accordingly the provisions of this Part shall be deemed to be remedial and shall be given such large, liberal and purposive construction as will best ensure the attainment of the object of this Part.

That sort of language is rather novel in Australian legislation. It is not completely novel; it does, in fact, appear, for example, in clause 3 of the Freedom of Information Bill. Of course, that is not yet Australian legislation and indeed may never be, given the attitude of this Government. It also, even more immediately, appears in the language of some State enactments. One example is, of all things, section 3 of the Victorian Liquor Control Act. That in turn has a pedigree in some other Commonwealth jurisdictions, notably Canada, as was noted in a very interesting article by Geoffrey Sawer in a recent edition of the Canberra Times. Some people have suggested, indeed Geoffrey Sawer did, that in those other jurisdictions, and to the extent that these sorts of clauses have hitherto appeared in the Australian jurisdictions, they have not been especially effective in concentrating the mind of the courts on giving legislation of this kind a purposive construction.

It is our belief that times are changing, that judicial minds are becoming a little more sensitive to socio-economic realities. The evidence for that is cases like the one in the High Court last week-the Cooper Brookes (Wollongong) Pty Ltd case, which I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage. We also, of course, have as an additional crutch for limping judicial minds to rest upon the new section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act which was introduced and carried through this Parliament quite recently and which has been the subject of a good deal of attention. To make clearer what I am talking about, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act as recently adopted by this Parliament.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

''15AA. (1) In the interpretation of a provision of an Act, a construction that would promote the purpose or object underlying the Act (whether that purpose or object is expressly stated in the Act or not) shall be preferred to a construction that would not promote that purpose or object.

''(2) Nothing in sub-section (1) shall be construed as authorizing, in the interpretation of a provision of an Act, the consideration of any matter or document not forming part of the Act for any purpose for which that matter or document could not be considered apart from that sub-section.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we do have a direction of this kind instructing the courts to adopt a construction which would promote the purpose or object underlying the Act, whether that purpose or object is expressly stated or not, combined with an express purpose or objects clause of the kind that the Opposition is here suggesting, it really will, in our belief, be a very great incentive to judges to adopt the kind of interpretation that all of us would believe is appropriate in these cases.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to say a brief word about the application of section 15AA. There has been a lot of misunderstanding about it, not only within the community at large but also within the legal profession. Before we can even think about giving some application to section 15AA there has to be one or other of two threshold considerations satisfied in the particular statute that we are trying to interpret. Either there has to be some ambiguity of an obvious kind in the language of that statute or there has to be some manifest incongruity between the language of a particular provision in the statute and what the rest of the section, the rest of the Part, the rest of the Act as a whole, seems to be trying to achieve.

An example of ambiguity is easy to find. The statute book is littered with them. Let me take just one which recently came to my attention. If a statute such as the trade practices provision operates only in respect of trading companies, one of the questions that can arise is: What sort of company is in fact a trading company? One situation which has arisen recently is an incorporated football club which is in the business of running football matches, putting teams on the field and running associated activities and which happens, among other things, occasionally to pay transfer fees and so on to buy footballers from interstate or from other clubs. Is that corporation a trading corporation? There is an ambiguity about it. It is not what we would think of, at first blush, as being a trading company, but it is a company which does happen to do a bit of trading of a peculiar kind on the side. That is just one example. There are literally millions of examples that one could find in the statute book of ambiguities with which courts are occasionally confronted.

The other sort of situation that I said has to arise before we can even begin to apply this sort of provision is where there is some manifest incongruity between the language of a particular provision by itself, which might be quite plain but sit very oddly with what the rest of the section or the rest of the statute as a whole seems to be about. It was exactly that situation that was in issue in the Cooper Brookes case. If neither of those conditions obtains, if there is no ambiguity or if there is no incongruity, then the job of the court is plain. It has simply to apply the language as it comes, to give the words in front of the court's nose the plain meaning of those words, and that is all there is to it. If that means that some stringent procedural safeguard, for example, in a breathalyser test law, has not been satisfied and someone who manifestly deserved to be slotted gets off, so be it. The court under those circumstances will have no option, in the absence of ambiguity or in the absence of incongruity of the kind I am mentioning, to do otherwise than apply the direct words of the statute. But, if one or other of those threshold considerations is satisfied, what happens is that the court confronts, as it were, a fork in the road. It can either go down the literal path, giving the words, whatever oddness seems to flow from it, their literal meaning, or go down the path which seems to reflect the express or implied intention underlying the legislation when looked at as a whole. The utility of the section 15AA provision as it stands is to operate as a signpost at those particular forks in the road. It is sitting there as a legislative signpost saying to the courts that when they confront one of those forks in the road they should go down this way, down the purposive path. They should not do down the literal path. If it is that sort of situation, that is what they should do. Section 15AA by itself does not take the court very far at all down that particular road. If the court is to be able actually to identify what the purpose is and to step down the purposive road--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the arrangement that if you were given leave to extend your speech on the second reading you would not speak in Committee? You broke your word.

—I promised not to speak at the length that was undertaken in the other chamber, and interjections of that kind do not assist the expeditious conduct of this business. It is no wonder the honourable senator is leaving the chamber. His conduct in running this House for the last session, ever since he has been appointed to this job, has been an abomination and a disgrace. I am trying to act constructively, to contribute to what has been a very difficult debate and to communicate to the community why it is that sections of this kind do have an enormous utility. What I am saying about a section such as 15AA is that it does operate as a signpost. It does not necessarily take one very far down the track, unless there is some other aid by which the particular purpose can be identified-for example, the explanatory memorandum, other extrinsic material or a purpose or object clause of the kind that is in issue here. That is why there is a real utility in having a purpose or object clause of this kind, particularly when it is in association with the recently enacted section 15AA.

SPEECH.PARA: Much more briefly, I will deal with the other two points that I wanted to make. The dominant purpose question is one that does cause some heart searching in a number of breasts because this amendment is trying to say that what the Commissioner should have regard to is not a situation where the tax avoidance purpose is the dominant purpose and only give the section its operation in that situation; rather what is being said is that the Commissioner should require only to be satisfied that the tax avoidance purpose was 'not merely an incidental purpose'. In respect of that, although there has been some concern that that is too far-reaching, I simply draw the attention of the Government and the chamber to the existence of similar provisions contained in section 4F of the Trade Practices Act, the New Zealand general anti-avoidance provision and, most relevantly of course within the terms of this legislation that we are adding to here tonight, section 82KH (1A) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. In the context of tax avoidance in the situation of carry forward losses, this provision appears:
In determining for the purpose of the Subdivision whether an argreement is a tax avoidance agreement, no regard shall be had to a purpose that is a merely incidental purpose.
I suggest that the Government can hardly quibble about the use of the sort of language that the Opposition is proposing here when it appears in the Government's own Income Tax Assessment Act.

The remaining point that I wanted to make-again I can do it in just a sentence or two-is about the necessity for there being an explicit renunciation of the choice principle if legislation of this kind is to be successful. What we propose in our amendment in this respect-in this case it is the amendment to add a sub-section (4) to proposed section 177D-is to put down or suggest language which, in our view and in the view of all the highly qualified and experienced tax lawyers with whom we have been consulting in this matter, will be effective in removing the possibility of that choice principle being applied by the courts. I described that principle in my speech at the second reading stage. It has been the fundamental barrier in the way of a sensible application of these kinds of discretionary clauses in the past.

It was very surprising and very peculiar that Mr Howard, in his response to what the shadow Treasurer, Mr Ralph Willis, had to say in the other place, seemed to take the view that the Opposition, by the general thrust of its amendments was going back down the track of exposing itself to the operation of the choice principle and having the effectiveness of these things accordingly modified. I cannot imagine that the Treasurer read-or if he did read it, understood-what was involved in proposed sub-section 177D (4) because clearly, in our view, that deals with that particular situation. I believe the amendments proposed by the Opposition would improve this Bill, although they could change the basic approach that the Government seems wedded to. Accordingly I commend the amendments to the chamber.

I will not reiterate the kind of general points which were made at the outset in regard to the fundamental nature of the legislation which is before us. We intend to conclude the debate at this stage. I commend the Bill to the chamber.

That the amendments (Senator Evans's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Acts Amendment Bill is a multi-purpose Bill and an important Bill which was presented to the Senate with inadequate notice as this parliamentary session ends and, therefore, will get inadequate consideration by this place. It is worth while noting that the explanatory memorandum to the legislation reached this chamber only this afternoon, but when the Bill, which is long and complex, was presented to the House of Representatives the haste in its conception and its drafting was demonstrated by the fact that the Government had to introduce its own amendments to correct the difficulties which had obviously arisen in its preparation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill amends the Health Insurance Act, the National Health Act, the Nursing Homes Assistance Act, and the Therapeutic Goods Act. I suggest that it should not have been presented to the Senate and this Parliament in this omnibus way. In the past Bills to amend each of those Acts have been presented separately. This legislation should have been presented as separate Bills because it amends separate Acts and because the clauses of the Bill have clearly separate and unrelated functions. As a crude attempt to avoid opposition to the undesirable and reprehensible changes to the health insurance system, the Government has tacked on a series of unobjectionable pieces of legislation to cloud the issue. I repeat: It is a practice which should not be followed in the future and which in my view should not have been introduced at this time.

The Opposition in fact supports parts of the Bill. It supports the extension of the Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Scheme to orthodontic procedures for those who are under the age of twenty. It supports the assumption by the Commonwealth of responsibility for all nursing home benefits. We support the updating of the Therapeutic Goods Act. In general we support the amendments to the legislation concerning pathology services. But because of the time and because of the limitation of debate we will not be able to deal with those measures which we support. The amendment which I shall move to the motion for the second reading takes into account our support for those measures. I must of necessity concentrate on the prime purpose of the legislation which is the introduction of a regressive, inequitable and unfair system of health care delivery and insurance in this country. Together with the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill, which we debated some two days ago, it represents a complete abrogation of the Government's promise of the pre-election days of the past to maintain Medibank.

In 1969 the Liberal Party Government of the day became concerned about the health system. It was concerned about increasing costs, about the number of people who were not covered by health insurance and about the lack of access of numbers of disadvantaged people to adequate health care. The Government established an inquiry under Mr Justice Nimmo, who reported on the inadequacy and inefficiency of the health funds, the fact that they did not provide adequate cover, the fact that consumers were not represented on their boards, and the multitude of deficiencies in their operations. Above all, he criticised the complexity of the voluntary health fund system.

I understand that my microphone is not working and that I must move. Apparently I am allowed to speak out of my place, which is incredible. I hope that I am not offending against the Standing Orders, Mr President.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't want to hear you.

—I know that Senator Withers is not interested in the health and care of people in this country. The health costs problem and the other difficulties with the system continued in an uncontrolled manner until July 1975, when Medibank, a system of universal health insurance, was introduced. I remind honourable senators that Medibank was not introduced until July 1975. After its introduction the acceleration in health costs began to level out. Ever since then the voluntary health funds have been fighting for a return to those great days of the past when they purchased aircraft for their executives, built large and grandiose buildings in the capital cities and used contributors' funds to provide loans for houses and cars for their executives. To achieve that goal they have donated funds to the Liberal Party, have provided public relations men for it at election time and have conducted anti-Labor advertising campaigns-all with contributors' funds. This package of legislation represents the final pay-off. Not only is the Government returning to those days; it is attempting to force people into the private health funds. This, with legislation passed earlier to force State governments to charge fees in public hospitals and to introduce demeaning means tests, is a pay-off to some of the biggest parasites in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: Health care should be accessible to all at a cost they can afford. It should be provided and funded at an adequate standard on a community rating principle, through a levy or progressive taxation system. It will not be so provided under this legislation, as it has not been under the four previous health schemes that this Government has introduced in the last four or five years. We remember that those health schemes were introduced with great fanfare and were going to solve all our problems. In 1976, the then Minister for Health, Mr Hunt, said in the debate on the changes of that year:

The changes we are proposing are also designed to provide incentives to the medical profession, and private insurers, to constrain costs by establishing competition between the public and private sectors. Competition between private insurers and Medibank should maintain both the quality of services and their cost efficiency . . . What it does . . . is provide the widest ranging choice that any health scheme has ever offered the Australian people . . .

That scheme did not last long. Senator Baume said of the 1976 changes that he saw Medibank as basically a form of State capitalism, another Post Office. It seems that all the private funds will be that now. Dr Sax, in the document Paying for Health Care, said in 1978:
A health financing system should be equitably financed, easy to understand and administer and be acceptable both to the public and the providers of services.
In introducing the 1978 health changes on top of the 1975, 1976 and 1977 changes, Mr Hunt, the then Minister, said:
. . . a particular feature of these arrangements is their simplicity.
They were not simple. The Opposition knew they would have to be amended. Certainly, these latest changes cannot be considered simple. Senator Baume, in debate on the 1978 changes, said:

If we are ever to get some incentive into the health insurance system it is essential that community rating be done away with and that experience rating or individual rating be adopted. I welcome the opportunity to do so.

So at that time Senator Baume had given up his previous support for community rating in favour of the 1978 changes, which he said got rid of it. This year Mr MacKellar in the second reading speech on the Health Acts Amendment Bill said about this policy:
. . . recognises the importance of the community rating principle for a viable health insurance industry.

I will be interested to hear Senator Baume explain to us how anything in this legislation resembles anything like a community rating principle in the provision of health care. As I said, this legislation introduces the fifth Fraser health scheme in as many years. It provides for incentives for private health insurance programs in private hospitals such as these organisations never dreamed of before. By its nature it will force people into contributing to private health insurance on a flat rate basis, with no concern for ability to pay. It provides for a system for the provision of health care for the disadvantaged which is narrow in its definition and restrictive in its operation. Administrative costs will increase, bureaucratic complexity will increase, and inevitably many will be at a disadvantage and suffer a demeaning means test under this system.

The idea of a simple universal system of health care funded on the basis of ability to pay, side by side with a private health system, has been thrown overboard. I suggest that this is the creation not of health care experts or of humanitarians but of economic theorists and venal health fund executives, who have conned a Minister and a Cabinet obssessed with the theories of Milton Friedman and Ayn Rand. As a side effect of this legislation, some women needing terminations of pregnancy will be bereft of all Government assistance, despite their payment of taxes. In fact, the way is open for funds to introduce very selective health cover and I will deal more with that later.

I will explain now how this legislation will work. Firstly, through clause 8 of the Bill, apart from the rigidly defined group of disadvantaged people provided for in this legislation, only those who are in private health funds will receive the Government medical benefit. Only this group will receive 30 per cent of the schedule fee. Only they will receive the benefit of a maximum gap payment of $10 per service. Despite paying taxes, despite being citizens of this country, those people who do not join a private company will receive no share of their contributions to general revenue. What an enormous benefit this is to the Government's friends. What an enormous pay-off it is for past assistance. What an extraordinary purpose it is for legislation in this country to put a severe and direct financial penalty on those who will not or do not deal with private health funds. Add this to the removal of accessible and non-means tested public beds and we have a complete destruction of the concept of a universal health scheme. The Opposition deplores this, as I suggest should all reasonable people.

Secondly, the Bill defines the categories of people who will be treated as disadvantaged. At the same time, it removes completely any discretionary ability of a doctor to treat a patient as disadvantaged and accept a lower fee. I was critical, as was the Opposition, of the previous scheme which, apart from the case of pensioners and other beneficiaries in this community, left discretion completely to the doctor. We sought some definition so that there would be a clear right to be treated in this way. We did not seek so narrow a definition as to leave any compassionate or thoughtful doctor with no way to treat deserving cases outside these guidelines as disadvantaged other than to charge them nothing. This is a complete reversal by a party which 12 months ago assured us that the only reasonable way to judge whether a person was disadvantaged was, in fact, to leave it to the doctor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—The Government said that. Of course, under the present system existing pensioners will get their cover. As every honourable senator knows, pensioners live in fear and dread of losing their health benefit cover. But when they do under the present system they can at least use the public hospital beds and, if necessary, go to the out-patients department or their doctor can treat them as disadvantaged. All that will go. They will now be faced with paying $5 or $6 a week for insurance for a single person or $10 or $11 a week for insurance for a family. They will be up for other increased health charges. Everyone in this place is aware of the fear that exists in the minds of the pensioners who receive small superannuation payments or other incomes. How much more fear will be there now? What sort of burden will be placed on them, and on the chronically and recurrently ill aged in this community? The safety net of free hospital care-the altruistic doctor for the pensioners, up to 100,000, just over the fringe benefit level-is gone and we are left with the very hard landing of increased costs and worry.

SPEECH.PARA: The disadvantaged are defined by the Government in this legislation as migrants and refugees in the first six months, pensioners and social security beneficiaries under the fringe benefit level and what may be described as the working poor. In this legislation there is no reference to the chronically ill. There is no reference to those who have frequent illnesses and difficulties. The fee paid to the doctors for treating these people will be increased from 75 per cent to 85 per cent of the schedule fee. At the same time the Government estimates, as it said in a reply to my colleague in another place, Dr Klugman, that in fact the present system will save some $9m. I believe this is the real reason for this measure. In the Government's view, doctors have been too generous in treating the disadvantaged. Anyone who knows the situation will know that there are in this community large numbers of disadvantaged and worthy people who are unable to be treated as disadvantaged because some doctors do not do so.

What is of greater concern in this definition is the administrative nightmare which is introduced by these rigid requirements of definition of disadvantaged and disadvantaged people who are not working. It is estimated that there will be some 800,000 potential applicants and they will need to be assessed twice a year at least. That many new files will need to be established in the Department of Social Security, with all that that involves in manpower and bureaucratic complexity. If, as will often occur, people do not apply before they need hospitalisation or other treatment there will be the extra administrative burden at the point of service, be it in the surgery or the hospital. The Department of Social Security is well aware of these problems. In instructions that have gone out to officers of the Department of Social Security it is obvious that the Department is quite aware of what has happened. These instructions state:
Media coverage of the new health arrangements as they affect pensioners beneficiaries can be expected to cause a flow of enquiries from people unsure of their position.
The new scheme comes into effect from 1 September 1981.

. . . In the meantime, however, the following information may be useful, particularly in respect of the around 340,000 pensioners, supporting parent beneficiaries and sickness beneficiaries who are not eligible for a pensioner health benefits card.
So, the Department is immediately anticipating 340,000 people from this group in the community. It goes on to say later:

All people over 70 are entitled to an age pension irrespective of income. Many people over 70 do not test their eligibility for a PHB card because they claim the pension at the basic rate and do not disclose details of any income they may have-while many may have incomes over the PHB limits or may prefer to take out or continue private health insurance cover, others may now wish to test theit PHB eligibility.

Not only is eligibility being tested but also the ability of the social security system. We are told that claim forms will be available from the Department of Social Security and post offices after 3 August. A large number of people who previously have not had much contact with the Department of Social Security will come into this category. The old subsidised health benefits scheme-the first legislation to be removed by this Government when it came to power in 1975-was a similar scheme. It failed. There was only a 30 per cent take up. This scheme may well fail for the same reason. We have had penalties introduced into this legislation and we will have bad debts for hospitals because of people who thought they were covered but found they were not.

A further problem arises because of the sudden death cut-off point of the means test in this case. The family with two children earning $199 a week will receive cover as disadvantaged. On $201 a week the family faces $12 a week insurance costs. To anyone's way of thinking, this is grossly unfair. This is the inequity faced in Senator Mason's proposed amendment to this legislation. The Opposition will support his amendment as a second best alternative, but we believe that a solution within the bounds of administrative possibility will not be found by the committee of inquiry that he has suggested should investigate this matter. The only solution is a universal, progressively funded scheme, and we believe that the committee proposed by Senator Mason's amendment can reveal only inequity, injustice and complexity beyond belief. The whole concept of this sort of disadvantaged provision introduces unnecessary complexity and categorisation which in fact will stigmatise those who are so categorised. It smacks of the nineteenth century concept of charity in an area where such a concept is unnecessary. It should not occur in a modern society.

As I said initially, a fair and equitable health system should provide universal cover, be easily understood and be funded on the basis of the ability to pay. It should be an economic operation. This system will be complex, will not provide universal cover and will be funded largely by a flat rate system unrelated to the ability to pay. The cost burden will fall far too much on the frequent users-the chronically ill. It provides no hope for economic restraint. In fact, the fault inherent in the fee-for-service system will be increased with the forcing of people into private health funds and into private health care. It contains injustices at the cut-off point for the disadvantaged which we believe are beyond repair. We will go back to this matter in the Committee stage.

I wish to mention one section of the Bill which is causing some concern. I believe it concerns people on both sides of this House. I refer to the clauses which amend section 73F of the parent Act. This provision allowed a health fund to obtain an exemption for services by applying to the Minister for Health. In fact, it applies to the termination of pregnancy, or abortion, and has been used by two general health funds to avoid paying a benefit. It is argued that one should allow such funds to do this when such treatment is carried out on religious or conscientious grounds. It was of little significance when there was an alternative and such patients had recourse to public hospital treatment, to which they had contributed through their taxes, therefore receiving a government benefit. As has been pointed out by members on both sides of the other place, under this legislation people who join one of the health funds applying this exemption will be considered as uninsured. Not only will they not receive a benefit from the health fund, but also they will not receive a Government benefit. They will have no fall-back position and in many cases they will not be able to go into a public ward because of the means test. Certainly, there is a provision that the organisation should advertise what it is doing. In some cases an adult age dependant of a contributor may not agree with the contributor's views. Faced with circumstances which he or she had not thought of previously, a contributor may have a change of mind.

I suggest that it is one thing for the Government to allow a fund to have in the legislation this restrictive clause and it is another thing to allow the fund to inflict its judgment on the Government and for the Government then to refuse to pay its contribution. The Opposition opposes this provision both for its direct and potential effect on the patients who may be concerned. The legislation does not state clearly what it is about. It allows for further and wider exemptions when quite clearly the exemption was intended to apply only to abortion. The situation, we suggest, should not exist where the disbursement of Government funds depends on the moral judgment of any such organisation. At the very least the legislation should make clear what the Government intends to be accepted as an exemption and the Government should pay its contribution to all unfortunate people who may fall into these circumstances. I believe, in the absence of an alternative public health system, the Government must consider whether such an exemption should exist at all. If organisations which claim that they are providing universal health cover introduce restrictions such as this one, they will be providing the sort of optional health cover to which the Government, in another part of the legislation, says that it objects. The legislation in its present form, as far as we see it, is unamendable in this regard. That situation arises because the Government has got away from the principle of universality and from providing to the ordinary taxpayers of this country the right of access to health care to which they have contributed. The difficulty has arisen because of that basic fault in the legislation. If the Government persists with this sort of legislation it really must consider whether it will allow this sort of exemption in the future. As I have said, there is a perfectly good argument for such an exemption under a different health system.

The Opposition will be opposing many of the clauses of the Bill in the Committee stage. We do not believe that this legislation is amendable in any way to provide a fair and decent health system. We have some sympathy with Senator Mason who wishes to improve this health system by introducing some sort of sliding scale means test. We have no objection to a committee looking into that matter but we believe the complexities of the system will be such that the only answer the Committee will be able to come up with is that what we need is a universal system. For these reasons and for the other reasons that we will advance in the Committee stage, I move:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Bill be withdrawn and re-drafted-

(1) to enable those sections of the Bill dealing with the Isolated Patients Allowance, Pathology Services, Nursing Homes Assistance and Therapeutic Goods to be separately introduced and separately debated;
(2) to delete all provisions dealing with the Government's health insurance changes; and
(3) to provide for a health cover system for Australians which will-
(a) guarantee universal cover, rather than the uncertain cover provided in the present Bill,
(b) provide a simple system rather than the complexity of the present Bill,
(c) remove the necessity for the categorisation of the disadvantaged, so prominent a feature of the present Bill,
(d) establish equity through income-related payments rather than the flat rate regressive insurance contribution of the present Bill, and
(e) contain costs by effective constraints on the providers of health services, neglected by the concentration on inappropriate and ineffectual restraints on patient usage in the present Bill'.
I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps listeners to the debate could be excused for being disappointed if they had hoped to glean anything of the Health Acts Amendment Bill from listening to Senator Grimes tonight. They heard for about 10 minutes how greedy the health funds were. I believe that people are basically very happy with the way their funds have looked after them over the years. Listeners to the debate then heard Senator Grimes's socialist philosophy for the next 10 minutes. In the last few minutes of his speech he went over the whole thing again. He has given us little information of the actual workings of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Senate will be aware, last year the Government set up an investigation into the hospital system. This was the result of the tremendous increase in hospital and health costs generally which has occurred over the last five years. In 1974-75 the cost of health care to the Commonwealth Government was $1,283m. Then the Labor Party brought in Medibank. In just one year that cost doubled. The following year the cost was $2,953m. The majority of people were still paying for private health insurance, yet the cost to the Commonwealth Government-the cost to the taxpayer-doubled in one year. It was in the light of this increase and the increases that have occurred since then that the Commonwealth Government decided there should be an inquiry into the hospital sphere. It was in this area of health care that the greatest expense had occurred.

The Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals came out with a very clear report in which it said that there was waste, inefficiency and unnecessary duplication of costly equipment in public hospitals. The reason that Jamison report gave was that nobody had responsibility for health care. Funding was divided. While anyone pays only half of a bill he will not really care about cost efficiency. He will not really care about those few extra dollars on the bill because he is paying only half. The Jamison report made it very clear that the major reason for this escalation in cost was that the shared responsibility between the Commonwealth and the States made it no one's direct responsibility. The recommendation from the Jamison report was that the States should bear their constitutional responsibilities and look after hospitals. Let us not forget that even if the Commonwealth wanted to take over the States' hospitals it could not do so. Constitutionally, the States must bear the responsibility for their hospitals. I will deal with the Bill in two separate areas-the hospital area and the medical area. Firstly, I will deal with the hospital area. Senator Grimes is correct in saying that we on this side of the House believe that private hospitals play a very important part in this country. They are able to care for people at a much cheaper rate than the big public hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—Senator Melzer would know that that is true as she is a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. She would know only too well that the cost of a bed per head is far, far cheaper in private hospitals than it is in public hospitals. This is quite justified.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was saying that it is cheaper in a private hospital and rightly so because the big public hospitals have very expensive treatments and intensive care units. They teach medical students and this adds to costs. The Government is well aware that the private hospitals play a very important part in the health care of this country. Consequently it has decided to raise the Commonwealth benefit for the cost of a bed per day in private hospitals. This will apply to surgical beds only. The benefit will be raised to $28 a day while medical beds and obstetric beds will stay $16 a day. According to the definition in the Bill, surgical procedure means a service which is a prescribed item. The regulations will deal with that in more detail. Surgical beds are described as any surgical item that has a doctor fee of about $100.

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to public hospitals. As I have said, their responsibility is seen as a State responsibility. The Commonwealth's agreements with the majority of States fall due this year, and that is why we have undertaken this big change at this time. All States except Tasmania and South Australia-the agreements with them fall due in 1985-are working under this new arrangement. For the year 1981-82, the Commonwealth grant will be the same as it was this year, plus 10 per cent inflation, minus 60 per cent of what the Commonwealth estimates that a State can raise in revenue. The Commonwealth is also looking after about 3 million people whom it has classed as disadvantaged. There will be a review at the end of this year when the States can put their case if they feel that this arrangement has not worked as they believe it should. As far as Tasmania is concerned, I believe it has the best of both worlds. The Minister of Health in Tasmania has decided to charge patients in public hospitals in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has not much choice.

—He had the option because Tasmania's agreement with the Commonwealth does not end until 1985. So it was completely up to the Minister of Health whether he abided by the present system or encompassed the new system. He decided-I believe rightly-that he could have the best of both worlds for that period. So he has accepted the system by which Tasmania will get the same grant in 1981-82 as it received this year, plus 10 per cent inflation, minus only 50 per cent of what that State decides-not what the Commonwealth decides-it can raise in revenue. There is also the fact that the Commonwealth is looking after that area of disadvantaged people. So my State is particularly lucky.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes spoke very disparagingly about the fact that our Government decided to extend the area of disadvantaged in such an enormous way. I believe it is quite a breakthrough. For the first time the Commonwealth Government has decided to look at families' incomes in relation to the number of children that they have. I will go through the various classifications of disadvantaged because clearly Senator Grimes seemed to keep away from this area. He spoke of it in a disparaging way but did not give any information about the groupings of these people. Pensioners who are already holding the pensioner medical card will experience no change. They will remain as they are. Refugees and migrants, for the first six months after their arrival in this country, will require no means test but will be classed as disadvantaged. They will be informed of this on entry so there will be no problems there. Any person receiving any part of the unemployment benefit will be automatically eligible. He will not have to apply. He will be automatically issued with a card or he may be entitled to use the unemployment benefit cheque butt. This has yet to be decided. He will be automatically included in this group. Those on special benefits will also be included in this group.

Outside these social welfare areas another group that could be considered disadvantaged are married couples whose income is $160 per week plus $20 for each child. That can be quite a considerable amount if one has a large family. A married couple with four children can earn up to $240 a week. If they have seven children they can earn up to $300 a week and still be classed as disadvantaged and still receive free health and medical care. The income for a single person is $96 a week, but the income of a single mother with a child is $160 a week, the same as that of a married couple. A single mother with two children will receive $160, plus $20 for that extra child. As I said, this gives these people free hospitalisation and free bulk billing of any medical costs. Doctors will receive 85 per cent of the schedule fee. This takes in about three million people.

The rest of the Australian community is expected to cover itself by insurance. Senator Grimes said that this was not a universal scheme. I say that it is a universal scheme. As a matter of fact it is far more universal than I believe the scheme has been in the past because the Government has said that there should be two tables only, the basic table and the ancillary table. Everyone who is covered by the basic table gets medical benefits, that is, the assistance subsidy from the Government of 30 per cent of the medical schedule fee.

This scheme comes into force on 1 September. Because the Government has decided that there will be no waiting period between 1 September and 31 October, people will have plenty of time to cover themselves. Anyone who is a pensioner or who is classed as disadvantaged will have no waiting period-if they fall outside that eligiblity they can join a fund immediately. Indeed, anyone classed as disadvantaged does not have to have his health card before he can receive a medical service. He can go along and receive some medical service and then apply for his disadvantaged eligiblity and be able to receive his card up to 13 weeks after that service. The Commonwealth medical benefit payable to those people who are insured is 30 per cent of the fee for any item of the medical benefits schedule. Any fund-Senator Grimes seemed to concentrate on this aspect of the legislation-that seeks the permission of the Minister not to have to pay benefits for certain items on the schedule will be entitled to do so as long as the Minister agrees. The funds will be excluded from having to pay benefits for those items but in this respect the advertisements must be extremely clear. The people must be made aware. If a fund has decided to cut out benefits, for instance, for cosmetic surgery, this must be clearly put in the advertisements.

The main concern seems to be about a couple of funds-and this is not new; this has been going on for some time-that have decided for religious reasons to drop payments in respect of abortion. As Senator Grimes has complained bitterly about this I feel it probably needs some explanation. In this country we have a freedom of choice on religion. I believe this is something of which every Australian is proud. We do not have any restrictions in this respect. If people believe according to their religion that abortion is murder-a considerable number of Australians do-they are entitled, I believe, to pay their contributions to a fund which does not provide cover for abortion, something which they vehemently oppose.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the other contributors are entitled to know.

—As Senator Melzer has said, they must know. The legislation points out very clearly that advertisements on this aspect must be clearly spelled out. I have undertaken that if any information is brought to my notice which indicates that the position is not clearly spelled out I will be only too happy to take the matter to the Minister who will insist upon this being done. Senator Grimes spoke about the distribution of Commonwealth medical benefits, which is the reponsibility of the funds. People who claim abortion expenses from funds with such a policy would not get either the fund benefit or the Commonwealth benefit. As I have said, this is a choice. Contributors may not believe in abortion, they may not want their contributions to go towards abortions, they may not want their taxes to go towards abortions. This Commonwealth benefit is a small area in which their taxes can be seen as not going towards this item. I believe that has been clearly spelled out in this Bill. I have no problem with that. I believe in this country, where we have freedom of religion, this is the least we can do to fulfil the desires of those people who hold this belief.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government-Senator Grimes certainly left out this aspect too, as is his wont-has introduced a rebate system. We have gone back to the system of giving people some incentive to insure. The Government has decided that the rebate should be 32c in the dollar for basic table insurance. Nobody can say that those people who can afford to pay for the ancillary services which are provided by a private hospital will get any extra tax benefit from this provision. They will not. Everyone will get exactly the same rebate of 32c in the dollar for basic table insurance.

There seems to have been some confusion about entitlement to the rebate depending on when insurance contributions are paid. There have been some confusing articles published recently in the Canberra Times. If I may put the position pretty clearly, anyone who pays his contributions-whether they be half yearly, yearly or monthly-will be entitled to the rebate. People are concerned that they will not get the rebate. If I pay my contribution now, in June, and I make another yearly payment next June, I will be entitled to a rebate because the payment has been made in the one financial year. The position is exactly the same as if I pay my contributions in September. So there is no need for concern on this aspect. I believe that people have been going along to the funds and saying: 'I will pay my contributions for only the next couple of weeks because unless I pay my yearly amount after 1 July I will not get my rebate'. That is not the case. So long as people pay their contributions within the one financial year, no matter in what month the payment is made, they will be entitled to a rebate at the end of that financial year.

The Commonwealth has decided that it will take full responsibility for the payment of nursing home benefits. I believe this is an extremely good idea mainly because people who go into nursing homes are not really insurable. The system is such that there is some benefit from being insured but these people are not really insurable. The Government has decided to provide insurance for these patients by taking over full responsibility for their payments. This will make the contributions by the funds much lower than if they had to foot the bill.

The philosophy of this Government is that the taxpayer should pay for essentials and that people should pay what they can afford to contribute towards their health services. Taxpayers should pay also for those who cannot afford to look after themselves. Technology has given us the opportunity to enjoy perfect health care. It could be said that the best health care for a pregnant woman would be for her to have a scan every time she visits her doctor. Many doctors say that this is excessive and that women should have a scan once or twice during their pregnancy but certainly not on each visit to the doctor. However, it could be argued that, if a scan was done on each visit to the doctor, some abnormality could be picked up at an earlier stage. We could talk about all the new technology under the sun and we could come up with a health system that would cost the earth and that the taxpayer would never willingly take on. A judgment has to be made about the sort of health care that we want and the sorts of costs that that health care would entail. The costs of this health care could be excessive, extreme, or the ultimate but is the taxpayer prepared to pay for it? I am sure that every honourable senator in this place has had representations concerning the lowering of taxation. Not one honourable senator has not had people say to him or her: 'We are paying too much tax'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or too much to the doctors.
—Senator Melzer is back on her old theme. We come back to the same basic proposition--
—We pay too much money to the doctors.

—We discussed this earlier tonight, Senator Melzer, and I said at that time how much I will miss you chipping in at every opportunity. Frankly, I will miss it tremendously and I do not know what I will do when you are gone.
—I will arrange a stand-in.

—The stand-in would have to be well briefed. I return to the costs of health care to the taxpayer. These are the costs that we have to bear. This is what we have to take into consideration. If the introduction of Medibank by the Opposition doubled health costs to the taxpayer in one year-the majority of people were paying private health insurance at the same time-surely we have to understand that this cannot go on? If the Jamison report says that, if no one is responsible for hospital costs, inefficiency, waste and duplication will take place, this is a problem that has to be cured. We can produce the best possible health care in this country but it will be at a cost. The Government has noted that the taxpayers have said that there is a limit to what they are prepared to pay for health care. That limit has been defined by the Government. It has said that if the majority of people can afford to pay for their own health costs through insurance, they should do so, and that the taxpayer will only look after those who are the real needy, that is, those who cannot afford to look after their health. That is the philosophy of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Acts Amendment Bill is a very important one indeed for the Australian people since it brings into being virtually a whole new ball game in the area of health care with the demolition of the Medibank concept and its replacement by the concept that people should pay for their own costs. The Australian Democrats have seen a rather tragic dichotomy between the view of the Australian Labor Party and the Government over this matter because we see problems on either side. It is true that the Australian community cannot go on indefinitely bearing the enormous costs of health care, yet at the same time it is very important, if one is to deviate from that point of view and say that people are to pay for themselves, to be absolutely certain that one will not place large and unprotected sections of society at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have done a little homework on this matter. We are absolutely convinced that the Bill as it stands will put hundreds of thousands of Australians at risk-not only Australians of whom it might be said that they can look after themselves but also those who cannot and whose interests and needs we as a society should be watching more than anything else. I refer to the next generation, the children of this nation, who are in no position to guard themselves but who face the world and its problems, including illness and injury, only by virtue of the extent to which their parents can afford to help them to see that they are provided with medical attention when they need it or, failing that, that the State does in some way. I suggest that here lies the dilemma which we should be considering at this time. This is the reason why the Australian Democrats are taking the action in this debate which we are taking.

Of course, this Bill ought not to be passed in the Senate at this time in any case. It should be given much more mature consideration for a number of reasons, not the least being that last October the Australian people elected a new Senate, and their intention then was expressed clearly. Their intention, which was expressed as I said last October, removed the control of the Senate from the Government. Due to the provisions of the Constitution which say that a new Senate will not be constituted until 30 June after an election, the new Senate in fact will not assemble in this place until the Budget session-the next session of Parliament-begins on 18 August. The Australian Democrats find it intolerable that the Government should use this procedure on the last sitting day of the Senate to force through a Bill of tremendous importance and significance to so many Australians. The Government has no moral right to push through this legislation, and it knows it full well. It is legislating, in any moral terms at all, against the will of the Australian people as expressed at an election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute nonsense!

—Senator Baume says that it is absolute nonsense. Does he deny that the Australian people voted in October last to remove control of the Senate from the Government? I would like Senator Baume's reply to that, but I find no interjection when he is put on the spot. He is silent on that matter. I am not surprised because he knows that what I say is not nonsense but the truth. The Australian people also know it is the truth and they will hold him to account for the underhand way in which he has been pushing legislation through this place. He knows he has to do it before that mandate can be expressed. He is hiding behind an antiquated constitution to go against the will of the people.
—Absolute humbug!
—I ask the question again since Senator Baume raises it: Is it or is it not a fact that in October last the Australian people voted to remove control of the Senate from the Government? Yes or no?
—You know what the election result was. You know that it does not take effect until June. If you want to propose a referendum to change it, say so.

—When was the will of the people expressed, Senator Baume? Last October! Senator Baume knows that only too well. He can wriggle on the pin but there is no way he can escape that point. The first point about this Bill is that it should not be here in the first place. The Australian Democrats recognise that the Bill will be passed by the Senate simply because the Government has, for the moment, the numbers to get it through legally if not morally. Of course, it is absolutely immoral. However, it will be a fact of real life. Following on from that, the Australian Democrats concern is to see that this new system of financing health care will not create too many victims within the Australian community. It is for that reason that I shall move a motion following the second reading of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the problem? It is basically the heavy burden the costs of health insurance will place on families which are just above the levels of income that would permit them free health care on the grounds of being disadvantaged. I felt a tremendous sense of irony and unreality when Senator Walters pointed out that the exempt level for a family with seven children would be the princely sum of $340 a week. I wonder whether she feels she would be in a position with a husband to bring up seven children on such an income. I wonder whether she would consider that an adequate income from which to pay medical expenses as well as everything else that is involved with bringing up a family. I was amazed and appalled to hear her stand up in this place and actually say that the people are adequately provided for. An average family consisting of a young married couple with two young children is allowed to earn the princely sum of $200 a week. If it earns any more it would not be regarded as disadvantaged and would have to meet the total cost of health insurance. I would have thought that $200 is not very much with which to bring up, properly house and look after four people.

I am especially concerned about and I have a special anxiety for the tens of thousands and possibly hundreds of thousands of people in that category who live in my home city of Sydney. My reason is, of course, that rents in Sydney are so high. They are higher than rents in any other parts of Australia and very much higher than most other parts of Australia-to the extent that an unfurnished unit that would minimally house a family of four costs from $60 to $90 a week. Rents are actually rising. When I say that such accommodation would minimally house people, I should point out that children would not have separate bedrooms. The family would be living in a two-bedroom unit which would not be too close to the centre of Sydney. Rents for a two-bedroom apartment in central Sydney are now up to $130 to $150 a week. The payment of $12 to $15 by such a family for medical insurance will create severe, not just minimal, pressures and hardships. Families will not have to do without only some things. I believe that in some situations families will have to decide whether to insure against the contingency of illness or else cut back on food. I think we have reached the disgraceful stage where the Government cannot see this problem. The Government is going to impose that hardship not on a few people in this country, not on people who perhaps we could say should have been more provident but on young married couples with young children who have married with good hopes and intentions for the future. In many cases the wife is looking after her children and cannot work. Those are the kinds of people who will be the victims of what the Government is doing. It is not sufficient for the Government to say that it is going to victimise people who do not have children; it is also going to victimise children. Children will be victims from the moment they are born.

I think that states part of the problem quite fairly. I would like to raise another matter which reveals just how absurd and poorly thought out this legislation is. We have the absurd situation that a man with two children earning $205 a week-I must say that Senator Walters did not say that the incomes she quoted are before tax; they are gross incomes-will be worse off financially than a man who earns $199 a week. The man on $205 a week is worse off even after existing tax concessions because he has to pay medical insurance whereas the man on $199 a week is classified as disadvantaged and pays no medical insurance. So we have this unjust and anomalous situation which I suggest will affect many people. The man on $205 a week would probably be better off from 1 September going to his boss and saying: 'Please, sir, reduce my salary'. I commend that idea. If this mad hatter legislation goes through I suggest to anybody in that position that that is probably the best thing to do. If people sit down and do their arithmetic for a few minutes they will see that it would be well worth their while to follow that course of action.

The subsidy plan that the Australian Democrats envisage would at least remedy that situation. We do not want to be hard and fast about how this plan should be implemented. That is why we suggest that this matter should be referred to a committee which we recognise would have more wisdom and experience than we have. We are merely posing this problem and suggesting a possible way of overcoming it. We say that there should be a subsidy plan which operates on a sliding scale covering people, say, up to $100 per week better off than the present cut-off figure. We think that not unreasonable. With an income of $200 to $300 a week, a family with two children is still pretty much up against it, and we believe they need assistance. The greatest assistance should obviously go to the ones who are poorest, at the bottom of that range. We believe it is desirable that a family with two children should pay perhaps $2 a week for health insurance if its income is $210, and that a family on $290 per week, on the other hand, should attract only a $2 subsidy. We have done some costing on this, within our resources. We estimate the average cost per subsidy to the Government to be some $5.50 a week on what it would appear at this stage that medical insurance will cost. We estimate that between 550,000 and 600,000 families would be affected, and we suggest it would cost the Government about $180m in a full year. However, as the Government would otherwise be returning one-third of this amount to the taxpayer in any case, since medical insurance is tax deductible, the actual cost to the Government would be closer to $120m, and indeed should be less than that, for reasons I will detail in a moment.

What would we get for $100m? Literally hundreds of thousands of the young people of this country would not be in a situation in which their families had to take a desperate gamble, and it would be that. No parents want to be in a position where they cannot take their children to a doctor. But unless the Government accepts this measure, or something like it, it will force them into a position where they will have to say: 'We cannot afford it. We cannot afford to get out of this flat'-or whatever they have-'Where do we live otherwise? The children have to have shoes, they have to be decently clad. What about those things?' I suggest that any honourable senators who believe that that sort of dilemma will not happen have never tried-let them be honest with themselves-in today's society and today's cost structure to look after a young wife and bring up two young children on $200 a week, from which tax is deducted, of course. If honourable senators consult their consciences on that, I think they will realise that what I am saying is true. It is particularly true of our major cities, where the bulk of our population lives, because of the high costs involved-not only the high cost of rent but also the high cost of transport. The breadwinner in that place has a very high charge coming out of that same $200 per week, on which he has probably already paid out $70 in rent, for his transport to and from work, and he has to be decently clad for his work. It is not a matter then of these people simply giving up luxuries to pay health insurance. They will be compromising with necessity, and that is something that no government has any right to ask of its people.

We believe that health funds ought to be able to reduce their costs in the future. We have a number of areas of policy in this regard which we hope they will look at and do something about. It is insane and ought to be illegal for health funds to spend lavish sums of money on advertising, turning out lavishly coloured printed brochures, putting advertisements in newspapers and so on, and having expensive secretariat and offices in expensive buildings. If they do that, they are merely adding elements to the cost of health care which ought to be there, and that also is something which needs to be said. Any Australian who picks up a beautiful and attractively printed brochure from a health fund should bear in mind that he, the average Australian, is paying through the nose for it and that it is being added to the cost of looking after his children in a hospital, and so on. We believe it is contemptible that the Government should be supporting and continuing to support organisations which it has told us will solve the problem of health care for us, and allowing them to go on with that kind of wasteful practice. There should be the strictest type of audit over the costs incurred by health funds. As the Government has said, those organisations have enormous power. We have given to them the means of life and death virtually over our people, over whether or not they can afford to go to a doctor. Therefore those organisations should reasonably be subject to the most extreme strictures and should be compelled by law to bear their responsibility to society.

As I have said before, and I now say it again, the Australian Democrats believe in private enterprise; but we believe in enlightened private enterprise, one which sees its obligation to society first and regards its obligation to make money as secondary. Organisations such as the health funds which have now received a mandate from the Government to carry out essential services for society should be even more closely scrutinised than other organisations to see that they meet their responsibilities. I trust that they will do so. If the funds do reduce their costs by eliminating some of the wasteful practices I have mentioned it would be possible to reduce the cost of the subsidy and the total cost to society would be lower. It is in the hands of the Government itself to insist that that area of costs be reduced and that subsidy brought back to an even smaller amount than the $120m I have mentioned. I am not saying that there would be huge savings, but perhaps we could get the figure down to $100m. An amount of $20m is an appreciable sum of money in anybody's terms. I believe that it could be saved.

We are worried that if this is not done our children will be at risk because their parents simply cannot afford to take out insurance. We think that the Commonwealth-this is a matter that a committee could look at-should pay that subsidy direct to the funds. That would follow the principle already established by the Commonwealth agreement to guarantee health care to the aged and chronically ill. The Australian Democrats cannot see any real difference between that area and the area which I have been talking about. It is possible that there could be even more flexibility. The Australian Council of Social Service, with which I was talking today in Sydney, mentioned some points to me that are worth putting forward to the Senate at this stage. The Council says that essential commitments, such as mortgage or rent and the cost of running a car if needed for work, should also be taken into account when assessing eligibility for government assistance, as is the case with eligibility for legal aid. Otherwise, as ACOSS says and as I said earlier in the debate, people will have to decide whether to take out health insurance, lose their homes or keep their homes and possibly go bankrupt if a major health crisis occurs in the family.

The final point made to me by ACOSS was that ill health in itself causes poverty. A person suffering from a severe chronic illness cannot work in a full time occupation. Here we have a catch-22 situation. People who are ill and who are perhaps just struggling along-we could look at a case where there have been two breadwinners in the family and they have two children but one of them is sick-are placed in the situation, at its worst. This ought to be squarely faced. Because of certain matters, the only mechanism that I can adopt to put an idea to the Senate is to foreshadow that after the second reading of this Bill I shall move pursuant to Standing Order 196A:

That the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare for inquiry, with particular reference to the provision of a sliding scale of subsidies for health insurance which would apply to families earning more than the aggregate amounts at which they would qualify for free health care as disadvantaged persons, and report by the first sitting day in August 1981.

The Australian Democrats suggest that this is the last chance for the Senate to take a second look at this area of gross and mass hardship which is about to be inflicted on the Australian people by this Bill. The Senate should try to do something about it. We should at least take another look at it in order to do something ourselves before the scheme commences on 1 September. I commend that thought to honourable senators. I ask them to give it the most earnest consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think Senator Walters will support you?

—I do indeed. I believe Senator Walters to be a person of great humanity. I think that perhaps she does not realise quite what is going on. I have the greatest confidence in Senator Walters. If she consults her own integrity and conscience, I am sure that she will cross the floor and vote with us on this matter. Otherwise I would suggest to her that she might find it very hard to live with her conscience when she considers some of the things I have said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the Health Acts Amendment Bill 1981. It is an absolute disgrace to bring forward such an important piece of legislation so late in the parliamentary session. In fact, the rush of legislation which has faced this chamber over the past couple of weeks shows the ineptitude of the present Government. If the Government cannot manage its legislative program any better than it has done over the past two weeks it is hard to understand how it thinks it can run the country. When this current session commenced we waited for weeks for legislation to come forward for debate. In the last three-week bracket of sitting days we have been assaulted with legislation as the Government panics, knowing that it will lose its majority in this place at the end of this month. As Senator Mason so eloquently put, it is determined to use the numbers given to it by the senators who were rejected by the electors in October last year but who, by a quirk of the Australian Constitution, remain here until the end of the month.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the late introduction of this legislation in some ways comes as no surprise. The behaviour of the Government in the first half of this year has been marked by its indecision and by its inability to agree within itself on possible legislation to bring before the Parliament. Although the late arrival of the Health Acts Amendment Bill 1981 comes as no surprise, that does not make the Government's tardiness in any way indefensible. This is the type of legislation that should have been placed before the Parliament in the first or second week of this session. The Parliament should have been given ample time to examine the legislation and the public also should have been given an opportunity to offer its opinion on these changes to Australia's health system. That, of course, would not happen with this Government. It has the simplistic idea that what it thinks is good for the Australian people must be good for the Australian people. But sadly this assumption is so often incorrect.

In discussing the Health Acts Amendment Bill 1981 it is worth examining this Government's record in health insurance since it came to power in 1975.
