I can well remember the 1975 election campaign as many honourable senators who were candidates can remember it. One of Mr Fraser's catchcries at that election was that he would retain Medibank. Of course he would, in 1975, say that he would retain Medibank. At that stage the Australian people understood what a sound scheme Medibank was. It was simple, it was effective and it was a health scheme which even the medical profession was willing to accept, after having been a bitter opponent in Medibank's developmental stages. Mr Fraser said, indeed he pledged, that he would retain Medibank. What happened? Less than six months after it had been elected in 1975, the Fraser Government announced a number of major changes to Australia's health insurance scheme. Amongst those changes was the imposition of a levy on income for those who wanted to remain in Medibank. It is worth remembering that when in Opposition the same parties blocked the Labor Government's efforts to introduce a Medibank levy.

In the 1976 changes Australians could opt out of Medibank but if they did they were obliged to take out private health insurance. They could not opt out altogether. Health insurance of some type was compulsory. Two years later there were other major changes. In May of 1978 medical benefits were reduced from 85 per cent to 75 per cent of the schedule fee. Bulk billing was abolished. Further modifications were announced in August of the same year. Health insurance was no longer compulsory and a universal Commonwealth benefit of 40 per cent up to a maximum patient contribution of $20 was introduced. That $20 was the maximum patient contribution per medical service where the schedule fee was charged. But this did not last long. In 1979 the 40 per cent medical benefit was replaced by a patient maximum payment of $20 for each medical service. Now we have the provisions of the Health Acts Amendment Bill before us. Since 1975 the Fraser Government has consistently altered the 1975 Medibank system which it has so solemnly promised to maintain. The Bill being debated today removes all vestiges of Labor's Medibank. It replaces Medibank by a giant medimuddle.

I shall outline some of the aspects of this Bill to which my colleagues in the Opposition and I take exception. Before I do so I mention something of the broad aspects of the Bill. At first blush it might be thought that this is a straightforward Bill. The term 'Acts' in the Bill's title, however, suggests that there could be more than meets the eye, and indeed there is. This Bill actually amends four Acts, the Health Insurance Act, the National Health Act, the Nursing Homes Assitance Act and the Therapeutic Goods Act. The fact that the Bill actually amends four Acts supports my earlier argment that it is a disgrace that this Bill should come to the Senate so late in the session and, along with other Bills, be pushed through the Parliament with indecent haste. It must also be remembered that one clause of another Bill relates to the current changes to health insurance, namely, clause 27 of the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill. It is worth mentioning that this introduction of amendments to four Acts was a deliberate ploy. Mr MacKellar let this slip the other day. Last Tuesday, 9 June, on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM Mr MacKellar said, amongst other things:

. . . the Government has made it clear that it's amending about four Acts in this current omnibus bill which is coming before the Parliament. I think it's due to come before the Parliament today. It's taking the opportunity of amending, as I say, these four Bills at the one time to avoid a series of debates over what are in many cases just machinery changes to various Bills.

Mr MacKellar was admitting there that the four amending Bills were put together so that the Government would avoid a series of debates over each one. The basic objection I raise to provisions of the Health Acts Amendment Bill is concerned with amendments to the Health Insurance Act. Certain provisions of this Bill are deliberately designed to force people to take out health insurance. Rather than be open about the matter and actually compel Australians to take out medical or health insurance, a course of action which would appear to be contrary to the expressed philosophy of this Government, the strategy has been, if not to compel, at least strongly to induce most people to take out health insurance. Why is that so? Australians have been leaving health insurance schemes in droves. The Government is rushing to get people back into the health insurance funds. Senator Grimes mentioned that earlier. He outlined the reasons why the Government was so keen to get people back into health insurance funds and what those health insurance funds have done for the present Government.

Even a cursory examination of the figures made available by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveals that Australian people are becoming less and less satisfied with Australia's health insurance mess. From March 1979 to March 1980 the number of Australians who were covered by some form of health insurance fell from 62.4 per cent to 59.4 per cent, a drop of 3 per cent. In each of the six States the downward trend was the same. For some reason that I have not been able to ascertain the trend was reversed in Australia's two Territories. However, the overall message was quite clear-health insurance contributors were expressing their dissatisfaction by opting out. Whilst Australian contributors thought they had the right to opt out, the Government thought otherwise. 'Get them back into the funds', is the message in this Bill.

How does the Government intend to persuade people to take out health insurance? If I may, I refer brieflly to a Bill that is not under discussion. The Government intends to offer a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar for the cost of basic hospital and medical insurance from 1 July. The fact that any personal savings in this area will be offset by the elimination of tax indexation seems not to concern the Government. As well, Commonwealth medical benefits of 30 per cent will be restricted to those who have basic medical cover. I find this provision to be totally objectionable and regard it as almost immoral. Why should any taxpayer who through his or her taxes makes a contribution to Commonwealth revenue not be eligible for a Commonwealth benefit because he or she decides not to join a health fund? As a senator for Queensland, I am even more opposed to such discrimination.

An examination of the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicates that the sunshine State has the lowest health insurance cover of any State. By using the figures I referred to earlier it may be seen that in March 1980, 45.4 per cent of Queenslanders had health insurance. That compares with a high of 66.7 per cent in South Australia. For the purposes of an Australia-wide comparison, however, it should be noted that Queensland's 45.4 per cent compares with an Australian average of 59.4 per cent. Obviously fewer Queenslanders see a need for health insurance than do residents of other States. Naturally the Fraser Government's moves will force more people in Queensland into health insurance, but I expect that Queensland will still retain the distinction of having the lowest rate of health insurance in Australia. What does this mean to Queensland residents? Obviously, many will not receive a Commonwealth medical benefit if they incur a medical expense, whilst their neighbours who have taken out health insurance will receive it. Admittedly, this will occur in all States but the statistics available suggest that it will occur to a higher degree in Queensland than in other States. All this could be offset by the uninsured seeking medical treatment at Queensland's free hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you make an assertion based on statistics which relate to different circumstances. How can you assert that fewer Queenslanders will join?

—I am not quite sure what point the honourable senator is making. I am not asserting that Queensland will not have exactly the same number of people covered by medical insurance as will other States. I am suggesting that because the rate of such insurance has been so low in Queensland it is unlikely to reach the levels in other States.
—In the past circumstances were different.

—They were, but one must remember that in Queensland we still have a free hospital system. It is probably for that reason that the number of insured people has been at a fairly low level. Perhaps not all who were uninsured partook of the free hospital system, but they knew that it would provide a backup system if they had a catastrophic illness or accident. My prediction is that because that free hospital system will remain we will still have a fairly low rate of health insurance. Many people, knowing that if the worse comes to the worst they can use the free hospital system of Queensland, will not take it out.
—What is wrong with that?
—What is wrong with it is that a lot of people--
—Order! I suggest that the senators from Queensland sort out their problem afterwards and allow us to get on with the debate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, as a Queensland senator you would understand that this involves a very important point. Many Queenslanders will not take out health insurance because they know that they can fall back on the free hospital system which still remains. However, many of those who do not will not necessarily use that system for routine medical vistis and might well go to a private medical practitioner. They will know that if they run into really serious trouble they can fall back on the free hospital system. People who have not taken out health insurance and who go to the general practitioner, knowing that they may have to go to the public hospital at some stage, will not receive a Commonwealth medical benefit. My argument is that the percentage of such people will be greater in Queensland than it will in the other States. Only time will tell whether my argument is correct, but it is worth considering and has a basis of validity.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to my discussion of Queensland's free hospital system: The Commonwealth has attempted to close that loophole by making it more difficult for that free system to continue. However, I have no doubt that Queensland will win through. I suggest that, despite the problems for Queensland that might result from this discriminatory type of legislation, people from other States should keep the fare to Queensland handy.

At this stage of the debate I will mention just one other aspect of the Bill. Any previous attempt by the Commonwealth to provide some security to those who decided not to arrange some health benefit cover or who, through a variety of other reasons, did not do so has now vanished. At present Australians are given some protection against catastrophic illness. The $20 maximum patient contribution fee to which I referred earlier however will not apply from 1 September. The uninsured from that date will be liable for all their medical expenses, irrespective of how high those expenses may be. Uninsured patients are now facing the greatest gamble they have been confronted with since the early 1970s. The withdrawal of this benefit, of course, is another element of the Fraser Government's strategy of forcing Australians to take out private health insurance.

I digress here to mention the free hospital system that we have in Queensland. This is probably one of the major benefits that Queenslanders have at the present moment. Probably they will not have the same gamble as do people in other States so that if the worse comes to the worse and they have a major illness or a major accident they can fall back on the free hospital system which has been a feature of Queensland for over 40 years.

This Bill which amends four Acts has 87 clauses, some of which are highly complex. I do not intend to pursue this Bill any further at this stage except to say that at the time of the last election the people of Australia did not expect that the Government would make such radical changes to the health insurance as has been done in this and associated legislation. The Labor Party made its position clear in relation to health policy prior to the last election. Labor leader, Bill Hayden, said amongst other things in his 1980 election policy speech:

A Labor Government is committed to restoring universal health insurance. It cannot be done immediately, but as a first step we announced 11 months ago we will extend free medical care in the next Budget to all expectant mothers and all dependent children.

Clearly, the electors understood what Labor's plans for health were if it were returned to government. They understood that a Labor government would be committed to restoring a universal health insurance scheme. It was pointed out well before the election that Labor realised at that stage that it was not possible to do that in one fell swoop. It did say it would move in that direction by extending free medical care to expectant mothers and to all dependent children. The people of Australia were able to make a choice. They were able to look at that policy outline stated almost 12 months before the election took place and compare it with the policy of the present Government.

Mr Fraser in his policy speech mentioned nothing about health at all. If one read the supplementary statements which accompanied his speech-I wonder how many electors actually read the supplementary statements-a reference to health would have been noted. Even that reference to health in the supplementary statements gave no indication that the current changes to health insurance would be introduced. In short, the Government has no mandate for the changes it has introduced in this current session of the Parliament. It may be 2 1/2 years before we go to the polls again, but the electors will remember this legislation. They will remember that the Fraser Government brought this legislation before the Parliament without having a mandate for it. In my estimation the electors will react accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak just briefly to the Health Acts Amendment Bill tonight to raise one aspect of health insurance which has been raised publicly in the last few days. Some publicity has been given this week to the effects of health funds having the right to opt out of offering insurance for certain items. It has been plain that this has a very particular effect on women who might want to have an abortion and that it removes something that is presently available. I understand from my reading of the Bill and from assurances made by the Minister that this Bill does not, in fact, do that. But it has revealed an aspect that I think has not been realised or recognised by this Parliament in the past, an aspect which was emphasised by one extra factor in the policies put forward by the Government in this Health Acts Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1978 the Parliament passed amendments to health insurance legislation which gave two funds the opportunity to apply to a Minister to have the right not to offer insurance for certain items. That application, subject to approval, applied only to medical benefits. Clause 60 of this Bill extends that right to hospital insurance. It has been suggested that something is being taken away from people that they have now. In fact, nothing is being taken away. What is revealed is a deficiency in the 1978 legislation, reinforced by an additional factor in this legislation. In 1978, when the Bill gave to funds the right to opt out under certain conditions, it was never suggested that the funds would take away from contributors their entitlement to the Commonwealth contribution to health insurance. That is what has happened.

If a fund says to its contributors that it will no longer offer insurance for certain medical items and that is approved by the Minister and all the procedures are gone through, the contributor not only loses access to a fund payment which he may or may not object to, but also he loses access to the Commonwealth payment. I am assured privately that that was not the intention of the Government. I went back to the debates on various health amendments during 1978 and found reference in those debates to something called 'optional deductibles'. This reference arose in the first instance in a speech made by the then Minister for Health to the House of Representatives. The speech was a statement on health policy which preceded the introduction of certain legislation. It was not a speech on the legislation itself. In that speech, referring to optional deductibles, the Minister said:

The rising cost of private health insurance has brought forward a significant number of proposals to the Government for further modification of health insurance arrangements. One suggestion is that people should meet a specified amount of their health costs in each year before becoming eligible for benefits. This concept, known as 'deductibles' is somewhat akin to arrangements to pay an 'excess' in comprehensive motor vehicle insurance. Other suggestions have been that medical services rendered in certain circumstances should not attract benefits-for example, some forms of cosmetic surgery and some terminations of pregnancy. Consequently, the Government has decided that in addition to offering the present standard or basic medical and hospital benefits tables, private health insurance organisations will be permitted to offer optional deductibles in those tables within reasonable limitations to be approved by the Government.

Certain legislation was introduced into the House of Representatives on 6 June 1978 and was debated there on 7 and 8 June. The legislation was introduced subsequently in the Senate and was debated on 9 June. Reference was made in that debate to deductibles but the debate was entirely in terms of this excess motor vehicle insurance type of analogy that people could undertake to pay a certain amount of their own medical costs or gamble on a certain level of medical costs, pay that and be insured only after that. The debate that raged at that time was, of course, that the young and the healthy would not insure or else they would take very low cost insurance with a large gap in excess. The high cost insurance would fall on the elderly and the infirm. The one sentence in the Minister's statement on health in May 1978 relating to certain medical services not attracting benefits was at no stage subsequently in the health debate either on those Bills or subsequent Bills in 1978, picked up. In September 1978 some further amendments to the National Health Bills were brought in by the then Minister. On 28 September, he said:

New section 73F, in clause 14 of the Bill, provides for the Minister, upon application by a medical benefits organisation, to grant an exemption to the organisation from paying out of its basic medical benefits table benefits for specified professional services.

I would have understood from that, and apparently both Houses of Parliament understood from that, that the only payments to a contributor that were affected were those out of the fund's medical benefits table. We have an arrangement with the funds whereby the Commonwealth benefit is actually paid by the fund to a contributor for an item. The fund then applies to the Government for reimbursement of that section of the payment which represents the Commonwealth payment. When we gave to funds the right not to pay benefits for certain medical items we took away the mechanism for paying the Commonwealth benefit for those items. I do not believe that was the intention of the Government and it certainly was not the understanding of Parliament because that issue was at no time addressed by either Government or Opposition members or senators. A couple of assertions were made earlier in the debate this evening in relation to that but I find no evidence in any of the speeches, from either side, of that matter. I believe it was not understood by Parliament that when it gave the opt out provision it was also setting up a situation whereby not only would fund benefits be not paid but also Commonwealth payments would not be paid.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you, and through you to the Minister representing the Minister for Health (Senator Peter Baume), that an undesirable effect of approving the application of a fund, on conscientious grounds or whatever, not to offer certain items in its benefits table is that Commonwealth benefits are taken away. I do not suggest for one minute that this is the Government's motivation but a cynical extension of this situation would be that a government of the future faced with an application by a fund to not pay fund benefits on certain items would see an advantage in approving that application because Commonwealth benefits would thereby be saved. There would be a financial incentive inherent in any such application for the Government to approve it because by the fund opting out the Commonwealth also would opt out. I do not believe that was the Government's intention. There is no indication in the debate that it was understood, much less was it the Government's intention, that that was what should happen. This has been highlighted in this debate because of the provision that in order to be paid Commonwealth benefits in future people must belong to private health funds. That makes the situation just a little different-undesirable as it was previously, although it was a situation that was overlooked or not brought to people's attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an option, then; there was the option that people could go to public hospitals. We understood it, but there is no option now.

—The honourable senator may have understood that but nowhere in all the debates was that ever pointed out to the Parliament. It was never mentioned. All health debate during that year was on the subject of bulk billing, on the subject of whether there should be this excess provision and so on. This present debate has highlighted for everyone that there have been for the last three years people who have belonged to private health funds who have not received Commonwealth benefits for certain procedures if approval had been given to the fund to not pay fund benefits for those procedures. Now the Government is saying that any person who wishes to get the Commonwealth benefit must belong to a private health fund. That takes an element of competition out of the market place for the private health funds. To get the Commonwealth benefit, people must join a private health fund. That puts pressure on people to join a private health fund. That takes away an element of competition. The private health funds will not have to try quite so hard to get contributors. More people will join private health funds. It is possible that in the future with our range of health funds and with the funds not having to compete so hard for contributors, more funds will seek to get opt-out provisions, whatever their reason, and contributors or potential contributors will be faced with a range of choices where there are possibly none.
—They will need approval, will they not, Senator?
—Yes, they will need approval. I am not saying--
—That is a protection, or at least a potential protection.

—Certainly it is a potential protection, but it is possible that no fund will offer benefits for a certain item although the Commonwealth still prefers to pay benefits for that item. It may be Government policy that benefits are payable for the item but there may be no way, through mechanical means, of paying the benefits to people who are insured and who may have become insured in order to get the Commonwealth benefit. It is possible that people will be faced with a range of health funds, each one of which has opted out of paying benefits for selected items. In that situation people may be faced with making a choice as to the best of a bad lot.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot buy our health insurance piecemeal. We buy a package. We buy the entire thing from a health fund. We cannot buy part of our health insurance from one health fund. We cannot insure ourselves for certain items with one fund and insure ourselves for certain other items with another fund. We have to buy the entire package. In those circumstances, I think we have to take care to make sure that people get their Commonwealth entitlement, and that we do not give incentives to any fund to find means of opting out and have inadvertent casualties. At the moment the range is very limited, but it is not good enough to say: 'With notice, you can go to another health fund', because in the future there will not be as much competition amongst health funds to attract contributors as there is at the moment. I cannot accept that when a contributor joins a fund, because that fund does not offer benefits for a certain item, there is any suggestion of an endorsement, a compulsion or a direction on the Commonwealth on how it ought to pay its benefits. The funds do not determine what Commonwealth benefits are payable. The Commonwealth Government determines what Commonwealth benefits are payable. The funds do not determine to what medical application Commonwealth taxes may go. The Commonwealth Government determines the medical application of Commonwealth taxes. The Government has never claimed that in giving funds an opt-out provision, in giving contributors access to a fund with an opt-out provision on moral, religious or conscientious grounds, it was giving any sort of opt-out to itself in relation to paying Commonwealth benefits. The Government has never claimed it; it has never been an objective.

I seek from the Minister an assurance that the Commonwealth will try to rectify this situation. At the moment it is essentially a mechanical matter. It does not arise in relation to hospitals because the Commonwealth hospital benefit goes to the hospital. The benefit is taken off the top of a hospital's bill. There is no question of a refund to the patient who receives hospital treatment. The Commonwealth benefit is paid before the bill is received. The contributor is not billed for it. In the case of medical benefits, I believe that we have inadvertently taken away the trigger mechanism whereby the Commonwealth benefit reaches the contributor. I ask the Minister for an assurance that the Government will rectify this situation and an assurance that when a fund opts out of paying fund benefits it is not thereby given a means of taking away from its contributors or depriving them of-I am not suggesting that this is necessarily intentional-their entitlement to a government rebate. As I said, I do not believe that this was intentional. There is absolutely no suggestion in any of the debate that any moral judgment was applied to the payment of Commonwealth benefits whilst the Government might have allowed moral judgment to apply to fund benefits. It was not suggested that the same judgment was given to Commonwealth funds. I ask the Minister to address himself to this aspect of the legislation.

I suggest to the Government that it act to rectify this mechanical problem. I realise that it is not a simple one but I believe it is important because the flow-on consequences could be very serious. I think the problem is serious enough now. I do not know how many people are affected but the principle is serious enough, I believe, for the Government to take a good hard look at the matter and, perhaps, in the future make some move to rectify an anomaly. I believe it is just that-an anomaly, not an intention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -I thank honourable senators who have taken part in this debate. I will respond to some of the points made. I start by taking up the point that this Bill includes amendments to a number of Commonwealth Acts. This has been done in a constructive way and quite deliberately. In no sense has it been an attempt to short circuit or otherwise mistreat the Senate. Honourable senators will be aware that the legislative load in this place has been increasing year by year. A number of senators have expressed the view from time to time that there should be some sensible move to reduce the number of pieces of legislation we have to consider. There is some sense in aggregating a number of matters for the purpose of debate. The Parliament, of course, is in charge of how it debates and considers issues. It is able to determine which parts of a Bill it might hold up or not pass. The object has been to minimise in some way the number of pieces of legislation with which honourable senators are presented during each session. The Government can say to honourable senators that there have been no gags and there has been no guillotine. Although we have sat late, honourable senators have been able to speak to the Bills. We have accommodated the Senate. Whatever else can be claimed, we have not in this session attempted to truncate debate or to abridge otherwise the rights of honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty for anyone speaking in this debate, whether from the Australian Labor Party or the Australian Democrats, is that everyone knows that the new scheme will work to provide access and equity for Australians in terms of health care. Since it has not come out in the debate, I mention that this omnibus Bill covers four major areas. It covers amendments to the Health Insurance Act which themselves cover a number of areas. There are alterations to Commonwealth medical benefits to make arrangements for benefits to be continued for pensioners, to define and make arrangements for disadvantaged people and to provide for the payment of 30 per cent of the Commonwealth medical benefit as a universal cover for medical services for those who are insured. The amendments to the Health Insurance Act make provision for new pathology arrangements. They make arrangements for medical service committees of inquiry which themselves are serving a useful function in regulating the activities of those who provide medical services.

The second part of the omnibus Bill provides for some amendments to the National Health Act. These relate to areas of administration of health insurance and, of course, to the Isolated Patients Travel and Accommodation Scheme. The third Act which is amended by this Bill is that concerning the Nursing Homes Assistance Act. The amendments proposed by the Government in this area are significant and have been welcomed. Finally, this omnibus Bill amends the Therapeutic Goods Act to include a number of changes which are desirable in that legislation. So it is a very comprehensive piece of legislation which is before the Senate. It covers a number of areas and a number of them confer considerable benefits upon the community. It is a new and coherent health package. I was interested to read in the May 1981 edition of the Hospital Journal of Australia an editorial concerning the changes in the health insurance system. It was written by a guest editorial writer, Milton Noble. He says:
There may be one consolation and that is concerning health insurance. It will be a relatively simple system.

That is the view of Milton Noble, President of the College of Health Service Administrators, New South Wales branch. His considered opinion is that the proposed system of health insurance will be a relatively simple system. It is also a generous system in terms of the provisions which have been made for the treatment of disadvantaged patients. For some time I have been worried about the way the previous system has been working. There can be considerable geographical disadvantage. There were areas in which none of the medical providers chose to classify anyone as disadvantaged. Under this system there will be a formula under which people can identify themselves as disadvantaged and that can increase the access to the health care system for those people.

People have commented about the drop-out rate over recent months from health insurance and have seen some sinister significance in the Government's desire to have people return to health insurance. I remind honourable senators that those people who drop out are generally those who are good risks. If the good risks drop out it makes the system that much less viable for those who remain. I think honourable senators will be aware that a year or so ago the Mutual Hospital Association Ltd, South Australia published a table which showed that just 9 per cent of its contributors were responsible for just over 50 per cent of all the services rendered. If the other 91 per cent drop out the system becomes impossible as an insurance system. One of the effects of extended coverage of a greater number of people coming back into the system will, of course, be a return of the better risk patients and a chance to share the insurance risk.

I will not address each of the matters raised by honourable senators. I am perfectly happy to answer any of these matters in Committee, if it is so desired. But it is necessary, I think, to address the question which was raised by Senator Martin and also Senator Grimes concerning the fact that some services can be excluded from the benefits which are offered by particular health insurance funds. The fact is that the Government is aware that under its policy certain health funds are able to apply for exemption from paying benefits for particular services. That is the policy of the Governmnent. The Bill provides some extension of that system. That is government policy, and it is intentional. Nevertheless, I have been interested to listen to the debate and to the considerable detailed argument which has been advanced. It is not the intention of the Government to hold up the passage of the amendments which it has proposed. However it would be our intention to go away and examine the Hansard record of the debate, check out the arguments which have been raised and apply the most serious consideration to the matters which have been put before us. I repeat the determination of the Government to provide for a fund, such as the Hibernian Society of Australia, to be able to apply for the exemption of a particular service is a decision which the Government deliberately took. If honourable senators are concerned that particular results flow from that, then it will be the desire of the Government to examine those very carefully.

It only remains to speak briefly to the amendment which is to be moved by Senator Mason and which he was good enough to foreshadow during his speech on the second reading of the Bill. That amendment seeks to refer the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare in lieu of our going into Committee and completing consideration tonight. If that course were followed then there would be some undesirable results. I think it would create confusion in the minds of most Australian consumers of health care about where they would stand until the Committee reported. It would not enable us to bring people back into the health insurance system to support the community rating principle. It would mean, particularly, that those parts of the Bill which the Opposition and everyone else regards as desirable for passage would not be implemented. These include such things as the Commonwealth picking up nursing home benefits now paid by the health insurance funds. They include the strengthening of medical service committees of inquiry. They include the mechanisms for peer review. A number of items which are considered desirable for passage now would be delayed. Particularly in relation to the nursing home benefits, there could be some disadvantage to a large number of people if these were not put into place.

The amendment itself would do nothing to simplify the health insurance arrangements. It would not allow for the new levels of Commonwealth medical benefits to be put into place. Of course, by providing 30 per cent of the cost of all medical benefits to insured people, it extends a certain universality which is lacking at the present time. It would not allow for the new benefit levels of 85 per cent with a $10 limit for schedule fees services. It would mean also that the Acts concerned would not reflect changes to the States' and Territory funding arrangements in relation to the funding of hospital services, which we know are to apply from 1 September 1981. While there may be merit in having this matter referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, while it may be the wish of the Senate to refer this or other matters to the Committee, I believe it is not appropriate that the Bill be held up and referred as the honourable senator has suggested. Having said that, I thank the Senate for its consideration and commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Grimes's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Friday, 12 June 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Standing Order 196A, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare for inquiry with particular reference to the provision of a sliding scale of subsidies for health insurance which would apply to families earning more than the aggregate amounts in which they would qualify for free health as disadvantaged persons and report by the first sitting day in August 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment but not because I believe that the referral of this legislation to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare will come up with a feasible solution. As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the situation is so administratively impossible that such an inquiry could only come up with the answer that we need to go to a universal health insurance scheme. I speak merely to point out that in summing up the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) said that there was nothing sinister in introducing the legislation in this way, namely, to amend four Acts in one Bill, the Health Acts Amendment Bill. He said that the Government did this for reasons of simplicity and for other reasons. At the end of his summing up he said he could not support Senator Mason's amendment because the amendment would have the effect of stopping the application of that desirable part of the legislation, namely, the Therapeutic Goods Act and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act.

SPEECH.PARA: If this amendment is passed, there is no reason that the Minister should not go back to his Government and do what has been done in the past; that is, bring in individual Bills to amend those pieces of legislation. The Minister cannot have it both ways. He cannot say that there is nothing sinister in the legislation, and then say that he opposes Senator Mason's amendment because it will affect those inoffensive parts of this Bill. We hold no hope that Senator Mason's amendment will achieve much but, if the Government is willing to accept it, we believe any fair-minded committee would demonstrate the administrative impossibility of the legislation which the Government has presented tonight. Therefore, we support the amendment.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Mason's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 8-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek some information from Senator Peter Baume, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who represents the Minister for Health in this chamber. Perhaps I could use myself as an example and refer to the pre-Medibank concept and the post-Medibank concept. I put the test to the Minister this way: In the 1953-55 era I joined the Hospital Benefits Fund and the Medical Benefits Fund. Also, becasue I worked in the New South Wales Railways, I joined the railway hospital fund. I have got nothing out of the funds although I contributed to them for 16 years. In 1969 I was in Lewisham Hospital for 10 days for minor surgery on a leg as a result of a football injury. I was robbed because I was not able to get money from all the funds. I was told that I could get money out of only one fund. I ask the Minister: If people in this post-Medibank era join several health funds, will they be able to get money out of all of those funds following medical treatment or will they be entitled to get money out of only one fund?

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I raise also concerns my own saga. In the days of the Whitlam Government, a crane driver in the railways paid less in health insurance than did a senator. Under the Government's post-Medibank system I take it that a process worker and a production manager would both make the same contribution. To me, that is not equitable. They are the two questions I throw at the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be wise to dispose of these questions because unlike most of the others I might receive I think I can answer them. The answer to the first question is that one can draw benefits from one health fund only. The honourable senator will be aware that in making a claim one needs to certify certain matters on a claim form. This enables an assessment to be made as to whether one is also claiming from another fund. So that, short of false certification, people are required to identify whether another fund is involved. A person can claim from one fund only.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator is correct in that whilst rates may vary between funds-whilst it may be cheaper to belong to health fund A than to health fund B-everyone who belongs to the one table in the same fund will contribute the same rate of premium.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will go on television and tell my opponents, those buccaneers of the hospital funds, Cade and Turner, what he has just told me because they robbed me of my rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in some difficulty because Senator Mulvihill succeeded in doing what other people cannot do, that is, rendering Senator Baume speechless. The Opposition opposes clauses 1 to 8. In particular, we oppose clause 8 because this is the clause which restricts the Commonwealth benefit and provisions to those who only insure with private health funds. We think this is an outrageous use of legislation by the Commonwealth. In fact, the aim of this legislation is to force people into private health funds and to restrict the citizens of this country who are taxpayers or whose spouses are taxpayers from receiving benefits through the health system unless they join private insurance organisations. We consider this outrageous. We consider that the reasons given by Senator Baume to be quite specious.

SPEECH.PARA: When the fourth Fraser health scheme was introduced, Opposition members pointed out that the inevitable result would be that the fit, the healthy, the young and those who were willing to gamble would not join health funds, and therefore the health funds would be left with high risk patients. That in fact happened. The way to overcome that is to introduce a universal system which is funded through a levy on taxation or through Consolidated Revenue so that people pay according to their ability to pay. When this is done, there is no need for the great definitions of 'disadvantaged', the extraordinary series of clauses which involve penalties for those who give false information and the cut off points that Senator Mason talked about under which a husband and wife and two children in receipt of an income of $205 a week are in fact worse off than a man and wife and two children on $199 a week because of the penal effect of the sudden death cut off point. We point out that this new system is futile. On the seven previous occasions that I as shadow Minister for health in this place have spoken on health insurance, I said that we would be back again next year to make up for the mess that the Government had made of the matter this year. I predict that we will be back next year to make up for the inequities and the mess that the Government has created now. It is for that reason that we oppose these eight clauses.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 9 to 68-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We in the Opposition do not oppose clauses 9 and 10 which deal with pathology provisions. We oppose clauses 11 to 23 because they deal with the introduction of the new health scheme. We do not oppose clauses 24 to 36 because they are to do with pathology and other provisions. We oppose clause 37, which is to do with penalties. We do not oppose clauses 38, 39 and 40 which are to do with pathology provisions. We oppose clauses 41, 42 and 43 because they are to do with disadvantaged persons and restrictions. We do not oppose clauses 44 to 47 because they are to do with pathology provisions; nor do we oppose clauses 48 to 68 because they are to do with the isolated patients scheme and the nursing homes fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 69 and 70-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses relate to a matter referred to by Senator Martin and the question of the amendments to section 73F of the principal Act. Senator Martin pointed out that on the previous occasion there was little debate on this matter which provides for certain funds to opt out of providing benefits for certain items provided they advertise that they will do so. This applies particularly to the benefits paid for the termination of pregnancy or abortion. At that time we had a health insurance system-unsatisfactory as it was-whereby people who found themselves in this situation had the option, if they required this procedure, of going to a public hospital, having it done there and, therefore were penalised. We now have a new ball game. The Government has introduced a general system whereby people who do not take out insurance with a private health fund receive not only no benefit from those health funds but also no government benefit at all. People who join the organisations which refuse to pay a benefit in this regard not only do not receive a benefit from those organisations but also they do not receive a government benefit despite the fact that they are taxpayers and despite the fact that they may have had a change of heart or may be adult dependents of people who hold such views.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two aspects to this matter. The first relates to the situation regarding those who seek, for medical reasons, the termination of pregnancy. Under the proposed legislation they will receive no benefit and will have to pay a considerable amount of money. The second aspect is that the Bill as it is written opens the way, as Senator Martin said, for health funds to set up optional tables whereby other items can be excluded. Obviously this is not the intent of the Government which has in this case legislated against optional tables. We believe, as I understand Senator Martin believes, that this is wrong in principle. One should not have government payments determined in these situations by organisations which have personal, conscientious or religious objections. The Opposition and, I understand, Senator Martin and others, have sought a means of amending this legislation. There seems to be no way in which we are able to do so. The simple fact is that the Government's intent is that people who are not insured will not receive government benefits. The Government considers people in this situation as not being insured.

Our concern is that the provisions of the original legislation and this legislation may be extended by some other organisation which only needs to apply to the Minister for Health and have the application approved and can extend the provisions of this legislation to consider all sorts of other items. The Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) has assured us that there is no intention that this will happen but it could happen in the future. We believe it is wrong in principle for legislation to be open in this way. We believe the legislation should name the items that were considered when this provision was inserted. Obviously the item is the termination of pregnancy.

We wonder why there cannot be the specific item of termination of pregnancy and we wonder what requirements the Government has for the two organisations in particular which wish to make this exemption. How do they have to advertise? Is it required that they point out to the applicant for medical benefits that it is quite clear that they have this exemption and it is not just something in fine print somewhere? Is it a fact that the organisations can state, 'We will not pay benefits for the evacuation of a gravid uterus' which means nothing to the average patient in the community? Many people just would not understand what those terms mean. Is there any requirement that these organisations actually point out to their potential contributors that this is what they are about? Finally, I ask: In a situation where there is no alternative as there was in the past and where the Government wishes health funds to provide comprehensive health care, is it desirable that we should have these restrictions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to say that the clause, as Senator Grimes said, has applied only to the two particular funds that have applied in relation to item 6469. It is not intended that it should apply to any other item. I pick up the point Senator Grimes made that it can be done only with the approval of the Minister. I am advised-Senator Grimes would know this-that there is a procedure required if a fund embarks on seeking a new exemption. It is a fairly complicated procedure which would ensure that all contributors to a fund knew of any new exemption.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator's question was different. He wanted to know what happens to a person who goes along to join the fund in which the exemption has been in place for some time. That is the way I understand his question. I am advised that the brochures which the fund put out in fact would contain that information. I understand that in New South Wales and Victoria only 24,000 people are in those two funds. They are fairly small operations. It is known generally that those funds have that exemption but the brochures which they put out would in fact contain that information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally I take up a point that Senator Martin raised. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) assured the Senate that the Government was in fact going to look at this matter. Does the Government believe that it is fair that government payments should be restricted in this area in the way they are? Does the Government intend to reconsider the situation in view of the remarks made by Senator Martin and by Mr Steele Hall and others in the other House? Has the Government any intention of extending exemptions beyond this item, a concern which has been expressed by me and by Senator Martin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know of no intention to extend the exemption beyond this item. That is the first matter. The fact that is important is that there is a choice between funds. People have a choice to get away from a fund if they object to the particular exemption in question. As I have said, provisions in the Act ensure that all contributors are informed of the entitlements to benefits should those entitlements alter. I refer now to the matters which have been raised by Senator Martin and by other honourable senators. As I said earlier, the Government now wants to examine very carefully what has been said and what has been put forward, to make an assessment of what exactly is comprehended by the comments and to make decisions from there. I do not think I can commit the Government any further.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Koongarra Project Area Bill is to change the boundaries of the Kakadu National Park so that the original Koongarra special mineral lease excision area is included in the park and a new area of the park is excised for the proposed Koongarra uranium mine. In the view of the Opposition, the means by which this is being carried out are deceitful and dishonourable. The Bill retrospectively amends the proclamation by the Governor-General of 5 April 1979 to substitute a new Koongarra project area as defined by Denison Mining for the area originally excised. Sub-clause 3 (2) of the Bill deems that amendment of the proclamation shall have been made in accordance with section 7 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like honourable senators to pay attention to what section 7 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act says. That section requires that before park boundaries are varied 60 days be allowed for public comment, that the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service consider any comment and make a report to the Executive Council and that the Executive Council then consider the Director's report and commend a resolution to this Parliament. It also requires that excision of an area of a park not take place except in accordance with a resolution passed by both Houses of Parliament after 15 sitting days notice of motion. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) in his second reading speech had the effrontery to call sub-clause 3 (2) of the Bill 'a technical provision'. It is not a technical provision. It is a gross abuse of the legislative procedures of Parliament. It introduces an insidious legalistic form of doublethink whereby honourable senators know full well that the provisions for public consultation and parliamentary scrutiny laid down in section 7 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act have not been complied with. Yet we are asked to pass a piece of legislation which deems that they have been complied with. In other words, the Parliament a couple of years ago passed a law which said that certain things should happen before the boundaries of the park should be changed. The Government refuses to carry out the provisions of its own legislation and instead introduces a new piece of legislation, saying: 'We will pretend that those provisions have been complied with'. That is a dishonourable and deceitful tactic.

Of course, it is true that the Parliament has the power to make laws and to repeal them. That is a proper exercise of the Parliament's function. It is when laws are applied selectively, when they are riddled with exemptions and when things are deemed to have complied with the law when in fact they have not, that the whole integrity of the Parliament is called into question. How can the Government criticise tax dodgers for constantly seeking legislative loopholes to avoid their moral and legal responsibility to pay tax when the Government itself seeks to create legislative loopholes through which to avoid its moral and legal responsibilities to ensure public participation and thorough scrutiny by Parliament of legislation? If members of parliament are not prepared to comply with the spirit and the letter of their own legislation, they will command little public respect or credibility by calling for the rest of the community to do so. I think it is fairly clear at this stage of this parliamentary session just how little public credibility and respect the Fraser Government is able to command.

This legislation retrospectively changes a Governor-General's proclamation and enshrines in legislation a lie by deeming that legislative requirements for public consultation and proper parliamentary scrutiny have been complied with when in fact they have not. On those grounds alone it ought not to be passed by this Senate. Why is it being forced through the Senate at this stage? The only reason for changing the boundaries of the Kakadu National Park at this time and in this manner is to ensure that no impediment to the Koongarra project can be presented by a new Senate which more accurately reflects the views of the Australian people.

The Bill clears the last legislative hurdle in the path of the Koongarra uranium mine, a mine which in the public interest should never go ahead. The Government is fond of saying that this legislation does not allow uranium mining to proceed at Koongarra; that it does not change the status of the Koongarra project area as Aboriginal land; and that it does not bypass foreign investment guidelines.

It is correct to say that after the passage of this legislation the Government will still face two obstacles in its quest to mine Koongarra: First, resistance to the project by Aboriginal traditional owners, who have a right of veto over mining on Aboriginal land under sub-section (1) of section 40 of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act and, second, the fact that the project is 100 per cent foreign-owned by Denison Co. of Canada, which puts the project in contravention of the Government's foreign investment guidelines which have a 75 per cent Australian equity objective. However, these obstacles can be overcome without further reference to the Parliament. The foreign investment guidelines are just that-guidelines. They can be changed or ignored by the Government, as has been done in other cases, for example, Yeelirrie. As for the Aboriginal traditional owners, the intense pressure on them to allow mining has already begun. The passage of this legislation will only intensify it. They will be hounded by Territory and Federal governments and by the mining company until they sign an agreement. Does any honourable senator really believe that if this legislation is passed mining will not go ahead?

The Senate must look realistically at what it is doing in passing this Bill. In effect, it will be giving the final legislative nod to the Koongarra uranium project. As the Senate is aware, the Australian Labor Party has an anti-uranium policy. We believe that the risks inherent in uranium mining and processing outweigh the potential benefits and would therefore oppose the legislation on these grounds. However, even for senators who do not share the Labor Party's concern about the hazards of the uranium industry there are three major and compelling arguments as to why this particular uranium project should not proceed. First, it threatens a unique and beautiful environment of great ecological significance and would cause massive environmental disruption for a relatively small amount of uranium. Secondly, Aboriginal people have not been properly consulted about what is planned for their land. The development of another uranium mine in the Kakadu area would stretch the fabric of Aboriginal society to breaking point. Thirdly, Koongarra may well turn out to be an uneconomic proposition if proceeded with at present. The value of, and demand for, uranium on the world market has plummeted steadily for six years. It is simply not a sensible time, in market terms, to develop a uranium mine.

I could present a number of arguments concerning the environmental damage which the park would cause. Because of the lateness of the hour I will not go into them in detail but I remind honourable senators that Justice Fox said that any contamination of Woolwonga wetlands, which is the area under consideration, would threaten 'the most important refuge and habitat for aquatic wildlife in the Northern Territory'. I am sure that the Acting Deputy President, Senator Mulvihill, will be well aware of the pertinence of those remarks. His Honour went on to say:
We would oppose in principle any mining development upstream of it-
That is, the Woolwonga area-
Until it had been demonstrated by experience that it could take place without environmental damage.

Reports of a collapse of Ranger uranium's heavy metals tailings dam in its first wet season is the only experience we have had so far of the environmental safety of uranium mining in areas which experience tropical wet seasons.

Furthermore, Mr Justice Fox recommended that if mining were to proceed in the Kakadu region it should be restricted to the Magela drainage basin so that environmental damage could be geographically contained. Jabiluka and Jabiru are within the Magela drainage basin. Koongarra is not. Mining Koongarra would open a whole new drainage basin-the Nourlangie Creek catchment area-to potential environmental disaster. The passage of this legislation must put in jeopardy any serious consideration of the Australian application for inclusion of Kakadu National Park in the World Heritage List. It is nonsense for the Government on the one hand, to argue, for the uniqueness and value of the environment and, on the other hand, to do everything in its power to extend mining in the area.

I will now direct my remarks to the Aboriginal people affected by this legislation. My claim is that there has been a lack of consultation. Of course, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) has made a counterclaim about consultation. The Aboriginal traditional owners of the area have been angered by the lack of consultation over the whole Koongarra issue. We can understand why. Put yourself in their position. They are the traditional and legal owners of the Kakadu region. First, they are told they are to have a uranium mine on their land. Then they are informed that the site of the mine-which they have not yet agreed to have-is to be changed. They are told in a letter by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that that area of land which they have leased to the Director of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is to be the new mine site and that legislation is to be passed nullifying that lease. Understandably this treatment angered the Koongarra traditional owners and they put out a Press release on 5 May this year, the full text of which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PRESS RELEASE BY TRADITIONAL OWNERS OF KOONGARRA PROJECT
On Friday 1st May a large meeting of Traditional Owners and the Gagadgu Association Inc was held at Patonga in the Kakadu National Park.

The meeting was held in response to a letter sent by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Baume) to the Northern Land Council which advised that the Federal Government had decided to excise a further area from the Kakadu Park in response to a request from Denison (Australia) Pty Ltd.

Denison have for some time been negotiating with the traditional owners of the area, through the Northern Land Council, for the right to mine Uranium at Koongarra, which is 20km south of the uranium mine at Jabiru.

Denison delared that the existing mining lease was unsuitable for their proposed mine. Denison asked the Federal Government to excise a further area from the Kakadu Park, thereby excluding any control over their mining lease by the ANPWS which presently manages the Kadadu Park under a lease from the traditional Aboriginal owners.
On 28th April, the Northern Land Council received a letter from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume which advised that the Federal Government would implement Denison's request.

At no time were the traditional owners of the area, the Kakadu Association (The Aboriginal Owners of the entire area of the Park) nor the Northern Land Council invited to give an opinion about the application for the new lease, although the Northern Land Council were aware that a submission was to be made to the Federal Government.
Indeed, for the owners of the area, the very first they heard of the lease question was that Denison's application had been already implemented.

The day after receipt of the letter by the Northern Land Council, a meeting was held at Patonga to discuss the issue. The meeting lasted two days and was attended by the traditional owners of the mine site and surrounding areas, representatives of the Gagadju Association, the members of the Northern Land Council negotiating team and representatives of the Northern Land Council.

The traditional owners, after considering various options decided to ask the Northern Land Council to write the Minister and declare their opposition to the granting of the new lease. They demanded that the Minister revoke his decision until such time as the traditional owners had been consulted regarding the matter and until they had the opportunity of having from their own advisors as to possible effects the excision would have on the management of the Kakadu Park.
They also resolved to immediately suspend all negotiations until further notice with Denison (Australia) Pty Ltd in respect of the Koongara Project.
They further demanded that Denison cease having any contact with the Aboriginal people of the area.

The traditional owners expressed their absolute disappointment that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs regardless of the rhetoric about consultation by himself, his officers and those who went before them could again make decisions about what would happen to Aboriginal land.

As the traditional owners ask 'How can it be that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs can give our land away to a mining company without asking what we think'. This is not self-determination, this is the same as always, white fellahs making their own decisions about what is good for Aboriginals.
Further enquiries: To be made through Gagadju Association, Mr Ross Hebblewhite, Phone 81 4228.

TALK.START.PARA: —That release concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: As the traditional owners ask 'How can it be that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs can give our land away to a mining company without asking what we think'. This is not self-determination, this is the same as always, white fellas making their own decisions about what is good for Aboriginals.
I would also seek leave to incorporate a telegram I received yesterday expressing the views of the traditional owners in the Kakadu National Park area.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CAA 323-AST 398-SNDB101-
9 Sin Cooinda Outpost, Radio Darwin, NT 519/512 4 p.m.
Senator Susan Ryan
Parliament House
Canberra, ACT

As traditional owners in the Kakadu National Park we are feeling very unhappy and frightened by the Government because it wants to pass a law about changing the Kakadu National Park boundary in a hurry. We have only just had a letter from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to say that the Government wishes to push the law through. It is all very well to say that the boundary will not be changed until or unless we reach agreement with Denison Mines. That is still holding the gun at our heads. As some of us told the Minister before it seems that the Government is determined to mine the area regardless of what we say. We have also made it clear that we feel threatened by the mine in this area and would like a lot of time to think it over. As it now stands we might be a tiny group of people saying no almost as the conscience of the whole of the Australian people but we own this country. We love our land and this park which we are trying to share with all the world. The Government itself has said it is one of the great wonders of the world to be put on the world heritage list but in the next breath it wants us and us alone to stand up against putting something big in the middle of one of its best areas Nourlangi Rock. We think there are many things for all the people of Australia to think about and not just us. The mine is upstream of one of the best water bird areas of Australia. Also we still use some of this area for hunting as our fathers did for thousands of years. No one can guarantee that this will not be polluted by the tailings or silted up in some way. We also think about all the disturbance in the area. There will be loud noise a lot of traffic and thousands of people for miles around the mine. We feel that we could be saying goodbye to Burrunggui Nourlangi Rock which has been a big part of our lives and also the people who came before us. Senator Baume has written to us in sweet words about this but on the same day we have got a rough letter from the Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment saying that the Government will dump us to the Northern Territory Government which fights against Aboriginal land. This is our land and our fathers land and the Federal Government agreed with this. We have lent our land freely to the people of Australia to make a great national park for use of all people and to protect that land. We therefore ask all senators to defer this Bill until we have had a chance for discussions amongst ourselves.
Gagadju Association and the Traditional owners of Kakadu National Park.

TALK.START.PARA: —The impact of Ranger and Queensland Mines Ltd developments on Aboriginal people in the Kakadu region has been significant and in some respects devastating. The Aboriginal people are still adjusting to these developments and they need time to make those adjustments if their traditional society is to survive. Yet Aboriginal people are not being given even this breathing space. This week negotiations between Aboriginal traditional owners and Pancontinental Mining Ltd are due to commence. Many of the traditional owners of the Jabiluka area are also traditional owners of the Koongarra area. The Government therefore intends to put these Aboriginals under double pressure to sign mining agreements. That is what the passage of this legislation will mean.

SPEECH.PARA: I now proceed to a brief discussion of the economic argument. Koongarra contains only small reserves of uranium. Australia's biggest uranium reserves are at Ranger and at Jabiluka. Ranger is estimated to have reserves of 110,000 tonnes of yellowcake and is capable of an annual production of 6,000 tonnes. Jabiluka has estimated reserves of 206,000 tonnes of yellowcake and is capable of an annual production of 3,000 tonnes. Koongarra has only 13,300 tonnes of minable yellowcake and is capable of producing only 1,000 tonnes annually. Currently, there is a world over-production of uranium. The price of uranium yellowcake has crashed from $US43 per lb in mid-1979 to $US28 per lb at the end of 1980. In 1981 the price fell to $US25 per lb. This is indicative, honourable senators will agree, of world overproduction. World demand has not increased at the rate predicted in the mid-1970s and may decline even further. I refer honourable senators to an article in this week's National Times entitled 'Nuclear Power Falls on Hard Times'. The article is written by Mr Anthony Parisi, a well-known energy correspondent in the United States of America. He argues:
The prognosis for nuclear power in America is bleak . . . and not because it is too dangerous. Rather it is too costly and may not even be necessary in a new era of slackening demand.

In this context Australia has nine uranium mines on the drawing board for the 1980s. These are: Ranger, Jabiluka, Yeelirrie, Koongarra, Beverley, Honeymoon, Lake Way, Ben Lomond and Roxby Downs. If all of these mines go ahead Australia could be producing at least 14,200 tonnes of yellowcake a year. Yet, even the most optimistic Australian Atomic Energy Commission reports estimate that we could only sell between 8,000 and 9,000 tonnes a year. Developing Koongarra at this stage in this context does not make economic sense. Of course, there are other arguments against Koongarra proceeding. The Fox report, for instance, recommended that if uranium deposits in this area were to be mined they should be mined in a sequential fashion. However, this is not the first time that the Government has demonstrated its disregard for the findings of Justice Fox.

In conclusion, the Government has gone about this exercise in a shoddy and deceitful way. All the arguments are against facilitating the development of Koongarra now. It threatens a unique natural environment and Aboriginal traditional society in the area. The Aboriginal people have not been sufficiently consulted and have indicated that they do not want the mine to proceed. Finally and, one would hope with this Government, most persuasively, it makes no economic sense. These are compelling arguments against the project. There are no good reasons why it should proceed, and I urge the Senate to vote against the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Ryan has said, the purpose of the Koongarra Project Area Bill is to make changes to the boundaries of the Kakadu National Park. The first thing I want to say is that I think all Government senators would want to reject the assertion that making changes in the boundaries of the national park by passing an Act of parliament is somehow improper or immoral or contrary to parliamentary practice. One would have thought that nothing could have been more open and more squarely within the framework of the democratic procedures of an elected parliament than to change the boundaries of a national park by an Act of Parliament, subject to scrutiny in both Houses of Parliament and subject to the full amount of public debate which regulations and changes to administrative procedures very often manage to avoid.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, within the framework of the Kakadu National Park some 15.7 square kilometres are excluded from the 5,700 square kilometres which constitute the park as a whole. Apart from the exclusion which currently exists so far as the Koongarra site is concerned, there is the exclusion of the area around the border store, two exclusions at the Cooinda Hotel-Motel area, the exclusion at Spring Creek Garden and the exclusion of the Dampier mine mineral leases. This proposes a change in the park which in fact will add marginally to the total amount of the park. An area of 1,197 hectares goes out of the park; an area of 1,228 hectares comes back into the park. Those who have had the opportunity, as I have, to spend some time walking over the area will know that the area which is going out of the park is not one of as much scenic beauty or significance as the area that is being brought into the park. What is being brought in is the Nourlangie Rock area, and the massif and foothills of Mount Brockman. Within that area not only are they amongst the most attractive and significant parts of the park from an ecological point of view but also, in the case of Mount Brockman, they are certainly the most significant areas in the whole region of northern Australia in regard to Aboriginal culture, sacred sites, paintings and totemic significance. All that is being brought into the park. It has previously been excluded; it is now being brought in. As to the way in which the management plan for the Kakadu National Park has been drawn up and developed, one can see quite clearly that the original plan of management states:

The area of the Koongarra Special Mineral Lease application located close to Nourlangie Rock is not included in the Park. In order to facilitate the finalisation of an environmental impact statement by Noranda Australia Ltd in relation to the Koongarra uranium deposit, work of an investigative nature, such as drilling to determine soil and subsoil properties, will need to be carried out in the area of the Park adjacent to the deposit and may be authorised by the Director.

It was, in fact, so authorised, and I will come back to that in a few minutes. Senator Ryan has sought to make out a great deal about the processes of consultation with the Aboriginal people. I draw the Senate's attention to clause 2 (2) of the Bill, which refers to clause 3, dealing with the changes in the park. Clause 2 (2) states:

Section 3 shall come into operation on a date to be fixed by Proclamation, being a date not earlier than the date on which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the relevant Land Council have consented, in writing, for the purposes of sub-section 40 (1) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, to the making of a grant of a mining interest in respect of the relevant land, whether or not that consent also applies to the making of the grant of a mining interest in respect of any other land.

There, in a piece of legislation that the Parliament is asked to pass tonight, is a clause that says the legislation will not come into effect until there is an agreement in writing between the Minister and the relevant land council. I cannot see how any intelligent person would say that the processes of consultation with the Aboriginal people are being subverted, are being ignored, and are not being complied with when the Bill itself is dependent upon the signature of the Northern Land Council and the Minister on a document before it has any operation.

If one looks at section 40 (1) of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and one is aware of the procedures, as one would have thought the shadow Minister would have been, one would accept that there, in a piece of legislation that could be altered only by an Act of this Parliament, is a guarantee that no proclamation of that clause of the Bill can take place until the Northern Land Council has signed a written agreement with the Government on that matter. The 1979-80 report of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service stated, among other things:
Steady progress was made in the development and refinement of consultative processes with both the traditional Aboriginal owners of land in the Park and the Northern Land Council.

That refers to the Kakadu National Park. To come along here and say there is no consultation when the Act is dependent on an act of consultation committed to a legal document with the signature of the Northern Land Council is to make an absolute farce of the meaning of the words in the English language. It is quite clear from what Senator Ryan has said, and quite clear from the representations I have received from groups such as the Total Environment Centre, that one thing they have not bothered to do-I do not particularly blame them for it-is to look at the document I have here, which is one of the four volumes of the environmental impact statement which deals with the Koongarra project and which was prepared by Noranda at the direction of the Commonwealth Minister for Environment, Housing and Community Development in 1977. That company was instructed under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 to prepare this environmental impact statement.

I will come back to that briefly because the accusations made about the protection of the Woolwonga wildlife area, the accusations made about the tailings dam, the accusations made about development in the Magela Creek region and the accusations made about developments that will take place as far as the actual siting of any work which may be in progress are all answered in the environmental impact statement.
