I put it to the Senate that what we have had from the Opposition is a statement which is not based upon a reading of the environmental impact statement which has been prepared to cover this development. Perhaps the first of these matters on which I might touch is the question of the siting and location of the tailings works. Rather than detain the Senate by reading it, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard page 395 of the statement, which deals with some of the technical aspects but concludes with these words:

It must be concluded that on the weight of evidence and experience, placement of the tailings, as proposed, in an engineered and excavated retention structure on the divide between Hickey Creek and Koongarra Creek is best practicable technology and is entirely within the overall concept of a no release objective. Close monitoring of the system is proposed and the facilities for this have already been established.
I seek leave to incorporate that page in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
5. Advantages of the proposed rationale

The proposed tailings retention pond represents a fully engineered, largely subgrade disposal site for the tailings, which will achieve the highest levels of compaction and monitoring of tailings leachate movements and effects, before the cessation of operations on site and before the completion of rehabilitation on site.

The proposed tailings retention pond also provides for a high likelihood that the leachates which will escape in time will never appear in the surface environment in a form which will present a significant environmental problem. At this time and at Koongarra, no guarantee can be given that these statements are true, but given overseas experience and the advantageous mineralogical and density situations which exist, the concepts and effects discussed herein must be accepted as probable. Monitoring of the system over the next 18 years will prove the situation and if it proves incorrect, alternative measures can be taken.

Inherent in the programme is the acceptance of the worked-out Koongarra Mine as a lake, but this is to be a clean lake, not a contaminated lake such as exist where tailings were returned at Rum Jungle (Whites Open Cut and Dysons Open Cut).
The depth and unnatural boundaries of the lake can be modified if this is desirable, but its use as a sub-grade burial site for tailings is to be avoided.
Finally, the tailings retention pond currently proposed will result in a reduced period for rehabilitation and a reduced impact of the overall environment.
From the viewpoint of the long term safe retention of tailings and their byproducts, the current proposal incorporates virtually all the barriers identified by Kaufmann, namely:
Sub-grade disposal-internal borrow pit
Engineered barriers-bunds, walls, caps and rock encasement
Geological barriers-geochemically active formations with a long flow path
Environmental barriers-deep percolation, resulting from density, to a low flux groundwater environment
6. Conclusion

It must be concluded that on the weight of evidence and experience, placement of the tailings, as proposed, in an engineered and excavated retention structure on the divide between Hickey Creek and Koongarra Creek is best practicable technology and is entirely within the overall concept of a no release objective. Close monitoring of the system is proposed and the facilities for this have already been established.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It would also not be true to say that this is simply an attempt to clear hurdles so that one can go rushing into the mining of uranium from the Koongarra deposit. That matter was specifically addressed by the Minister in his second reading speech on 28 May in the House of Representatives when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The establishment and definition of the Koongarra project area provided for in this Bill does not imply approval for mining.

As we know, a number of things need to be addressed. There needs to be a full assessment by the Commonwealth of all the issues raised in the environmental impact statement. There is also the question of the 100 per cent ownership of the Denison company and the question of other government priorities and policies concerning uranium development. I turn very briefly to the three matters that are raised in the environmental impact statement. The first of these deals with the visual impact of the Koongarra project. The EIS states:

During the life of the Project, the visual impact of the project will be localised and distinct. After completion of rehabilitation the Project area will be returned to the Park in an appropriate state for Park use and the long term impact will be minimal.

So not only under this legislation is the park getting a far more significant area included within it, but it is also, in terms of the EIS, to get back when the project has been completed, the exclusion that this Bill makes, and it will be returned to the park in an appropriate state for park use. The long term impact will be minimal. There has been a great deal of discussion-this is the second point arising from the EIS-about Aboriginal sites in the area. There is a very lengthy description in the statement of the several hundred sites which are either in or adjacent to the proposed area. One of the things that is said, particularly in an archeological sense, in the EIS is:
. . . Noranda is not aware of any site of significant archeological interest in, or in the vicinity of, the Project Area.

One can go through the document and see that that statement is correct. One can again address oneself to the statement that the area that is coming back into the park and which is currently excluded from the park contains one of the most significant collections of Aboriginal paintings and among the most important sites anywhere within that part of northern Australia. The area was previously excluded from the park and, under the terms of this legislation, it will now come back into the park. The sites will be protected under the normal regime of the parks service.

I turn finally to the criticisms that somehow this is an overturning of the Ranger uranium inquiry recommendations concerning this part of the park or this particular development. Section 7 of the environmental impact statement, in the summary which runs over four and a bit pages and which I will seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard, deals with each and every one of those points. I shall go through them as quickly as I can. Reference is made to the positioning of tailings. The EIS states that original design concepts have been altered to provide for the neutralisation of tailings, the construction of the tailings and evaporation ponds in a particular fashion, the covering of the tailings, the returning of the tailings to certain pits and further developments. As to the criticisms made by Mr Justice Fox, the EIS states that the original design concepts have been altered to provide for them. The recommendations of Mr Justice Fox in relation to sulphur stockpiles are taken care of. The recommendations of Mr Justice Fox as to test blasting are taken care of. As to water release, the subject of the point that Senator Ryan raised in relation to the Woolwonga wildlife area, the EIS statement reads:
Noranda has elected to implement a water management system designed with a 'no release' objective.

So the criticisms made about the pollution of creeks and about the water system have been entirely taken care of in the environmental impact statement. As to the question of the use of respiratory devices and rehabilitation, the EIS states:
Noranda accepts responsibility for rehabilitation of the Koongarra project Area.

The return of the tailings, the acid plant, the use of explosives and the development of the Koongarra project in general are all dealt with in the environmental impact statement. Every single one of the references that Mr Justice Fox made has been taken up in the environmental impact statement and has been answered and, I believe, answered in full. For instance, on the question of the overall development of the project, the statement reads:
In the case of Koongarra, there will be no release of water into the downstream environment.

Yet Senator Ryan has criticised the project, saying that that will be done. The Total Environment Centre people, who clearly have not read the environmental impact statement, say that water release will occur and that pollution and degradation will result. The very statement that the developers have produced for the Commonwealth Government says quite clearly:
. . . there will be no release of water into the downstream environment.

So that honourable senators can have the chance to study the responses of the environmental impact statement to Mr Justice Fox's comments, I seek leave to have that section of the report incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SECTION SEVEN
References to Ranger Inquiry
7.1 Introduction

Although primarily concerned with the Ranger Project of Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd, the Second Report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry contains some comments and recommendations which warrant reference in this draft EIS. The matters involved are dealt with in detail under other sections of this draft EIS, and are summarised below with page references to the Ranger Inquiry, Second Report.
7.2 References

Tailings Dam (Pages, 165, 166, 289, 327) The Inquiry was concerned at Noranda's original proposal to store tailings from the Koongarra Project in an acid condition in a pond to be formed by damming a natural gully at an elevated location north of the plant. It was felt that seepage, eroded material, and any release of contaminated water from this dam would enter Nourlangie Creek and be a potential threat to the Woolwonga Wildlife Sanctuary.
Original design concepts have been altered to provide for: Neutralization of Tailings.

Construction of the tailings and evaporation ponds on an impermeable sub-base on flat lying ground south of the plant and within a hydrological cone of depression which will ensure that any seepage does not escape from the Project Area during the life of the Project.
Covering of the tailings, upon cessation of operations, with impermeable material to eliminate leaching by surface waters.
or alternatively
Returning the tailings to the open pit should that be shown by detailed investigation and monitoring programs to be more desirable environmentally.
Sulphur Stockpile (Page 325) The Inquiry recommended that sulphur stockpiles be surrounded by an embankment.
The sulphur stockpile at Koongarra will be bunded.
Test Blasting (Page 325) The Inquiry recommended that before mining begins, small test blasts be carried out on site to predict ground vibration from blasting.
This will be done at Koongarra as soon as approval for such tests is granted. Proposed blasting patterns and programs will be modified as, and if, necessary.

Water Release (Page 326) The Inquiry expressed concern about the possible effects of discharge of water from the Ranger project area into the down-stream environment of the Magela Creek catchment, and recommended this be permitted only under certain strict conditions and controls.
Although not in the same catchment as Ranger, similar principles and considerations apply to Koongarra.

Noranda has elected to implement a water management system designed with a 'no release' objective. This design will ensure that no release will occur, except during the February to March months of an unusually wet year which is part of a prolonged wet cycle with an estimated recurrence of 1 in 1000 years. In the unlikely event of these rare conditions occurring during the 12 year life of the Project, the high volumes of naturally occurring surface water flows will dilute the small quantity of low contaminant-level water released.
Respiratory Devices (Page 327) The Inquiry recommended that, if possible, operations in pits be planned so as to avoid the need for habitual use of respiratory protection devices.

Pit mobile equipment at Koongarra will be fitted with filtered airconditioned cabs. Calculations indicate that radon and dust levels will be below those set out in the Code of Practice. Accordingly, respiratory protection devices are likely to be required by personnel only intermittently and on an occasional basis.

Rehabilitation (Page 327) The Inquiry recommended that the operator be responsible for all rehabilitation work and recommended measures to be taken to ensure that such work is carried out satisfactorily. Noranda accepts responsibility for rehabilitation of the Koongarra Project Area.
Return of Tailings to Open Pit (Page 327) The Inquiry recommended that tailings and any remnant low grade ore stockpiles from the Ranger Project be returned to the open pit.

Any low grade ore stockpiles remaining at Koongarra after milling ceases will be handled through the process plant for impoundment with the tailings or returned to the open pit, whichever is environmentally preferable. While return of tailings to the pit remains an option, subject to continuing investigation and monitoring, Noranda believes that the tailings disposal scheme proposed in this draft EIS is more secure environmentally.
Acid Plant (Page 327) The Inquiry recommended the installation of a stack gas scrubber to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions from the Ranger acid plant.
The acid plant to be installed at Koongarra will be of a double absorption, double catalysis type which produces lower SO2 emission levels than the plant considered by the Ranger Inquiry.
Explosives (Page 328) The Inquiry indicated that explosives should be stored at a safe distance from the tailings dam and ecologically significant features.

Primary blasting in the Koongarra pit will be with ammonium nitrate and fuel oil mixture which is an inherently safe blasting agent. The storage of pre-mixed bagged blasting agent will be in magazines meeting all applicable codes.
Only limited quantities of high explosives for secondary blasting are required and these will be stored in an approved magazine.

Jabiru Reginal Town and Impacts on Aboriginal Society (Pages 328, 329) The Inquiry was concerned at the possible impact on Aboriginal society of an influx of a large number of non-Aboriginal people into the Region. The Inquiry therefore recommended that the number of non-Aboriginals be kept to the minimum both in construction camps and the planned Regional Town.

The workforce needed for Koongarra is very small compared with the total work force which will be resident in the Region. The construction camp will be in an area remote from Aboriginal populations and the incremental effect of housing Koongarra employees and their families at the Regional Town during operations will be minimal.

Development of the Koongarra Project (Pages 165, 166, 289, 322) The Inquiry was concerned at the potential for environmental damage from contaminants being injected, or escaping into, water drainage basins downstream from the proposed projects. In the case of Koongara, there will be no release of water into the downstream environment. The Inquiry's concern about the initial Koongara concept for tailings disposal is referred to earlier in this Section. The Commonwealth recognised and accepted the Inquiry's comments and, in announcing its Uranium Policy in August 1977, the Prime Minister stated:

'The Government has decided to accept the Inquiry's recommendation that the Ranger and Pancontinental lease areas should be excluded from the National Park. On the same basis, the Government has decided that the Noranda lease area should be excluded. The Government has made these exclusions without commitment in order or timing of any development.

Because of the Government's requirement that it be satisfied as to the acceptability of the impact of each development on the environment, a considerable amount of planning and investigation into the environmental effects of any development of Noranda's deposit at Koongara will have to be undertaken. That deposit has particular environmental problems because of the sensitivity and fragility of the environment of the area and the location of the deposit upstream of a major wetlands area'.

Noranda has taken particular note of these comments in the complete revision and subsequent adjustment to its design concept and water management system. Noranda is confident that its revised proposal is environmentally secure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say in conclusion that the criticisms that have been made of this Bill are entirely improper and wrong. It has been criticised on the basis that it should have been done in some other way. I put it to honourable senators that the way to deal with major changes in national parks is by Act of Parliament. Any honourable senator who believes that there is some better way to deal with things than by Act of Parliament should perhaps seriously consider what his role as a legislator would be reduced to. There has been a quesion about what goes in and what goes out of the park and the relative value. It has been clearly demonstrated that the area going out of the park is of less ecological value of less value to the Aboriginal community and of less historical, archaeological and artistic value, and that the area going into the park, the Nourlangi Rock-Mt Brockman massif, is of considerable importance and will obtain under this Bill its first real protection in the plan of management.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said that there has been no consultation with Aboriginal people. Yet the Act cannot come into force until there is a written agreement with the Aboriginal people. It has been said that the Bill ignores the recommendations of Mr Justice Fox. Yet the environmental impact statement clearly demonstrates in every single regard that the comments by His Honour have been taken care of and responded to in a most responsible and intelligent manner. It has been said that there will be a visual pollution and desecration of Aboriginal sites. Both these claims are false. Above all, I say in support of this legislation that the environment, the Aboriginal people, the demands and the proper requirements of the Commonwealth Government and the Parliament have all been satisfied. The legislation should be enthusiastically supported by all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support to the hilt the fears expressed by my colleague Senator Ryan. I well remember the famous occasion when the second Fox report was released. A spate of reports from about four Ministers were delivered in the Senate. It was as well that they delivered those reports which I regarded as a snow job. They told us what lessons they had learned about protection for the future. At the time Mr Nixon produced a paper which said that the Federal Government was spending $1.5m to rehabilitate the Finniss River in the Nortern Territory which had been seriously damaged by the Rum Jungle operations. That announcement was preceded by promises that everything was all right. The message there is that we cannot take environmental impact statements at face value.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick has argued that the matter has gone before the Senate. Of course, that is a laudable thing. But to me this is a gigantic snow job. I say that for this reason: The second Fox report referred to Ranger and Jabiru. Mr President, I have been asked to seek leave to continue my remarks. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What research was conducted to ascertain the cost effectiveness of the International Business Opportunity Program (IBOP) following last year's Australian delegation to the IBOP in Davos, Switzerland.
(2) What was the total cost, including (a) fares; (b) accommodation and (c) travelling allowance, and (d) other costs associated with staging the presentation.
(3) What increased business and/or investment resulted directly from this visit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Cost effectiveness was demonstrated by the impact which the 1980 Australian delegation to IBOP had on the European and other businessmen attending Davos. This was evidenced by the 70 direct enquiries received by the delegation during the symposium, by the comments subsequently received from European and other participants and by the European management forum's decision to invite Australia back for a second year in succession-an almost unprecedented step. Australia's acceptance of that invitation led in turn to a further 158 business enquiries from participants in the 1981 symposium.

(2) The total cost to the Commonwealth of the 1980 Australian delegation to IBOP was $51,258, including (a) fares of $15,045, (b) accommodation costs of $5,290, (c) travelling allowance of $4,925 and (d) other costs of $25,998.

(3) While it is not possible to attribute increases in business or investment directly to this visit, it is noteworthy that western Europe sent some 18 major trade, investment and energy missions to Australia in the succeeding twelve months, compared with seven in the previous year, and that a survey which EMF took of its members following on Australia's 1980 appearance at Davos reportedly showed that Australia was the non-European country of greatest interest to European businessmen.

(3) Are they given information as to how and where they can appeal at the time of cancellation.
(4) Are there any circumstances in which pensions are continued while investigations are made or appeals are in progress.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A pensioner residing overseas is advised of the reason if the pension is cancelled.

(2) No. The honourable senator would be aware that many pensioners would have difficulty in attending either of the two overseas offices located in Geneva and London for an interview prior to cancellation of pension. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: How many pensioners receiving the maximum rate of pension now pay tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There is insufficient information available to the Department of Social Security or the Taxation Office to answer the question. But the following information may give some guidance on the matter.

For those social security pensioners eligible for an incometested pension but exempt from personal income tax, that is invalid pensioners (except the permanently blind) below age pension age, no tax would be payable for 1980-81. In the case of those whose pension is income test-free and exempt from tax, that is the permanently blind under age pension age, tax would be payable if non-pension taxable income was above the tax threshold.

The tax threshold for a single person (other than a sole parent) in 1980-81 is $4,041 ($77.71 a week). The maximum rate of basic pension payable in 1980-81 for a single person is $3,299 ($63.45 a week). Tax may therefore be payable by a person who is a maximum rate pensioner in receipt of a taxable pension for the whole of 1980-81 if his taxable non-pension income exceeds $741 ($14.26 a week).

The position of married pensioner couples is more complex due to the operation of the separate net income test for the dependent spouse rebate. However, a married person in receipt of the maximum (married) rate of a taxable pension for the whole of 1980-81, whose spouse has no non-pension income, would not generally be liable to pay tax because the level of non-pension taxable income required-$1,908 ($36.70 a week)-is above the pension income test free area.

Because of the operation of the sole parent tax rebate, the sole parent pensioner in receipt of the maximum rate of pension for the whole of 1980-81 would be unlikely to be liable to pay tax unless he or she had five or more children, as the non-pension taxable income required would also exceed the pension income test free area.

At December 1980, some 60,000 single pensioners with no children receiving taxable pensions had non-pension incomes in excess of $14.26 a week ($741.52 year) but below the income test free area of $20.00 a week ($1,040 a year). Not all these, of course, would necessarily be liable to pay tax.

The latest statistics available from the Taxation Commissioner refer to 1978-79. For that year, taxable individuals included over 250,000 people in receipt of Commonwealth Government pensions and other benefits. Few would have been maximum rate pensioners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 December 1980 (Hansard, page 440) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, a question relating to comments in the Foreign Investment Review Board Report 1980 which revealed a significant increase in foreign takeovers of Australian manufacturers of electricity generation and transmission equipment. In particular Senator Button asked why, in view of the fact that this industry is in the forefront of Australia's development plans, and given the remarks made by my colleague, Mr Thomson, that the Government is 'working on' the problem of the entrepreneurial side of the technology issue, is the Government allowing this industry to fall increasingly into foreign hands? The honourable Senator asked also whether the Government would review the situation as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following information:

In the House of Representatives, on 4 December 1980, I referred to a number of Government initiatives designed to increase industry competitiveness through encouraging inventions, innovation, the development of new products and the introduction of new technology. In particular, I noted the importance of matching Australian inventiveness with the entrepreneurial spirit required to take inventions to the market place and mentioned a workshop in innovation and entrepreneurship sponsored by my Department.

Initiatives to develop Australian entrepreneurship comprise only one element of a balanced range of measures designed to stimulate increases in manufacturing competitiveness. Of equal importance are those elements of the industrial development component of the Government's industry policy directed at assisting Australian industry to cope with adjustment problems, to gain increased access to foreign markets and to take advantage of the latest technology.

Government innovation programs, including the workshops in entrepreneurship, are primarily directed at encouraging the creation and development of a 'seed-bed' of smaller technology-based companies to provide stimulus to economic growth and employment generation. Measures such as productivity development and technology transfer programs are primarily directed toward strengthening Australia's existing manufacturing base. It is these latter measures, therefore, which are of greater relevance to our existing industrial capability in the manufacture of components for electricity generation and transmission equipment.

The activities of foreign companies also have a significant impact on the strength and structure of Australian industry; the electricity generation and transmission equipment industry is no different to other industries in this respect.

Whilst the Foreign Investment Review Board Report 1980 commented that a number of takeover proposals concerning companies manufacturing components for electricity generation and transmission equipment had been submitted to the Board, it should be emphasised that each foreign investment proposal is considered on its own merits against national benefits criteria. If net economic benefits cannot be demonstrated and a proposal is judged to be contrary to the national interest, no approval can be given.

The recent proposals submitted to the Board have concerned companies engaged in the manufacture of small to medium sized transformers, electrical switchgear, heat exchangers, steam generating units and electrical carbon products. In most cases, the parties were able to demonstrate that net economic benefits would accrue to Australia from the proposal through access to overseas technology, the introduction of new products, exports, access to financial resources and, in relation to the transformer industry, through rationalisation of the industry.

In one major proposal, not only were net economic benefits expected to result because of better access to advanced technology but, in addition, the net result of the proposal was for Australian equity in the target company to be significantly increased resulting in control becoming Australian. In two cases where net economic benefits were only marginal or not sufficient to offset a loss of Australian control, approval was given by the Government on condition that significant Australian equity be maintained or reintroduced at a later date into the businesses.
In one proposal, where no net economic benefits could be demonstrated and because it was judged to be contrary to the national interest, no approval was given.

The Government acknowledges the need for foreign investment in Australia because of the contribution such investment has made, and will continue to make, to the development of Australia's industries and resources. Equally, the Government is taking many initiatives which should lead to Australian companies right across our range of industrial activities being better prepared to compete in both domestic and foreign markets. The combination of foreign expertise and capital with more competitive companies will lead to Australia and Australians gaining increased benefits from the development of our resources and skils.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 879) Senator Chipp asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: What specific action has the Government in mind to close the loophole through which tax can be avoided on gains made within 12 months by the device of buying shares in the name of a subsidiary company and then selling the subsidiary company rather than the shares which it bought.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have asked the Commissioner of Taxation to examine the question of possible weaknesses in section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act which is the section dealing with a sale of property within twelve months of its purchase. Matters of no little complexity are involved but I expect to receive a report from the Commissioner soon.

I would, however, point out to the honourable senator that, section 26AAA aside, there are other provisions of the income tax law under which profits made in the manner referred to by him may fall to be taxed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 April 1981 (Hansard page 966) Senator Lajovic asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question asked:

ANSWER.PARA: Whether an article which appeared in the Australian newspaper of 22 March 1981 was correct. The article, datelined Washington, reported that officials of the United States of America and Australia were having informal discussions with a view to eliminating on a reciprocal basis the necessity for short-term tourist visitors to obtain visas.
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

While the newspaper article is not strictly correct it is true that on 4 March 1981 the Consulate-General of the United States of America made an informal approach to the Regional Director of my Department in Sydney to enquire whether Australia might be interested in extending, on a reciprocal basis, the maximum validity of visitor visas from 48 months to 60 months or even to indefinite, or whether Australia might be interested, again on a reciprocal basis, in waiving the visa requirement for visiting US citizens.

The workload involved in issuing visitor visas throughout the world has increased dramatically in recent years and there are no indications that this pressure is likely to ease within the foreseeable future. Consequently, it is necessary to adopt any reasonable measures which will alleviate the burden of issuing visitor visas while at the same time maintaining to the maximum extent possible the protection and security afforded to Australian society by the checks encompassed in our visitor visa procedures.

Following a recent preliminary study of the practicability of Australia entering into no visa agreements with certain countries it was concluded that in the absence of any internal controls within Australia such as social security cards, registering with policy, penalties for employers who employ visitors, and so on, which most overseas countries have, it was not possible for Australia to agree to abolish visa requirements.

However as a further step towards reducing the visitor visa workload and streamlining visitor visa procedures I have agreed that the United States' authorities be informed that we would be prepared to extend, on a reciprocal basis, the validity of visitor visas issued to United States citizens for the full period of the validity of the US passport in which the visa is placed (this is normally five years) and for multiple entry to be permitted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1038) Senator McClelland asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that the tax avoidance industry is currently marketing on a large scale throughout Australia a recoupment-type tax avoidance scheme whereby the taxpayer obtains an offset against his tax for moneys invested in an afforestation company but in circumstances where the taxpayer is reimbursed all of his investment less the scheme's seller's fee by means of a combination of loans and dealings in shares of the afforestation company? Is it a fact that under this type of arrangement the taxpayer obtains the tax benefit but at no time is he at financial risk? Will the Treasurer investigate this type of scheme in accordance with his statement of 1978 and take action accordingly to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation is currently investigating the scheme mentioned by the honourable senator. To date, however, the information available is insufficient to identify the full nature of the scheme. When the enquiries are completed no doubt the Commissoner will advise the Government of any further legislation that he may consider to be required.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1037) Senator Elstob asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: How much longer will new home owners need to wait for the implementation of the initiative, announced in the October Federal election campaign by the Prime Minister, for the allowance of an income tax deduction for the cost of the insulation of a person's first home, which was stated to be effective from the date of the announcement.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The provisions to authorise an income tax deduction for expenditure incurred on home insulation are contained in the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1981.

The deduction is available in respect of amounts paid by a person for the cost of insulating his or her home (or, in the case of a married couple, their home) where the home is the sole or principal residence of the taxpayer in Australia and neither the taxpayer nor (in the case of a couple) his or her spouse previously owned and used as a residence another dwelling in Australia.

The concession applies to the cost of insulating a dwelling purchased under a contract entered into on or after 1 October 1980 or, if built by the taxpayer, the construction of which started on or after that date. The deduction is granted in respect of the cost of thermal insulation materials and their installation.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Donations to Sporting Clubs: Tax Deductibility

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1381) Senator Archer asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There are many pressures on the Government to expand the gift provisions of the income tax law to include gifts made to various bodies and in various circumstances. It is necessary to consider these in the context of the Budget. The honourable senator may be assured that gifts by individuals in the circumstances outlined will receive consideration in this context.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2144), Senator Keeffe asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Can the Minister representing the Treasurer inform the Parliament whether the Government has changed direction, in opposition to promises previously made to central Queensland miners, regarding the levying of income tax in respect of homes occupied by miners and others in Queensland.

It has not proved possible to have the necessary legislation prepared in time for introduction before the winter recess. It will be introduced early in the Budget sittings.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1981 (Hansard page 2249) Senator Robertson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned the migration requirements for spouses of Australian residents/nationals.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
There has been no change to the government policy announced in the Parliament on 7 June 1978 stating that spouses of Australian residents will be admitted subject to:
sponsorship by the Australian resident spouse provision of maintenance and accommodation good health (criteria may be relaxed) good character.

These requirements (and others arising in individual cases such as assessment of the marriage's validity under Australian law) are in accordance with the immigration principles forming the basis of the government's migration policy.

Spouses of Australian residents do not have automatic right of entry into Australia and no changes granting them such a right are envisaged. At the same time they are accorded the greatest concessions on entry possible-consistent with protection of the interests of the Australian community as a whole.
Every effort is made to process applications for visas by these persons as speedily as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 May 1980 (Hansard, page 2250) Senator Kilgariff asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned the migration of East Timorese in Portugal.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Implicit in the interim reply provided by Senator Durack is the fact that the Timorese in Portugal are not refugees. Timorese leaving Indonesia have automatic right to Portuguese nationality and are accorded this status by the Portuguese authorities on request. As a consequence, they have a country willing to accept them and offer them protection.
Over 3,000 Timorese have arrived in Australia since 1975 under a variety of programs:
The initial group of evacuees from East Timor;
the group specially agreed upon between the Australian and Indonesian governments in 1978;
specially relaxed humanitarian programs; and
normal family reunion movement.
1,308 Timorese in Portugal have been nominated under the current special humanitarian program. Of these, 287 have been granted visas and the processing of the remainder is being expedited.

No particular difficulties are being experienced in processing applications from this group. Minimal delays sometimes occur in co-ordinating visa processing of family units split between Lisbon and Jakarta.
